fields.headline: Davies hands Hoddle winning return
fields.trailText: There was a poor turnout at White Hart Lane for Glenn Hoddle's homecoming as Simon Davies scraped a win over bottom club Bradford.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Tottenham fans will hardly be talking of championships and glorious new eras on the basis of this nervy victory over Bradford City. But, if the performance was poor and the crowd surprisingly low, Glenn Hoddle's homecoming at least ended with the win the script demanded.

Not that it came without a struggle. Until Simon Davies scored his first Premiership goal in the 76th minute it seemed Bradford might snatch at least a point. Even then it needed a good save by Neil Sullivan to deny Ashley Ward, who had earlier hit a post.

Already muted Tottenham celebrations were further dampened by the news that Steffen Iversen, the scorer of their first goal, left the ground in an ambulance after being knocked unconscious in a collision with Andy Myers and was kept overnight in hospital as a precaution.

Iversen was taken off in a neck-brace and Hoddle said: "He took a hell of a bang on the head as he hit the ground. It is obviously a concern because he did the same thing three weeks ago playing for Norway when he was also knocked out."

Of the game Hoddle rightly pointed out that only several fine saves by Gary Walsh prevented a more convincing win. But the frequency with which Spurs gave away possession, particularly in the second half, and their vulnerability to Bradford's counter-attacks confirmed it will take a great deal of work to transform this club into the free-flowing, trophy-winning machine the new manager is dreaming of.

"If we had taken our chances we would have had a bucket full," Hoddle said. "Of course we can improve but I saw some good things out there from Steffen Iversen, Simon Davies and Stephen Carr in particular. This was all about bouncing back from the weekend and we did that. Physically and mentally they were tired, so it was a good result under the circumstances."

Sunday's FA Cup semi-final defeat by Arsenal seemed to have ensured that the great homecoming fell flat from the start. Far from turning out euphorically in huge numbers to welcome back Hoddle, thousands of Tottenham fans decided on a night at home.

The attendance of 28,306 was Spurs's smallest of the season in the Premiership by some distance, almost 5,000 fewer than the previous low against West Ham and only marginally bigger than the crowd for Brentford in the Worthington Cup.

The atmosphere was low-key, with only the occasional chant for Hoddle despite pre-match big-screen entertainment which featured some of the midfielder's finest moments in a Spurs shirt.

Hoddle was greeted rapturously when he sidled towards the touchline just before kick-off. But how far this, with empty seats all around, felt from those glory days. "The idea for me is to get 35,000 in every week," Hoddle said, "to bring the success the club is looking for and to get the atmosphere going more than it was tonight. That takes time."

Although Sergei Rebrov wasted a fine early chance presented to him by Robert Molenaar, Spurs took their time to get going against a feisty Bradford side playing with freedom and adventure now their fate is all but sealed.

Spurs fans had little to cheer until Iversen scored in the 26th minute, taking one touch from Rebrov's cross before volleying past Walsh as Molenaar and Myers failed to clear.

As the passing improved, Walsh was called on to deny Stephen Clemence and Davies before half-time. But Bradford made Spurs pay for poor defending just before the interval when Ashley Ward knocked down near the edge of the area and Eoin Jess sent an impressive first-time shot beyond Sullivan.

Walsh was called on deny Tim Sherwood and Rebrov just after half-time but Bradford caused plenty of nervous moments for Spurs, with Ward hitting a post and Robbie Blake seeing his effort from the rebound ruled offside.

Spurs were creating little, though Davies ensured a happy homecoming for Hoddle by shooting in from around 15 yards when Wayne Jacobs failed to clear a Rebrov cross.

"If we can develop and improve players like Simon, he can be a £10m player," Hoddle said. "He's nice and bright, he wants to learn and he's a Tottenham-style player." In every respect, though, Hoddle will know there is a long way to go yet.

fields.headline: Ipswich lift their bronze hopes
fields.trailText: Alun Armstrong's late goal was enough to restore Ipswich to third after Emile Heskey had given Liverpool the lead in their third game in six days. It was a point not lost on Gerard Houllier.
fields.body:
The prospect of Ipswich leaping from Nationwide League to Champions League in two seasons is no less real after last night's draw with Liverpool here but the real beneficiaries of this result could well be Leeds United.

A late goal from Alun Armstrong brought George Burley's side the point which was enough to restore Ipswich to third place in the Premiership. Liverpool, who led after Emile Heskey scored immediately after half-time, were not too disappointed to remain three points behind them with two matches in hand.

On Good Friday, however, Leeds, who are fourth only on goal difference, will go to Anfield hoping to exploit any growing weariness among Gérard Houllier's players, facing their fourth match in nine days. Fixture congestion, as much as any respect for the quality of the Ipswich attack, conditioned Liverpool's approach last night.

Leaving Heskey up front - and Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler on the bench - Houllier concentrated on getting eight or nine men behind the ball when possession was lost to stifle Ipswich's normally fluent passing game. The tactics were similar to those which brought Liverpool a goalless draw in Barcelona last Thursday in the Uefa Cup, and for a long time the spectacle suffered in similarly drab fashion.

Liverpool's manager made no excuses for accentuating the negative at the expense of the positive. "You may think it was not the best Liverpool attacking display," Houllier said, "and I would agree with that. But as a manager of a team playing its third match in six days I had to make sure we got a satisfactory result.

"If we'd lost we would now be six points behind Ipswich. I'm proud of the character my team showed, playing a game like this only two days after an FA Cup semi-final."

In fact Houllier made six changes in the side that beat Wycombe Wanderers on Sunday but, given that Liverpool are having to play four matches, including a derby at Everton on Easter Monday, before the return against Barcelona, his plea of mitigation was well made.

The way Liverpool played, moreover, offered Ipswich a foretaste of what they might expect in Europe next season. As a learning process the experience was possibly as useful for Burley's side as the point they took from the game.

Not that the lesson was quickly assimilated. Matt Holland and Jim Magilton were denied their usual lines of communication with Marcus Stewart by Steven Gerrard and Igor Biscan, and Liverpool in general allowed Ipswich a bare minimum of space once they had crossed the halfway line. As a result Burley's team found themselves being forced to lob the ball over the midfield, which is hardly their style.

Until the extra strength in the air of James Scowcroft was introduced for the last half-hour the authority of Sami Hyypia at the heart of the Liverpool defence was absolute. And only when Ipswich raised the overall pace of their game as they searched for an equaliser did Houllier's plan of containment begin to go awry.

Until half-time the football of both teams struggled to find space in which to breathe. Often all 20 outfield players were confined to a narrow, crowded corridor and scoring chances were never likely to be plentiful.

Equally, mistakes were liable to be costly, witness the aberrant pass back by John McGreal, under pressure from Heskey, midway through the first half which left Christian Ziege with only Richard Wright to beat. Portman Road hearts almost stopped but the German wing-back wastefully dragged his shot wide.

Jermaine Wright did better for Ipswich just before the half-hour. A long throw-in from Martijn Reuser was cleared beyond the Liverpool penalty area where Wright met it with a well-struck 30-yard drive which Sander Westerveld did well to keep out.

With Gerrard largely confined to a holding role Ipswich were less at risk from the England midfielder's penchant for surging runs into scoring areas. Liverpool concentrated more on trying to find Heskey in positions to outpace Ipswich defenders and, when they did this 20 seconds after half-time, they took the lead.

As Ziege nodded on a ball from Gerrard, Chris Makin ducked under it and Heskey's acceleration did the rest. The burly striker cut into the penalty area and scored through the legs of Richard Wright. At that point Houllier appeared to have conceived a grand larceny worthy of Raffles.

For a time Liverpool's football became as positive as it had been negative hitherto and Heskey, who when he is not falling down subjects referees to endless ear-bashing, did have reason to complain when wrongly flagged offside as he was about to break clear once more.

The onset of first Scowcroft and then Fabian Wilnis, with his ability to turn defences on the right, gave Ipswich added momentum. They should have drawn level, or at least gone closer to drawing level, after 65 minutes when Scowcroft, granted a free header at the far post by Magilton's deep centre, nodded the ball across goal when he could have glanced it into the net.

Portman Road could sense redemption, however, and after 76 minutes it arrived. From Stewart's pass on the left Makin produced a searching cross which cleared the Liverpool defence and found Armstrong sprinting in at the far post to guide the ball past Westerveld.

fields.headline: Solskjaer steals in late
fields.trailText: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer struck a late winner to take Manchester United to within six points of the title after Charlton's Mark Fish had cancelled out Andy Cole's opener.
fields.body:
Two more wins will do it for Manchester United. Supporters of other clubs may stifle an envious yawn but victory over Coventry at home on Saturday would give Sir Alex Ferguson's team the opportunity to confirm their seventh Premiership title by beating Man- chester City, also at Old Trafford, the following week. And that is assuming Arsenal have not slipped up in the interim.

While it is possible to argue - the annihilation of Arsenal apart - that United have not been at their best since the New Year, the fact is that defeat by Charlton would have been the first time they had lost three games in succession since late 1996.

Well though the Londoners played, there was never any chance of that; they were outclassed by the pace and brio of a United team which, as well as scoring two through the opportunism of Andy Cole and the familiar late heroics of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, hit the woodwork four times.

Roy Keane was everywhere in the opening period, evidently still smarting after coming out such a distant second best to Steven Gerrard in the 2-0 defeat at Anfield 11 days ago. It was his pass, breaking from a Charlton corner, which gave Gary Neville the chance to put in a cross from which the unmarked Dwight Yorke should have at least tested Sasa Ilic.

The Irishman was again the threat after 20 minutes, Mark Fish somehow clearing another low driven cross off his own line before one of four lurking United players could turn it home.

At this stage Charlton were taking an old-fashioned battering but, as the force of the United storm inevitably began to drop a little, the Londoners were able to show they had not come only to defend.

Only a last ditch tackle by Denis Irwin stopped Jonatan Johansson getting in a close-range shot after a Scott Parker run and pass; and the hugely promising young midfielder almost produced a remarkable goal a few minutes later, landing a 30-yard chip on the bar. Whether Fabien Barthez had it covered is a moot point.

Having had reason to be grateful to the referee Mark Halsey, who had the nerve to turn down two United penalty appeals that lesser men might have given, Charlton were less enamoured of the official shortly before the break.

Yorke, running from deep within his own half and hurdling tackles as he went, crossed to Cole; the centre- forward's first shot was blocked but the ball came back to him via a rebound off Halsey. Given an unexpected second opportunity, Cole buried it in the far corner.

Concerned at the ease with which Ryan Giggs and Keane were finding space down the flanks, Alan Curbishley switched to a flat back four. Even then Giggs' pace and trickery on a greasy surface were far too much for Mark Fish to cope with but the South African defender was in the right place shortly after the break, clearing Giggs' shot from Nicky Butt's cross off his line.

Five minutes later Keane, powering forward yet again, was allowed to take the ball almost to the edge of the area before shooting hard and low. The diving Ilic got a hand to the ball, pushing it on to the post.

A second goal had to come but amazingly it was not scored by United. Parker, his spirit splendidly uncrushed by the barrage, skipped skilfully out of a challenge and found Johansson on the right. The Finnish international drove the ball in low and Gary Neville scuffed his attempted clearance only as far as Fish, who banged it joyfully home from close range.

Back came United, as an Irwin cross drifted beyond Ilic and back off the angle of post and bar. When Scholes then hit the post, Charlton must have sensed they could hang on for a remarkable point.

But where there is Solskjaer there is hope. Four minutes after coming on, the little Norwegian striker was lurking in the penalty area to turn in an Irwin cross.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Corridor capers
fields.standfirst: Machinery does matter so reform it
fields.trailText: The case for an authoritative, external look at the civil service has been strong for at least 15 years - ever since its then head, Sir Robert Armstrong, produced his notorious maxim to the effect that permanent officials are there to do their ministers' bidding and no more.
fields.body:
The case for an authoritative, external look at the civil service has been strong for at least 15 years - ever since its then head, Sir Robert Armstrong, produced his notorious maxim to the effect that permanent officials are there to do their ministers' bidding and no more. Margaret Thatcher's political extinction calmed fears about "politicisation" in Whitehall but left many questions pending. Armstrong's memorandum on civil servants' duties raised the central one. Officials have to be more than yes-people. If the public cannot rely on them to say no when power is being abused and blow the whistle, our scheme of executive government becomes even more lopsided than it already is. But if civil servants are to have such a constitutional role it must be written down clearly and their accountability established.

In recent years Giles Radice on the former Commons Treasury and civil service committee and now Tony Wright at the head of the public administration committee have made a start at doing just that. The latest report from Mr Wright's committee says the time has come to round out a wider plan for reform. Look, it says, at the ferment - over Whitehall's departmental geography, the impact of even milk-and-water freedom of information, over pay and conditions and ethos in the public service at large, the residual role of elected local authorities and the expansion of delegated government. Beneath the surface, there is rumbling discontent at the qualities and formation of top officials, their gender and backgrounds.

Once, a "royal" commission might have been convened. But another Tony, the prime minister, has shown scant interest in how government works. He let Armstrong's successor but one, Sir Richard Wilson, proceed with an internal reform which, it is now clear, has been anything but. Perhaps, belatedly, No 10 realises that machinery does matter. A civil service that entered the 1980s still clinging to an ethos shaped in the 1940s was left battered by Thatcher's handbag and now wanders the corridors bemused. It is in no fit state to deliver the service promises Labour has made - and on which its political fate depends. In a better-ordered political world an able MP such as Tony Wright would be a Cabinet Office minister. As it is, he should be asked to continue his committee's excellent work and make positive recommendations for Whitehall reform.

fields.headline: Beyond the fringe
fields.standfirst:
The big three political parties tend to hog the media limelight but there's much more to politics than the battle between Blair, Hague and Kennedy. Matthew Tempest investigates in the first of a series, looking today at the Green party, the Socialist Alliance and the Liberal party.
Part two: ambitions on the right
fields.trailText: The Greens have come the furthest since the last general election in 1997.  The past four years has seen them send two Green MEPs to Brussels, put three Green members on the London Assembly, and gain an MSP in the Edinburgh parliament
fields.body:
The Greens have come the furthest since the last general election in 1997. The past four years has seen them send two Green MEPs to Brussels, put three Green members on the London Assembly, and gain an MSP in the Edinburgh parliament

Yet Spencer Fitzgibbon, the Green party's national press officer, works from home, unpaid, around childcare responsibilities. For him the postponement in the general election date means simply that his party may be able to field an extra five candidates - people who couldn't spare the time to fight an election for May, but now may be able to make new plans for a June poll.

It also creates a worry which would cause the bigger parties press offices barely a blink: the Greens have a strong vote in and around Oxford, with eight councillors on the local authority. Will a June poll mean their student vote is too busy swotting for finals to turn out in the polling booths?

For the smaller parties, of which the Greens, having been around since 1975 in Britain (the second oldest environmental party in the world) can fairly claim to be the granddaddy, there is a paradox illustrated by this scrabble for votes: every vote counts, and yet, under Westminster first-past-the-post system, no vote will count.

Although the party plans to field around 135 candidates (some standing for the Green's sister party in Scotland), almost double their 1997 tally, it would take a minor miracle for even a radical, green constituency such as Hackney South and Shoreditch, in London to return a Green MP.

That's the dispiriting fact facing the group as Mr Fitzgibbon debates how and where to spend the party's £50,000 election budget. - around £14,950,000 less than the big two parties, and still paltry compared with Liberal Democrats more modest budget of around £3m.

Uniquely among UK political parties, whether large or small, the Greens are willing to be open about their finances and membership. Most revenue for the forthcoming fight will come from their 4,000 party members - half of whom are on the 50% reduction for the unwaged. They spent around £380,000 on their 1999 European election campaign which got two MEPs to Brussels, and are happy to admit this election will see them spend around £50,000.

According to Mr Fitzgibbon: "The biggest difference between now and 1997 is we have some credibility with the media because we have elected representatives. The biggest similarity is that we had no money then, and we've go no money now. So when the big parties complain they will have to cancel their million pound billboard campaigns I have no sympathy at all."

In keeping with Green philosophy on home working and family-friendly responsibilities, he remains in Manchester, requiring only a computer, telephone and mobile to pull together what he describes as a "small but slick" operation.

Their website, another innovation since the 1997 campaign, is professional, and, unusually among political sites, elegantly designed. It is run by one volunteer, who fits the task around a full-time job.

The Greens are reluctant to discuss celebrity backing, having been burnt in the early nineties when David Icke briefly became a Green party spokesman, between being a BBC presenter and believer in a world dominated by a secret elite of 12ft lizards.

Many apolitical punters may remember the Green astonishing 15% polling in the 1989 European elections. It was, concedes Spencer Fitzgibbon, a mixed blessing.

"It certainly put us on the map, and forced the mainstream UK political parties to adopt a veneer of environmental policies.

"It even resulted in Mrs Thatcher claiming the Conservatives were the 'guardian angels of the environment,'" he says.

"Unfortunately, that massive vote didn't translate into seats or power, and so for some people it was a disheartening experience."

However, with policies such as the decriminalisation of cannabis and the renationalisation of Railtrack, they may find themselves in tune with a large swathe of the electorate this time around.

A similar groundswell of popular support, at least in London and some northern industrial cities, has given birth to the Socialist Alliance - the one major new party on the political horizon since the 1997 election.

They were born out of the London assembly campaign just 12 months ago, yet will put up around 100 candidates around the country, and a air a party election broadcast directed by respected film maker Ken Loach.

The SA is carefully targeting only what members class as the most New of New Labour MPs. So-called turncoats, such as immigration minister Barbara Roche will be forced to defend their record in government, in her case against Paddington rail crash victims solicitor Louise Christian.

Old Labour heroes such as Alan Simpson will not find an SA candidate standing in their seat, and the party is diplomatically not joining the scramble in Hartlepool, where Socialist Labour candidate Arthur Scargill is challenging Peter Mandelson.

The party can also boast a high-calibre, if predictable, range of prestigious backing from luminaries like Harold Pinter and John Pilger.

Their uncompromising agenda: a £7 an hour minimum wage, support for all strikes and the ending of all private-finance initiatives may not endear them far and wide outside their chosen target seats, but the sheer number of candidates fielded - over 100 - will ensure this fledgling and unquestionably principled group a party election broadcast.

Anna Chen, their spokeswoman, refuses to detail their campaign budget, but admits "it's grim."

The minnow of the minorities is the Liberal party. As the remainder of the party which did not sign up to the Liberal/SDP alliance in 1988, it might almost be described as the minority party's minority party.

Kept alive by their presence on various local authorities around the UK, primarily in the south-west and north-west of England, the party led by former Liberal MP for Leeds Michael Meadowcroft likes to quote Cyril Smith's aphorism "In politics there is power, and there is influence."

The most noticeable distinguishing issue between the Liberals and the Lib Dems is Europe, where the former favour a strongly anti-euro line.

They too see the election of independents such as Westminster's Martin Bell, and Ken Livingstone as London Mayor, as an encouraging trend. David Morrish, a Liberal county councillor in Devon, says: "It's a question of having space at the margins.

"We have councillors on around 40 local authorities, but we are more like guerrillas in the hills - we travel light and can make telling interventions."

With little budget to speak of, the Liberals will be reviving the ignored art of doorstep canvassing this time around. "That's our style, and that's what we can afford," says Mr Morrish.

Their essential policy plank is for a single transferable vote system. However, even they admit that their 100,000 votes in the 1997 general election would not have seen them win a Westminster seat under any PR system.

· fielding 130+ candidates.
· high point: having elected members in London, Edinburgh, Brussels.
· unique selling point: only anti-consumerist party.
· election budget: c.£50,000.
· celebrity backing: novelist Julia Stephenson, Peter Polycarpou, star of Birds of a Feather.
· website: Green party.
· Green prime minister would be: greens would abolish the post of PM and have a cabinet collective.

Socialist Alliance
· fielding about 100 candidates
· high point: first general election campaign.
· unique selling point: end all private finance initiatives.
· election budget: "grim".
· celebrity backing: Harold Pinter, Ken Loach, Mark Thomas, Jeremy Hardy, John Pilger, Peter Tatchell.
· website: Socialist Alliance.
· Socialist Alliance prime minister would be: Dave Nellist.

Liberal party
· fielding 20 candidates.
· high point: saved two deposits in 1997.
· unique selling point: unwavering commitment to single transferable vote system.
· election budget: "very small - every £50 counts."
· celebrity backing: no.
· website: Liberal party.
· Liberal party prime minister would be: Michael Meadowcroft.

webTitle: Top Scots clubs fail to get finances in order

fields.headline: Top Scots clubs fail to get finances in order
fields.trailText: Eleven of the 12 Scottish Premier League clubs face financial ruin unless they slash their wage bills, according to a new survey.
fields.body:
Eleven of the 12 Scottish Premier League clubs face financial ruin unless they slash their wage bills, according to a new survey.

The accountancy firm Deloitte & Touche has claimed that, with the exception of Celtic, all the clubs are spending more than 50% of turnover on players' wages, with Hibernian the worst offenders at 89%.

However Rod Petrie, Hibernian's managing director, pointed out that the survey's use of accounts for the 1998-99 season, despite the availability of figures for 1999-2000, had helped paint a misleading picture. "The figures for this club refer to our season in the First Division [which] inevitably saw turnover fall significantly," he said.

"Had the research looked at the accounts which were issued at our annual meeting last year, it would have become obvious that in our first season back in the SPL our wages accounted for 69% of turnover, a fall of 20%, due to the significant increase in revenues."

Wage cutting has become a fact of life in the SPL over the last few months, with Hearts releasing high earners such as Gordan Petric while Motherwell, who ran up a loss of £3m in the last financial year, have sold three players and released two more. "We have just taken in £2m in transfer fees," said the Fir Park club's chief executive Pat Nevin. "From now on wages will constitute between 50 and 60% of turnover. We have taken the necessary steps; other clubs are doing it."

Aberdeen plan to cut their wage bill from 86% to below 55%. Rangers' wages account for 58.3% of turnover, while the figure at Celtic is 46%.

Middlesbrough's move for Szilard Nemeth, 23, has hit problems as the Inter Bratislava striker needs a work permit but has not appeared in the Slovakia team for 75% of competitive games for the past two years, as required.

Boro, though, are hoping that, as Nemeth is a current international and has been a regular for the under-21s for three years, he may get the go-ahead. A Uefa tribunal may also have to decide a fee if agreement is not reached between the clubs as even though the player is out of contract in the summer, Slovakia is not in the European Union and his club is entitled to compensation. Nemeth is scheduled to join on July 1 but the deal is unlikely to go through if Boro are relegated.

Kily Gonzalez will miss Valencia's European Cup quarter-final second leg against Arsenal on Tuesday due to a thigh-muscle injury sustained during Saturday's 4-1 victory over Rayo Vallecano.

Bayern Munich's Elber is also a doubt for their second leg against Manchester United the following day after injuring his left knee against Borussia Dortmund. The team doctor drained fluid from the Brazilian striker's joint on Monday and he will not train again until Friday at best.

A three-day disciplinary hearing into alleged financial irregularities at Chesterfield began at Hillsborough yesterday. A joint Football Association and Football League inquiry was launched in February into alleged irregularities concerning payments to players and attendance figures.

Chesterfield are five points clear at the top of the Third Division but could face a substantial points deduction if found guilty.

webTitle: Nigeria's stand on Kanu release threatens to open old wounds

fields.headline: Nigeria's stand on Kanu release threatens to open old wounds
fields.trailText: The Nigeria coach Jo Bonfrere is still considering a request from Arsenal to release Nwankwo Kanu from next week's World Cup qualifier against Sierra Leone, the Nigerian Football Association said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Nigeria coach Jo Bonfrere is still considering a request from Arsenal to release Nwankwo Kanu from next week's World Cup qualifier against Sierra Leone, the Nigerian Football Association said yesterday.

"We received a fax message from Arsenal requesting that Kanu be allowed to play in their Champions League match against Valencia next week," the NFA press officer Austin Mgbolu said.

Mgbolu added that the Dutch-born Bonfrere, who last month threatened to resign if his side failed to beat Sierra Leone, had been informed of the Arsenal request and "is still considering it".

Nigeria, currently third in a five-team group from which only the winners qualify, need to take all three points from the match to maintain their hopes of qualifying for the 2002 World Cup finals.

Last week Bonfrere named Kanu in an 18-man squad for the World Cup qualifier in Freetown on April 21. But, when his squad gather to train ahead of the crucial fixture, Arsenal will travel to Spain for the second leg of their Champions League quarter-final.

It is not the first time Kanu's services have been sought by both parties: last year the NFA and Arsenal were involved in a bitter row over the player's release for the football tournament at the Olympic Games.

Elsewhere Paris St-Germain hope to field their new signing Ronaldinho Gaucho in friendly matches next month, club officials announced yesterday.

The Brazilian Ronaldinho, regarded as one of the best young players in Brazil, has signed a five-year deal with the big-spending French club but is still at the centre of a row between PSG and his former club Gremio of Porto Alegre.

The striker, who played in Brazil's 1999 Copa America victory and finished as top scorer in the Confederations Cup the same year, is a free agent. But, as he will be available to join PSG only from July 1, Gremio are demanding compensation from the Paris club.

Gremio have appealed to the Brazilian Football Federation, claiming that PSG's offers of remuneration have so far been inadequate.

"There is no doubt that Ronaldinho will be playing for PSG next season," pledged the French club's president Laurent Perpere. "But for the moment he is here as a friend."

webTitle: Biotechs suffer the herd instinct of investors

fields.headline: Biotechs suffer the herd instinct of investors
fields.trailText: As Dolly the Sheep grazes in her isolated Scottish paddock this morning, safely quarantined from foot and mouth disease, she may catch a whiff of fear in the air.
fields.body:
As Dolly the Sheep grazes in her isolated Scottish paddock this morning, safely quarantined from foot and mouth disease, she may catch a whiff of fear in the air.

Her owner, PPL Therapeutics, is in such a perilous cash position that it will no longer be able to pay for her upkeep this time next year. After failing to raise funds on the stock market, the firm looks set to make a humiliating cap-in-hand approach to its development partner, Bayer, for more funds.

PPL's predicament was greeted with dismay, but lit tle surprise, in the biotechnology sector yesterday. Sentiment has turned sharply, with the Nasdaq biotech index down a third since the beginning of the year.

In January, Scotia Holdings became the first quoted biotech firm in Britain to collapse into administration, having consumed £164m of investors' funds without producing a penny of profit. Then last month, heart valves maker AorTech was forced to abandon a £64m cash call.

The gloomy outlook seems far removed from the dizzy heights of early 2000, when Cambridge Antibody Technology was valued at more £1bn despite boasting only two medicines in development.

The biotechnology industry is following a familiar pattern of tracking hi-tech shares, with a time lag of around three to six months. This has infuriated its followers, who point out that unlike dot.coms, biotech firms are actually delivering positive news, with a steady flow of strong results from products in clinical trials.

Celltech, Galen Holdings, Protherics, Vernalis and SkyePharma have all had recent approval to begin selling key medicines. A select few, led by Celltech, should produce profits this year. There is far more good news around than bad, but this has not stopped biotech from catching an even worse cold than the rest of the market.

PPL has shown poor timing before - the firm tried to raise money in the last biotech bear market in 1998, and only just succeeded. The company now faces a real struggle to pay for its new factory and, as one online investor put it, "without a manufacturing plant, there can be no products, and without products there are no potential profits".

fields.headline: City shuns Dolly the sheep
fields.standfirst: Institutions decline to support £45m rights issue for PPL Therapeutics
fields.trailText: PPL Therapeutics, the biotechnology firm which created Dolly the cloned sheep, is facing a financial crisis after City institutions refused to stump up for a £45m fundraising.
fields.body:
PPL Therapeutics, the biotechnology firm which created Dolly the cloned sheep, is facing a financial crisis after City institutions refused to stump up for a £45m fundraising.

The firm's managing director Ron James said he was in shock yesterday after the failure of the rights issue, which was intended to pay for the final stages of development of PPL's key product, a drug for emphysema.

PPL's cash reserves of £12m will run out in less than a year. The crisis could jeopardise plans for a £42m new drugs factory in central Scotland. Mr James said: "We're not in panic mode. We're in recovery from shock mode, perhaps. The last thing we should do is anything precipitous and rash."

PPL specialises in altering the genes of cows and sheep to make them produce therapeutic proteins in their milk. In addition to creating Dolly, the world's first cloned sheep, PPL also produced a cloned cow and a litter of cloned piglets.

Many existing shareholders were willing to support the fundraising but the company's broker, Deutsche Bank, had a tough job convincing new investors to come on board.

It is understood that Deutsche secured pledges of more than £20m in funding, but fell well short of the minimum of £40.5m necessary for the cash call to go ahead. PPL's shares plunged 19.5p to 113p.

PPL's advisers blamed stock market volatility. One said: "People were telling us they liked the PPL story, but they didn't like the timing of the fundraising. A lot of institutions are moving more of their holdings from shares into cash."

There was criticism from some quarters of the firm's decision to go for a book-building fundraising, rather than setting an offer price and seeking underwriting from a City bank.

Furthermore, one analyst suggested PPL's recent diversification into new areas of research was putting off investors: "I find it a very odd picture now. They started off doing walking factories for new drugs. Now they're into stem cell research and even generic biopharmaceuticals."

PPL, which has 160 staff and 3,500 sheep, is losing about £1m a month. The firm's lead product, a drug for lung disease called AAT, is due to reach the market in 2004.

In order to produce AAT, the company had hoped to begin construction of a factory this year, with the help of loans from Scottish Enterprise and Royal Bank of Scotland. However, the funding crisis leaves a question mark over PPL's ability to make repayments of these loans. Mr James said: "We are obviously going to take a prudent approach. We will not be immediately accelerating the [factory] programme."

PPL's room for manoeuvre is limited - construction and regulatory approval of the factory is likely to take three years, and any delay beyond 2004 will push back revenue and profits.

PPL is likely to turn to its development partners for cash. The company has relationships with the German drugs company Bayer and with the British health care firm Smith & Nephew.

The firm's managing director Ron James said he was in shock yesterday after the failure of the rights issue, which was intended to pay for the final stages of development of PPL's key product, a drug for emphysema. PPL's cash reserves of £12m will run out in less than a year. The crisis could jeopardise plans for a £42m new drugs factory in central Scotland. Mr James said: "We're not in panic mode. We're in recovery from shock mode, perhaps. The last thing we should do is anything precipitous and rash." PPL specialises in altering the genes of cows and sheep to make them produce therapeutic proteins in their milk. In addition to creating Dolly, the world's first cloned sheep, PPL also produced a cloned cow and a litter of cloned piglets. Many existing shareholders were willing to support the fundraising but the company's broker, Deutsche Bank, had a tough job convincing new investors to come on board. It is understood that Deutsche secured pledges of more than £20m in funding, but fell well short of the minimum of £40.5m necessary for the cash call to go ahead. PPL's shares plunged 19.5p to 113p. PPL's advisers blamed stock market volatility. One said: "People were telling us they liked the PPL story, but they didn't like the timing of the fundraising. A lot of institutions are moving more of their holdings from shares into cash." There was criticism from some quarters of the firm's decision to go for a book-building fundraising, rather than setting an offer price and seeking underwriting from a City bank. Furthermore, one analyst suggested PPL's recent diversification into new areas of research was putting off investors: "I find it a very odd picture now. They started off doing walking factories for new drugs. Now they're into stem cell research and even generic biopharmaceuticals." PPL, which has 160 staff and 3,500 sheep, is losing about £1m a month. The firm's lead product, a drug for lung disease called AAT, is due to reach the market in 2004. In order to produce AAT, the company had hoped to begin construction of a factory this year, with the help of loans from Scottish Enterprise and Royal Bank of Scotland. However, the funding crisis leaves a question mark over PPL's ability to make repayments of these loans. Mr James said: "We are obviously going to take a prudent approach. We will not be immediately accelerating the [factory] programme." PPL's room for manoeuvre is limited - construction and regulatory approval of the factory is likely to take three years, and any delay beyond 2004 will push back revenue and profits. PPL is likely to turn to its development partners for cash. The company has relationships with the German drugs company Bayer and with the British health care firm Smith & Nephew.

webTitle: Tesco sells its way to first £1bn profit

fields.headline: Tesco sells its way to first £1bn profit
fields.trailText: Supermarket group Tesco, now the biggest retailer in the UK, rang up its first £1bn profit last year and yesterday claimed to be the fastest growing major retailer in the world. The 700-strong chain, once regarded as a downmarket pile-it-high-and-sell-it-cheap business, is raking in sales of nearly £23bn a year and producing a profit of £3m a day.
fields.body:
Supermarket group Tesco, now the biggest retailer in the UK, rang up its first £1bn profit last year and yesterday claimed to be the fastest growing major retailer in the world. The 700-strong chain, once regarded as a downmarket pile-it-high-and-sell-it-cheap business, is raking in sales of nearly £23bn a year and producing a profit of £3m a day.

Only one UK retailer - Marks & Spencer - has ever breached the £1bn barrier before, and M&S has since suffered an about-turn in its fortunes. It will struggle to make £430m this year.

Despite criticism from consumer groups and some farmers' representatives, Tesco, which now accounts for £25 of every £100 spent on groceries in the UK, insisted it was not making excessive profits. Chief executive Terry Leahy said the chain was making only just over £3 profit from every £100 taken at the checkout and deputy chairman David Reid said the growth had been driven by "better service, quality and value for money".

The supermarket has also benefited from the lacklustre performance of some of its rivals, especially Sainsbury. Until 1995 Sainsbury was bigger than Tesco, but its last reported profits were barely half Tesco's £1bn. Safeway, which made £236m last year, is turning itself into a new breed of small-scale hypermarket while Asda appears to have lost some of its momentum since its takeover by the American Wal-Mart discount chain.

Tesco's £1.05bn profit, which was generated in the year to the end of February, is 12% up on last year. Sales were up 11.9%.

Earlier this year - in the wake of a two-year competition commission inquiry which cleared the supermarkets of making excessive profits - Tony Blair accused the supermarkets of having shoppers in "an armlock", but Tesco denied its profits and success were being driven by squeezing suppliers. It said it had cut prices by £1bn over the past five years and that its prices were now 11% lower than in 1996.

A spokesman for the company said: "Our profits have been growing in line with sales for a number of years. In other words, it is not margin expansion, or any rip-off, that is driving the profit growth."

"And in as much as farmers are experi encing tough times, why blame it on the supermarkets? Other macro factors are more important. Farm profits are extremely cyclical and in recent years the strong pound and the travails associated with BSE have been the main issues."

But a spokeswoman for the National Consumer Protection Council said: "It is high time Tesco cut their prices more and gave the customers more benefit from their profits", while Michael Hart, of the Small And Family Farms Alliance accused the supermarkets of being a "new food baronial class".

The Liberal Democrats' agriculture spokesman, Colin Breed, called for the appointment of a retail regulator "who would not be in the pockets of the supermarkets."

But the National Farmers' Union, while admitting that some of its members would find the earnings "hard to comprehend", backed the company. Spokeswoman Helen Lo said farmers hit by crises like BSE and foot and mouth should work with the big grocers, rather than "wage a war" on them. She said: "I think the way forward is to get farmers to muscle together to make a better profit for themselves, and they should look at efficiencies of operations."

Tesco is driving its growth through international expansion, and now operates 65 hypermarkets abroad, mostly in central Europe and Asia. Sales at those stores climbed to nearly £3bn last year and they produced profits of £74m.

At home, the group last year sold £45m of DVD players and TVs, extended its clothing range and put 8,000 new non-food products on its shelves.

Mr Leahy outlined plans to spend £1bn opening more Tesco outlets in the UK this year. He intends to double both the number of Tesco Express stores on Esso forecourts to 100 and the number of Tesco Extra hypermarkets to around 45.

The expansion plans are expected to create 20,000 new jobs - half in the UK - meaning Tesco's worldwide payroll will rise to 260,000.

The Tesco.com grocery home delivery business also brings in profits. The online grocer is now the biggest e-tailer in the world. Its 1m registered users and 70,000 weekly shoppers spend £6m a week.

fields.headline: A bumpy ride for consumers
fields.standfirst: Choosing an Isa
fields.trailText: A new survey suggests most users signing up for an online Isa found it a frustrating experience.Marianne Curphey reports.
fields.body:
The experience of trying to buy Individual savings accounts (Isas) online was a "very bumpy" one in the run-up to the end of the tax year, according to a new internet survey.

While websites were offering the option to buy tax-free savings accounts right up until the last minute before midnight on April 5, in some cases consumers would have found it extremely frustrating to apply online or search for Isa information.

The survey by Gomez, a firm that measures internet quality and service, found that the worst offender was Royal & SunAlliance, followed by E*trade. On average, it took five times' longer to download an internet page from RSA than from the best performers, Legal & General, M&G and DLJdirect.

Gomez measured site performance according to a series of benchmarks: speed of downloading, the frequency of the site failing or crashing, and the site's performance. The performance benchmark was compiled from visits in the weeks leading up to the end of the financial year, particularly in the final fortnight before midnight on April 5.

Matt Stamski, research director of Gomez UK, said: "We looked at the 17 top Isa sites and measured how fast their pages were. We examined the average download time for the last two weeks of the Isa season.

"We found that consumers signing up for Isas online experienced inconsistent website performance. Among the big names, RSA did a poor job of preparing for demand, while M&G and Legal & General did a good job. It was, overall, a very bumpy road for consumers."

Mr Stamski said that all websites that were tested became slower the closer it got to the end of the financial year, but added the best sites were still able to cope.

He said: "Companies need to prepare for their own success and while having huge demand for your website it great, being unable to handle that demand is not great. Poor performance and slow downloads erode trust and make it a frustrating experience for consumers.

"Website performance is critical to acquiring and retaining customers and it is the first step on the ladder to obtaining their trust."

The survey found that most Isa providers' websites were, at best, "consistently inconsistent" during the final weeks of the Isa season. Isa websites averaged a 3.2-second download time over the entire period. The overall best performer was L&G, whose pages downloaded on average in 1.5 seconds, followed closely by M&G at 1.6 seconds. The slowest site was RSA where viewers endured a wait of 8.1 seconds to access the main Isa page. Large Isa players such as Jupiter and Fidelity came in at 2.9 seconds and 3 seconds respectively.

Mr Stamski said: "Consumers have choice and with the internet they can move on if they find performance lacking. They are in the driving seat."

The results of the Gomez Isa Season Performance Benchmark was as follows:

The average download time in seconds:

Legal & General - 1.5
M&G - 1.6
DLJdirect - 1.8
Virgin Direct - 2.3
Britannic Asset Management - 2.4
Chase Fleming Asset Management - 2.6
Jupiter - 2.9
Inter-Alliance - 2.9
Egg -3
Fidelity -3
Benchmark average - 3.2
<A HREF="http://193.131.188.43/splash.cfm?CFID=130216&CFTOKEN=41531196" TARGET="_NEW"Investec Asset Management - 3.4
Comdirect - 3.7
Gartmore- 4.1
Chase de Vere Investments - 4.6
IDOL - 6.9
E*trade - 7.2
Royal & SunAlliance - 8.1

webTitle: Philips boss in insider dealing probe

fields.headline: Philips boss in insider dealing probe
fields.trailText: The Dutch president of electronics group Philips has announced that he is the subject of an insider dealing investigation in relation to shares he bought in the entertainment firm Endemol, maker of the television series Big Brother.
fields.body:
The Dutch president of electronics group Philips has announced that he is the subject of an insider dealing investigation in relation to shares he bought in the entertainment firm Endemol, maker of the television series Big Brother.

The allegations are focused on an order that was placed on behalf of Cor Boonstra for shares in Endemol in March last year, days before a €5.5bn (£3.4bn) takeover bid from Spanish telecom group Telefonica was made public. Endemol's share price surged after a formal announcement.

The Dutch public prosecutor is reviewing the case against Mr Boonstra after receiving a report from a bourse watchdog in the Netherlands indicating that he had tried to act on insider information.

Boonstra's one-time partner, Sylvia Toth, was on Endemol's supervisory board, charged with overseeing the company's management. A spokesman for Endemol said he could not confirm whether Ms Toth would have been aware of the Telefonica bid prior to a formal announcement.

"We do not discuss information that has gone to the supervisory board," he said.

Boonstra and Ms Toth formally separated in 1998, though there have been reports that their relationship is still close.

Ms Toth, who was a member of the supervisory board from when Endemol was founded in 1994, left the company after the Telefonica takeover was completed last summer.

On March 17 last year, Telefonica bid for Endemol at a considerable premium to the entertainment company's then valuation.

Mr Boonstra, who will be succeeded as Philips president by Gerard Kleisterlee next month, is said to be confident about defending himself against the allegations. His lawyer said Mr Boonstra would not be denying that he placed the order to buy shares. However, in a statement on Mr Boonstra's behalf, no mention of Ms Toth was made.

A spokesman for Endemol said the company had not known of the allegations faced by Mr Boonstra. "We were just as surprised by this news as everyone else," he said.

"We didn't know that the STE [the bourse regulator] was investigating shares bought in our company. They didn't ask any questions of anyone at Endemol."

webTitle: City faces renewed fears of job cuts

fields.headline: City faces renewed fears of job cuts
fields.standfirst:
• 100 shown door at Merrill Lynch's stockbroking division
• IT and support staff first in firing line
fields.trailText: Fears of a wave of job cuts in the City were reinforced last night when Merrill Lynch, the US investment bank, wielded the axe at its 8,000-strong London workforce.
fields.body:
Fears of a wave of job cuts in the City were reinforced last night when Merrill Lynch, the US investment bank, wielded the axe at its 8,000-strong London workforce.

Around 100 staff at the bank's stockbroking division are understood to have been shown the door yesterday, adding to the general anxiety that slow, steady job cuts are in store across the City as difficult market conditions begin to bite.

The economic thinktank, the CEBR, recently warned that as many as 20,000 City jobs could be lost if the economic slowdown continued.

Unlike three years ago when Merrill Lynch reacted to the Asian economic crisis by firing 5% of its staff worldwide, the bank is thought to be taking a more measured approach to any layoffs this year.

Its rivals believe that Merrill learnt a painful lesson in 1998 because it reacted too quickly to the downturn in the markets and as a result missed out on the bull run in the stock markets which took place soon afterwards.

The leading investment banks in the City need to cut costs as revenues dry up, but they are reluctant to admit that staff are being made redundant as a result. However, the biggest cost for an investment bank is its people, especially with their annual bonus payments.

So far contracting staff in IT and so-called support staff to the bankers are thought to be among the first in the firing line. The heavy-hitting, highly paid bankers who are expensive to dispense with and even more expensive to rehire are thought to be safer in their positions.

The dramatic reduction in activity in the first quarter of this year, most dramatically illustrated by the halving in the number of mergers and acquisitions which took place in Europe compared with last year, has led to fears in the City that the recent years of record employment and bonuses cannot be repeated.

One City source said: "Most of the big banks are looking at their headcount from week to week to see what's happening in the markets."

While none of the leading banks will admit that they are being forced to make bankers redundant, Goldman Sachs is known to be using its annual performance review to reduce its 22,000 global workforce by as much as 5%. At least 100 staff are thought to have left Goldman in recent weeks, with a handful being made redundant as recently as last week.

Last night, Merrill Lynch, which failed to renew contracts of 80 staff last week, refused to comment on rumours that it had yesterday started to make full-time staff redundant.

A spokesman said: "Due to the continuing weak business environment affecting the entire industry, we continue to examine how we are allocating resources, including staffing levels and all other expenses."

webTitle: Dow clambers back on rate cut talk

fields.headline: Dow clambers back on rate cut talk
fields.standfirst: Pressure grows on European Central Bank to move into line
fields.trailText: American investors piled back into the stock market yesterday amid fevered speculation that the US central bank is planning another surprise cut in interest rates.
fields.body:
American investors piled back into the stock market yesterday amid fevered speculation that the US central bank is planning another surprise cut in interest rates.

The Dow Jones index of US leading shares rose nearly 300 points by noon, breaking through the 10,000 barrier for the first time in three weeks and lifting the London market. The FTSE index closed up 139.7 points at 5803.

Rumours that the US Federal Reserve could be planning to cut interest rates before its next scheduled meeting in mid-May helped erase some of the gloomy sentiment prevailing on Wall Street since early March. Analysts said investors had seized on the absence of any bad news from US companies to snap up stocks at bargain basement prices, but they warned yesterday's rally did not mean that the share price slide was over.

"The bear market is still in force. This rally is a good and an important sign that maybe we're starting to bottom, but there's no evidence we've bottomed yet," said Bob Streed, portfolio manager of Northern Select Equity Fund.

Hi-tech stocks led the rally, boosted by the news that a leading investment bank had upgraded its forecast for Europe's debt burdened telecoms firms. Credit Suisse First Boston raised its weighting in European telecoms to "neutral" from "underweight".

Investors' attention will now turn to the European Central Bank, which is under mounting pressure to join global efforts at warding off recession by lowering borrowing costs at its meeting today.

As the ECB's governing council prepared for its meeting last night, independent forecasters slashed their predictions for growth in the euro zone. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development announced it had cut 0.4 percentage points off its forecast for the 12 members in the single currency area, expecting growth to expand by 2.7% this year, well down on last year's 3.4%.

Earlier, six German think tanks warned that growth in the euro zone's biggest economy is slowing sharply, and called on the ECB to deliver a steep cut in interest rates.

Most economists expect the ECB to announce a quarter percentage point cut in interest rates today, but there are now increased worries that this may not be enough to ward off the impact of the global slowdown.

"I don't think anyone is of the opinion that they are going to procrastinate long. It's getting clearer and clearer that the European economy is slowing," said Gianpaolo Mosconi, an analyst at Sanwa International. The ECB has held interest rates at 4.75% since last October.

fields.headline: Prudent Parveen is the chancellor's fictitious saver
fields.standfirst:
Those on low incomes may not benefit from stakeholder pensions, writes Polly Toynbee

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Those on low incomes may not benefit from stakeholder pensions.
fields.body:
Here is the story of Parveen. "Parveen is a self-employed fitness trainer in her late 20s, earning around £14,000 a year. She has recently bought a flat with a friend, and now that the initial expenses are out of the way she thinks she can afford to start a pension. She has considered the information on stakeholder pensions, including the 'decision trees' and this helped her to decide that a stakeholder pension would be suitable for her." Parveen is the star of the government's guide to stakeholder pensions.

Parveen went to work pretty fast, since stakeholder pensions were only launched by the government last Friday. So who is this model citizen, this perfect Asian gymnast who has a mortgage and a pension before the age of 30 on a very modest salary? She seems surprisingly certain about her future life. Is she perhaps a lesbian in a settled relationship with the friend who co-owns her flat? That might explain why she is quite sure she will not have children and will not need any rainy-day money, her savings untouchable until she is 65.

Parveen is a paragon of prudence. With a mortgage on £14,000 pay, (she plainly lives far from the south-east), Guardian personal finance writers, using average mortgage figures, reckon that after tax, national insurance, council tax, mortgage and energy bills, she has about £6,480 a year, or £135 a week to live on. So what made her decide that a pension was right for her? Shouldn't she have put any savings into an ISA where she could get the money back if she ever gets sick, loses her job or just needs it? Did she have a financial adviser? If so she was mis-sold this pension.

I called the Department of Social Security in whose stakeholder guide Parveen features. Would it be possible to interview her? The press officer retired to enquire and returned a bit embarrassed. "Um, well, actually, she's just an example." Oh? "She's not real". Just as well, since a real-life Parveen might be going hungry to pay for her old age. No Parveen is just a decoy duck, displayed to entice in the real-life Parveens.

There are, the government says, 5m sitting ducks at whom stakeholder pensions are primarily targeted. They earn between £10,500 and £20,000, and currently have no pensions. However, research suggests that most people on below-average earnings can't afford pensions. (A third of those who take out personal pensions default within a few years, losing most of their money). Most people who are rich enough, do save. So there is a danger that with its new high profile advertising, the government is embarking on its own pensions mis-selling campaign.

Make no mistake, Gordon Brown's new stakeholder is a genuinely brilliant innovation. He has forced the finance industry to create far better pensions than ever existed before, in the teeth of bitter opposition. The kite-mark guarantees no charges more than 1%. It is completely flexible: you can put in vary ing sums, as much or as little as you like, free to move your funds from one company to another with no penalties. It has made a mini-revolution in the City, forcing them to obey the chancellor's determination to get a better deal, a pension easy to trust without needing to understand its small print. For the better off, it is yet another tax break, as people can pay extra tax-free sums into partners' and children's pension funds with full tax relief. As with ISAs, products designed for low earners always end up sheltering huge amounts more money of the rich into tax havens and capital gains avoidance. So stakeholders are very good for average earners and just dandy for the rich.

B ut this is not something to sell Parveen. By 2003 the minimum income guarantee (MIG) will deliver at least £100 a week to all pensioners. Parveen cannot possibly pay enough into her pension to reach that: as a fitness trainer she is unlikely to earn much more. (The Institute for Fiscal Studies reckons she needs to pay in an unbroken 5% of her income for 49 full years before it is really worth her while). True, in 2003 the government is bringing in the pension credit which guarantees anyone with small savings can keep 60p in every £1 saved, on top of their MIG. But that is only up to a maximum of £13.80 a week - and losing 40p in every pound makes it pretty doubtful that low earners should save their money this way.

Oddly, one reason the government gives for saving is that none of us can rely on the state in, say, 40 years time. Maybe we will have had decades of Tory slash and burn. Maybe no one will vote to take reasonable care of the pensioners and the steep increases made by this government will be swept away. (The MIG has already delivered five times more to the poorest one third of pensioners than if Labour had restored the earnings link for the basic pension. But the Tories refuse to commit to keeping the link between the MIG and earnings.) However by pre-empting some Tory future even worse than the Tory past, the existence of large savings by poor people will only make it easier to cut back state provision.

Even more alarming is the long-term future of all pension funds. Current generations swelled the pot, paying in massively and inflating share prices as pension funds hoovered them up. But as baby boomers start drawing their pensions out, funds will be selling shares, pouring billions of shares onto the market and deflating share prices. Already out-dated calculations expecting high interest rates have thrown people's retirement planning awry. In other words, the pension future is uncertain. It always was and always will be for anyone trying to guess the politics and the economy 40 years ahead. The affluent can take the risk, helped by huge tax breaks making it worth their while. But any financial adviser would tell Parveen to put spare money where she can reach it or get a bigger mortgage as a safer bet. There is an interestingly different tone in the government's own somewhat gung-ho stakeholder guide, and the far more cautious note struck in the Financial Services Authority's guide, warning people to consider their personal circumstances with care - and get advice. They might add a warning never to take advice from governments of any hue.

There is another reason why Parveen should not pay. The government says that as many people as possible should (morally? fiscally?) pay for their own retirement. But those who are low earners in their working lives, scrimping to get by with mortgages, would do well to let the state worry about their old age. The ever-widening divide between rich and poor will not narrow by taking more off below-average earners to save for a decent retirement that should - and increasingly is - being provided by the government's own good minimum income guarantee. As Labour rightly raises the MIG, it reduces the incentive of low earners to save - and that is as good a form of redistribution as any.

fields.headline: Suck up to your boss
fields.standfirst: Judi James follows an alternative route to promotion
fields.trailText: Judi James follows an alternative route to promotion.
fields.body:
Suffering from over-work and under-praise? Well perhaps you need to indulge in a little brown-nosing to get yourself noticed at higher level. Recognition is one of the greatest motivation factors in the workplace, and yet the majority of us whinge that we rarely get enough of it.

Sucking up to the boss is a vital component of being acknowledged and fairly praised. Forming one of the silent minority - that unsung gang who keep their heads down and get on with their job - expecting that the meek shall inherit the earth, or at least merit promotion, is a waste of time in modern business.

But how do you curry favour without being labelled a creep? The stigma of "teacher's pet" is a hard one to shake off. And yet it is possible to worm your way into your boss's respect - if not affection - without coming across as a complete toady.

Stake out your prey

First, know your target. What motivates your boss? What are his/her core values? How does he/she conduct their business and what are their interests outside the workplace?

Try to pinpoint areas of strength in the way that he/she works, and any areas of potential weakness. What hours does he/she keep? Are they a morning person, or do they only perk up after lunch?

Listen to the type of language they use when they speak. Are they speedy and concise? Do they reach quick decisions and keep to them, or are they slower and more cautious? Do they stop for a chat and a joke or are they more likely to indulge in discussions about staff stress levels and creche facilities?

Business psychologists usually pinpoint four main behavioural styles in the workplace. To create rapport with any one of these types it can be important to flex your own style a little. Very few people fall into an extreme of one behavioural style and most of us are blends, but, by identifying a preferred type you can work on ways to improve your own communications with them:

The pragmatist

A linear thinker who likes step by step plans and procedures. This person likes working with fact, figures and logic. They tend to be calm and rational but are also often boring. This boss will only be impressed with thoroughly researched ideas and careful planning. They work slowly and meticulously and don't like to be rushed. Impress him/her by your own thoroughness and the fact that you are dependable and reliable.

Be prepared to listen while he/she goes through all the dull details of any job. Never be seen to start a job you can't finish. Never skip small steps or details to get a job rushed through.

The nurturer

Another Linear thinker, but this boss is more concerned with team relationships than cold facts and figures. He/she will be thoughtful and concerned about the staff, rather than the task. The nurturer inspires a loyal team but through encouraging, rather than pushing them. Trust is an important issue in your relationship with him/her. If you screw up a job always come clean and ask for help, rather than covering-up.

Impress this boss by allowing yourself to be coached and developed. Ask questions and bond like crazy. Show concern for other colleagues. If you are the office bitch who loves to gossip then learn to behave more hands-on touchy-feely. Be prepared to show an interest in this boss's family and home life. Share details of your own.

The entertainer

A born gut-reactor of a boss, someone who likes to be spontaneous and optimistic and who admires those qualities in his/her staff. This boss likes to talk and share a sense of humour. The main weakness of the entertainer is a lack of planning or attention to detail. Make him/her the centre of attention and always sound positive in your dialogues.

Whingers will be given a wide berth. If you want to suck up to this boss, offer to take on some of the more boring tasks involving detail. They are big-picture, rather than linear workers, who specialise in intuition and creativity.

The driver

This boss is concise, direct and often adopts a bossy style. He/she will have little time for small talk, being task, rather than relationship-focused. He/she likes all the trappings of power and will be keen to remind staff of his/her status.

The style of the driver is quite confrontational. Avoid being seen as an overt sycophant, though. Challenge him/her now and again to grow mutual respect. Be quick, direct and to the point yourself and avoid chat or waffle. Do your job quickly and allow for the fact that this boss will often pinch your best ideas or your share of the glory. Bite the bullet but don't be a complete doormat.

fields.headline: Controversy comes as a bonus
fields.standfirst: Worries about Soho wine-bar kudos are buried as Royal Bank faces a shareholder rebellion over takeover rewards
fields.trailText: Worries about Soho wine-bar kudos are buried as Royal Bank faces a shareholder rebellion over takeover rewards, writes Jill Treanor.
fields.body:
Viscount Younger of Leckie, to use his official title, is accustomed to battle. Handpicked by Margaret Thatcher to become defence minister after the damaging Westland affair, the 69-year-old Scot has toughed out tricky situations and engaged in some rough sparing matches.

Today, as he presides over his last annual meeting as chairman of Royal Bank of Scotland, he may need all the diplomacy he can muster to stem a possible shareholder revolt over the pay deals handed out to the bank's top executives.

His successor, Sir George Mathewson, who takes over today, tried to shrug off rumblings of unrest over the pay deals with the explanation that they "wouldn't give you bragging power in a Soho wine bar".

By the end of today's meeting the bank will know whether shareholders agree with Sir George, who is one of several bosses to share in the £2.5m bonus to reward them for taking over NatWest last year.

Some big shareholders admitted yesterday that they had already registered their unease at the bank's policies - not only on the bonuses but also on a new "incentive" plan - by exercising their right to vote against certain resolutions. Others, such as Standard Life, are expected to save their votes until today for maximum impact. A number say they have decided to let the matter pass after listening to Royal Bank's explanation.

It is unclear whether the number of rebellious votes will be large enough to prevent the approval of any of the proposals. What is certain is that Viscount Younger is unlikely to be alone among chairman of big firms in presiding over potentially difficult shareholder meetings.

As it stands, some big corporations will face uncomfortable questions about the behaviour of the remuneration committees that set pay levels. Rows between investors and executives are heating up at banking group Schroders, mining firm Billiton, hi-tech group ARM, and Marks & Spencer.

Behind the scenes, private conversations are taking place between shareholders and companies from a range of sectors in an attempt to keep the lid on corporate excess.

Something to prove

Such conversations, or "private soundings out", as one investor describes them, are common at the end of most big firms' financial years - and come ahead of their annual meetings. There is a furore nearly every year as one company or another oversteps the mark of what is deemed acceptable to City investors - as Vodafone did last year with a £10m bonus to chief executive Chris Gent.

Such accusations of fat-cattery have been made since the Thatcherite privatisations of the 80s, most famously with regard to Cedric Brown, then boss of British Gas, who had the indignity of seeing the unions name a pig after him. This year, City investors seem more prepared to flex their muscles - for which there a number of possible reasons.

Some suggest that the big shareholder groups - the National Association of Pension Funds and the Association of British Insurers, which between them represent as much as half the money invested in the stock markets - feel they have something to prove. The government is watching their actions closely. It has already, in private at least, used their potential influence as a reason to back down from some of its tougher proposals on executive pay.

The NAPF is also providing guidance to its powerful pension fund investors on how to vote at annual meetings for the first time - which may also be focusing the minds of major investment groups.

The public fracas might also be the result of new guidelines published by the ABI on how the crucial link between pay and performance for top executives should be defined - and companies are now testing those limits. There is also the influence pay practices in the US are having on recruiting executives to British firms.

Stuart Bell, a research director at the veteran corporate governance watchdog Pirc, believes it may also be a question of money for the shareholders themselves.

"There are more institutional investors aware of the importance of governance. It is a reflection of the economic circumstances we're in. Share prices have been flatter. The link between payment and performance [of the company's shares] concentrates the minds of institutional investors," Mr Bell said.

The ABI's new rules on directors' pay are intended to strengthen the link between pay and performance. Peter Montagnon was recently appointed head of investment affairs at the ABI . He believes that, while devising such new performance schemes for top executives is important, it is the cash bonuses to directors that are attracting an unusual amount of attention this year. "We're looking at bonuses - or their cash equivalents - more than we have before," he says.

These bonuses are similar to those fac ing scrutiny today at the Royal Bank and which frustrate shareholders because they do not appear to have any connection with the long-term performance of the company. While Royal Bank has argued that its bonuses were a reflection of the success of its takeover battle for NatWest, shareholders feel it is too early to gauge whether the deal is a success.

The NAPF has conceded that it may have not allowed enough time to lapse between making its concerns public and allowing the bank to respond. One shareholder says it makes little difference: "We just don't like transaction bonuses."

This year's scapegoat

Expressing disapproval of pay and other so-called cooperative governance issues could create problems for shareholders. Companies rarely give shareholders an opportunity to vote directly on the remuneration report at annual meetings, something the NAPF hoped the government would require them to do. The DTI insists it is waiting for the completion of the review of company law before deciding if such a requirement will be necessary.

Instead, in the case of the Royal Bank, the NAPF is recommending that its members vote against the reappointment of two non-executive directors, BT boss Sir Iain Vallance and banker Sir Angus Grossart. Both sit on the remuneration committee but Sir Angus is no longer considered an "independent" non-executive.

Some industry sources suggested last night that a rebellion of a 20% vote among shareholders against the pair might be registered tomorrow - certainly not enough to prevent them reassuming their positions on the board, but a potential embarrassment for Royal Bank.

The row has evoked sympathy in some quarters, with the bank being seen as this year's scapegoat despite a strong rise in its shares last year.

As Lord Younger calls time at today's annual meeting after 10 years at the helm, he can be confident that it will only be a matter of time before investors prepare for battle with their next prey. Luc Vandevelde, his counterpart at M&S, might do well to start to prepare his defences against shareholder doubts about his right to claim a £650,000 bonus in the coming months.

Both sit on the remuneration committee but Sir Angus is no longer considered an "independent" non-executive. Some industry sources suggested last night that a rebellion of a 20% vote among shareholders against the pair might be registered tomorrow - certainly not enough to prevent them reassuming their positions on the board, but a potential embarrassment for Royal Bank. The row has evoked sympathy in some quarters, with the bank being seen as this year's scapegoat despite a strong rise in its shares last year. As Lord Younger calls time at today's annual meeting after 10 years at the helm, he can be confident that it will only be a matter of time before investors prepare for battle with their next prey. Luc Vandevelde, his counterpart at M&S, might do well to start to prepare his defences against shareholder doubts about his right to claim a £650,000 bonus in the coming months.

fields.headline: Think tank challenges chancellor
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is criticised today by an influential independent think tank for claiming that business investment in Britain is at a post-war high.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is criticised today by an influential independent think tank for claiming that business investment in Britain is at a post-war high.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies argues that the chancellor chose a measure which exaggerates the increase in spending because it strips out any changes in prices.

"Suggestions that there has been a sea change in the level of UK investment are difficult to reconcile with the range of available evidence," the IFS says in a paper published today.

The institute points out that the government's own figures show that business investment is not at record levels. Last year, firms spent less on investment as a share of GDP than they did 10 years ago.

"When Gordon Brown suggests that business investment as a share of our economy is 'over 14%, higher than at any time in 40 years' you might think that this would be a straightforward statistic," said Steve Bond, from the IFS.

"Yet the share of GDP that was actually spent on business investment last year was 12.3%, well down on levels seen in the late 1980s.

"The figure quoted by the chancellor revalues actual spending on investment using earlier and higher prices for capital goods. It is the correct answer to a less straightforward question."

Mr Brown is keen to proclaim an improvement in investment because the government believes this is key to closing the productivity gap between Britain and other leading economies.

A Treasury spokesperson said the IFS was making a technical argument about different measures of investment. "The IFS admit that neither series is right or wrong," he added.
