webTitle: The Industry Standard calls a halt in Europe

fields.headline: The Industry Standard calls a halt in Europe
fields.trailText: The Industry Standard magazine, the weekly news source for a generation of dot.com entrepreneurs, yesterday closed its European operations, writes Neil Hume.
fields.body:
The Industry Standard magazine, the weekly news source for a generation of dot.com entrepreneurs, yesterday closed its European operations only six months after starting up with the loss of about 60 jobs.

In a move similar to Thestreet.com's closure of its British operations, it was the US parent company, Standard Media International, that decided to pull the plug.

The London-based publishing operation had last week confirmed that it was seeking a buyer - and the speed of the decision to shut it down took staff by surprise.

"They're overstaffed in the US, and it appears the easiest solution was to shut us down," said one employee. "It's pretty galling, to be honest."

The company is understood to have promised to honour all its debts.

Journalists writing about the internet economy have not been immune from the downturn that has so badly affected those working in it.

Red Herring has made job cuts and Business 2.0, the new economy magazine owned by Future Network, is up for sale.

Pearson, the owner of the Financial Times, has a 2.5% stake in Standard Media International but turned down the chance to make a bid for the European edition's publisher. Other investors in the venture included French billionaire Bernard Arnault.

The Industry Standard Europe was launched at a lavish cocktail party at the prestigious Coq d'Argent restaurant in the City of London only six months ago.

During its short life the magazine attracted significant advertising but had been looking for partners to improve its pan-European distribution. Publisher Neil Thackray said last week that he was confident the magazine would reach break-even at the end of next year.

Earlier this month the American parent company said it had shelved plans for a German language version of the magazine.

Financial news magazines and websites enjoyed boom times before the dot.com bubble burst, but advertising revenues have slowed as businesses have become bankrupt and the flow of deals slowed.

Thestreet.co.uk has closed, Netimperative has been rescued from financial collapse and Sharecast has merged with Nothingventured.com.

Even FT.com, which has been the strongest brand in the sector, has been forced to cut about 10% of its staff.

webTitle: Ricard Williams on the awesome Dutch side of the 70s

fields.headline: Total recall of a rhapsody in orange
fields.standfirst: Johnny Rep, one of the awesome Dutch side of the 70s, talks to  Richard Williams  about the great days
fields.trailText: A quarter of a century later the legend of Dutch striker Johnny Rep remains powerful enough to have drawn a queue of admirers in London, for his is a story worth hearing.
fields.body:
He was supposed to be the last piece in the Total Football jigsaw, the striker who would score the goals invented by Johan Cruyff and Johan Neeskens, adding the final touch of glamour to the already irresistible footballing mechanism shared by Ajax and Holland in the early 70s. And who cares, now, that his arrival coincided with the beginning of Ajax's decline, or that he played on the losing side in two World Cup finals? A quarter of a century later the legend of Johnny Rep remains powerful enough to have drawn a queue of admirers to a book-signing session in London the other day.

Those Dutchmen, and the wonderful freedom and intelligence of their play, made a powerful and lasting impression on young minds. Now 48, and the coach of a second division side in Amsterdam, Rep has been the inspiration for a suite by the Dutch free-jazz pianist Leo Cuypers and a character in a Soho-noir fiction by the English novelist Chris Petit. But his down-to-earth manner makes it clear that such tributes have not formed part of his own self-image. You would have to go a long way before you found a Dutch footballer willing to come up with aphorisms about seagulls and trawlers as a way of indicating his intellectual reach, and Rep is no exception.

His first big match, at 19, was in the 1972 Intercontinental Cup against Independiente of Argentina. Replacing the veteran Sjaak Swart, a legend with the Amsterdam club, he scored two goals. He was in, and the following year he scored the only goal in the European Cup final against Juventus, completing Ajax's hat-trick of wins in the competition.

Essential instinct

The amazing thing about that game was that, having conceded a goal early on, when Rep headed Horst Blankenburg's cross past Dino Zoff, the Italian team showed no interest in attacking. Despite the presence in their forward line of such players as Pietro Anastasi, Jose Altafini, Roberto Bettega and Franco Causio, they stayed fatally within their shells.

"Juventus were so frightened," Rep remembered. "We were surprised. A good team but they did nothing. They seemed satisfied to lose 1-0. We were waiting for them. Come! But nothing. For the public, I'm afraid, it was a very bad game."

Unlike most of his team-mates, he has not been brought up within the legendary Ajax school. Between the ages of eight and 16 he had played for Zaandam, his hometown club, yet there was no real problem of acclimatisation. "All the teams wanted to play the same system - but at Ajax the players were better, so it was easier to play with them."

At first it was hard for him to win a first-team place. Swart, after all, had scored five goals in the debut game of the great coach, Rinus Michels, a 9-3 defeat of MVV Maastricht in 1965. But Michels left in 1971 and it was his successor, George Knobel, who gave Rep his chance. He played throughout the 1972-73 European Cup campaign, in the dazzling 4-0 quarter-final victory over Bayern Munich in Amsterdam and in the home and away victories over Real Madrid in the subsequent round, but not until his decisive strike in the final did he score.

After that triumph, however, the team began to break up. As David Winner recounts in his hugely enjoyable book Brilliant Orange, which Rep was signing in the Sportspages bookshop, Knobel foolishly held an election for the captaincy of the following season's team. When the vote went in favour of Piet Keizer, Cruyff took umbrage and accepted an offer to follow Michels to Barcelona.

Like several of his contemporaries Rep clearly has mixed feelings about the man most identified with Dutch football of that era. "I learnt a lot of my own play from Johan Cruyff," he said. "Of course, the most important things for a footballer to have are instinct and talent. When you can play football, you don't need to learn. If you don't have the instinct, you cannot be a good player. But I learnt a lot from Cruyff. When I was 19 years old, he was my mentor. If I was a little bit too relaxed, he was always behind me, always pushing. He made a professional of me."

On the other hand, while discussing the propensity of Dutch footballers to argue among themselves, he talked about the difference between Cruyff and Wim van Hanegem of Feyenoord, both midfield geniuses with an inclination to speak their mind. "They could both be pretty extreme. But Van Hanegem is fine when you know him. Cruyff is more distant. If you get in bad with him, he'll never speak with you."

Rep was 21 when he played in his first World Cup final, the traumatic defeat by West Germany in Munich in 1974. They had beaten Brazil 2-0 in a very physical semi-final, during which Rep responded to Roberto Rivelino's niggling by using his elbow, unseen by the officials. "Today Rivelino is my friend," he said. "But if we played that game today, there would be six red cards." And then in the final, having taken a first-minute lead with a penalty, they invited their bitterest enemies back into the game.

Had they thought that, by beating Brazil, they had already won the World Cup? "Yes. And our biggest mistake in the final was to score the first goal in the first minute. We thought we had the cup already. We made fun of the Germans. But we forgot to score the second goal."

Still, they had a party afterwards with their conquerors. "We drank a lot. And we hadn't been allowed to exchange shirts after the match, so I exchanged my jacket with Paul Breitner. The next day we flew home and went to see the queen and the parliament. So I met the queen in Paul Breitner's light blue jacket."

In Germany, even though they had the bad luck to meet the hosts in the final, their matches had been attended by large numbers of Dutch supporters. In Argentina four years later, where they were to suffer the same ultimate fate, the atmosphere was very different. "It was far away from home and people didn't have the money to go. We spent three weeks in a training camp in the Andes. Nobody there. We went crazy. In the first game, against Iran in Mendoza, there were 5,000 people - not many Dutch. No atmosphere. We played very badly. Against Scotland, 10,000. Again no atmosphere. Against Austria in Cordoba, maybe 15,000.

Against West Germany, maybe 20,000. That was the difference. Later, when we played against Italy in the River Plate stadium in the semi-final, there were 80,000 - mostly Italians. Then there were 80,000 for the final, of course - but that was terrible, too. Argentina had to win. It was bizarre. Not a normal situation. There was some fear, too. A lot of people said that if we won the game, there would be a big problem afterwards."

By that time Rep had left Ajax, opting like most of his team-mates for a foreign salary four or five times higher than the 100,000 guilders a year he had been earning in Holland. He had two seasons in Spain with Valencia, where he played alongside his friend and World Cup adversary Mario Kempes, and a Paraguayan No9, Carlos Diaz. "Only one year Diaz played with us. Then he left to play his guitar. His nickname was El Lobo, the wolf, because he was also very dangerous at night. That was the best attack I played in. Better than with Cruyff and Keizer." But the supervision, by Heriberto Herrera, another Paraguayan, was somewhat lacking in inspiration. "Discipline? Good. Coaching? Terrible. We never played with a ball in training. Always running. He's dead now, so I can say it."

He left Valencia after a row with the president over money and moved to Corsica to join Bastia, with whom he played in a Uefa Cup campaign which took them all the way to the final, against PSV Eindhoven. Bastia lost 3-0 on aggregate but Rep recalls it was "fantastic - the whole island was crazy for one year". Then came four years at Saint-Etienne, playing alongside the young Michel Platini and Dominique Rocheteau in the most successful French club of its era, let down only by "a bad defence, too old and too slow - a pity".

His last years as a player were spent back with Zaandam, where he finished as player-coach at the age of 41. Now he is grooming young players from the Surinamese and Moroccan communities in Almeer, a new town built 20 years ago on reclaimed land in the Ijsselmeer, where promotion to the first division would mean the club turning professional and building a proper stadium. But he enjoys watching English football - much more than Italian, which sends him to sleep - and would like to coach here.

And at Almeer, in front of a crowd measured in hundreds, do they play Total Football? "No, no. We like to try it. But it's only in our heads, eh?" And in ours, too.

webTitle: Brits fly away from disease and rain

fields.headline: Brits fly away from disease and rain
fields.trailText: The Easter weekend will see around 1.75 million Britons escaping the twin spectres of rain and foot-and-mouth by travelling abroad, the tourist industry said today.
fields.body:
The Easter weekend will see around 1.75 million Britons escaping the twin spectres of rain and foot-and-mouth by travelling abroad, the tourist industry said today.

While cabinet ministers jostle to be photographed holidaying at home, a million travellers have already booked to fly out of the UK, and 500,000 more have cross-channel tickets.

The Canary Islands, mainland Spain and Majorca and Ibiza are proving again the most popular short-haul destinations for package holidays.

Cyprus and Tunisia are also selling well, while long-haul travellers are mainly heading for Florida and the Caribbean.

The British Resorts Association said the foot-and-mouth outbreak could result in more visitors flocking to towns and the seaside this Easter.

Association's director Peter Hampson said: "There is still a lot of misunderstanding about what is open and what isn't.

"Towns and coastal resorts are generally free of the outbreak and given some dry weather people will want to get out to these areas during the holiday weekend."

Bookings in Britain may also be affected by predicted cool and showery weather. The PA weather centre said that Easter "is not going to be a wash-out", but there would be a lot of cloud around. The only heavy rain is likely to be in the far north.

The AA warned of heavy traffic over the weekend, with Thursday afternoon and evening likely to be the busiest time on the roads.

webTitle: MPs urge Coke drinkers to back Kyoto email campaign

fields.headline: MPs urge Coke drinkers to back Kyoto email campaign
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: A cross-party committee of MPs has launched an unprecedented campaign to persuade Coca-Cola's customers around the world to strongarm the global soft drinks company into backing the Kyoto protocols against global warming.
fields.body:
A cross-party committee of MPs has launched an unprecedented campaign to persuade Coca-Cola's customers around the world to strongarm the global soft drinks company into backing the Kyoto protocols against global warming.

They appealed to young customers to bombard both Coca-Cola - initially in Britain - and the White House urging the world's largest creator of greenhouse gases to fall in line with growing demands for greater restraints on pollutants.

''We turn not to the foes of President Bush, but to his friends, those whose wise counsels have influenced the president, those whose wide pockets have sustained him,'' explained the former consumer affairs minister, Nigel Griffiths.

The MPs are targeting Coca-Cola because it gave nearly $1m to George Bush's successful bid for the presidency last year and they want to persuade the drinks giant that it should use its ''influence'' with the US administration to abandon last month's sudden repudiation of Kyoto.

They are also incensed that Coke has borrowed the environmentalists' slogan ''think globally, act locally'' and hope it can be persuaded to act upon it. ''We want Coke to act locally to get the president to think globally. Coca-Cola are the sole marketing partner of Harry Potter, the world's best known wizard. We want them to work their magic on the president.''

Although they are in touch with MEPs at Strasbourg, with French Greens and with Senator Joe Lieberman - Al Gore's running mate in November - the MPs believe that Coke's marketing image as a friendly, global drink for young people makes it vulnerable to pressure from precisely that group of consumers.

''We are encouraging every Coke drinker to email the UK vice president (of Coca Cola), Thomson Long, on tlong@eur.ko.com urging him to impress on President Bush the vital importance of ratifying the Kyoto protocol. We also urge people to email President Bush on president@whitehouse.gov.'' the MPs said.

Tory backbenchers including Peter Bottomley, and Liberal Democrat Tom Brake have joined 30 Labour MPs in launching what they hope will turn into the global email campaign - directed at Coca-Cola's ''ear, not its wallet'' though leftwing signatories such as Alan Simpson believe that a boycott of Coca-Cola's products would also be legitimate.

The national union of students (NUS) is also backing the campaign. Tony Blair and his ministers have signalled their dismay that Mr Bush has reversed his campaign pledge to back Kyoto, arguing that US interests are not served by it.

But there are signs that American public opinion, surprised by the near-universal hostility of world reaction to such unilateralism, is shifting towards seeking to implement the Kyoto deal - stalled in the Hague in December - which will be discussed in Berlin in July.

The deal would commit the US to cut carbon emissions by 7% compared with 1990 levels by 2012, difficult for a car-dependent culture whose per capita emissions are the highest in the world. The US has sought swap arrangements which would fend off carbon taxes in a low fuel price economy.

• Email President George Bush on president@whitehouse.gov

fields.bodyText: A cross-party committee of MPs has launched an unprecedented campaign to persuade Coca-Cola's customers around the world to strongarm the global soft drinks company into backing the Kyoto protocols against global warming. They appealed to young customers to bombard both Coca-Cola - initially in Britain - and the White House urging the world's largest creator of greenhouse gases to fall in line with growing demands for greater restraints on pollutants. ''We turn not to the foes of President Bush, but to his friends, those whose wise counsels have influenced the president, those whose wide pockets have sustained him,'' explained the former consumer affairs minister, Nigel Griffiths. The MPs are targeting Coca-Cola because it gave nearly $1m to George Bush's successful bid for the presidency last year and they want to persuade the drinks giant that it should use its ''influence'' with the US administration to abandon last month's sudden repudiation of Kyoto. They are also incensed that Coke has borrowed the environmentalists' slogan ''think globally, act locally'' and hope it can be persuaded to act upon it. ''We want Coke to act locally to get the president to think globally. Coca-Cola are the sole marketing partner of Harry Potter, the world's best known wizard. We want them to work their magic on the president.'' Although they are in touch with MEPs at Strasbourg, with French Greens and with Senator Joe Lieberman - Al Gore's running mate in November - the MPs believe that Coke's marketing image as a friendly, global drink for young people makes it vulnerable to pressure from precisely that group of consumers. ''We are encouraging every Coke drinker to email the UK vice president (of Coca Cola), Thomson Long, on tlong@eur.ko.com urging him to impress on President Bush the vital importance of ratifying the Kyoto protocol. We also urge people to email President Bush on president@whitehouse.gov.'' the MPs said. Tory backbenchers including Peter Bottomley, and Liberal Democrat Tom Brake have joined 30 Labour MPs in launching what they hope will turn into the global email campaign - directed at Coca-Cola's ''ear, not its wallet'' though leftwing signatories such as Alan Simpson believe that a boycott of Coca-Cola's products would also be legitimate. The national union of students (NUS) is also backing the campaign. Tony Blair and his ministers have signalled their dismay that Mr Bush has reversed his campaign pledge to back Kyoto, arguing that US interests are not served by it. The deal would commit the US to cut carbon emissions by 7% compared with 1990 levels by 2012, difficult for a car-dependent culture whose per capita emissions are the highest in the world. The US has sought swap arrangements which would fend off carbon taxes in a low fuel price economy. fields.headline: Sunday Mirror expresses regret
fields.trailText:
6pm: The Sunday Mirror has expressed its deep regret at the collapse of the Leeds footballers trial, writes Claire Cozens.
Apr 10: Sunday Mirror could face £10m fine
Apr 10: Trial could become TV drama
fields.body:
The Sunday Mirror has expressed its "deep regret" at the collapse of the Leeds footballers trial following the publication of an article in last Sunday's paper.

The newapaper, which is facing contempt of court charges over the publication of the article, said it had begun an investigation into how it came to be published.

In a statement issued this afternoon, the paper said:

"We are currently seeking to establish the precise editorial and legal processes that were taken last week. We'd like to take this opportunity to express our deep regret about the subsequent chain of events."

The Attorney General said today a decision on possible contempt of court proceedings against the Sunday Mirror would be made "as quickly as possible".

The trial of the Leeds footballers has cost taxpayers an estimated £8m.

A retrial was ordered today.

fields.headline: Bectu halts BBC action
fields.trailText:
6.15pm: BBC unions have suspended their work to rule after a new expenses policy was put forward by management, writes Jason Deans.
Apr 10: Dyke clamps down on awards liggers
Read Dyke's memo to staff
Feb 26: BBC boosts presence at Dando trial
Feb 15: Expenses policy sparks BBC work to rule
More BBC stories
fields.body:
BBC unions have suspended their work-to-rule after a new expenses policy was put forward by management.

After talks with the Inland Revenue, the corporation is scrapping the expenses rules that required camera crews working within five miles of any BBC office to return to base for their meal breaks.

The rules resulted in the BBC TV news bulletins, particularly at lunchtime, missing several key court verdicts.

Camera crews belonging to broadcast union Bectu downed tools outside the Old Bailey in the centre of London and returned to TV Centre six miles away in west London for their lunch.

In an e-mail to staff, BBC director-general Greg Dyke announced the BBC had agreed with the Inland Revenue that BBC News and News Resources staff would not be taxed on meals if they worked less than five miles from their home base.

BBC staff working in other areas now only need to be away for five hours - and at least five miles from their home base - for a meal claim not to be taxable.

The £55-a-night hotel cap has been lifted to £65 and, after 8pm, staff can claim £10 for dinner if they have been on duty for five hours or more and are more than five miles from their office.

In addition, a separate expenses policy is to be introduced for BBC Resources staff.

"Before anyone asks, these changes do not signal the end of One BBC," Mr Dyke wrote in his email to staff.

"It's worth remembering we will have reduced 26 different expenses policies down to just two.

"I hope everyone accepts we've listened to the genuine concerns expressed by staff and we have changed the new policy as a result."

The email is signed-off: "Yours, Greg".

The work to rule began on Monday February 26.

Bectu is to suspend the industrial action while it ballots members on the new proposals.

The ballot will be completed within two weeks and Bectu insiders are expecting their members to accept the changes.

"We welcome these proposals from the BBC," said one Bectu source. "It's just a shame it needed industrial action to get this sorted out."

fields.headline: Police arrest celebrity stalker suspect
fields.trailText: A man in his 70s was tonight being questioned by detectives investigating obscene mail sent to female celebrities including Dame Diana Rigg and Joan Bakewell.
fields.body:
A man in his 70s was tonight being questioned by detectives investigating obscene mail sent to female celebrities including Dame Diana Rigg and Joan Bakewell.

Detectives from Scotland Yard arrested the man at a house in Wigan, Greater Manchester, at about 7.45am after appeals on BBC1's Crimewatch UK programme.

He was detained on suspicion of causing a public nuisance and is being interviewed by detectives.

Police launched an investigation in December after a complaint from actress Moira Lister about pornographic letters.

It later emerged that the stalker may have targeted up to 60 women over the last 20 years.

Victims also included former newsreader Jan Leeming, Radio 4 presenter Sue MacGregor and Pan's People dancer Dee Dee Wilde. All the recipients are famous women "of a certain age". Many are stage actresses who were at the height of their popularity in the 1970s and 1980s.

Scotland Yard said that police investigating the stalker had been led to the Wigan area after a call from a Crimewatch UK viewer responding to an appeal on the programme two weeks ago.

Speaking recently about the harassment, McGregor said: "This has gone on long enough. It is more than a nuisance and it is actually against the law."

webTitle: Boy of 11 facing race charge after playground taunt

fields.headline: Boy of 11 facing race charge after playground taunt
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A boy aged 11 who called a schoolmate a "Paki bastard" in a flurry of playground name-calling faces being prosecuted for racially aggravated assault after a high court attempt to block his trial failed yesterday.
fields.body:
A boy aged 11 who called a schoolmate a "Paki bastard" in a flurry of playground name-calling faces being prosecuted for racially aggravated assault after a high court attempt to block his trial failed yesterday.

Lawyers for the child, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had sought to overthrow the crown prosecution service's decision to prosecute by arguing that "a glorified schoolyard incident" threatened to have a "devastating and disproportionate effect" on both him and his school.

But Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Garland, said although he "fully understood" the arguments for not going ahead, he could not interfere with the discretion of the director of public prosecutions and the CPS. Rejecting the child's application for judicial review, he added: "It is in many ways a tragic matter. It may be argued that even to think in terms of a prosecution is using a sledgehammer to crack a nut.

"It may do more harm than good and is unlikely to be particularly helpful to G [the Asian boy allegedly assaulted] or to H [the boy who allegedly assaulted him] or the other children in their class, or the reputation of their primary school and the teachers."

Earlier, Stephen Ferguson, appearing for the boy, claimed that the incident in September last year stemmed from little more than "tit-for-tat name-calling between children".

H, who at the time was "a very young 10-year-old from a very good family" and who had no previous convictions, reprimands or warnings, had allegedly been teased in the classroom by G for being overweight, with taunts of "teletubby".

The court heard that H and a 10-year-old friend, S, then confronted G as he walked home. G claimed he was punched twice in the back and called a "Paki bastard". Both H and S now also face charges of common assault.

It had taken place just outside the schoolyard, said Mr Ferguson. There had been no serious injury, and it was a "farce" that a decision had been made last December to prosecute the now "remorseful, distressed and tearful" boy, who was staying away from school because of the pressure he was under. "If the matter is pursued to conviction there will be a very significant labelling of this young boy... The whole of his chances of employment in the professions could also be affected if he were convicted of the racially aggravated offence."

The headteacher of the primary school in Ipswich had not even deemed the incident significant enough to ban H from the class for a day, while the police advice was not to prosecute him, Mr Ferguson said.

At its highest importance, the appropriate way to deal with it was a reprimand or a final warning, he said.

If H had been a few months younger - under 10, the age of criminal responsibility - a prosecution would not have been possible.

webTitle: Cricket: Wondrous Woods rips up records and rivals

fields.headline: Wondrous Woods rips up records and rivals
fields.standfirst: Tiger's iron nerve leaves opponents trailing in his wake
fields.trailText: Tiger Woods finally did what no other golfer has ever done and what no golfer may ever do again: he won his fourth consecutive major championship, a simply fantastic feat. In winning the US Masters on Sunday for the second time he took his championship-winning streak to five of the last six, demonstrating that in modern golf there is no one remotely as good.
fields.body:
Tiger Woods finally did what no other golfer has ever done and what no golfer may ever do again: he won his fourth consecutive major championship, a simply fantastic feat. In winning the US Masters on Sunday for the second time he took his championship-winning streak to five of the last six, demonstrating that in modern golf there is no one remotely as good.

On Sunday afternoon Woods, the world No1, was paired with the world No2, Phil Mickelson, and two groups in front was a man who has very recently occupied both those positions, David Duval. And yet, when the bell rang and Tiger stood up, both men sat on their stools, mesmerised by the awesome ability of this phenomenal golfer.

On Sunday evening, wearing the green jacket and facing the world's press, Tiger at last smiled. He had broken down and cried when the last putt was holed and in the heat of battle had played as if hypnotised, so fierce was his focus.

Now, though, he could be happy and, despite promptings from some eager for controversy, the words "grand slam" did not cross his lips. "Now that you've won it," he was asked, "what do you want to call it?" Woods said: "I'll let you guys decide, you guys are very creative."

Then it was put to him outright. "Is it a grand slam in your eyes?" Woods looked the man in the eye and said: "I've won four."

He was wise not to continue with an earlier assertion that all four majors at the same time somehow must be a grand slam, not only because the weight of opinion is that it must be done in a calendar year but also because he must suspect he is capable of the real grand slam.

So for now it is the simultaneous slam, or the straight slam, maybe even the Tiger slam while the grand slam still awaits the attention of this extraordinarily gifted player.

The magnitude of his achievement surpasses anything done previously by the game's greats. Ben Hogan won three in one year in 1953, the Masters, the US Open and the Open at Carnoustie, but was unable to play in the US PGA because it clashed with the Open. In any case, the concept of the slam had not been re- invented, as it was by Arnold Palmer in 1960, and Hogan played in only six events in his glorious year, winning five.

Jack Nicklaus had a chance to hold all four majors at the same time, albeit not consecutively, when he arrived at Muirfield with three under his belt - the US PGA which was played in February of 1971 and then moved to August for 1972, and the Masters and US Open of '72.

He played the first three rounds so conservatively that he did not even carry a driver in his bag. He arrived at the final round with Lee Trevino and Tony Jacklin ahead of him, cast caution aside, smashed his driver miles, got round in 66 and failed by one shot.

Since then no one has won more than two on the trot, let alone by some of the margins Woods has put together. He took the US Open by the humiliating margin of 15 shots, the Open at St Andrews - where he completed a career grand slam - by eight shots and the only close-run thing was the US PGA, where he was taken to an unlikely play-off by Bob May.

Sunday's win was not in any of those categories. Woods said he "grinded it out" and, given that his 68, rather than the official 72, is actually par for him, that is true. But what it amounted to was a slow strangulation as he choked the life from his competitors. On several occasions Woods made mistakes but, just as Nicklaus before him, Woods is the greatest putter in the game.

The despair he wrought in Duval and Mickelson, who had to stand there and witness as he holed putt after important putt, was sufficient to destroy them. There was a spell, beginning on the 7th, when he single-putted five consecutive greens, each vital psychologically, giving his competitors no hope whatsoever.

Mickelson had good reason to hope that the seven-footer at the 7th would be missed, given it was a nasty slider on the slippiest of greens, but it went in dead centre. At the 8th Woods again birdied after a second shot that finished 40 yards wide of the green. A chip to 10 feet did the trick.

Then it seemed Woods must surely bogey the 9th, his second shot spinning back off the green, trickling down a bank and leaving him with a 30-yard chip. He hit it to seven feet and again it went in. But, if such putts are sickeners, they were as nothing to the one he holed at the 10th.

Woods misjudged his second which ran to the back fringe, elected to putt down the frighteningly fast green and somehow succeeded in leaving it 10 feet short and 10 feet wide. It was an awful effort but of course he holed it and afterwards unhesitatingly picked it out as the most crucial of the round. "By far the biggest putt," he said. "Making that was big."

Just how big became clear on the next tee. Mickelson must have been close to desperation and, in going for a big drive through trees leading to the fairway, caught one of them and dropped down 100 yards from the tee. That is an automatic bogey and Tiger closed for the kill.

From 149 yards he almost holed his second shot, the ball running over the edge of the hole and stopping 18 inches away. As soon as the ball stopped his caddie, Steve Williams, proffered the putter and Woods snatched it eagerly; he could hardly wait to get there and ensure the inevitable two-shot advantage.

There were further challenges to come, of course, but it seemed Woods knew his destiny. At the 13th he hit a drive he had been practising since January but had not used to that point, a shot he called "a big slinger" that curled round the left-handed dog-leg as if on rails. Mickelson had hit his best drive there; Woods was 25 yards past him, another devastating psychological blow.

The final chances went to Duval, who at least had been spared from actually witnessing what Woods was doing. Over the closing two holes he hit some great shots but, when it came to the cold-blooded bit, the putting, he could not summon the courage. There was the 10-footer on the 17th, the easiest putt on that green, which was not hit hard enough and then, cruelly, a four-footer on the 18th.

That too was underhit and like its predecessor trickled away on the low, or amateur, side. Both were failures of will, hit by a man who had bowed his knee. "It is not easy for me to talk about this," said Duval afterwards.

The perfect scenario would have been for Duval to hole that putt and for Woods to do as he did: march majestically up the 18th fairway, hit two shots to 18 feet and then hole the birdie putt.

It would have made for more drama but with no added significance. That lies in the achievement, the like of which we may never see again.

webTitle: 'Filthiest' NHS hospitals cleaned by private contractors

fields.headline: 'Filthiest' NHS hospitals cleaned by private contractors
fields.trailText: Four of the five trusts which run the 10 hospitals "named and shamed" as the filthiest in the NHS employ private contractors to clean their wards, toilets and other public areas.
fields.body:
Four of the five trusts which run the 10 hospitals "named and shamed" as the filthiest in the NHS employ private contractors to clean their wards, toilets and other public areas.

The five trusts now face visits from cleanliness "hit squads", and will be given cash handouts from the NHS of up to £750,000 each in order to bring their facilities up to scratch.

Ministers have revealed that 40 NHS hospitals have failed hygiene and cleanliness inspections. They were formally labelled England's dirtiest after being classified "red" - meaning "poor" under the Department of Health's so-called "traffic light" system of classification.

The results were seized on by unions as further evidence that the contracting out of NHS cleaning and catering services to the private sector has in many cases failed to raise or maintain standards.

Paul Marks, Unison national secretary for health, said: "The destructive impact of contracting out is still evident that many of the services named are run by private contractors."

The government promised last year to abolish compulsory competitive tendering of NHS support services, although it has refused to stop trusts using private contractors where they think this will improve the quality.

Four of the trusts, all of which were put on special measures, use the following private contractors:
 Royal Liverpool and Broadgreen University Hospitals NHS trust (Broadgreen Hospital) subcontracts its cleaning services to Sodexho.
 Bristol Royal Infirmary, part of United Bristol Healthcare NHS trust, subcontracts to Rentokil-Initial.
West Hertfordshire Hospitals NHS trust (Mount Vernon Hospital, Watford Hospital), subcontracts to Medireft.
 Essex Rivers Healthcare NHS trust (Essex County Hospital), subcontracts to Carillion Plc.
 Maidstone and Tunbridge Wells NHS trust (Pembury Hospital) subcontracts to Medireft.

The fifth trust, The Dudley Group of Hospitals (Russells Hall Hospital, Wordsley Hospital, Corbett Hospital, Guest Hospital) uses NHS cleaning services.

Of the 41 "red" trusts, 10 were considered so dirty or shabby that they have been put on "special measures", which means that special support teams will be sent in to improve facilities by autumn 2001.

Ministers claim the figures show that the NHS has made a "marked improvement" in cleanliness and hygiene standards over the last nine months - the last inspection, in the autumn, classified 253 hospitals as "poor".

The figures show that 280 hospitals are classified as green or "excellent" (compared to 162 in autumn 2000), and 367 were deemed to have yellow or "acceptable" standards of hygiene (298).

The announcement follows hundreds of unannounced inspections carried out by patient environment action teams, made up of patient's representatives and NHS professionals.

Four of the 10 hospitals are run by a single trust, The Dudley Group of Hospitals NHS trust. It blamed its classification on the shabby state of three of its sites which are converted workhouses built in Victorian times.

A spokeswoman for the trust said it hoped to improve its performance from red to yellow by autumn 2001 but it would not be able to achieve excellence until 2004, when its buildings were replaced by a new, privately financed hospital.

Unison staff at Dudley - including cleaning staff - have been carrying out a series of strikes since August 2000 over plans to transfer their employment from the trust to the private sector as part of the private finance initiative hospital deal.

The trust said that its "red" autumn cleanliness classification which followed an inspection in early October was unrelated to the strikes.

The government announced its clean-up initiative in the NHS plan in July 2001, when trusts were allocated a total of £31m to smarten up the hospital environment.

fields.headline: Harvard-style PhDs to be introduced
fields.trailText: From September, students at ten universities will be able to complete vocational American-style PhD courses that will enhance their employability.
fields.body:
The prime minister today welcomed the introduction of new Harvard-style PhD courses, as the Department for Education and Employment announced 41 new PhD courses in ten of Britain's universities.

Mr Blair said that the "New Route" PhD was "designed to give students from both home and abroad a competitive edge in the knowledge economy of the Twenty First Century."

Professor Clive Booth, former Vice Chancellor of Oxford Brookes University and current Chair of the New Route PhD's steering group, said that he originally looked into the idea because so many of his overseas colleagues asked why Britain did not provide the same kind of vocational PhDs as those found in America.

He said, "The traditional PhD is an excellent training for specialised research based careers - particularly academic careers - but these New Route PhDs are being set up with the intention of broadening out our postgraduate training. They will not have such a narrow focus; students will attend seminars and they will be able to learn team and management skills. There will be particular emphasis on entrepreneurial skills."

He added: "Having looked at systems overseas, we've found that it works well. The intention is to enhance the employability of those who choose this kind of PhD. Students will be equipped to enter the high income end of business and management."

The Higher Education Funding Council for England (HEFCE) and the universities involved have jointly funded the project on a fifty-fifty basis, and intend to do so for the next three years.

The ten universities involved are: University of Birmingham, University of Brighton, Brunel University, Cranfield University, University of Lancaster, University of Loughborough, University of Newcastle, University of Nottingham, University of Sheffield and University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST).

All ten have programmes due to start in September 2001, which will consist of 40% taught modules and 60% research training, which will lead to a thesis. Models include titles such as "Business methods and enterprise skills", "Technology transfer and intellectual property rights" and "Forming high technology companies".

Professor Booth said the ten universities were selected "very informally". "Essentially, universities which had shown an interest and had been active in this area were invited on-board. But the idea is to roll this out to as many universities as possible. We are committed to welcoming other institutions."

The Education and Employment Minister Tessa Blackstone said, "The new PhDs have been developed in response to the changes in knowledge and skills demanded of PhD graduates in a rapidly expanding worldwide market. They will be an attractive alternative for both international and home students. They draw on the highest quality examples of PhDs offered at the best American universities.

"The New Route PhD will not replace existing PhD courses. They provide an alternative method of learning at PhD level. I would encourage students from home and abroad to consider these new courses at some of our leading universities. We hope that these new courses will serve as a model to other universities to introduce similar PhD programmes in the future."

Students are expected to complete the courses within three years.

fields.headline: Mike Cullen
fields.standfirst: The unsung hero of a golden age in the development of understanding of animal behaviour
fields.trailText: The unsung hero of a golden age in the development of understanding of animal behaviour.
fields.body:
Mike Cullen, who has died in a car crash in Australia aged 73, had an extraordinary influence on the development of ethology, the biological study of animal behaviour. He was of the generation of Oxford ethologists that included Robert Hinde, Aubrey Manning and Desmond Morris, and he was in many ways the unsung hero of that golden age in the subject. The impact of his razor-sharp, quantitative, analytical mind came not from his own research publications, which were modest in number, but from the difference he made to those who worked with him as doctoral students or colleagues.

Unusually, he was a scientist who put the development of others and of the subject as a whole ahead of his own career. All of us who worked with Mike can recall how he would take our half-baked ideas, inadequately analysed data, or the hesitant beginnings of a mathematical model, and transform them into a polished gem.

He would listen while eating his lunch from an old biscuit tin with a wire handle, one knee up, shoulders slightly hunched, rocking back and forth with absorption, hands fanned open and palms facing each other as if to grasp the issue under discussion. He would then rush off to a tutorial or lecture. But next day one would receive a handwritten letter with the solution to the problem, some lines of algebra, embellished by an apt - and untranslated - quotation from Catullus or a comic verse made up by Mike himself to suit the occasion.

Mike hardly ever accepted co-authorship of publications, but the acknowledgements sections of key papers published between the mid-1950s and 1980s show the breadth and depth of his influence, as do the career successes of his students. He was the kind of academic that would be pruned out in the contemporary, publish-or-perish, environment in universities. But if he had followed what is now the common practice of putting his name on all the papers of students and co-workers whom he had helped, he would have stood out as one of the most prolific ethologists of his time.

Mike was born in Bournemouth, but spent his first six years in India, where his father worked for the Bombay Company. Subsequently, together with his younger sister, he was brought up in England by a great aunt and educated at Marlborough College before going to Wadham College, Oxford, to read mathematics. He switched to zoology after the first year and graduated in 1952. His interest in natural history, and birds in particular, had been triggered in Kashmir in 1942.

A few years before Mike graduated, the Dutch ethologist Niko Tinbergen had moved to Oxford to set up the Animal Behaviour Group. Tinbergen is generally regarded, alongside Konrad Lorenz - with whom he shared a Nobel Prize in 1973 - as one of the founding fathers of ethology. Mike, with his interest in field biology, was naturally drawn to Tinbergen's group, and he completed his doctorate under Tinbergen on the behaviour of Arctic terns.

Tinbergen sent Mike and a Swiss student, Esther Sager, who worked on kittiwakes, together to the Farne Islands, off the coast of Northumberland. Perhaps unsurprisingly to their peers, Mike and Esther not only both came away with D Phil theses, but, in 1954, married and were to have two children. They stayed in Oxford, where Mike was Tinbergen's right-hand man from 1956 to 1969 in the Animal Behaviour Research Group, which was funded by Nature Conservancy.

Ethology at that time had been developing, under Tinbergen's influence, from largely observational studies of the behaviour of animals in their natural environment or in semi-natural captivity, into an experimental and quantitative discipline. Cullen's role in shaping this research agenda at Oxford was crucial: partly because of his mathematical facility - which Tinbergen almost totally lacked; but also because of his extraordinarily quick intelligence and his generosity in deploying it for the benefit of others

Almost all the students who came through the Tinbergen group from the mid-1950s to the early 70s found their intellectual inspiration in Mike. To collaborate with him was exhilarating. Everything happened at high speed, using rapidly improvised equipment which cost nothing. Typical of his ingenuity was his method of plotting the three-dimensional coordinates of fish swimming in schools: simply photograph them in a bright shadow-casting light, and do the necessary trigonometry using the distance between each fish and its shadow.

When Tinbergen retired in 1974 from the chair in animal behaviour, Cullen, who in 1968 had become lecturer in psychology - and a fellow of Wadham - was seen by many as his natural successor. However, although his huge influence was acknowledged, his modest output of published research weighed against him.

In 1977, Mike accepted an offer from Monash University in Melbourne, where he remained until he retired in 1993. While there, he dedicated much effort to preserving the penguins of Phillip Island, on which he also did much research: he considered his victory in this battle to be one of his greatest achievements.

Sadly, Mike and Esther separated after their move to Australia, but Mike later found happiness with Rita Krishovski. Mike was a warm-hearted, humorous and extraordinarily generous colleague, with an insatiable appetite and youthful enthusiasm for research. He was also a brilliant lecturer, and a model of what an Oxford tutor should be. Though a very private person, he would provide a sympathetic shoulder and a strong arm when a student or colleague came to him with private difficulties.

Stories of his mild eccentricities abound: his party act of fire-eating; his habit of knitting in seminars to avoid wasting time with his hands; and taking binoculars to conferences, to scrutinise details of tables and graphs shown by speakers.

Partly as a result of his casual dress and athletic appearance, he always looked much younger than he was. In seminars he was a formidable sceptic and questioner: if you could get your research past those quizzical eyebrows, you had nothing to fear from any audience in the world. We have lost a much- loved mentor who taught us how teaching should be.

 Michael Cullen, ethologist, born December 14 1927; died March 23 2001

webTitle: Issues facing university managers at their national conference

fields.headline: Goodbye to the 'old school'
fields.standfirst: Unequal internet access for students, lack of public funding and growing 'consumer' demands are just three of the headaches facing university managers at their national conference this week.  Peter Reader  reports
fields.trailText: Unequal internet access for students, lack of public funding and growing 'consumer' demands are just three of the headaches facing university managers at their national conference this week. Peter Reader reports
fields.body:
Research and teaching draws a lot of attention, with the Research Assessment Exercise and the debate over teaching quality assessments. Some lecturers feel they get too much. But it's quite the opposite for managers and administrators, who sometimes appear almost invisible and feel their contribution to the higher education sector can be neglected.

This week they are meeting at Exeter University (April 9-11) to consider how they can promote excellence in management through the sector. Managers and administrators are grappling with a fresh series of challenges from a newly dynamic sector, according to Sir Geoffrey Holland, host of this year's annual conference of the Association of University Administrators (AUA). As a former civil service mandarin, he is well placed to comment on matters of administration as well as academe.

Managers have to deal with a global "village" separated by those with and those without internet access and expertise, a funding system that places ever greater reliance on income from outside the public purse, and increasingly sophisticated and informed student customers.

"That these pressures are diverse and sometimes conflicting is particularly apparent as we juggle our workloads," said Sir Geoffrey. "If we're to meet these challenges and seize the opportunities they present, the excellence and professionalism so often demonstrated will become more vital."

Professor Christine King, vice- chancellor of Staffordshire University and the AUA conference's plenary speaker, is well aware of the suspicion and hostility with which some academics view recent changes in management. "We are used to a 'golden age' of pre-managerial collegiality when scholars pondered and the rest of us knew our place!" she said.

"The debate now seems a trifle sad. Advocates of 'the old way', while sincere in the belief that core values of higher education were at risk as we expanded and necessarily smartened up our acts, were, in fact, in a worse state than King Canute. They were not only trying to hold back the tide, but were missing the great beauty of a changing seascape. Just a few were mightily frightened that they might get their feet wet.

"Excellent management is no longer an option, it is a necessity. It can also be a liberating and empowering experience, involving all of us, working together in new ways." m

Professor Elaine Thomas, director of the Surrey Institute of Art and Design, said: "It is particularly important that academics and administrators achieve a sense of common purpose and mutual respect.

"There remain many challenges in achieving this aim. There is much talk of collaboration and partnership between higher education institutions and other organisations, while cooperation and sharing of goals within our institutions remain limited.

"The divide between the academic and the administrator can manifest itself at all levels, demonstrated by lack of trust, perception of difference in attitude and values, differences in status and power, in opportunities for career development, and a tendency on all parts to stereotype colleagues."

Alison Johns, chair of AUA and also staff development manager at Plymouth University, adds that those working in higher education share responsibility for furthering lifelong learning. And they include students, academics, managers and administrators, whatever their specialism and interest. In recent years, the AUA has carried out various initiatives to raise the profile of higher education management and training, including publication of its code of professional standards and development of a continuing professional development programme.

Problems of a growing body

One of the biggest challenges facing administrators is the widening participation agenda. As a cornerstone of the government's higher education policy, it questions many traditional approaches to management.

While some institutions have long accepted that students can no longer be considered a homogeneous commodity, it is a new challenge for others.

For many years, students who did not follow the traditional pattern of full-time, post-18 higher education were unusual; today at many institutions, they are anything but.

As students are increasingly seen as "customers", a change exacerbated by the regime of students as fee-payers, traditional patterns of administration and management will not do. Basically, offices can no longer work "office hours" if they are to provide a true service. The issue, however, goes much deeper and is reflected in the breadth of training sessions at this year's AUA conference.

Sandra Hayes, chaplaincy and pastoral care coordinator at Sheffield Hallam University, says administrators need to know more about the diverse nature of university student communities and their needs. She intends to delve into the "roots, shoots and fruits" of meeting such needs and to share ideas and examples of good practice in student support.

Hawinder Lawley, head of access development at North London University, is to give an overview of national priorities for the widening participation agenda and highlight good practice, including higher and further education partnerships. She intends to review targeted initiatives from the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the impacts and implications of joined up thinking, the potential of collaborative activities, examples of tried and tested approaches and innovative practice, and ask what "the punters" think.

Strategies for improving the retention of undergraduate first-year students, and understanding the reasons for students leaving courses prematurely are to be tackled by David Berry, assistant director of business services at Southampton University. He sees the need for a multi-strand strategy to reduce the adverse affects on students who drop out of their courses and the institutions they leave.

Meanwhile, Dr Gerry Webber, university secretary at Napier University, will explore institutional diversity and ask what it really means. Does it matter, who does it benefit, how can diversity be promoted and sustained, and what are the implications for providers, customers and funding bodies?

Hawinder Lawley, head of access development at North London University, is to give an overview of national priorities for the widening participation agenda and highlight good practice, including higher and further education partnerships. She intends to review targeted initiatives from the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the impacts and implications of joined up thinking, the potential of collaborative activities, examples of tried and tested approaches and innovative practice, and ask what "the punters" think. Strategies for improving the retention of undergraduate first-year students, and understanding the reasons for students leaving courses prematurely are to be tackled by David Berry, assistant director of business services at Southampton University. He sees the need for a multi-strand strategy to reduce the adverse affects on students who drop out of their courses and the institutions they leave. Meanwhile, Dr Gerry Webber, university secretary at Napier University, will explore institutional diversity and ask what it really means. Does it matter, who does it benefit, how can diversity be promoted and sustained, and what are the implications for providers, customers and funding bodies?

webTitle: Scientists find way to turn fat into bone

fields.headline: Scientists find way to turn fat into bone
fields.standfirst: Tissue is ideal source of stem cells for transplants
fields.trailText: American scientists report today that they have found a way to turn human fat into bone, muscle and cartilage for transplant surgery.
fields.body:
American scientists report today that they have found a way to turn human fat into bone, muscle and cartilage for transplant surgery.

The scientists took stem cells - the keys to the body's ability to renew itself - from fat supplied by liposuction, and turned them into three other types of cell, they report in the journal Tissue Engineering.

Stem cells from bone marrow have already been used to treat leukaemia. Ten days ago, two separate teams in New York reported that they used bone marrow stem cells to repair heart damage in rats and mice. In February, Florida University reported that stem cells from umbilical cord blood could restore brains damaged by stroke - once again in rats. A British biotech company is preparing to treat stroke-damaged victims with injections of human foetal stem cells.

But adult bone marrow and nerve stem cells are difficult to collect. Fat is more available. Obesity in the US is reaching epidemic proportions. In 1998, American women spent $607m on liposuction operations.

"Fat is perhaps the ideal source. There's plenty of it. It's easy and inexpensive to obtain. It even has a secondary cosmetic benefit," said Marc Hedrick of the University of Los Angeles school of medicine. "Our findings show that fat is not the tissue we once thought. Just as the industrial revolution transformed oil from trash to treasure, our research shows that unwanted human fat is actually a vigorous tissue with a tremendous potential for good."

Stem cells are the agents that turn a tiny embryo into a collection of 100 trillion cells of 300 different kinds in just nine months. In January, after nearly two years of debate, parliament permitted embryo stem cells not needed for fertility treatments to be used for research into diseases. But campaigners said that embryo research might not be necessary. They argued that stem cells harvested from adults might be used to reverse neurodegenative diseases and eventually treat heart conditions and other illnesses. The catch is to learn how to "reprogramme" an adult stem cell to become something else.

"Stem cells are like little kids who, when they grow up, can enter a variety of professions," Dr Hedrick said. "A child might become a fireman, a doctor or a plumber, depending on the influences in their life - or environment. In the same way, these stem cells can become many tissues by making certain changes in their environment."

Dr Hedrick worked with Adam Katz of the University of Pittsburgh school of medicine to persuade the fat cells to become cartilage, bone and muscle. "We are just figuring out the best way to apply this technology," Dr Kendrick said.

So far the experiments have been limited to the laboratory dish but the technique could be used in the future to repair liver or lung damage, glands, nerves, or brain tissue.

webTitle: Students hit by privatisation of university residences

fields.headline: Student rents soaring
fields.standfirst: Student pockets are being hit the hardest by large-scale privatisation of university residences, according to research out today.  Donald MacLeod  on a worrying trend
fields.trailText: Student pockets are being hit the hardest by large-scale privatisation of university residences, according to research out today. Donald MacLeod on a worrying trend
fields.body:
Student rents are soaring at much more than the rate of inflation, according to a National Union of Students survey published today. Since the last academic year, rent rises for self-catering accommodation are particularly steep, up to 8% compared to a national inflation rate of 2.7%. Not surprisingly, London shows the highest rents in the current academic year - a probable factor in the fall in applications to several universities in the capital.

Preliminary results of the annual NUS survey showed the average weekly rent for students in university or university-linked accommodation has risen from £54.72 to £57.32, an increase of 4.75%. But for self-catering accommodation, rises ranged from 8.2% for single rooms (an average rent of £50.40), 7.6% (£41.82) for shared rooms and 6.5% (£62.84) for en suite provision.

This reflects the declining popularity of communal dining halls among students as well as young people's efforts to economise by doing their own cooking.

Students were being priced out of education, said Rachel Cashman, the union's vice-president for welfare. "Housing for students continues to take up a huge proportion of their income. Accommodation costs are rising in some areas at almost three times the rate of inflation."

The situation was set to get even worse as universities privatised their halls of residence to raise funding, she argued. "It's like top-up fees through the back door. Universities are trying to privatise large chunks of their student accommodation. The priority for a lot of these private companies is building accommodation for conferences in the vacations rather than building a home for students during term-time.

"We have got to stop the conference culture where it is OK to sell off student residences to make big bucks from conferences."

But companies involved in building or managing student residences for universities and colleges argue their investment releases funds that institutions can invest in libraries and laboratories.

Clive Crawford, managing director for Jarvis University Partnerships Programme, said its investment at Plymouth University where they run 645 rooms had helped the university mount its bid for a joint medical school with Exeter.

"We have so far invested £100m in the sector - money which universities would otherwise have had to provide for themselves."

Crawford denied that students would pay higher rents in private-run halls. Rents had to relate to what the universities themselves charged. "They create the benchmark for private providers. I don't think from the student point of view what we do has any impact."

Jarvis, which manages 3,600 student rooms and has a further 2,600 under development, is building a student village in Manchester with more than 1,000 rooms for the city's three universities and the Northern College of Music. The firm also has developments at Reading, Glasgow, Oxford Brookes, York and Ulster, as well as managing 1,600 rooms for Luton University.

Many universities are struggling to modernise their halls of residence on dwindling funds, believes Crawford. All face what he calls the "en suite bomb" in trying to let rooms and attract students. "There will come a time when students no longer accept non-en suite accommodation. This accommodation fills up first - students don't want to share facilities with strangers."

 A legal judgment last week will strengthen the trend towards universities using property companies to manage their student accommodation. Greenwich won a six-year case against Customs and Excise over whether its student village should be zero-rated for VAT. Customs claimed the concession applied only if the university itself dealt directly with vacation lettings. A judicial review ruled that Customs should have made this clear, opening the way to possible claims for substantial refunds by other universities.

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.standfirst: higher news
fields.trailText: The third degree
fields.body:
The third degree

 We can all imagine the academic's perfect fantasy desert island: sun, sea, sand, no students, and no teaching quality inspections. No surprise, then, that Cambridge University's vice-chancellor, Sir Alec Broers, told Sue Lawley that it was paperwork and committee meetings that drive him mad when he appeared on Radio 4's Desert Island Discs last week.

And no wonder Cambridge is now discussing plans to opt out of the Quality Assurance Agency's inspection regime altogether.

 Spotted in the Quality Assurance Agency's acrimonious correspondence with the funding council, a reference to the latter's chief executive Mr Brian Fender. Surely this wasn't cheeking Sir Brian?

 "Sorry, not my academic area," is just not an excuse you can use as the government's chief scientific adviser, as Prof David King is quickly finding out.

The Cambridge chemist recently advised the prime minister that the worst of the foot and mouth crisis was probably over. According to one uncharitable former colleague, he would have had to look up the definition of epidemiology in the dictionary not long ago. Just wait till those urgent requests for comprehensive briefings on genetically modified humans, near earth asteroids and young Leo's teething pains come King's way.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com or lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News

Cubist

A consensus for Cubie-style student payments for degree courses after graduation has emerged among UK university heads - at least in private. But vice-chancellors are stressing that a move to follow Scotland's example and abolish upfront fees will not address all the academic sector's financial needs, estimated to be an extra £900m a year at least.

During a conference at the Hotel Russell in London last week, the president of Universities UK Sir Howard Newby reiterated the decision of vice-chancellors not to openly back one funding plan for universities. Newby argued that the decision should be left to politicians. The heads harbour bad memories of 1997, when the government scrapped maintenance grants, rejecting Ron Dearing's proposals for higher education on the day his report was published.

Education minister Tessa Blackstone could not resist some pre-election strikes against the policies of the Tories and Lib Dems. Having dealt with the Tories, she turned on the Lib Dems. "No serious political party," she said, "would advocate abolishing fees for undergraduates." Don't remember Labour mentioning fees in the 1997 campaign.

Research news

Unwellcome news

The tempestuous relationship between the world's largest biomedical charity and the UK government appears to be on the rocks again, after a blast from the Wellcome Trust's director Dr Mike Dexter. Last week Dexter told the Save British Science Society that charities should "not pick up the bill for things that are the state's responsibility". He said: "The medical research charities were not established to invest in equipment or bricks and mortar, but that is exactly what the lack of state funding has led us to do in recent years."

Universe

China crisis

The case of the United States plane that was forced to make an emergency landing in China was not the only Sino-American imbroglio to have taken place this week.

Chinese security services have arrested three international scholars over the past month on charges of spying, and in the process sent a shiver down the spines of many researchers in Hong Kong, writes David Cohen.

But why are they doing it? Theories abound. See theguardian.com/ education/higher.

fields.headline: Where have all the radicals gone?
fields.standfirst: After a decade of market imitation, is it possible to be a radical intellectual?
fields.trailText: After a decade of market imitation, is it possible to be a radical intellectual?
fields.body:
Have you had yours yet? One astonished academic after another has sent me copies of letters asking them to consider a little school teaching on the side. It is unclear if the private company soliciting us imagines, correctly, that the wages of many academics are so meagre that extra work is needed to feed mortgages and families or that they assume, incorrectly, that we have time on our hands.

These are strange times, as Stan Cohen noted recently, for those who ever took seriously the "role of the intellectual". Yet this was a gripping topic in the immediate wake of sixties radicalism. A cohort of students and academics pondered the place of intellectuals in contesting discrimination and inequality. In his own latest book, States of Denial, Cohen remains resolutely rooted in the legacy of this past, paradigmatic in the diffusion of radical sociology in the 1970s.

This was a decade when "new criminologists" like him were at the forefront of a politicised academy, rethinking Marxism and joining struggles for social change. These were driven by the growth of new social movements: grass-roots trade union radicalism accompanied the rise of feminist, gay, anti-war and anti-racist politics.

Long gone from the cutting edge of university life, the radical sociologist was replaced by the poststructuralist literary scholar. Stuart Hall remains one of the few trail-blazers from that time still able to inspire a broader public.

Past intellectual vanguards such as the Conference of Socialist Economists persist to this day, but have lost their influence. The radical thinking of recent years is different. Its concern is with language, sexuality, the stories we can tell about ourselves.

For its critics, these new directions renounce the importance of preserving some kind of common discourse and response to corporate structures of global dominance and inequality. For its advocates, they suggest new ways of thinking about ourselves, and therefore new ways of challenging conventional frameworks that repress and constrain us. Yet whatever our theoretical framework, it is not primarily the exposition or rejection of universal aims which determines the role intellectuals play in revitalising cultural life.

Over the past decade it is true that fewer alliances have been forged between students or academics and the remains of the new social movements. Nor have the universities been seedbeds of anti-globalisation protests.

But then scholarly work, institutionally, has always tended towards conceptual conformity. It is specific conjunctions, rather than the precision of our theories, which promote greater interchange between academic life and the wider world. It was HIV/Aids and increased homophobia that added passion to gay and lesbian politics, promoting the advent of Queer theorising in the 1990s. It is the existence of significant cultural networks, and our desire to sustain them, which is crucial to the impact of intellectual work.

After a decade and more of student hardship and bureaucratic prescriptions in higher education, neither staff nor students share much of that radical spirit which once nourished collective desires. Yet our governing elite now wants us to devote more time to "community building" (around family life, neighbourhood and church) to counter the decline of collectivity, which its own incessant imposition of managerialism and market imitation have furthered.

Now that so many of us spend ever-longer hours in the workplace, it's a good time to rethink the role of intellectuals. We could begin by fostering more collectivity through encouraging as much controversy as we possibly can - from resisting the auditing of every move we make to the questioning of overly instrumental notions of learning at the expense of critical thought. Then indeed we might have something to offer in the schoolrooms.

Lynne Segal is Anniversary Professor of Psychology and Gender Studies at Birkbeck College, London University.

fields.headline: Going private
fields.standfirst: Despite economic crisis, Argentina's students are increasingly attending private campuses and turning their backs on the country's once renowned, now ramshackle public universities. By  David Cohen
fields.trailText: Despite economic crisis, Argentina's students are increasingly attending private campuses and turning their backs on the country's once renowned, now ramshackle public universities. By David Cohen
fields.body:
The old imperial spectre of Britain no longer excites much student angst in Argentina, nor does the cultural bogeyman of the US - much. What does worry them, says Catherine Wannier, a young Buenos Aires postgrad, is their own ailing public education system. Once one of Argentina's success stories, it now faces hard times in one of the country's worst economic crises.

Wannier had always wanted to attend a public university. And it was not only because of the prestige of national institutions like the 180,000-strong Buenos Aires University. It was more an article of faith that even the lowliest of government-supported Argentine colleges were the envy of all Latin America. But she eventually enrolled at the private Belgrano University, in one of the city's wealthier neighbourhoods, surrounded by shady streets and fragrant gardens, where she majors in international relations.

Local educators established the non-profit university in 1964, making it one of the country's oldest private colleges. Belgrano has 14,000 students, and its major programmes in the social sciences and humanities are recognised by the ministry of education and sought after by growing numbers of career-minded students.

"Times have changed," Wannier says, to a chorus of murmured agreements from her cohorts seated together with a visitor in one of the university's plush meeting rooms.

During the past decade, Argentine higher education has seen a huge surge of activity in the private sector. The number of private, not-for-profit universities has doubled since 1990. Of 99 universities serving a population of 36.9m, 48 are privately run. Moreover, private institutions are now attracting more new students than their public rivals - more than one in seven of all undergraduates - even though they have traditionally been comparatively small. The figure is rising to one in four students at graduate level. Analysts say this trend is even more remarkable, because public universities run open admission policies and do not charge tuition. And a private education hardly comes cheap: students have to pay up to $15,000.

Traditionally, public university degrees have carried far greater social prestige. But at the same time, classes at the public universities are increasingly chaotic, lecturers are underpaid, and students often find themselves squeezed out of the courses they want. The typical scene in lecture halls can be compared with rush hour at Paddington.

While the centre-left government has said it wants to improve conditions, it has first to work out if Argentina can ever regain the prosperity on which its university system was based. A leading economy in the 1930s - when its climate and soil made it a major agricultural exporter - Argentina is now seen internationally as just another of Latin America's emerging economies.

A bustling cafe culture, opulent shops, and a kaleidoscope of tango shows make Buenos Aires one of the continent's nightlife capitals, but for much of the past 25 years economic recession, stagflation, and political turmoil have been the rule.

Since the worsening of the country's economic troubles in 1991, policy-makers have tried, without much success, to refashion the public universities into institutions with strong financial support and high morale among faculty members, says Dr Avelino J Porto, president of Belgrano University. He believes their disorganised state is turning off more and more prospective students.

By comparison, he says the private universities have shown "the organisation and quality" needed for their students to do better. One advantage often cited is the choice of courses offered by private institutions and the individual attention that professors lavish on students - unlike the first-come, first-served set-up in the public universities.

However, that view is not shared by everyone. Ana Garcia de Fanelli, a senior researcher at the government's department of higher education who graduated from Buenos Aires University, says public institutions still provide the best - and, in most cases, the only - instruction in the natural sciences and technology.

She says the problem is that "public funding for higher education has not kept pace with demand" in Argentina and elsewhere on the continent.

"Students here basically go private because they like the wealthier style."

Belgrano students echo their president's view, though with some regret: "Young people still prefer public universities over private - even many of us here at this university probably believe that, in our heart of hearts," says Jessica Schmukler, who is majoring in international relations.

"This was once the golden country," says the Swiss-born Ms Wannier, whose family moved to Buenos Aires when she was a young girl. "It was a European country, a place where people used to come to make their dreams come true," she says. "We weren't a Latin American country at all - or, at least, we didn't consider ourselves to be one - but, rather, a satellite of Europe, not least when it came to our welfare state, especially in the area of higher education.

"This is still the expectation of the people, but any data you look at now shows ours is an impossible dream. The vision's been betrayed."
