What does worry them, says Catherine Wannier, a young Buenos Aires postgrad, is their own ailing public education system. Once one of Argentina's success stories, it now faces hard times in one of the country's worst economic crises. Wannier had always wanted to attend a public university. And it was not only because of the prestige of national institutions like the 180,000-strong Buenos Aires University. It was more an article of faith that even the lowliest of government-supported Argentine colleges were the envy of all Latin America. But she eventually enrolled at the private Belgrano University, in one of the city's wealthier neighbourhoods, surrounded by shady streets and fragrant gardens, where she majors in international relations. Local educators established the non-profit university in 1964, making it one of the country's oldest private colleges. Belgrano has 14,000 students, and its major programmes in the social sciences and humanities are recognised by the ministry of education and sought after by growing numbers of career-minded students. "Times have changed," Wannier says, to a chorus of murmured agreements from her cohorts seated together with a visitor in one of the university's plush meeting rooms. During the past decade, Argentine higher education has seen a huge surge of activity in the private sector. The number of private, not-for-profit universities has doubled since 1990. Of 99 universities serving a population of 36.9m, 48 are privately run. Moreover, private institutions are now attracting more new students than their public rivals - more than one in seven of all undergraduates - even though they have traditionally been comparatively small. The figure is rising to one in four students at graduate level. Analysts say this trend is even more remarkable, because public universities run open admission policies and do not charge tuition. And a private education hardly comes cheap: students have to pay up to $15,000. Traditionally, public university degrees have carried far greater social prestige. But at the same time, classes at the public universities are increasingly chaotic, lecturers are underpaid, and students often find themselves squeezed out of the courses they want. The typical scene in lecture halls can be compared with rush hour at Paddington. While the centre-left government has said it wants to improve conditions, it has first to work out if Argentina can ever regain the prosperity on which its university system was based. A leading economy in the 1930s - when its climate and soil made it a major agricultural exporter - Argentina is now seen internationally as just another of Latin America's emerging economies. A bustling cafe culture, opulent shops, and a kaleidoscope of tango shows make Buenos Aires one of the continent's nightlife capitals, but for much of the past 25 years economic recession, stagflation, and political turmoil have been the rule. Since the worsening of the country's economic troubles in 1991, policy-makers have tried, without much success, to refashion the public universities into institutions with strong financial support and high morale among faculty members, says Dr Avelino J Porto, president of Belgrano University. He believes their disorganised state is turning off more and more prospective students. By comparison, he says the private universities have shown "the organisation and quality" needed for their students to do better. One advantage often cited is the choice of courses offered by private institutions and the individual attention that professors lavish on students - unlike the first-come, first-served set-up in the public universities. Ana Garcia de Fanelli, a senior researcher at the government's department of higher education who graduated from Buenos Aires University, says public institutions still provide the best - and, in most cases, the only - instruction in the natural sciences and technology. She says the problem is that "public funding for higher education has not kept pace with demand" in Argentina and elsewhere on the continent. webTitle: Experimentation thrives at the National Student Drama Festival

fields.headline: Stage flight
fields.standfirst: As other drama festivals become more and more commercial, Scarborough's yearly student jamboree has taken wing as a hotbed of experimentation.  Elaine Williams reports
fields.trailText: As other drama festivals become more and more commercial, Scarborough's yearly student jamboree has taken wing as a hotbed of experimentation. Elaine Williams reports
fields.body:
Visitors to Scarborough with an eye for the incongruous are never disappointed. The past week has been no exception, as the dogwalking refugees from foot and mouth have mingled along the prom with zealous thespians, both battling against the whiplash rain and grey of the North Sea. It's that time of year when the National Student Drama Festival descends on the overblown Victorian splendour of the old spa with its vistas of the sweeping bay. But the cold and wet has done nothing to cool the passion of the occasion. At a time when student drama is thriving, the festival seems to be serving a new role in which experimentation is to the fore. At Scarborough a climate of creative risk-taking survives as it does not at arts festivals such as the Edinburgh Fringe, where the commercial imperative is increasingly powerful.

The number of people attending this year is at an all-time high - it has doubled in the past two or three years, while the number of plays entered for the festival has increased to 117. As well as performing arts students, it draws in both school productions and university shows by law students or scientists who dabble in acting.

Scarborough works on a very different basis from Edinburgh. Devotees pay for the whole week and follow the tradition of seeing every show. Among the 15 shows selected this year there are no classics, no big, familiar titles.

Students can attend many of the 150 workshops and masterclasses offered. They can also listen to Michael Attenborough, principal associate director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, expounding the moral imperative of rich, expressive language, or listen to composers Alain Boublil and Michel Schonberg of Les Miserables and Miss Saigon fame taking them through the angst of making big music.

But they themselves are fired to devise their own pieces, paring everything down to the conceptual bone. As student theatre thrives there is a new interest in work with visual and physical impact rather than scripted pieces with conventional narrative. Today's students are interested in Shakespeare - Attenborough's workshops have been vastly oversubscribed - but their concern is to play with the text and the characters rather than pursue faithful interpretation.

Greats who found their voice at the festival include Caryl Churchill, Tim Piggot-Smith, Dennis Potter, Alan Yentob, Stephen Fry and John Godber. Timothy West, who was there at the very beginning in 1956, says: "Since that time how many people have used this unique national event to perform, learn, listen, drink, criticise and argue? It would be an awesome total, and include many of our leading performers, writers, producers, directors, designers and technicians. Scarborough in April is the place to be."

Kieran Balfe, head of drama at Hitchin Girls School, has attended the festival for the last 20 years, first as a Hull University drama student, later on bringing school parties. He remembers Godber, then a school teacher, putting on a production with his students from Minsthorpe High School in Pontefract before going on to found Hull Truck. "I bring students to see a range of theatre they wouldn't have the chance to see anywhere else like physical theatre," he says. "It's also great for them to see how it's assessed and debated."

Every lunchtime a discussion is timetabled during which each play is opened to the floor for criticism. Although this is intended to be constructive, the session is notorious for its crushed egos and occasional bouts of vitriol.

The festival also prides itself on its irreverence. In 1969 Prince Charles became the most distinguished actor to enter a production for the festival but was not selected. In 1970 rebelliousness prevailed, and students decided they wanted more say in the way the festival was run. A meeting was held, chaired by Jack Straw, the current home secretary, and a National Union of Students party was set up to advise on festival policy. Anti-establishment feelings were running so high that year that when Sir Laurence Olivier paid a visit to see Joan Plowright, his wife, who was taking workshops, and attended a production, students occupied his seat during the interval and the company started the second half early. Olivier sat on the auditorium steps to watch the rest of the performance. The next year it was decreed that all plays must be original and no prizes were to be awarded for productions.

These days the festival is less politically charged - the prizes have come back and the student-elected working party was disbanded long ago. But there is a desire among students to create a new order of performance.

Dominic Leclerc, 21, an English and drama undergraduate at Warwick University, is thought to be a bright new talent. He won a director's award last year for the play Insomnia, a physical and multi-media work looking at sleep and wakefulness. This year he has returned with two shows: Dystopia, a physical dance creation employing masks and poetry and Witness Me, a slow piece of body art. "There is a surge of interest in devised experimental, physical stuff," he says. "Devised is a dirty word in the wider world, but this festival is encouraging students to take risks, pushing boundaries, mixing genres. Risk-taking at the Edinburgh Fringe has become more dangerous, because you can so easily sink, but you can do it here. There is mood of real excitement because students feel there is genuine support for new ideas. It has guts, it's a very brave festival."

Some of the excitement has been engendered by the appointment of a new artistic director. At 48 Nick Stimson has taken over from Clive Wolfe, who has retired after running the festival for the last 30 years. Stimson is no stranger to young people's theatre - he taught drama in schools and university, worked with young offenders with the youth theatre at the Young Vic.

He is particularly keen to promote the raw young energy that characterises the festival, which he refers to as one of the nation's "best-kept secrets". One of his ambitions is to find the funding to move some of the NSDF productions on to other venues and festivals elsewhere in the country as a way of promoting its mission."It's not and should not be a choreographed event," he says. "It's about giving new voices a chance to find their way. It's as educational as it is artistic. I am interested in allowing young people the opportunity and providing the environment in which they can develop their ideas."

This is not about virtuoso performances, or even about honing performance skills. It is notable that the drama schools are largely absent from the list of show entries or even from groups of students who attend. According to Stimson it has to be about exploring expression.

"We are seeing fewer and fewer classics," he points out. "We did see one Shakespeare this year, and it nearly got in, but on the whole it's not there. You won't be seeing the Chekhovs. Students want to invent their own productions and that can be dangerous, but I want dangerous things to happen. That's the way to learn. It's the only opportunity in the country for students to say exactly what they want to say in performance. This event can be literally life-changing. It's such an intense experience. That's the beauty of it."

Vince Nappo, 22, is a member of the Highlighters Travelling Theatre Troop from Stamford University in the States, which has sought out the festival for its play The Grandmother Project, about a girl's relationship with her grandmother. Last year, while at the Welsh College of Music and Drama, he was in a production at Scarborough called Silence.

In the US, he says, there are no such opportunities for experimental student drama in the US: "We don't have access to this many quality practitioners in workshops, nothing with the same forum for feedback, for real criticism from such a wide variety of people. You get the sense that theatre here is a living thing, not a relic in which you always have to do Shakespeare."

Michael Attenborough first came to the festival as a Sussex University student in 1970 and is still excited about the possibilities it offers to each new generation."This generation of young people are wanting to express theatre in a way unique to them," he says. "They are hungry for self-expression. As you get older I think you are happy to express yourself through other people's voices.

"I did wonder if I would get any interest in a Shakespeare workshop. Well they are interested, very much so, and they are listening very hard. But they also want to connect with it in their own way.

"As a student you have that last moment before you enter a competitive world and I think students are turning more and more to performing arts. In a world where computers and email are becoming the predominant communication, I think young people are also looking for a much more direct, physical form of expression."

The drama festival, sponsored by the Sunday Times, continues until tomorrow.

webTitle: University aims to bring forensic science to schools

fields.headline: Dead cert
fields.standfirst: A murdered man is found face down in the mud. One hundred 15-year-olds are asked to solve the case.  Simon Midgley reports on one university's attempt to tackle a shortfall in science undergraduates
fields.trailText: A murdered man is found face down in the mud. One hundred 15-year-olds are asked to solve the case. Simon Midgley reports on one university's attempt to tackle a shortfall in science undergraduates
fields.body:
A group of young people cluster around a shallow, muddy grave in a remote woodland. They are gathering samples of soil for forensic analysis. A hundred yards away another group are investigating a second site, where someone has discovered the blood-stained handle of a car jack. This tableau was played out last week in a rainy Egham, Surrey, when 101 year-10 pupils from around the county took part in a murder investigation organised by Royal Holloway College. They used the techniques of forensic science to work out who murdered a man found face down in the shallow earth scraping.

Chris Elton, aged 15, from Heath End School, Farnham, who is hoping to do science A-levels, said that he had learnt that you cannot just take everything to be true. "You have to be a bit sceptical of what you find. Students can see a use for science in an exercise like this, otherwise they find it boring at school."

With the help of around 30 scientists and postgraduate students from Royal Holloway, the teenagers used DNA analysis, sedimentology, electron microscopy, forensic biology and analytical chemistry to establish the identity of the murderer, the cause of death, where the murder took place and the date and time at which it happened.

The death uppermost on the minds of the Royal Holloway academics is the slow demise of science A-levels and the knock-on effect on university applications. They know they cannot just sit back and hope - they have to sell their subject to school pupils. The murder hunt is just one example of ways in which universities throughout the United Kingdom are working in partnership with local schools during the spring holidays. Some are subject-based, others aim to reach children from disadvantaged backgrounds who may not think higher education is for them at all.

As the postmortem at Royal Holloway continued, Stephen Ward, 15, from the Priory School, Dorking, said that it was interesting to see how people do the different tests: "It shows that science covers a whole range of issues and not just the same stuff you learn in lessons."

Students analysed mud from boots and car tyres, examined fragments of glass and clothing, visited potential crime scenes and constructed DNA profiles of suspects. They also pieced together circumstantial evidence to test their theories about time and manner of death. A member of the geography department, Scott Elias, provided expert analysis of insect infestations on the victim's body to help the participants ascertain date and time of death.

Halliford Mere Trout Fishery in Shepperton provided one of two possible "scenes of crime". The other was a patch of woodland in the college grounds. A member of the geology department, Kevin D'Souza, played the body. The project gave pupils an opportunity to develop their skills in data interpretation, presentation and debating scientific results.

Ruth Temple, outreach officer for the college's faculty of science and one of the project's coordinators, said: "The aim was to make science exciting and to develop other transferrable skills as well. We looked at the science but we also looked at teamwork skills, networking, interpreting and presenting results. All those things can only be done by having the time to do the scientific experiments, to work in teams, write up results and then present them. The students also got a bit of a taste of university life as well.

"We are very proud of what we do at the college in terms of our science teaching and research, and I think that what this provides us with is a way of showing talented students how exciting training in science can actually be."

The idea for the event sprang from a pilot one-day forensic science conference last year organised on behalf of Surrey County Council.

The council is concerned that the number of students choosing to do science A-levels in the county has fallen by around 70% in the past decade. It also predicts a county-wide shortage of science, technical and professional-grade workers of around 20,000 by the year 2010.

In an attempt to tackle this potential shortfall, the county is working hard at enthusing its primary and secondary pupils about science.

The one-day event at Egham was such a success that this year the council asked the college to stage a three-day residential exercise.

Temple, who was in charge of the incident room during the exercise, said: "Surrey County Council wanted to do something that involved making science exciting - as a stepping stone, really, to reverse the decline for the county."

The students, who were accompanied by seven school teachers, were joined by academics - who volunteered their services without payment - from the departments of geography, geology, biological sciences, chemistry and the college's electron microscopy unit.

The event was entirely free for pupils, but it cost the council some £15,000 to stage. Ron Bibby, the county's science consultant, says the council sees the task of instilling more excitement about science in the county's 53 secondary schools and 350 primary schools in young people as a long-term project.

Sophie Pinn, 14, from Glebelands School in Cranleigh, said the day gave her "a chance to experience different things, learn new skills and see how science is applied in the real world".

Stephanie Marchese, 15, from St John the Baptist School in Woking, said she had been getting "some real hands-on experience" and the opportunity to see what scientists can do. Christopher Roberts, 14, from the Royal Alexandra and Albert School in Reigate, said he enjoyed using high-tech equipment such as rotary evaporators and electron microscopes.

Professor John Lowe, who helped set up the exercise, felt it gave an authentic taste of the application of science in the real world. Dr Paul Finch, a lecturer in organic chemistry, said students became incredibly enthusiastic when they started to see positive results. "A lot of top-class scientific thinking is going on," said Maggie Cunningham, head of science at Gordon's School near Woking.

A taste of the action

 A five-day space school being staged at Leicester University this week (the 40th anniversary of Yuri Gagarin's first trip in space) will be repeated in the summer (fee £199). The course is aimed at students preparing for GCSEs and post-16 education. The summer school - July 29 to August 3 - will include a day at the National Space Science Centre in Leicester. Details: Space Research Centre, Leicester University, University Road, Leicester, LE1 7RH; tel: 0116 2522675; fax: 0116 2522462; email jco@star.le.ac.uk

www.star.le.ac.uk/spaceschool/

 Central Lancashire University is organising play schemes at its £12m Preston sports arena. They run this week and from Tuesday April 17 to Friday April 20, 10am-3pm, at £6 per day or £20 for the week. There is also a two-day Get Set Cycling course on Thursday and Friday April 19 and 20, to teach cycling safety and skills.

Keen footballers can book on to one of two junior football coaching courses on Wednesday April 11 and Wednesday April 18. Contact the Preston sports arena on 01772 761000.

 London University summer schools offer 4,500 places on a non-selective, first come, first served basis on courses from now to July. Subjects range from medicine to criminology to television production. Details from Mrs Pat Evans, University of London, Senate House Room 229, Malet Street, London WC1E 7HU, tel: 020-7862 8034; email p.evans@academiclon.ac.uk

Christopher Roberts, 14, from the Royal Alexandra and Albert School in Reigate, said he enjoyed using high-tech equipment such as rotary evaporators and electron microscopes. Professor John Lowe, who helped set up the exercise, felt it gave an authentic taste of the application of science in the real world. Dr Paul Finch, a lecturer in organic chemistry, said students became incredibly enthusiastic when they started to see positive results. "A lot of top-class scientific thinking is going on," said Maggie Cunningham, head of science at Gordon's School near Woking. They run this week and from Tuesday April 17 to Friday April 20, 10am-3pm, at £6 per day or £20 for the week. webTitle: Teachers win right to refuse disruptive pupils

fields.headline: Teachers win right to refuse disruptive pupils
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Teachers won the right to refuse to teach disruptive pupils, in a landmark ruling for the profession by the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
Teachers won the right to refuse to teach disruptive pupils, in a landmark ruling for the profession by the high court yesterday.

The mother of a 16-year-old boy, known as Student P under a court anonymity order, took the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers to court, saying he was being deprived of his right to a proper education in the classroom. He had been expelled by the headteacher at a secondary school in Bromley, south London, last summer, for alleged disruptive behaviour.

When the governors overruled the head, staff at the school in the NASUWT balloted for industrial action and voted not to teach him. They claimed that the boy had threatened teachers, assaulted other pupils, and was unteachable in the classroom, allegations he denies.

Student P, who is due to take eight GCSEs this spring, has been taught at the school in isolation by a supply teacher (at an estimated cost of £600 a week) since early December. His lawyers argued in court that the teachers' action was illegal, because it was unrelated to their terms and conditions of employment.

The NASUWT said there had been no diminution in the boy's education because he had the benefit of one-to-one teaching. It argued that the action constituted a valid trade dispute arising out of the head's direction, at the governors' insistence, that their members should teach the boy.

Neither the boy nor his mother was in court to hear Mr Justice Morison dismiss the action and refuse permission to appeal, although they can apply to the court of appeal direct. The NASUWT made no application for costs against the boy, who is legally aided. The cost to the taxpayer is estimated at around £30,000, and the boy may also sue at a later date if he does badly in his exams.

Ruling that the union action was lawful, Mr Justice Morison said it was a "tragedy" that the difficulties in schooling should have reached the courts. "There must be a better way, given reasonable goodwill, for the problems to be overcome. I trust the parties will now find it possible to turn over a new leaf. P is at an important moment of his educational life."

He said the case raised difficult questions of law and that the court had heard no evidence. Witnesses had not been called and many of the details about the boy's conduct remained untried and untested.

In a statement, the boy's mother said: "Jesus said 'Those without sin shall cast the first stone'. Faced with adversity, a parent has to do what's right within the law to seek justice for their young." She said she had always worked in partnership with the school as far as her son's education was concerned.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, said he felt relief, rather than elation. "No one can feel any sense of satisfaction at having this unfortunate case dragged through the courts. The judge was right in his belief that the real needs of pupils are unlikely to be met in the courts. The NASUWT has secured another dramatic victory in the courts, not only for its own members, but for all teachers, pupils and parents who believe in insisting on civilised standards of behaviour in schools".

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the largest teaching union, the National Union of Teachers, said: "It would have been a nonsense if the decision had gone any other way. The NUT has won many cases for members who have had their careers destroyed at the hands of violent and disruptive pupils. The union has made clear its determination to ensure teachers are given more protection from totally unacceptable behaviour which threatens both teachers' and pupils' wellbeing."

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My seven-year-old daughter has recently been diagnosed as having dyspraxia. She is now being removed from mainstream schooling. I would like to know what options are available for her. I would also like some information on dyspraxia and its implications.
fields.trailText: My seven-year-old daughter has recently been diagnosed as having dyspraxia. She is now being removed from mainstream schooling. I would like to know what options are available for her. I would also like some information on dyspraxia and its implications.
fields.body:
Dyspraxia is an impairment or immaturity of the organisation of movement and it affects anything between 2% and 10% of people, to varying degrees. Children with dyspraxia exhibit difficulties with their motor skills, they fall over a lot, they have trouble with throwing and catching, they find organisational skills very difficult and it can overflow into fine motor skills like writing. They are what used to be called "clumsy" children. You can often see the signs of dyspraxia from the age of three, though sometimes it's not diagnosed until the child reaches senior school. Most children with dyspraxia remain in mainstream school, though they need extra support in the classroom and with games. There are lots of things teachers and parents can do to help children; for example, they can break down lists of instructions so the child isn't receiving too many at one time, and make sure a child has understood instructions by asking for them to be repeated. For an older child, you can provide a diary to keep a note of their homework and give them little jobs they have to remember at home, and tick these off on a chart. And there are lots of fun games to build up muscle strength and stamina. The Dyspraxia Foundation has lots of information, and you can see great improvements in as short a time as eight weeks. Children don't grow out of dyspraxia but they can overcome the worst difficulties; it shouldn't impair their quality of life.

Michèle Lee
Chair of the Dyspraxia Foundation

Dyspraxia Foundation helpline: 01462 454986.

We begin working with children from the age of six-and-a-half. It's a time when there is great development and sometimes a child who has problems at six may overcome them simply through that phase of development. When parents contact us, we ask them to fill in a questionnaire to see if the child would benefit from what we offer; the next step is a family consultation. We then devise a home programme of exercises that take from three to 10 minutes each day. The child needs to be monitored every two months, and we have trained people in other parts of the country who can monitor them if they don't live near the institute. You first see improvements in muscle coordination, balance and organisational skills; the academic changes tend to come later. We have also devised a programme for teachers to use in schools. Pilot schemes on integrating this kind of approach into state schools are being researched by the DfEE. Dyspraxia is an umbrella diagnosis; at one end of the scale you have children with a few coordination problems, at the other you can have a condition that is virtually Asperger's. A child with mild dyspraxia can be very successful in a mainstream school.

Sally Goddard Blythe
Neuro- developmental therapist, Institute for Neuro Physiological Psychology

Institute for Neuro Physiological Psychology: 01244 311414, or see www.inpp.org.uk.

Conductive education is a system of teaching and learning that originated in Hungary. Many people have heard of the Peto Institute, which uses conductive education. Essentially it's about teaching individuals who have difficulty processing information how to learn, and building them up to believe they can learn - we bridge the gap between health and education. With dyspraxic children, we work in groups of five or six, so that children can learn from peers who are in the same situation, following a specific movement programme. We've been working with dyspraxic children for a few years now and we have found that the way we work, with an organised routine, is one they really enjoy - they like to know what's expected of them, and it helps them to develop concentration and teaches them how to inte grate into a group. The wonderful thing about these children is that they are in fact quick learners, and though we don't do academic work here, the strategies and problem-solving techniques we teach have a knock-on effect on maths and writing. We are based in Birmingham and generally work with local children, but we are hoping to start week-long courses that families from all over the country can attend, if there is sufficient demand.

Melanie Brown
Senior conductor, the National Institute of Conductive Education

National Institute of Conductive Education: 0121-449 1569.

Coming next

My 13-year-old son is in year 8, but is quite bored in maths. I can see it would only take a little bit of work to get him through GCSE with high marks. Would you recommend he took the exam early?

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or fax them to 020-7239 9933 or e-mail to: education.letters@theguardian.com

webTitle: Could all exams soon be taken online?

fields.headline: Tests, but no papers
fields.standfirst: Following a trial in Northern Ireland, could all exams soon be taken online?  Rosie Cowan  reports
fields.trailText: Following a trial in Northern Ireland, could all exams soon be taken online? Rosie Cowan reports
fields.body:
Almost 300 children in Northern Ireland swapped traditional pen and paper for mouse and keyboard by sitting their mock GCSE science exams on computers in a pioneering experiment.

Pupils at seven schools in Belfast, Derry and several other towns did online tests in biology, chemistry and physics as part of an innovative research project run by the province's exam body, the Council for Curriculum Examinations and Assessment, last week.

Half a class completed their scripts on screen while the rest used pen and paper. The results and questionnaires filled in by teachers and pupils will be analysed and will contribute towards the eventual development of paperless exams.

So, is this how all children will be tested in future? The CCEA qualifications manager, Roger McCune, admitted there were lots of issues to deal with before online exams became a reality, such as disparity between schools over access to computers, differences in pupils' IT skills and lack of mathematical symbols on keyboards.

But he was optimistic these would eventually be ironed out and Northern Ireland pupils would be the first to sit live GCSEs and A-levels online.

Richard Wallace, vice principal and information technology teacher at Ballyclare High School, some of whose pupils tried out the electronic exams, sees tremendous potential for online exams, despite some pitfalls.

"Computers are so widely used in the classroom and at home now that it seems inevitable they will be used in exams," he said. "The fact that everything is typed eliminates any difficulties markers might have with handwriting and many pupils found it also made them faster, plus they could go back to delete and add very easily.

"Assessment can also be much more uniform as the marker uses a limited series of electronic 'notes' beside each question, and can quickly flip back to other scripts to compare and contrast.

"Pupils also commented that the use of colour helped on what are normally black and white science papers. We didn't have videos in these particular tests, but I can see how videos or power point presentations of science experiments, history and geography field trips could greatly enhance understanding and get rid of ambiguities.

"There was an on-screen timer that let pupils know exactly how much time they had left, but they couldn't flick over pages and see how many questions they had or the length of questions, so that was a disadvantage."

Wallace said it would be hard for large classes to sit exams at the same time because of the numbers of computers necessary, making invigilating more difficult. A security programme blocked out everything but the test, making it impossible for pupils to search the net for answers, although Wallace could foresee the possibility of hi-tech cheating if some children were sophisticated computer users.

"The lack of handwriting identification also means invigilators would need to be very sure those sitting the exams are who they say they are, which might open up the need for some sort of photographic ID," he added.

He said the lack of mathematical and science symbols on keyboards also meant some exams would require symbols to be provided in an onscreen menu. "Not every subject might lend itself to online exams and it does depend on children's level of IT literacy and being able to type. But these are very useful talents and we should be teaching the skills that will make pupils attractive to employers."

Two Ballyclare High pupils, 14-year-old Ashley Davison and Tom Burch, 15, who sat their mock GCSE biology online, were enthusiastic about computer exams.

"It wasn't as hard as I thought it would be and I could go back over answers and delete mistakes," said Ashley. "I found it easier to type as my handwriting isn't very neat. I'd like to sit my English this way. I thought the timer was a good idea as you could freeze it if you needed a toilet break, so I found it less stressful."

Tom, who has used computers since he was eight years old, also found it easier to fix mistakes. "I didn't worry about accidentally deleting things or anything going wrong with the computer, I just did not think about that. Some exams, like English, I'd just prefer to write but I can see more and more being on computer. I want to be a graphic designer so I'm keen on computers anyway."

fields.headline: Holiday? What's that?
fields.standfirst: It's not just GCSE students who'll be revising this Easter. Many 11-year-olds are at it too. So much so, that the Sats revision industry is now big business.  Dave Hill reports
fields.trailText: It's not just GCSE students who'll be revising this Easter. Many 11-year-olds are at it too. So much so, that the Sats revision industry is now big business. Dave Hill reports
fields.body:
Just a few minutes in WH Smith provides the basic picture. The shelves in the education department are dominated by test books and revision guides: not simply for A-levels and GCSEs as you might expect, but for another type of exam, one that yields no qualification, whose results have no immediate bearing on opportunities later in a child's life, and which are of no interest to employers, yet are taken seriously enough to have visibly expanded the market for the literature of cramming.

The exams in question are the National Tests - or Sats as they are still widely known - particularly those taken towards the end of key stage 2. Next month most of the nation's year 6 children will sit them in the "core" national curriculum subjects of English, maths and science.

What makes them so important? For primary schools, and especially their heads, this has always been easy to see: to paraphrase a legendary baked beans commercial, bad Sats meanz bad league table showing meanz bad local reputation meanz school is in a hole. That is why in classrooms up and down the land, 10- and 11-year-olds are being coached by their teachers to help their school meet those coveted performance targets: a fat percentage of pupils at level 4 or better; strive, strive, strive to reach that level 5; groom those little stars to shoot to level 6.

But the reasons why parents are becoming increasingly preoccupied with adding their own push to their children's KS2 test preparations are not quite as clear-cut. There is, after all, nothing very bankable in it for them or their offspring. No certificates are issued and results arrive too late to influence secondary school entrance. Yet somebody is buying all those cheery revision texts, and quite a lot of somebodies account for the figure of over 600,000 online hits a week on the BBC's KS2 ReviseWise website during the run-up to last May's National Tests.

ReviseWise TV programmes for KS2 pupils are now showing as part of BBC2's Learning Zone service between 3am and 5am. Mums and dads can set their video timers and earnestly promote the programmes a little later as rivals to the delights of Cartoon Network. The BBC also offers its own range of software, videos, "quiz books" and even last year's test papers as listed in its brochure, A Parents' Guide to Key Stage 2 Revision, of which 800,000 copies were dis tributed via primary schools last year.

Clearly National Test revision is a commercial concern. But what is signified by this explosion of demand and supply? An invigorated culture of educational achievement reaching into the home? Or disturbing evidence that tests which are ostensibly merely a means of measuring attainment against a uniform scale have become an obsession for many parents?

For some these are simple matters of good parenting and human nature. Roger Croft, a father of two and financial consultant from Nottinghamshire, expresses this sentiment with a mixture of fortitude and resignation. "The reality is you have to do all you can to help your children to succeed. It's beside the point that these tests don't get you very much that you can put your finger on. The hard fact is that they exist and your kids know it. What's more, they'll know what score they've got and what scores all their mates have got. At that age they've already figured out that life can be a race, and just like anybody else they don't want to come last."

To this end Croft has encouraged his oldest child, Owain, aged 10, to polish his performance for the testing time to come. Owain says that he mostly enjoys it: "I'm not that keen on the books cos it's a bit like extra homework, though I suppose I'm used to that. The BBC website is more fun, because it's all on the computer. I haven't seen any of those Learning Zone programmes yet. Don't tell dad!"

Owain attends a primary school that prides itself on its test scores, striving to improve them year by year. Other schools - probably a majority - take a more low-key approach, in part to foster a similar outlook among pupils and, hopefully, their parents.

Amanda Bell from Adlington near Macclesfield pays tribute to the approach of the school her year 6 daughter, Harriet, attends, Adlington Primary. "The head, David Hudson, sees that the school deals with the Sats very responsibly," she says. "That's helped Harriet not to get her knickers in a twist about them. She knows she's meant to do her best work on the day, but she also knows it's not the end of the world if she doesn't."

At Morningside primary in Hackney, north-east London, feelings about the tests are ambivalent - the more so in light of the school's turbulent recent past. Not long after Labour got elected, David Blunkett took what many saw as the self-serving decision to "name and shame" a list of "failing" schools, Morningside among them. Headteacher Jean Millham, then only recently installed to sort out the school's problems, publicly criticised the secretary of state for making them still harder to solve in one of the most socially deprived areas in London.

While disliking the stigma the tests have visited upon the school, she welcomes their part in cranking up standards. And while she knows that a different component of Morningside's improvement strategy was responsible for spotting that her second child was having difficulty with reading, she feels sure that the later prospect of the test helped to motivate him. He was delighted by the idea of reaching level 5 and thrilled when he achieved it: "He was very shy and in his shell before," says Cath, "and having the test to aim for helped to concentrate his mind. fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
A brief news item I noticed last week suggests that Mr Richardson, the head, may have been a trifle disingenuous about his plans to increase the levy on school meals. When they were last discussed, Mr Richardson mentioned that he was considering raising the daily charge to £1.50 in order to finance a great leap in food quality.

Now, though, I read that legislation has just come into force that makes it illegal for schools to serve chips every day. Presumably Mr Richardson would have been well aware that the school kitchen was about to be legally obliged to provide a balanced diet - "including healthy items such as fish, vegetables and fruit".

In the meantime, the termly parent-teacher encounters have come around again. Lucy's teacher, Miss Narayan, is running a good 20 minutes late today.

There is an animated conversation going on between two of the waiting mothers. I sidle into the conversation.

"And apparently, he was still shouting 'effing this' and 'effing that' at James and his friends. I couldn't believe it when I heard some of the things he was saying," says Sophie's mother (James being her older son in year 6).

"But that's not the worst of it. According to Ian, James's friend, he said he was carrying a knife and was threatening to use it on them," she continues.

"A knife?!" I exclaim, more or less involuntarily. This is too shocking. We're talking about a primary school and a 10-year-old.

"I reported the whole thing to Mr Richardson," she says. "And you know what he did? - even though this boy's been excluded before for bullying - he excluded him for one day."

She pauses for dramatic effect.

"One day! I ask you. And him carrying a knife. I was disgusted. I don't want him round my kids at all, I complained to Mr Richardson."

"And what did he say?" I ask.

"Not much. Just some rubbish about disciplinary procedures."

"Well, you know, if you're not happy, you could raise the issue with the governors," I suggest.

"What's the point? They won't do anything about it. They'll just follow what he says," she adds.

At this I keep quiet. What's to say? She's probably right.

fields.headline: 'I will not explode'
fields.standfirst: An egg-timer is just one tool in a campaign to teach children to control their rage. By  David Ward
fields.trailText: An egg-timer is just one tool in a campaign to teach children to control their rage. By David Ward
fields.body:
Everyone knows what happens if you give a full bottle of Coke a vigorous shake and then unscrew the top. So the year 3 children at Benchill primary in south Manchester dived for cover when visitor Kim Wade flexed her muscles.

Wade, head of Manchester's behaviour and support service, resisted the temptation to open the bottle and let the fizz drench the pupils. She had made her point: the frothing of the drink was a metaphor for the build-up and explosion of temper.

Benchill's children were having a session on anger management. There is no suggestion that they are any more angry than children at other schools in the city and the lesson was intended to help identify and deal with the rages that life in the classroom and playground can provoke.

Wade and her team run courses for four- to 16-year-olds in both anger management and conflict resolution as a way of defusing situations that lead to exclusions. They have devised their own programmes and do not confine their activities to children.

"If parents or teachers are having problems managing a child, we work with them too," said Wade. "And if children see everyone coming from the same direction, they tend to toe the line more readily."

Her team grabbed the headlines when the story broke of how they used a one-to-one anger management course to return to the classroom an eight-year-old girl (not from Benchill) who had been excluded five times in three years.

The crisis came when the girl kicked and spat at a teacher whose colleagues then threatened to strike.

The girl returned to school with the help of an egg-timer: when her temper threatened to explode, her teacher turned the timer over and the rage evaporated as the sand flowed through the glass.

Wade did not pack an egg-timer into her briefcase when she went to Benchill, but she did include reels of stickers (rewards for good behaviour) and Angry Arthur, Hiawyn Oram's prize-winning story of a boy whose rages set off thunderstorms, earthquakes and cosmic meltdown.

What, she asked, could Arthur have done rather than lose his rag when his mum refused to let him watch a cowboy film on television?

"He could have gone to bed as he was asked," suggested one angelic child. "He could have calmed down a bit and asked his mum nicely," said another. A third pragmatically suggested that he could have asked his mother to video the film.

"There's nothing wrong with getting angry, but it's what we do when we are angry that can cause problems," added Wade. "Put your hand up if you get angry and do the wrong thing."

A forest of hands shot up: infants tend to be honest and uninhibited.

The children then broke into groups to write down what made them angry: "nicking money", "snatching things", "when our mum wakes us up for school", "when I can't watch Popstars", "when someone gets in the bathroom before you", "scrime" [ie screaming].

The children gathered back in a corner of the sun-filled room and the bottle of Coke made its appearance as they were asked to consider the physical signs of their anger. They decided that they ground their teeth, went red in the face, stamped their feet and made fists as their hearts beat faster and their veins stood out.

"My baby stops breathing when he cries 'cos he's angry," said a voice from the middle of the crowd.

Wade invited the group to show what they looked like when they were in a temper. Most pulled horrible faces but Shelley let out a bat-like squeak of fury.

It was time for suggested antidotes. "Close your eyes and breathe in very slowly for five, count five and then breathe out very slowly for five," suggested Wade. Some children breathed too fast for therapy but slowed down at the second attempt before returning to their tables to draw pictures of angry people: some of the resulting Lowry-like figures were horribly deformed with frenzy.

"We are hoping to spread this work across the city in a preventative way, not just when a problem strikes," confided Wade in a quiet moment. "We tend to find that our work brings an early improvement. If progress dips, we will come back."

Dave Smith, Benchill's new head, sees anger management and conflict resolution as strategies in creating an atmosphere of stability and trust in which learning can flourish. "I'm trying to teach children that you don't run away from a problem," he said. "You confront it and someone will be there to support you."

Back with the year 3s, Wade asked how they might pass on to others - including adults - what they have learned. They agreed that slow breathing was a useful way to knock the stuffing out of rage.

One small girl suggested another helpful technique. "Give your mum a vodka and Coke," she said, with an eye on the bottle which had not been opened.

webTitle: Parents go to war with the system over childrens' school places

fields.headline: Sink or swim?
fields.standfirst: So, your child hasn't got in to any of the schools you chose. Neither have the children featured here. Over the next few months,  Martin Wainwright  and  David Grace  will follow their fortunes as they go to war with the system. Today: planning the appeal
fields.trailText: So, your child hasn't got in to any of the schools you chose. Neither have the children featured here. Over the next few months, Martin Wainwright and David Grace will follow their fortunes as they go to war with the system. Today: planning the appeal
fields.body:
The Dixons

Alan Dixon is a quality technician with a car parts firm. His wife, Christine, is a school helper. They live in Hertfordshire with their two children, Tony, nearly 11, and Steven, age nine.

"We live about 600 metres from our first-choice school, but Tony hasn't got a place there. Siblings get priority, and as it's a foundation school they also select up to 35% of its intake by entrance exam and 10% by proficiency in music.

"Then it's whoever lives the nearest. Tony took the entrance exam but obviously didn't do well enough, and there are so many siblings applying that even families living closer than us haven't been offered a place. It's frustrating, because we don't know how close Tony came in his exam, and we won't know where we are on the waiting list until the end of April. Our second choice was another foundation school a few miles away where they interview the pupils and pick the ones they want. I've written to David Blunkett saying I find it incredible that a school can choose its pupils in that way when it's supposed to be the other way round.

"We have been offered another school, a county comprehensive that's working hard to improve, but why should my child have to go on a long bus ride every day to a school that's not as good as any of the ones we wanted? We're hoping an acceptable place will eventually come up, and we'll go to appeal if we have to. But we're also thinking of moving, probably down to the Swindon area, where Christine's family comes from. Maybe Tony and Steven will have a better chance there."
DG

The Trans

Hung Tran was an architect in Vietnam until he and his family fled the country seven years ago. His wife, Tuyet, was a sales assistant. Both are now unemployed. They live in inner London with their three children, Duy, 17, Hoa, 14, and Thanh, 11.

When Thanh arrived from Vietnam as a refugee seven years ago he spoke no English, but has thrived in his cosmopolitan, inner-London primary school. He is also a keen musician, specialising in the oboe. Sadly, secondary provision in his home borough is uneven and Thanh lives too far from his first-choice school, an over-subscribed mixed county comprehensive, to have been offered a place there. Instead, he's been allotted to a boys' school nearer his home. Thanh's parents do not speak English well, which is why he must speak for himself.

"I want to go to the mixed school because I know it is a good school, especially for a musician. I was very upset when I didn't get a place there.

"I have an older brother who finished at the boys' school last year. He did well in his GCSEs and had some friends, but he was bullied. Because of that I am frightened. We have decided to appeal, and my teachers are helping all they can. They are going to fill in all the forms and someone is going to write a letter for us, explaining all the reasons why my parents think I should go to the school I like. If we don't win the appeal we hope for a place at our second-choice school where the waiting list is shorter. It is not a very good school, but it is still better for me than the boys' school. We don't know what else to do, so if the boys' school is the only one where I can get a place I will have to go there. We don't want to make a fuss."
DG

The Worralls

David Worrall is a plastics manufacturer. His wife, Lorraine, is a clerk at Asda. They live in Halifax with their three children, Lee, 13, Jamie, 11 and Katie, six.

Lorraine and David spent ages leafing through school details, sports facilities and exam results before filling in their first three choices for Jamie, 11 in June and due to move up to high school next September. But when the buff envelope came back from Calderdale council this month, it was like a Lottery scratchcard gone wrong.

Four schools were offered, but not one of them was from the Worralls' own list. The couple were astonished, especially as one of the comprehensives was 12 miles away from their home in Halifax - almost in a different county.

The other three were more predictable: schools that Calderdale is trying to rescue from the bottom of its strangely assorted heap. For sad historical reasons, the Yorkshire council has a mixture of grammars, former grant-maintained schools, strongly neighbourhood comps in outlying towns and what amount to secondary moderns, although everyone is trying to raise their game.

The squeeze on parental choice is such that the Worralls' ace - a sibling already at their first-choice school for Jamie - has been trumped. Their elder son Lee is 13 and flourishing at Holy Trinity, but the CofE high school had 242 applications for 180 places. Lorraine can do the sums. But she and David are also counting on strength in numbers. "There are five children in Jamie's class at the primary who now haven't got schools to go to - who'll be staying behind when the others go off for the transition day at Holy Trinity or the other high schools," she says. Parents have been galvanised to tackle the appeals system, which involved writing three initial letters, fast.

First, Lorraine politely turned down the four Calderdale offers, in spite of approaches from one of the schools, which she knows from living nearby in the past. She says: "They said, 'don't worry Lorraine, Jamie will be in an express class' [part of reforms to attract back motivated parents and groom promising students]. But I don't want him segregated like that. We're a normal family and he's a normal boy who's bright enough but doesn't want 'expressing'. At that school, I'm scared that he'd either be segregated and maybe picked on, or dragged down with the rest - which is why we moved away from there."

The second letter went off to Wakefield diocese to get an appeal form, and the third was the form itself, sent to Holy Trinity, which runs its own appeals; the Worralls are expecting a date at the end of this month. Lorraine and David kept their case simple and direct. "We had to," says Lorraine. "There wasn't that much room."

Lee's place at the school was one point; the other a strong and honest case for the family as active Church of England parents. In the squeeze on Holy Trinity, this is a key area of point-scoring; the family's initial application, refereed by their vicar whose own son is in Jamie's class and going to Holy Trinity, had to specify between types of churchgoing (the child alone, with family etc).

The Worralls want to go every week, and Jamie does Bible class on Monday evenings; but David's continental shifts at work rule out a lot of Sunday mornings for him, and then there's football. Lorraine says: "Jamie and Lee are really keen, but team practice is on Sunday morning at the same time as church." Like so many parents of three children (six- year-old Katie has all this to come) she is torn all ways.

That's another of her appeal points; sending Jamie somewhere else will mean that two hard-working parents have children at three separate schools - "but I pride myself on having a very close family, and the children would benefit from being at the same school." She has tentatively approached the vicar about midweek worship, but it isn't yet a runner.

So all eyes are back on the letterbox at the family's home in Pellon, Halifax, waiting for the appeals appointment to drop through. Meanwhile, the Worralls draw strength from neighbours with the same problem, and sympathetic primary teachers who warn: "It's just never been this difficult before."
MW

The Gilletts

Gary Gillett is a nurse. His wife, Jill, is a teacher. They live in Withington, south Manchester with their son Jack, 11 and Georgia, eight.

Jack Gillett's parents got him into nursery school in Withington at the age of four, with cast-iron guarantees that he would "feed" into Parrs Wood high school eight years later.

But the cast iron has shattered. The letter from the local education authority turned Jack down for the highly rated comprehensive in Didsbury and offered him more distant schools or ones with a struggling - at best - reputation.

The shock is palpable in the voice of his mother, Jill, in spite of her long personal experience of the LEA and its workings. Now teaching at a special school in a Manchester education action zone (she is strongly committed to state education), she used to be in charge of transition arrangements to high schools in north Manchester.

"You do feel desperate, especially when everything has pointed to Parrs Wood for so long," she says. The family moved to be near one of the comprehensive's official feeder primaries, St Paul's, when Jack was tiny. Every assumption has been Parrs Wood.

"Jack plays his trombone in the orchestra there, he's done sports sessions in his holidays there, and he went on an Excellence in Cities course there last year," says Jill. "Most of his friends are going there. It's a wonderful school with beautiful new buildings, thanks to getting specialist technology status. It's got a great academic record and it would be just right for Jack."

The iron began to crack when Manchester decided to change its catchment policy two years ago, in an attempt to tackle a yawning imbalance between high school intakes. In place of "official feeder schools" with guaranteed places, each high school now runs a geographical catchment.

Now, Jack's house is just too far away from Parrs Wood, and the family cannot afford to move again to Didsbury - as many people in Withington have done in the past year. The school at the top of Jack's offer has 137 places going begging - not surprisingly after a wretched Ofsted which referred to problems with violence. Jill shudders. You've read those letters of rejection, you've wept, raged or simply groaned in resignation, and now you're facing the fact that your secondary transfer saga has entered a new and even more desperate phase.

It's not as if you haven't already invested enough time and energy trying to secure a place at a secondary school that's to the liking of you and your worried year 6 child. Depressed or even frightened by what your local education authority has to offer close to your home, you devoted most of last autumn to trekking around, attending open evenings, poring over admissions criteria, listening to headteachers assure you that your already slender hopes will disappear completely unless his or her school is at the top of your wish list, unless your little Nibs or Nellie is a violin virtuoso or an intellectual giant, or unless the 300 children likely to be ahead of yours on the waiting list all emigrate or drop dead before September.

After intense consideration you pitched your applications and have spent the last two months sleeping with your fingers crossed. And now you've received the bad news.

So, what do you do next? First, take what grim comfort you can from knowing you are far from alone. The logical consequences of "parental choice" fostered under the Conservatives manifest themselves ever more clearly under new Labour. The over-subscription of popular secondary schools continues to increase, leaving the unpopular ever more beleaguered, and more and more education-minded parents with the distinctly bitter feeling that, in the end, they've been left with no choice at all.

The concentration of demand upon the best-regarded schools is a major social phenomenon. Homes are sold, jobs are changed, private tutors are hired and serious lies are told in the battle to be included on next year's year 7 roll. Even schools whose admissions policies conform absolutely to comprehensive principles find their intakes slanted towards those in society best equipped to become winners in the great admissions game.

Here, we have interviewed four very different families who have found themselves bruised by this trend. Today, we ask them what exclusion from the school of their choice means to them, and what they intend to do about it. In the weeks to come we shall follow their attempts to overcome that exclusion, peering over their shoulder as they struggle with letters of appeal, following them to the appeal room itself and, finally, accompanying their child to the school gates - wherever they end up.

It is impossible to predict what will happen to these families, and to the thousands of others like them. It is certainly true that many will find they have been too quick to dismiss so-called "sink" schools. Some will reluctantly settle for such a school in the interim, only to find that, actually, their child settles happily there.

It is also true that many disappointed applicants will still get the school they want if they hang on for a bit before calling in Pickfords: even long waiting lists shorten, with places sometimes cropping up as late as the first week of September.

But all that notwithstanding, most - like the four families featured here - will already be pondering an appeal. This time two years ago that's just what I was doing. Not for any thing fancy: just a reasonably proximate non-selective, non-denominational mixed school with a broad social blend, wise pastoral policies and an attitude to teaching that combined liberal values with intellectual grit. In other words, one of those "bog standard" comprehensives.

From the excellent Advisory Centre for Education (ACE) I learned that there are basically two ways to succeed. One is to show that the LEA has messed up its procedures. The other is to convince the panel of (usually three) neutral experts that the problems caused for the school by having to accommodate an extra child would be less than those your child would endure if he or she had to go anywhere else. You make your case for being let in, someone from the school or LEA makes the case for keeping you at bay, and the panel makes its judgment in due course. In other words, you go to war, not only against the school, but against all the other children who have been turned down.

My appeal was successful, and I'm glad. But the whole experience also made me sad: sad for other parents and sad that such situations should arise in the first place. The extension of "choice" and competition has brought us to a point where the most affluent and well-informed parents tend to take most of what is best while the children of the rest have to make do with what's left over. Even in scenarios where there is no selection by examination, other forms are becoming more entrenched: selection by mortgage, by social skills, by stealth. And the more there is selection, the more there is exclusion.

fields.bodyText: The Dixons Alan Dixon is a quality technician with a car parts firm. His wife, Christine, is a school helper. They live in Hertfordshire with their two children, Tony, nearly 11, and Steven, age nine. "We live about 600 metres from our first-choice school, but Tony hasn't got a place there. Siblings get priority, and as it's a foundation school they also select up to 35% of its intake by entrance exam and 10% by proficiency in music. "Then it's whoever lives the nearest. Tony took the entrance exam but obviously didn't do well enough, and there are so many siblings applying that even families living closer than us haven't been offered a place. It's frustrating, because we don't know how close Tony came in his exam, and we won't know where we are on the waiting list until the end of April. Our second choice was another foundation school a few miles away where they interview the pupils and pick the ones they want. I've written to David Blunkett saying I find it incredible that a school can choose its pupils in that way when it's supposed to be the other way round. "We have been offered another school, a county comprehensive that's working hard to improve, but why should my child have to go on a long bus ride every day to a school that's not as good as any of the ones we wanted? We're hoping an acceptable place will eventually come up, and we'll go to appeal if we have to. But we're also thinking of moving, probably down to the Swindon area, where Christine's family comes from. Maybe Tony and Steven will have a better chance there." He is also a keen musician, specialising in the oboe. Sadly, secondary provision in his home borough is uneven and Thanh lives too far from his first-choice school, an over-subscribed mixed county comprehensive, to have been offered a place there. Instead, he's been allotted to a boys' school nearer his home. Thanh's parents do not speak English well, which is why he must speak for himself. "I want to go to the mixed school because I know it is a good school, especially for a musician. I was very upset when I didn't get a place there. "I have an older brother who finished at the boys' school last year. He did well in his GCSEs and had some friends, but he was bullied. Because of that I am frightened. We have decided to appeal, and my teachers are helping all they can. They are going to fill in all the forms and someone is going to write a letter for us, explaining all the reasons why my parents think I should go to the school I like. If we don't win the appeal we hope for a place at our second-choice school where the waiting list is shorter. It is not a very good school, but it is still better for me than the boys' school. We don't know what else to do, so if the boys' school is the only one where I can get a place I will have to go there. We don't want to make a fuss." The couple were astonished, especially as one of the comprehensives was 12 miles away from their home in Halifax - almost in a different county. The other three were more predictable: schools that Calderdale is trying to rescue from the bottom of its strangely assorted heap. For sad historical reasons, the Yorkshire council has a mixture of grammars, former grant-maintained schools, strongly neighbourhood comps in outlying towns and what amount to secondary moderns, although everyone is trying to raise their game. The squeeze on parental choice is such that the Worralls' ace - a sibling already at their first-choice school for Jamie - has been trumped. Their elder son Lee is 13 and flourishing at Holy Trinity, but the CofE high school had 242 applications for 180 places. Lorraine can do the sums. But she and David are also counting on strength in numbers. "There are five children in Jamie's class at the primary who now haven't got schools to go to - who'll be staying behind when the others go off for the transition day at Holy Trinity or the other high schools," she says. Parents have been galvanised to tackle the appeals system, which involved writing three initial letters, fast. First, Lorraine politely turned down the four Calderdale offers, in spite of approaches from one of the schools, which she knows from living nearby in the past. She says: "They said, 'don't worry Lorraine, Jamie will be in an express class' [part of reforms to attract back motivated parents and groom promising students]. At that school, I'm scared that he'd either be segregated and maybe picked on, or dragged down with the rest - which is why we moved away from there." She has tentatively approached the vicar about midweek worship, but it isn't yet a runner. fields.headline: Q&A: hospital cleanliness
fields.trailText: Q&A: Hospital cleanliness
fields.body:
Why is cleanliness such a big issue?
The filthy state of many hospitals is perennially high on the list of public complaints about the NHS. It is also a health hazard - dirty wards and poor standards of hygiene are believed to be linked to sharp rises in the number of patients who get hospital-acquired infections, which kill 5,000 people a year and cost the NHS £1bn. What do you mean by filthy hospitals, exactly?
Dirty linen, cigarette buts in the corridors, uncollected litter, food trays not removed for days, dust under the beds, overflowing toilets, and - in one survey - pigeons flapping around a canteen. Hospital inspection teams assessed hygiene and cleanliness in 14 categories, including ward furniture, linen, car parks, toilets, smells and the state of public areas such as accident and emergency departments. How did the NHS get so dirty?
One explanation is the decision to contract out health service cleaning and catering services to the private sector in the 1980s through the competitive tendering process. Unions claim that contractors frequently cut corners in order to come up with the lowest bid, and that quality suffered as a result. The outsourcing of cleaning meant that cleaners were no longer accountable to ward sisters and other NHS staff, who found it difficult to order improvements. What has the government done about it?
Last summer it launched the NHS hospital clean-up initiative, backed with £31m allocated to trusts to redecorate wards and refurbish public areas. Each trust was then inspected in the autumn by patient environment action teams, made up of patient representatives and NHS professionals. In the autumn it promised to end compulsory competitive tendering of cleaning services - although trusts can still go private if they believe it will raise quality. It has also announced it is to re-introduce hospital matrons - who will have the power to sack contractors who fail to meet cleanliness standards. What did the inspections find?
In autumn 2000, some 253 of 700 hospitals in England received "poor" ratings for cleanliness. By the end of the second round of inspections in January and February 2001, that figure had dropped to 40, with 10 of those hospitals put on "special measures" as a result of the poor cleanliness standards. Of the five trusts that ran these trusts, four had employed private contractors. How will standards be maintained?
The government has launched national cleaning standards for all NHS hospitals. These have five key objectives: taking cleanliness seriously; listening to patient feedback; ensuring hospital-acquired infections are controlled; ensuring staff are properly trained; and that cleanliness is monitored. Ministers have promised that by the autumn no hospital will have "poor" standards of cleanliness.

webTitle: Joe Peel is not going to give up the fight against the college that failed him

fields.headline: Raw deal
fields.standfirst: Joe Peel is not going to give up the fight against the college that failed him
fields.trailText: Joe Peel is not going to give up the fight against the college that failed him
fields.body:
In August 1998 I was unemployed. It was the pilot year of the Employment Zones / New Deal scheme and I had been told I could go into full-time education or training for up to a year and still get my unemployment benefits, plus an extra £15 per week. I saw a poster advertising a course. It was exactly what I was looking for and had been designed to fit the criteria for Employment Zones/ New Deal. I went in and enquired.

Next day, I was a full-time student. I began my full-time programme of study mid-September. Although the course was managed and administrated from the college's gleaming new, superbly equipped arts centre, it was actually delivered in the cellar of a building across the road which had been converted into a resource centre for the unemployed and which the college used as an outreach centre.

By the time the academic year had slipped its September moorings and reached December, it was apparent that we were very definitely "steerage" passengers; the planning, preparation, accommodation and resources were very definitely "third class" and pitifully inadequate.

We did what we could. The students formed a pressure group. We lobbied, complained and begged, but to no avail. Although we all came from the dole with a tidy bounty of FEFC, DfEE and European Social Fund funding per head, it was obvious that the money was not being spent on us. By January we had lost almost half our number, the weaker ones finding it too hard to cling to the upturned lifeboats with no rescue in sight. In March, one course was suddenly withdrawn without warning and we lost another boatload, as students who had applied for university places on the strength of the expected award were scuppered and abandoned ship.

By the time the year ended in June 1999, just five of us remained. I had spent a year getting nowhere, chasing management with complaints. One by one the last few students gave up and swam for safety, returning to the dole queue. That left me. I lodged a formal complaint against the college that September.

Looking back over the 18 months since then, I have made some interesting discoveries. One of the courses which made up the programme of study had never been submitted for validation to the awarding body; and the other, an NVQ, the college did not hold a licence to offer in the first place. At the time of advertising and recruitment to that programme of courses, the college knew that there was absolutely no possibility that they would be able to deliver them, with awards, by the end of that year.

The whole "sting" was based on the theory that if you pick a "certain type" of person off the dole and treat them in a certain way, they will all have given up and left long before the awarding of certification is due, so no one is the wiser and the college will have picked up the "bounty" for every name on the register.

Despite having complained to the college, its corporate board, the FEFC, the QCA, both the awarding bodies involved, the local TEC, Employment Zones and yes, the DfEE, I have still not received a satisfactory response.

I would like to sue the college management for the waste of my year of study and the year since, but still being unemployed and this type of case not qualifying for legal aid, what chance have I? It looks like the end of the line. But perhaps not. Not all hands were lost when the year of 98-99 went down. One survivor remains bobbing about and determined - a determined little iceberg.

Joe Peel is not the writer's real name.

fields.headline: College Days
fields.standfirst: Gurbux Singh
fields.trailText: Gurbux Singh
fields.body:
Born: December 4, 1950

Occupation: Chair of the Commission for Racial Equality

College: Wulfrun College - named after Wulfruna, the Saxon broad who gave her name to Wolverhampton - now Wolverhampton College.

Attended: 1966-1969

Courses: Certificate office studies; A-levels in government, economics and law; diploma in municipal administration

A contemporary recalls: "We played in the same football team. He was centre forward, I was on the right wing. He was very good, but let's say he wouldn't pass the ball. He had a bit of a reputation for wanting to score goals. He was a very nice guy."

Vice principal Cliff Hall says: "We're extremely proud of Gurbux's achievements and work with the CRE."
