There are talented players in Portugal and Spain too, even though it's difficult to compete there with Real Madrid and Barcelona. "Milan have always had big players and I think that it is the president's intention to buy champion players who are able to make a difference," he added. Fiorentina's Portuguese midfielder Rui Costa is widely considered Milan's number one target, while Barcelona's Brazilian forward Rivaldo has also been frequently linked with a switch to the San Siro. Galatasaray winger Hasan Sas and Leeds United's Australian striker Mark Viduka are also among those recently rumoured to be on Milan's wish-list.

fields.headline: The Guardian graduate jobs email
fields.trailText: In a week when it was reported that Luton University gives its students a better chance of finding work than either Oxford or Cambridge, here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.
fields.body:
In a week when it was reported that Luton University gives its students a better chance of finding work than either Oxford or Cambridge, here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.

This is our last missive until after the Easter break - but fear not, we return chocolate-egged up in two week's time.

If you were too busy visiting the home of Vauxhall, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 7 April).

Don't think much of your careers service? You're not alone. A new report by Sir Martin Harris says the whole sector needs a shake-up and improvements are been promised. Only problem is, they won't happen until the start of the 2002/3 academic year. http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,469546,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Comedy, claims Tola Awogbamiye, is a great way to break the ice in interviews and during presentations, but the joke's got to be right for the circumstances. Use it to your advantage and you'll be laughing. http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,469558,00.html?bnr=email.grad

NEXT WEEK RISE takes a break for Easter but we'll be back the following Saturday.

This week's RISE GOLD is our own guide on how to read job adverts. They don't exactly lie - they just exaggerate, according to Hilary Freeman. She gets underneath the "fast-growing, young, dynamic company" copy to reveal the truth about the man in the garage. http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,3929894,00.html?bnr=email.grad

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP

Start honing a cultured sense of humour. Lose the pants jokes, it's time to acquire a few sophisticated "bon mots" for the interview season. Remember tone is everything and under no circumstances make any references to Wagner's Ring Cycle.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS

If you have just graduated in PR and you are prepared to go up against the Countess of Wessex who is understood to be in the market again, Interface International, a marketing agency with an excellent travel client portfolio are seeking a confident, articulate graduate to join its team. Only £14K - might put Sophie off.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100113037,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you have a deep love of breakfast cereals - hey, some people do - HGCA, the body tasked with promoting the UK's cereal and oilseed industry, is looking for six grads to take up various positions. Based in central London and 25 days hols.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100111624,00.html?bnr=email.grad

The Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons is looking for an administrative officer to do admin for its education department and "and the occasional servicing of working party/sub-committee meetings." See what I mean about those jokes.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100112985,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you've got some telly experience and a burning desire to get into the medium, ONdigital is looking for a project co-ordinator ready to move into the brave new world of digital TV. You'll need good planning and general IT skills, and an ability to work on your own initiative - no less.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100112771,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you have a science background and enjoy passing on information, this company is looking for a junior information scientist to join a small research team providing some answers. You'll also assist in the editing of 3 news-sheets on UK food retailers, and international food manufacturers.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,-18153,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you want to work with disadvantaged kids to provide alcohol/drug education, Lewisham Council is looking for a young people's worker to take the message into South London. You will have good experience of working with disadvantaged young people and/or offenders.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100112316,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Calling all Psychology graduates - Wolverhampton Council is looking for an Assistant Educational Psychologist with some teaching experience to join its teaching department. Lots of on-the-job training guaranteed.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100113200,00.html?bnr=email.grad

This week's editorial assistant job is with Law Pack, publisher of consumer self-help legal and business titles. As usual you need to be "motivated, conscientious and an adaptable team-member". Wouldn't it be refreshing if they asked for unmotivated, disorganised loners - you can but dream.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100113055,00.html?bnr=email.grad

And finally, if you have always wanted to travel the world's exhibition halls, this company is looking for events assistants who want to get into the crazy world of conferences. Got to have one year's experience but I'm sure you could talk your way in.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100112835,00.html?bnr=email.grad

fields.headline: Two new cases in Netherlands
fields.standfirst:
 French farmers protest
 Expected cost increases
 Irish and French export bans to be lifted

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 French farmers protest
 Expected cost increases
 Irish and French export bans to be lifted
fields.body:
Two new cases of foot and mouth were confirmed in the Netherlands today, bringing the total number of outbreaks in continental Europe to 23.

The infected farms were in two towns, Heerde and Wapenveld, in the east of the country, already affected by the epidemic.

Dutch farmers protested yesterday in Kootwijkerbroek against the mass culling of animals in angry scenes that led to 16 arrests.

Today it was the turn of the French. Farmers in Toulouse parked dozens of lorries in the middle of main roads leading to the airport, prompting the cancellation of most morning flights.

France, which reported two cases last month, has not had a new outbreak for three weeks. The farmers were demanding an end to the export ban on their meat, which is due to end on Thursday.

The EU health commissioner, David Byrne, said today that the disease was expected to strip 250m (£155m) from the union's budget - much higher than the 170m (£105m) he predicted last week.

The figure does not take into account the bans many countries have imposed on EU meat imports but Mr Byrne was optimistic that the outbreak would not spread beyond the four infected countries.

"In all other member states, there are grounds to consider that they have succeeded in avoiding any outbreak," he said.

Mr Byrne even had a glimmer of hope for Britain, pointing out that the daily rate of new cases was falling - although he said it was too early to say the epidemic had peaked.

The export ban on Irish meat, dairy products and livestock will be lifted on April 19, a week after France.

webTitle: Dyke clamps down on awards liggers

fields.headline: Dyke clamps down on awards liggers
fields.standfirst: Click here to read Dyke's email to all BBC staff
fields.trailText:
5.45pm: Greg Dyke has ordered staff to cut down on the number of awards ceremonies they attend, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
Click here to read Dyke's email to BBC staff
fields.body:
Greg Dyke has ordered staff to cut down on the number of awards ceremonies they attend in a bid to save hundreds of thousands of pounds of licence-payers' money.

He has expressed concern many of the ceremonies on the TV calender are simply created to make money for the organisers.

And he has hinted the corporation will no longer pay for the hangers-on who manage to lig into glitzy ceremonies such as the Baftas and Royal Television Society.

In a postscript to an e-mail about expenses that was sent to staff, the BBC director-general said he was not banning BBC staff from attending awards ceremonies.

"This is certainly not the case for those who are nominated as we should celebrate our successes.

"However, I am concerned at the ever increasing number of awards - and awards dinners - which are being created," he said.

At the weekend it emerged a single night out at the Bafta television awards in May will cost the BBC £40,000 of licence-payers' money.

Nearly 200 executives and programme-makers will attend the event, at a cost of around £200 each.

And in the past month, another £62,000 has been spent on sending around 270 BBC staff and their guests to two black-tie RTS awards dinners.

The RTS alone runs half a dozen awards ceremonies a year.

There are also three Bafta ceremonies, the National TV awards, the Soap awards, TV Quick awards and various ceremonies abroad.

fields.headline: Greg Dyke's email
fields.standfirst: Greg Dyke's email to staff
fields.trailText: BBC director general Greg Dyke's email to all staff
fields.body:
As everyone knows we launched a new BBC wide expenses policy at the beginning of February. As you also know this has upset quite a few people and we have received a lot of negative feedback from staff, from members of the Staff Forum and from the trades unions.

Having listened to these views and having had further negotiations with the Inland Revenue we have decided to make a number of changes, which will take effect immediately (if expenses are not to be taxed the rates have to be approved by the Inland Revenue).

One major change will be that instead of having one expenses policy we will have one for Resources Ltd. and one for virtually all of the rest of the BBC, including Radio Production Resources (we*ve always had separate expenses policies for BBC Worldwide and the Orchestras and these will continue).

Our attempt to create a single policy from the 26 different ones we had before has proved too difficult. As a business competing for outside work we've come to accept that BBC Resources Ltd is subject to different commercial pressures and, as a result, needs a different policy.

As from this year BBC Resources Ltd is free to operate its own pay policy with its staff regardless of the overall BBC pay deal, so we have decided it should have its own expenses policy as well.

For the rest of the BBC we plan to make the following changes to the expenses policy:

The Changes:

The BBC has negotiated a dispensation with the Inland Revenue so that people only need to be away for 5 hours and 5 miles from their home base in order for a meal claim not to be taxable (ie the current restrictions that staff have to be more than 5 miles from any BBC base and that their home base must have canteen facilities will no longer apply);

Also, after negotiations with the Inland Revenue, it has been agreed that for News and News Resources staff (and similar staff in Nations & Regions and World Service), meals will not be taxed if they are working within 5 miles of their home base and cannot return to a BBC site for operational reasons (i.e. they are covering a story);

Mileage rates will be increased in line with Inland Revenue changes for 2001/2002. This will only affect vehicles in the 'up to 1500cc' category, which go up 5p per mile.

The £55 hotel accommodation guidance rate is increased to £65;

Where staff are entitled to both a lunch and dinner, with prior permission, the rate for the two allowances can be combined to pay for dinner up to the value of £16;

That after 8pm, staff can now claim the higher (£10 'dinner') rate if they have been on duty for more than 5 hours and are 5 miles from base;

Staff will now be entitled to claim for a second meal 6 hours after the first - rather than after another 7 hours as the policy currently requires;

Advances for irregular expenses will be permissible in limited circumstances.

Those in BBC Resources Ltd should note that they will not get the increased allowances outlined above - but will have a different policy.

The Trades Unions are being informed of these changes.

Before anyone asks: these changes do NOT signal the end of 'One BBC'. It's worth remembering we will have reduced 26 different expenses policies down to just two.

Full details on the new policies can be found on Gateway at http://home.gateway.bbc.co.uk/ic/items/expenses-100401.html and, later today, for BBC Resources Ltd at http://resources.gateway.bbc.co.uk/hrshared/expenses/index.html

I hope everyone accepts that we*ve listened to the genuine concerns expressed by staff and we have changed the new policy as a result.

Yours, Greg

PS. I see from this weekend's papers that I am clamping down on BBC people going to awards dinners. This is certainly not the case for those who are nominated as we should celebrate our successes. However I am concerned at the ever increasing number of awards - and awards dinners - which are being created. Many of these are designed simply to make money for the organisers. The danger of creating more and more awards ceremonies is that they will undervalue the awards which do matter and which we will continue to support.

Issued by Russell Grossman Head of Internal Communications Third Floor, London Broadcasting House LONDON W1A 1AA

fields.headline: Netherlands prepares to legalise euthanasia
fields.trailText: The Dutch upper house is due to vote tonight on whether to approve a bill allowing doctors to help patients end their lives.
fields.body:
The Netherlands is today preparing to become the first country in the world to legalise euthanasia.

The Dutch upper house is due to vote tonight on whether to give final approval to a bill allowing doctors to help patients end their lives.

The Netherlands government has argued that the new legislation will hardly change the current practice of mercy killings. The justice minister, Benk Korthals, said the bill formalises guidelines adopted in 1993, under which doctors have been assisting suicides with tacit approval.

Under the strict limitations of the new law, a patient would have to be undergoing irremediable and unbearable suffering, be aware of all other medical options and have sought a second professional opinion.

The request would have to be made voluntarily, persistently and independently while the patient is of sound mind. Doctors are not supposed to suggest it as an option.

The new law also would allow patients to leave a written request for euthanasia, giving doctors the right to use their own discretion when patients become too physically or mentally ill to decide for themselves. Cases would be reviewed by an independent commission to ensure the guidelines were followed.

After 30 years of public debate on euthanasia, the lower house passed the bill in November by a vote of 104-40. The new legislation is expected to be passed by the senate, albeit with a narrower margin.

The bill has faced opposition from anti-euthanasia groups both in the Netherlands and elsewhere. Protesters gathered outside government offices today as the 75-seat senate reconvened ahead of this evening's vote. The upper house has been swamped with more than 60,000 letters in the weeks preceding the debate, most of them urging the legislators to vote against the bill.

Germany's justice minister, Hertha Daeubler-Gmelin, has questioned the idea of mercy killings, saying it involves "the decision of a third person on the death of a human being".

Speaking in favour of the bill when the debate began yesterday, Diana de Wolff, of the Greens party, said the law will "codify a practice which has a very broad consensus", claiming that the Netherlands would "even remain on the conservative side of that consensus".

fields.bodyText: The Netherlands is today preparing to become the first country in the world to legalise euthanasia. The Dutch upper house is due to vote tonight on whether to give final approval to a bill allowing doctors to help patients end their lives. The Netherlands government has argued that the new legislation will hardly change the current practice of mercy killings. The justice minister, Benk Korthals, said the bill formalises guidelines adopted in 1993, under which doctors have been assisting suicides with tacit approval. Under the strict limitations of the new law, a patient would have to be undergoing irremediable and unbearable suffering, be aware of all other medical options and have sought a second professional opinion. The request would have to be made voluntarily, persistently and independently while the patient is of sound mind. Doctors are not supposed to suggest it as an option. The new law also would allow patients to leave a written request for euthanasia, giving doctors the right to use their own discretion when patients become too physically or mentally ill to decide for themselves. Cases would be reviewed by an independent commission to ensure the guidelines were followed. After 30 years of public debate on euthanasia, the lower house passed the bill in November by a vote of 104-40. The new legislation is expected to be passed by the senate, albeit with a narrower margin. The bill has faced opposition from anti-euthanasia groups both in the Netherlands and elsewhere. Protesters gathered outside government offices today as the 75-seat senate reconvened ahead of this evening's vote. The upper house has been swamped with more than 60,000 letters in the weeks preceding the debate, most of them urging the legislators to vote against the bill. Germany's justice minister, Hertha Daeubler-Gmelin, has questioned the idea of mercy killings, saying it involves "the decision of a third person on the death of a human being". Speaking in favour of the bill when the debate began yesterday, Diana de Wolff, of the Greens party, said the law will "codify a practice which has a very broad consensus", claiming that the Netherlands would "even remain on the conservative side of that consensus". fields.headline: Future close to selling Business 2.0
fields.trailText:
5pm: Future Network remained tight-lipped today following reports it is selling the title to Time, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 9: Future Network courts buyers for top title
fields.body:
Business 2.0 owner Future Network remained tight-lipped today following reports in the US it is close to selling the ailing magazine to Time.

A Future spokeswoman was unable to confirm reports a deal is to be completed "within days".

Time's US office also declined to comment.

Meanwhile, staff at Business 2.0's London office have asked Future to keep them informed of developments but are being kept in the dark.

According to US reports, Time is planning to merge Business 2.0 with its own title eCompany Now.

But it is believed the sale may be abandoned if it is not concluded imminently.

Consumer magazine publisher Conde Nast and computer specialist Ziff Davis have also been suggested as potential buyers.

Future is reported to be asking just over £50m for the business, which it wants to offload after suffering a series of profit warnings a plummeting stock price.

Business 2.0 is one of several "new industry" magazines put up for sale following the downturn in the technology and new media industries.

Red Herring and the Industry Standard Europe are both believed to be talking to buyers.

The Industry Standard Europe, which was launched six months ago by parent company Standard Media International, has said it would welcome investment from a European company.

Meanwhile, the Economist has emerged as the most likely purchaser for Red Herring, which has made several redundancies over the past few months.

fields.headline: Labour candidate fined
fields.trailText:
A prospective parliamentary candidate for the Labour party was today fined a total of £500 for illegally obtaining and using
information from a council database for political purposes.
fields.body:
A prospective parliamentary candidate for the Labour party was today fined a total of £500 for illegally obtaining and using information from a council database for political purposes.

Peter McDonald, 54, used data stored on Bromsgrove District Council computer for mailshots warning holders of concessionary bus passes that they could be scrapped if his Conservative rivals were elected in the 1999 local elections.

The £25,000-a-year college lecturer, who represents the Uffdown and Waseley ward on the Tory-led local authority and Rubery on Worcestershire county council, pleaded guilty to two charges of misuse of the Data Protection Act 1984.

Fining him £250 for each offence and ordering him to pay £780 in costs, chairman of the bench Cliff Weston said: "This is clearly a case where there has been a breach of trust."

Peter Wiseman, appearing for the information commissioner, Elizabeth France, told Redditch magistrates court that McDonald used his then-position as chairman of the local authority's financial services committee to obtain the information.

He passed on the list to Labour Party organiser Martin Angus. "Subsequent to his passing on the information, the 4,000 or so names that were appearing on the list were circulated on a mailshot which suggested that the political opponents of Mr McDonald, if elected, might well put their concessionary fares in some jeopardy," Mr Wiseman said.

Mr Wiseman added that it was "ironic" that McDonald used the council database as the Labour Party was also a registered data user and he could have compiled the mailshot from its records. Susan Snow, defending, told the court that the offences should be seen in context.

"Two pensioners have complained and quite understandably. It's regrettable they felt upset but that's the measure of the case. They, themselves, accept that they are personal friends of Mr McDonald's political opponent," she said.

The offences were a "technical mischief", she continued, and her client, had accepted full responsibility for his mistake. McDonald is to stand against sitting Conservative MP for Bromsgrove Julie Kirkbride in the next election.

webTitle: China and US continue spy plane standoff

fields.headline: China and US continue spy plane standoff
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: The war of words between the US and China over the stranded American spy plane and its 24 crew continued today with neither side appearing willing to break the deadlock.
fields.body:
The war of words between the US and China over the stranded American spy plane and its 24 crew continued today with neither side appearing willing to break the deadlock.

Zhu Bangzao, a senior foreign ministry official travelling with the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, in Argentina, repeated China's demand for an apology, which the US says is uncalled for.

Mr Zhu said the US should "respond appropriately". He added: "If they don't it's going to make things difficult. If they do, it's going to help resolve the problem."

American diplomats are seeking a way to express sympathy to China's satisfaction without making an outright apology.

The row erupted after a US surveillance plane collided with a Chinese fighter jet on April 1. The US plane made an emergency landing on the Chinese island of Hainan but the Chinese aircraft crashed and the pilot, who evacuated the jet, is missing presumed dead.

US Brigadier General Neal Sealock's had his fifth meeting today with the 24 Americans, who US officials have been careful to avoid calling hostages.

He said the crew members are aware of the stand-off that is detaining them. "We discussed the emotions on both sides," he said. "They realise it is a political situation."

As well as seeking an apology, the Chinese government has also demand that the US halt surveillance flights near its coast.

The White House said neither demand was warranted, and the US president, George Bush, warned anew last night that US-China relations could suffer without a resolution soon.

"There is a point - the longer it goes - there's a point at which our relations with China could become damaged," he said.

Mr Bush expressed regret last Friday for the loss and presumed death of the pilot. He also sent a letter to the pilot's wife, expressing similar sentiments.

The secretary of state, Colin Powell, said on Sunday the administration was "sorry" for the pilot's loss - the closest the US has come to an apology. China gave no direct reaction to Mr Powell's statement.

Mr Bush, who is hoping to keep public and congressional support behind him, said: "We've got every diplomatic channel open," but added, "diplomacy takes time."

Mr Bush urged patience, aiming his remarks at lawmakers who have stepped up their anti-China rhetoric and begun to question his handling of the situation.

Robert Torricelli, the Democratic senator of New Jersey asked "whether it is appropriate to have both an ambassador and hostages in the same country."

Polls show American voters support Mr Bush's leadership on China, but senior Republicans said the goodwill could erode if the standoff continues.

fields.headline: French rein in 'brutal' M&S
fields.standfirst: Troubled retailer's shares fall as Paris court rules closure of stores illegal
fields.trailText: A Paris court yesterday ordered Marks & Spencer to suspend its planned closure of 18 French stores, inflicting further humiliation on the retailer following the sales and profits decline revealed this weekend in documents leaked to the Guardian.
fields.byline: Paul Webster  in Paris and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
A Paris court yesterday ordered Marks & Spencer to suspend its planned closure of 18 French stores, inflicting further humiliation on the retailer following the sales and profits decline revealed this weekend in documents leaked to the Guardian.

Shares fell as much as 5% early yesterday in anticipation of a wave of profit downgrades by City analysts after the documents revealed that M&S's own forecasts were for £430m, lower than the City expected. But, by the close, the shares recovered some of the losses to end 2.75p lower at 260.25p.

One analyst said: "In some ways the lower profit forecasts by M&S are not as embarrassing as the in-fighting among management."

The document seen by the Guardian was received by only a small group of M&S's senior management, led by chairman and chief executive Luc Vandevelde who is facing opposition from shareholders about a £650,000 bonus.

M&S defended its decision not to update the stock market officially on its trading to the year to the end of March by saying: "We've issued two trading statements since that leaked report [was prepared]."

The company's problems are only just beginning in France where the courts yesterday ordered it to begin talks with unions over redundancy and compensation that could delay the closure date this year.

Union representatives, backed by prime minister Lionel Jospin and labour minister Elisabeth Guigou, were told by high court judge Catherine Taillendier that the company's Baker Street management had not respected laws on worker rights. This included compulsory consultation with workers on impending restructuring plans even before the stock exchange is informed, the basis of a proposed EU directive which would force British companies to follow French-style laws. M&S announced the surprise plan to close all its European stores, employing 4,390 staff, last month.

The French management were informed by email and fax, contravening local law in which staff have to be told first, opening the way to talks. What Mr Jospin denounced as "brutal" methods by Mr Vandevelde sparked customer sympathy for staff and a buying rush which doubled sales at Paris's Boulevard Hausmann store employing 470 people.

Socialist party officials have picketed the store and today staff will talk to the Communist party chief, Robert Hué, whose movement is planning nationwide demonstrations with other left-wing groups.

While the M&S staff in France fear for jobs it emerged yesterday that French retailer Pinault-Printemps-Redoute is expressing an interest in taking over some of the chain's French and European stores and would take on employees.

Mr Jospin is hoping to exploit the M&S crisis to deflect domestic pressure. He wants to accelerate the introduction of the EU directive and distract public attention from a two-week rail strike and demonstrations over the closure of plants belonging to processed food group Danône.

Mr Vandevelde told French newspaper Le Monde at the weekend that there would no going back on the closure plan although he would be prepared to consult staff if he was ordered to by the court.

webTitle: Labour must remember that violence begins at home

fields.headline: Labour must remember that violence begins at home
fields.standfirst: The home secretary has pledged to act on violent crime, should Labour win a second term.  But, argues Clare Sparks, the government's approach ignores the fact that women and children are more likely to fall prey to attacks in their own home rather than on the street
fields.trailText: The home secretary has pledged to act on violent crime, should Labour win a second term. But, argues Clare Sparks, the government's approach ignores the fact that women and children are more likely to fall prey to attacks in their own home rather than on the street.
fields.body:
The furore last week over the compensation payment to the parents of Damilola Taylor once again brought his horrific murder to the front of our minds.

The impact his killing had on public opinion is not lost on home secretary Jack Straw. The government has made clear that a significant theme of its second term will be a focus on violent crime - at the start of the year, Mr Straw unveiled his violent crime action plan in which he set out ways in which violent crime and the fear of it would be addressed.

But is this focus on street violence the right approach? The case of Damilola, like that of Sarah Payne, was unusual in the fact that it appears that both were murdered by non-family members. However, they were in the minority: of the 90 or so children who are killed in Britain annually, around 80 are murdered by a relative.

Mr Straw's approach ignores the reality that children and women are far more likely to be victims of violence in their own home than in the street. One in four violent crimes involve people in domestic relationships with a further 43% occurring between people who know each other. Incredibly, no less than a quarter of women experience domestic violence at some point in their lives.

So if violent crime is rightly to be a priority, policy must pay particular attention to violence that occurs in the home. Yet it remains the poor relation in terms of spending - just £7m of the £400m crime reduction programme budget has been allocated to addressing domestic violence.

The extent of domestic violence is disguised by the fact that statistics on violence against adults, children and older people are collected separately; as a result, the policies devised to tackle the problem are disjointed.

But the government's failure to give family violence priority really reflects its reticence to be seen to interfere in family life. It knows that the public is highly resistant to interventions from what it perceives as the "nanny state". It also seems to be the case that, to the public in general, a certain level of violence appears to be considered acceptable.

However, the government forgets that addressing violence within the home is key to addressing violent crime more broadly. Severe physical punishment of children is known to have a direct link to anti-social behaviour in later life.

Yet 14% of parents are known to hit their children with an implement, and it must be damaging that half of children in families experiencing domestic violence witnessed the abuse of their mother and/or personally experienced violence from the same man. One third of the children in such situations tried to protect their mother.

The government is failing to recognise the significance of connections between violence in the home and the levels of violence in wider society. The Metropolitan police are so concerned about the issue that they, together with several support groups, are campaigning for domestic violence to be considered an aggravating factor when offenders are sentenced for a violent crime. The Met's experience of dealing with racism in this way has persuaded them that this can make a real impact in influencing opinions of judges and magistrates, as well as the general public.

Violent crime committed by strangers does merit serious attention. It has a profound effect on victims and on society more widely, so Jack Straw is right to make it a priority for a potential second term.

But as Ian Blair, deputy commissioner of the Met, said recently: "We may never begin to effectively resolve the problem of violence in society until we have begun to deal with violence in the home." Mr Straw needs to tackle head-on the problem of violence that goes on behind our front doors.

 Clare Sparks is a research fellow at the Institute for Public Policy Research

fields.headline: Catching up on children's rights
fields.standfirst: Wales has made progress on ensuring the rights of children but campaigners believe the rest of the UK is lagging far behind Europe on the matter. Alex Dobson reports
fields.trailText: Wales has made progress on ensuring the rights of children but campaigners believe the rest of the UK is lagging far behind Europe on the matter. Alex Dobson reports.
fields.body:
Leading children's rights activists are unhappy with the way the UK is championing the rights of children.

Despite a series of high profile inquiries into how children have been failed, campaigners say the UK lags behind mainland Europe. On the continent a growing number of countries have set up commissioners who have wide-ranging powers to protect the young.

Campaigners want Britain to adopt the approaches of several European countries, where the work of commissioners or ombudsmen has had a major impact on the well-being of children.

Although Wales has appointed Peter Clarke as children's commissioner there are concerns his office will lack the power to go to the heart of children's welfare. This is because he reports to the devolved assembly, which has limited powers, rather than to legislators and national policy makers at Westminster.

England, Northern Ireland and Scotland are all examining setting up their own commissioners. But progress, say campaigners, is too slow.

"Opinion polls have shown overwhelming public support for a commissioner in this country. Europe has around 15 commissioners or children's ombudsmen and they all have broad powers to work on behalf of young people," said Peter Newell, adviser to the European Network of Ombudsmen for Children.

"They vary in the way the offices operate, but a common theme is that once set up by government they are left to do whatever is necessary to further the interests of children," he added.

Details of how children's advocates work in practice across Europe show just how differently countries promote and defend young people's rights.

Trond Waage, Norway's commissioner, has a permanent staff of nine advisers and his office has a major impact on policy. Norway was the first country to appoint an ombudsman for children, 20 years ago, and has given its children's advocate broad powers. These include the ability to gain access to all public and private institutions for children; the requirement that all agencies working with children give the commissioner any information he requests, and the power to ensure legislation relating to the protection of children's interests is observed. Mr Waage said: "What is important about the role is that we take a holistic approach to the way services are provided for children. Through the inter-disciplinary team in my office we look at major issues like health, education, law and social welfare, and consider if what is being provided by the state is adequate."

"We have enormous freedom to represent children and we aim to be proactive and lead the way in Norway where children's issues are concerned.

"All over Europe now there are offices opening up and, of course, there are different models. But what is vital is that there is freedom to act independently on behalf of children. Without us, children's interests may be forgotten," Mr Waage added.

Austria's federal system has a network of nine children's ombudsmen in each of the provinces. The advocates have extensive powers to represent children. The system was set up in 1989 through child welfare laws. The ombudsmen are all independent and have special privileges under the constitution that allow them to promote children's rights in a broad range of policy areas. They can defend children's interests by reviewing upcoming legislation and work to highlight the profile of children's needs.

Iceland, too, has its own advocate for children, who works to ensure the rights and needs of young people are represented in all areas of everyday life. In practice, that is achieved by checking that all new laws are in accordance with children's interests, and monitoring international agreements Iceland has signed up to.

The Russian federation recently joined the growing number of countries across Europe in appointing a network of federal ombudsmen. Outside Europe, New Zealand and Canada have commissioners for children, and several US states are examining the idea too.

In Wales, children's groups have lobbied energetically to make sure the first children's commissioner in the UK has wide powers. "From the children's point of view, it is vital the commissioner should have direct access to Westminster in order to reach and influence policy makers and lawmakers. But because of the nature of the devolved assembly, it is going to be difficult to do that," said Mr Newell.

He is now calling for a firm commitment to setting up a commissioner to be included in the Labour party manifesto. "Progress is frustratingly slow for what is undoubtedly a popular and progressive policy, we will get there eventually but it is taking far too long," he said.

fields.headline: Sunday Mirror could face £10m fine
fields.trailText: 11am: Legal experts have warned that the Sunday Mirror faces a £10m fine and editor Colin Myler could go to jail. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Legal experts have warned the Sunday Mirror faces a £10m fine while editor Colin Myler could go to jail following its role in the collapse of the Leeds footballers' trial.

London School of Economics law professor Michael Zander today warned that the Sunday Mirror article that led to the judge discharging the jury created a "real risk" of prejudice in delivering a verdict.

It now seems inevitable the newspaper will be charged with contempt of court for publishing material that might prejudice a fair trial.

Mr Zander said the Sunday Mirror faces an "unlimited" fine and could theoretically be forced to pay the £10m cost of the trial, although that remained unlikely.

"The fine could be enormous and unlimited. I have seen reports that they could made to pay the entire bill for the case. I think that is extremely unlikely, but I think there will be a swingeing fine," he said.

"There is an outside probability of a prison sentence," he said.

Even in the unlikely event the Sunday Mirror is not charged with contempt, it faces a long haul back to respectability following yesterday's events.

The majority of national newspapers put the story on their front pages and openly questioned the judgement of the Sunday Mirror's editorial staff and its owner Trinity Mirror.

Trinity Mirror's shares fell 3% on the London Stock Exchange this morning, amid fears that a whopping fine would cause serious damage to the company's balance sheet.

The Sunday Mirror has now joined the list of newspapers that have been accused of contempt. Here are some of the other high-profile cases.

1998: The Birmingham Post and Mail was fined £20,000 for publishing an article on drug wars in the city that caused a murder trial to be halted.

1997: The Evening Standard was fined £40,000 for an article that halted the trial of IRA terrorists accused of escaping from Whitemoor prison. The judge ruled that the story, which revealed that some of the six men on trial had been convicted of terrorist crimes, was a contempt that "had a very serious effect on the administration of justice".

1994: The Sun was fined £100,000 for publishing a photograph of a defendant in a murder investigation two days before an identification parade was due to be held.

1987: The Sunday Times and the Independent were found guilty of contempt for publishing material from Peter Wright's notorious Spycatcher book at a time when injunctions were in force against the Observer and the Guardian.

Related stories
Apr 10: Trial could become TV drama

fields.headline: Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper wins Credit Suisse account
fields.trailText: 4pm: The London advertising agency beat rivals in New York and Switzerland to the £15m global account, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The London advertising agency Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper has won the £15m global advertising account for the financial services giant Credit Suisse.

Euro RSCG Worldwide, a unit of French advertising giant Havas Advertising, said its London agency had beaten New York's Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners and two Swiss agencies in the pitch for the account.

The agency will create a global advertising campaign for the company to air on television and to appear in the press and online.

The banking group will also retain its local agencies around the world to handle product promotions.

Credit Suisse Group last advertised in 1997 with a small press campaign.

webTitle: Not a lot of people know this...

fields.headline: Not a lot of people know this...
fields.trailText: No matter who knows them already, there are certain facts about sports people that we compelled to share - and end up sounding like our grandparents with it.
fields.body:
When I was a boy our family outings were greatly enlivened by the presence of my grandmother. Gran had a habit of repeating herself, unwittingly becoming a maestro of the catchphrase to rival Dick Emery or Harry Enfield. One in particular stood out. There was a large, detached house which we used to pass just about once a week, at which point my grandmother would declare, "that place used to be a pub".

A view expressed before in this column (repetition being a family trait) is that sport, like pop music, has a habit of turning us into our parents. Much as our own mothers and fathers wondered why modern singers had ceased to smile or enunciate their words properly, so we will ponder the disappearance of those Scottish wingers who scurried about looking as if they had an invisible keg of beer stuck under each arm and slide into middle age as we do so.

After watching the FA Cup semi-final on Sunday afternoon, however, I feel I may have to re-evaluate this opinion. Because during the last ten minutes of the Liverpool v Wycombe game something strange came over me. Every time Guy Whittingham touched the ball I found myself driven to announce: "he bought himself out of the army, that bloke". By the final whistle I had begun to notice that whenever Clive Tyldesley said, "Whittingham", my family would exchange conspiratorial glances and begin to giggle in anticipation. Clearly sport is turning me into my grandmother.

It is not entirely my fault, of course. There are some sports people, and Guy Whittingham is one, about whom there is a single piece of trivial information that everyone seems to know, but which they nevertheless feel compelled to share. That England's World Cup-winning full-back Ray Wilson became an undertaker, for example, or that Gary Lineker's middle name is Winston.

Quite often it is this fact, at once obscure and yet paradoxically familiar, that defines these athletes, however unjustly, in the public consciousness. In places where snooker is as unfamiliar a concept as personal grooming is to the crowd at a WWF event, I am sure some people are aware that Ronnie O'Sullivan's dad is in jail. In remote corners of the planet I will bet that when locals hear the name CB Fry they gleefully respond: "He was offered the throne of Albania, you know."

Sometimes the athlete encourages the focus. Everyone knows what Terry Marsh did outside the boxing ring because he was always touted as "The Fighting Fireman". Henry Cooper's occupation, however, remains altogether less defining simply because the heavyweight was never billed as "The Slugging Greengrocer".

In many, many more cases, though, the exact process by which the nugget of information is absorbed by so many people is obscure. It also remains unclear why some details (Nigel Mansell's role as a special constable on the Isle of Man, for instance, or that Mike Tyson breeds pigeons) penetrate the minds of the masses while others (Bob Wilson's middle name of Primrose, or the fact that Babe Ruth kept his head cool by wearing a cabbage leaf under his cap) simply bounce off.

Personally, I am seeking professional help to deal with my problem. The chances of recovery are apparently good. They say that after only a few years of strict inversion therapy I may even be able to say "Dion Dublin" without adding, "his father played with Showaddywaddy, he did".

fields.headline: Agencies line up to say 'UK is OK'
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: Three PR agencies have been shortlisted to pitch for the account to promote Britain as a holiday destination. By Julia Day.
Apr 10: British rush to holiday abroad
Mar 27: 'Bargain Britain' slashes rates to tempt tourists
Feb 27: Foot and mouth hits tourism
fields.body:
The British Tourist Authority has shortlisted three PR agencies to pitch for the account to promote Britain as a holiday destination.

The BTA's "UK is OK" campaign is part of the government's push to lure foreign tourists, especially Americans, back to Britain in the wake of the foot and mouth crisis.

Hill & Knowlton, Weber Shandwick and GCI have been shortlisted to spearhead the PR campaign.

The three agencies have been chosen because of their international capabilities, said a BTA spokesman.

The agencies will make a final presentation to the BTA on Thursday and a decision will be made by the middle of next week.

Madonna, Robbie Williams, Sir Michael Caine and Sir Elton John have all been approached by the BTA to write a paragraph endorsing the UK as part of the push to show the country is not closed for business.

The appointment of a creative advertising agency to work on trumpeting the UK as a holiday destination will not be made until the foot and mouth crisis abates.

Related stories

Mar 27: 'Bargain Britain' slashes rates to tempt tourists

fields.headline: Survivor sues rival camp
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: The makers of a hit US gameshow are suing the company behind rival show Boot Camp, alleging it is a rip-off. By Jason Deans.
Apr 4:'Nasty' Nigel in legal row over Popstars follow-up
Mar 28: Boot Camp marches to Sky One
fields.body:
When Waheed Alli and his partner Bob Geldof dreamed up a new gameshow involving an endurance test on an exotic island, they had little idea it would be the start of a reality TV frenzy.

But now the producers of Survivor are battling against what they claim is a poor imitation of their hit American show.

Survivor's US producer and broadcaster are suing the company behind rival show Boot Camp, alleging it is a rip-off.

Survivor Productions and the CBS network have filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Boot Camp broadcaster Fox and producer LMNO.

"Aside from its military setting, the premise and format of Boot Camp are virtually identical to Survivor," the lawsuit claims.

Richard Messick, the former Survivor producer who is now working for LMNO as executive producer of Boot Camp, is also named in the lawsuit, which was filed yesterday with a court in California.

Former Planet 24 owners Lord Alli, Charlie Parsons and Bob Geldof hold the rights to the Survivor format through their company Castaway Television Productions.

Last year Mr Parsons had a law suit alleging a similar copywright infringement against Big Brother creator Endemol thrown out of the Dutch courts.

But the former Planet 24 owners are not thought to be directly involved in the Survivor lawsuit launched in the US yesterday.

The Boot Camp format was originally created by Granada Media, which sold the US rights to LMNO.

The US production outfit developed the idea further and sold it on to Fox.

The runaway ratings success of Castaway on CBS last summer kick-started the reality TV boom in the US, with 50m tuning for the finale when Richard Hatch won £700,000.

The Castaway format features 16 contestants on a remote island competing in a series of mental and physical tests and voting each other off the show, until a winner emerges.

An eight-part series of Boot Camp premiered on Fox last month with an impressive 23m viewers. The show is to be screened on Sky One in the UK.

Boot Camp has 16 contestants put through a series of tests by drill instructors over several weeks, with the participants voting each other out and being whittled down until a winner of the £350,000 cash prize emerges.

Last week the owner of the Popstars format threatened to take legal action against Pop Idol creators Pearson TV over alleged similarities between the two shows.

Related stories

webTitle: Opposition mounts to Bush's domestic agenda

fields.headline: Opposition mounts to Bush's domestic agenda
fields.standfirst: Spying rows are one thing, but, as Mark Tran explains, the US president has his work cut out on the home front
fields.trailText: Spying rows are one thing, but, as Mark Tran explains, the US president has his work cut out on the home front.
fields.body:
The US-China standoff over an American spy plane may have captured the world's attention, but in Washington the business of government grinds on.

Yesterday, the Bush administration unveiled its budget, setting out its domestic agenda. It is already in trouble.

President Bush's budget fleshes out how he intends to finance his previously-stated plans to slash taxes by $1.6bn (£1.1bn).

There will be increases in education and defence - where money will be needed for the much-touted and controversial national missile defence system - but these will be offset by large cuts in areas such as healthcare, agriculture and transport.

And, having repudiated the Kyoto accord on global warming, the Bush administration could bar spending on the implementation of the treaty and also cut spending on energy conservation and environmental protection. The assault on the Clinton legacy has begun in earnest.

As the governor of Texas, Mr Bush prided himself on being able to forge deals with his democratic opponents, and that was one of his major selling points during the election campaign.

But in Washington, even republicans are baulking at his rightwing agenda. Last week, the senate - made up of 50 republicans and 50 democrats - delivered a powerful rebuke to Mr Bush.

Under its own budget plans, the senate trimmed the Bush tax cuts of $1.6bn to $1.4bn, and increased government spending by 8% - double the White House target.

Plenty of hard bargaining lies ahead, and the house of representatives has been more receptive to the Bush tax cuts, having already approved the original tax package. However, it too wants more government spending than the White House.

Moreover, with a target to shoot at, the democrats are finally stirring from their torpor. They already sense political opportunities and are preparing to tear into Mr Bush's plans to cut health benefits for veterans, slash police funding, and financially devastate energy and after-school programmes.

As much as anything else, the even split in the senate militates against any sweeping plans for change. Mr Bush has run smack into a centrist bloc of republicans and democrats that will make it very hard for him to bulldoze through his agenda, whether he's talking about the environment or his beloved national missile defence system.

More than once before, the man in the White House has found his own party to be even peskier than the opposition.

Bill Clinton discovered it when he barely squeezed through his plan to cut the budget, and also over the north American free trade agreement. Neither could have passed without republican support.

Now Mr Bush is finding it tough to whip his fellow republicans into line. As he gets deeper into budget negotiations with Congress, he may well look back on the negotiations with the Chinese as a piece of cake.

fields.headline: Reuters eyes up US rival
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Reuters has admitted an interest in bidding for parts of Bridge Information Systems, reports Dan Milmo.
Apr 4: Reuters' online float under fire
Mar 23: Reuters gains from Bridge collapse
fields.body:
Reuters has performed an about-turn and admitted an interest in bidding for parts of rival financial news service Bridge Information Systems.

The company said in a statement it was "considering submitting a bid" for certain assets of its US competitor, which recently filed for bankruptcy after building up debts of more than £500m.

Tom Glocer, chief executive of Reuters, told analysts two months ago that Bridge had not improved in "attractiveness" but has since changed his stance.

Analysts gave the thumbs-up to the move, saying Bridge would bolster Reuters's weak position in the US and remove its biggest rival in the financial information business.

The acquisition of Bridge's best assets could improve the chances of meeting that target.

fields.headline: Renew public service 'ethos' say MPs
fields.trailText: All new public sector staff should be trained in the "public service ethos" in an attempt to help revive standards and morale, a committee of MPs has said.
fields.body:
All new public sector staff should be trained in the "public service ethos" in an attempt to help revive standards and morale, a committee of MPs has said.

In a wide-ranging report, the Commons' public administration committee recommends a new public service code, stronger regional government, and a review of the "excessive and poorly coordinated" regulation of public bodies.

The committee, which is dominated by Labour MPs, says it is not enough for ministers to champion public service in an "abstract way". The public service ethos should also be "actively encouraged and positively cultivated" with "training in what the ethos of public service entails and implies".

The report says the professional qualifications of key public service occupations such as doctors, social workers and teachers should incorporate a new public service code.

This would be based on the Neill committee's seven principles of public life: selflessness, integrity, objectivity, accountability, openness, honesty and leadership.

The MPs call for a "unified public service ethos" to replace the 1990s emphasis on cutting, privatising and criticising the public sector.

Their report warns against "improper professionalism that defends its own interests and resists public scrutiny". The committee claims this was evident in a series of recent scandals including the Shipman murders, the storage of body parts at Alder Hey without consent and the inadequate protection of children by social services.

On a visit to the north-east, the committee was also struck by the over-inspection of public organisations. "We were told by the head of the crime prevention partnership that he now had "more performance indicators than police constables".

The committee's report notes: "The audit and inspection explosion carries with it the danger that process will triumph over product."

It calls for a review to cut regulation and expresses concern that more energy is going into putting out performance information than monitoring it.

The report into the organisation of government and public services also complains of the over centralism. It points out that the plethora of top down programmes can prevent the local ownership of programmes. It adds: "In a world of partnerships, zones and area-based initiatives, there can be a real problem for accountability if citizens do not know who is responsible for the programmes that impact upon them."

The committee recommends a royal commission to review the civil service. The report will add impetus to a Whitehall review, already underway, that is understood to be considering setting up new government departments for the elderly, social exclusion, and work and family.

fields.headline: How sports stars cash in on sponsorship
fields.standfirst: Highest-earning sports stars in 2000
fields.trailText: Highest-earning sports stars in 2000
fields.body:
 Tiger Woods, 25, banked £40m from endorsements alone last year. This is double his total tournament winnings, which amount to around £20m since he turned professional in 1986.

 Grand Prix ace Michael Schumacher, 35, pocketed £37m last year, including £5m from a bank for a four-inch space on his cap.

 World heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis, 34, earned £20m, mainly through prize money. His sponsorship deals with American Express and French Connection bring in an estimated £2.5m a year.

 Manchester United and England star David Beckham, 25, earned £7.3m, which included lucrative deals with Adidas and Brylcreem.

 Tennis star Anna Kournikova, 19, banked only £467,000 in prize money last year - but earned £6.7m in commercial deals with the likes of Adidas and sports bra manufacturer Berlei.

fields.headline: Nationwide strikes £12m football deal
fields.trailText: 3pm: The building society is extending its sponsorship of the Football League for another three years, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Nationwide building society is extending its contract to sponsor the Football League as part of a £12m three-year deal.

Under the deal, sponsorship revenue will rise by 33% - from £3m to £4m each season - and Nationwide will sponsor the league until the end of the 2003/04 season.

Nationwide, which also sponsors the England national team under a separate deal, has been involved with the Football League for the past five seasons.

"The league is involved through its 72 member clubs across England and Wales and that's where our branches are," said Stuart Bernau, marketing and commercial director of Nationwide.

"Over the five years we've been associated with football, our membership has grown by 50% - we now have around 10m members.

"That growth is not solely down to football but our involvement in the game has certainly increased our profile very significantly.

"It also means the money going into our new sponsorship deal works out at a cost of around 40p per member per year. In that context, considering the massive exposure we get through football, we feel it is good value for money."

Nationwide also has sponsorship agreements with the England, Scotland and Wales teams well as the Nationwide Conference and Football League clubs Swindon, Northampton and Halifax.

fields.headline: Freeserve enters the ring with Lennox Lewis deal
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Boxing fans can dial up daily coverage from Lennox Lewis's world title camp on their mobiles, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Boxing fanatics will be able to dial up punch-by-punch coverage of Lennox Lewis while he prepares for his next match, thanks to a ground-breaking deal with an internet company.

Freeserve has grabbed the internet rights to exclusive footage from Lewis's camp as he prepares for his world title fight with Hasim Kahem in South Africa on April 22.

But the company will be restricting viewership to the UK because it will only grant access to those who dial up from UK mobile phones

Freeserve is using the coverage as a pay-per-view experiment to determine whether web users will pay for exclusive content.

Its coverage will start from Thursday, when Freeserve will be broadcasting on a daily basis from Lewis's camp.

The deal with rights holder Arthur Shaw also includes interviews with Lewis, sparring contests, a meeting with Nelson Mandela and footage from the boxer's dressing room before and after the fight.

For the first time in the UK, a mobile operator will be using premium-rate text messaging services to pay for content.

Vodafone has been pulled in to enable Freeserve to charge the public for the webcasts without forcing them to use their credit cards online.

To watch the coverage, Vodafone customers just enter their mobile number on the Freeserve website and they will receive a text message (that will cost them £1) that contains the access code for the PPV content.

Customers of other mobile operators have to call a premium rate number (also costing £1 per day) to get the access codes for the Lewis web footage.

The Freeserve trial is to test the consumer reaction to payment mechanisms, at a time when internet companies are trying to make the internet pay while allaying consumer fears about entering credit card numbers online.

"This trial represents the opening of a potential additional revenue stream via webcast content," said John Pluthero, chief executive officer of Freeserve.

"This should allow Freeserve in future to enhance its existing offering by providing new discrete packages of premium and exclusive content."

The deal was brokered by Arthur Shaw, which signed a three-year agreement with Lewis for an undisclosed sum.

It is believed that Freeserve, the first British internet portal to have developed a partnership with Arthur Shaw, did not pay for the rights to screen the footage.

In addition to the guaranteed traffic an event like this will bring, Freeserve will also benefit from a split of the premium rate call revenues, after Arthur Shaw and Vodafone have taken their share.

webTitle: Dacourt: Vieira comments were a joke

fields.headline: Dacourt: Vieira comments were a joke
fields.trailText: Olivier Dacourt has said comments he made to French TV over the weekend, which suggested he lied to save Patrick Vieira from a lengthy ban and a hefty fine, were a "joke".
fields.body:
Olivier Dacourt has said comments he made to French TV over the weekend, which suggested he lied to save Patrick Vieira from a lengthy ban and a hefty fine, were a "joke".

And the Leeds midfielder has confirmed he is willing to explain his story to the FA, who earlier said they would be calling him in to justify his comments.

In an interview with French television station Telefoot on Sunday, Dacourt revealed his defence of Vieira against an FA violent conduct charge earlier this season was done to help the Arsenal star escape a potential lengthy ban. But today Dacourt insisted his comments were meant as a joke.

He said: "I will happily help the FA with any enquiry because I have no problem with the interview on French television.

"If the FA look at a video tape they will see and hear that I was joking," he added. "It was agreed before the programme began that I would talk about Patrick Vieira. Everyone knows he is my close friend.

"When they asked me about the Arsenal game I joked that I had saved Patrick from a six-match ban and a big fine. I also joked about how he telephoned me asking for a letter from me to the FA and I said 'maybe I will, maybe I won't.'

"I also joked that Patrick should send me the cheque for his lost wages and any fine. I am sorry that a joke on French television has been taken so literally in England. But I don't want my reputation tarnishing by this."

Vieira was involved in two separate incidents during Arsenal's 1-0 defeat at Elland Road in November which immediately landed him in trouble with the FA's disciplinary committee.

Although seven Arsenal players were booked during the match, Vieira was not one of them, although he was later charged after the video advisory panel reviewed footage of the game in which he was caught apparently headbutting Eirik Bakke and kicking Dacourt in the throat.

Dacourt, however, quickly wrote to the FA claiming there was no malice in the challenge - evidence which almost certainly influenced the disciplinary committee as Vieira was only handed a one-match ban and £10,000 fine.

fields.headline: Chesterfield disciplinary hearing begins
fields.trailText: A three-day disciplinary hearing into alleged financial irregularities at Chesterfield has begun at Hillsborough.
fields.body:
A three-day disciplinary hearing into alleged financial irregularities at Chesterfield has begun at Hillsborough.

The joint Football Association and Football League inquiry was launched in February into alleged irregularities at the Derbyshire club concerning payments to players and attendance figures.

Football League spokesman John Nagle said: "We have charged the club, we are not saying how many charges, but it is fair to say the charge sheet is lengthy.

"The club was given 14 days to respond, which it has, and it will now go before a panel hearing," he added.

Chesterfield are currently five points clear at the top of the Third Division and seem certain to clinch promotion to the Second.

However, the club could face a substantial points deduction if found guilty.

Swindon - who had won promotion to the old First Division - were dumped into the Third in 1990, then allowed back into the Second on appeal - after similar charges against the club were proved.

fields.headline: British rush to holidays abroad
fields.trailText:
2.45pm: Millions of Britons are booking holidays abroad in the wake of the foot and mouth crisis, reports Julia Day.
Mar 27: 'Bargain Britain' slashes rates to tempt tourists
Feb 27: Foot and mouth hits tourism
fields.body:
Millions of British holidaymakers are flocking to book holidays abroad in the wake of the foot and mouth crisis as Tony Blair struggles to lure foreign tourists back to the UK.

The Association of British Travel Agents said nearly 1.75m British holidaymakers were set to leave the country over the Easter weekend.

Many holiday operators have sold out of Easter holidays and summer bookings are very well advanced.

Sales of walking holidays abroad have reached unprecedented levels at Thomson Holidays, at a time when British walkers are frustrated by having to stick to roads in the countryside.

"We have sold out for Easter, and July and August are selling extremely well. Walking holidays have hit the roof. Interest has been much higher than last year," said a Thomson Holidays spokesman.

First Choice reports record sales for the summer and is advising holidaymakers to book as early as possible.

A spokeswoman for First Choice said it was difficult to put the bookings increase down to the foot and mouth crisis alone, but if the crisis continued it would have a significant effect.

"Foot and mouth will contribute to the increase in foreign holiday bookings if things continue as they are," said an ABTA spokesman.

He said the number of British holidaymakers travelling abroad has steadily increased for the past 10 years, but a quarter of a million more people than last year were travelling abroad for Easter.

Eurostar trains are almost fully booked for the Easter weekend. Half a million Brits are expected to travel under or over the English Channel to France, the Netherlands and Spain.

Related stories

Feb 27: Foot and mouth hits tourism

fields.headline: Local election delay clears parliament
fields.trailText: Emergency legislation delaying this year's local elections by five weeks to June 7 because of the foot and mouth crisis has cleared parliament and awaits royal assent today to become law.
fields.body:
Emergency legislation delaying this year's local elections by five weeks to June 7 because of the foot and mouth crisis has cleared parliament and awaits royal assent today to become law.

The elections bill, announced by the prime minister last week, was rushed through the Commons in one day. It received its Lords second reading after two-and-a-half hours' debate.

Last night, after a further three hours' committee stage debate, peers gave the bill an unopposed third reading. The bill delays local elections in England and Wales from May 3 and in Northern Ireland from May 16.

fields.headline: Oh no - my book's a hit in Hollywood...
fields.standfirst: Tom loved it. So did Oprah and Demi. But, as novelist  Celia Brayfield found out, getting her book made into a movie wasn't that simple
fields.trailText: Tom loved it. So did Oprah and Demi. But, as novelist Celia Brayfield found out, getting her book made into a movie wasn't that simple.
fields.body:
"Welcome to Development Hell!" said my friend in Los Angeles, sending me the story in Variety announcing that my novel had been bought for a movie. Neither of us could have predicted that Development Hell would be extended to create a special room just for me.

What is Development Hell? It's the place you get to after a film producer takes you up to a high place and shows you the world. You sign a contract giving the producer the right to make a film from your book and then you enjoy a variety of torments - another writer, or 10, may "fashion" a screenplay, a producer, or 10, may come in on the deal, your story is relocated to the nearest tax haven, your characters change race, gender and political symbolism, the casting ambitions that began with Russell Crowe refocus on Rick Moranis. Your chances of progressing to pre-production purgatory are one in 200.

A couple of years ago I wrote a novel called Heartswap and sent it to my agent, Jonathan Lloyd. It was my first full-on comedy, about two girls who set their guys a fidelity test, the plot of the opera Cosi Fan Tutte with the genders switched, relocated to millennial London. Two Christmases ago, Jonathan called to tell me that the agency's media supremo, Nick Marston, had decided the story had film potential. Christmas happened, I went to parties, met a successful British film producer and told him about my book, which he asked to see.

I relayed his interest to Nick, who explained that my book was going directly to Hollywood with no side trips to British producers. Heartswap went to CAA, Creative Artists Agency, an awesome pantheon of talent. After a month an email from CAA proposed a submission list of producers and actors. Then Nick was on the phone.

Friday, 3pm: Cruise-Wagner, Tom Cruise's production company, wanted the story for Nicole Kidman and had made a pre-emptive bid! CAA were rushing the book out. Friday, 9pm: Oprah Winfrey and Demi Moore were interested! Monday, 3pm: Cruise-Wagner upped their offer. Bidding continued until 4pm Thursday, when Heartswap was sold to Cruise-Wagner. The following Monday we were on the front page of Variety. In May the book was published and in June word came from LA that Peter Hedges, the writer of What's Eating Gilbert Grape, was doing the screenplay. Nicole Kidman and Peter Hedges are both CAA clients. When I told the British producer what had become of the book he'd asked to see, he was a little bitter.

Eight months later, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman announced their separation and I'm the first guest in the new Tom & Nicole Suite in Development Hell. If human pain weren't involved, there'd be something piquant, in a Spencer Tracy/Katherine Hepburn way, about a star and producer getting divorced and fighting a custody battle over a script.

If you look at this story from a perspective wider than that of Hello! magazine, it dramatises a problem for the British film industry. This seems to be a boom era for British writers. Helen Fielding's Bridget Jones's Diary opens this week, Nick Hornby's High Fidelity made about $30m last year, JK Rowling's Harry Potter is taking over the world, nobody can resist Joanne Harris's Chocolat and we're eagerly awaiting Deborah Moggach's Tulip Fever, Hornby's About A Boy and Louis de Bernieres's Captain Corelli's Mandolin.

In Hollywood these titles gained American gloss, lost European integrity and will now make money for their American backers, including Universal, which has invested in Working Title, the British company that produced Bridget Jones's Diary. Their profits will further enrich the American film industry. If it had been possible to keep these titles in the UK, and make them look something like movies, the British film industry would be ploughing back hundreds of millions of dollars.

We may be brilliant at creating what Variety calls "first-rate source material" but we're crap at making it work for us. While our film industry, through the Film Council, is howling for good scripts, the most promising works by British writers are not even offered to British producers. The assumption is that British producers can't match the Americans' money.

Film rights are bought in stages. The first level of investment by the producer is the option payment, which confers the right to develop the script and raise money on it. Option payments are small, but agents aim to get the maximum money up front as guarantee of the producer's intentions. Those intentions may not be honourable, as Jenny Colgan, now entertaining Guardian readers with her dispatches from LA, has learned. The British book that holds the record for its sojourn in Development Hell is Douglas Adams's Hitchiker's Guide to the Galaxy, eagerly awaited for 20 years. A producer may even buy an option to prevent a book being filmed, fearing it may damage the market for another of his or her projects.

To help British producers compete, the Film Council has set up a Development Fund, making £5m a year available for three years. "We constantly lose out to the US because all the best-selling novels are optioned by them," their spokesman admits. "Development costs cripple British producers. Paying £10,000 for an option, then £5,000 to £8,000 for a first draft of a script, means that a producer can't afford to go any further to make the script really good."

Taking an option is still a minute investment, even for a British producer; £10,000, or a Hollywood-sized £50,000, is nothing compared to the total cost of making a film - £12m to £18m in the UK, 10 times that in the US. For a writer, a story beginning with a smaller option from a sincere British producer could have a happier ending than one that began with big bucks bullshit from Hollywood.

Film is too powerful a medium to be surrendered to market forces. Our cinema is the biggest and brightest mirror we can hold up to our nature and we need it to see who we are and what we believe. The French, whose domestic audience is the same size as ours, have never consented to see themselves through American eyes, but guarded their golden stories and pumped up commercial muscle. As a result, they can spend £40m on a film and their leading producers have offices in Hollywood.

If we are ever to have a healthy film industry, our native producers must be allowed to bid for the best material. If we can regulate the export of everything from live pigs to Canova's Three Graces, we can surely find a way to give the British movie business a fair crack at our fiction bestsellers. And no, I don't know if Tom is having a thing with Penelope Cruz, or if Nicole is. Just don't ask.

 Celia Brayfield's Heartswap is published by Warner Books, price £5.99.
