Neither of us could have predicted that Development Hell would be extended to create a special room just for me. What is Development Hell? It's the place you get to after a film producer takes you up to a high place and shows you the world. You sign a contract giving the producer the right to make a film from your book and then you enjoy a variety of torments - another writer, or 10, may "fashion" a screenplay, a producer, or 10, may come in on the deal, your story is relocated to the nearest tax haven, your characters change race, gender and political symbolism, the casting ambitions that began with Russell Crowe refocus on Rick Moranis. Your chances of progressing to pre-production purgatory are one in 200. A couple of years ago I wrote a novel called Heartswap and sent it to my agent, Jonathan Lloyd. It was my first full-on comedy, about two girls who set their guys a fidelity test, the plot of the opera Cosi Fan Tutte with the genders switched, relocated to millennial London. Two Christmases ago, Jonathan called to tell me that the agency's media supremo, Nick Marston, had decided the story had film potential. Christmas happened, I went to parties, met a successful British film producer and told him about my book, which he asked to see. I relayed his interest to Nick, who explained that my book was going directly to Hollywood with no side trips to British producers. Heartswap went to CAA, Creative Artists Agency, an awesome pantheon of talent. After a month an email from CAA proposed a submission list of producers and actors. Then Nick was on the phone. Friday, 3pm: Cruise-Wagner, Tom Cruise's production company, wanted the story for Nicole Kidman and had made a pre-emptive bid! CAA were rushing the book out. Friday, 9pm: Oprah Winfrey and Demi Moore were interested! Monday, 3pm: Cruise-Wagner upped their offer. Bidding continued until 4pm Thursday, when Heartswap was sold to Cruise-Wagner. The following Monday we were on the front page of Variety. In May the book was published and in June word came from LA that Peter Hedges, the writer of What's Eating Gilbert Grape, was doing the screenplay. Nicole Kidman and Peter Hedges are both CAA clients. When I told the British producer what had become of the book he'd asked to see, he was a little bitter. Eight months later, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman announced their separation and I'm the first guest in the new Tom & Nicole Suite in Development Hell. If human pain weren't involved, there'd be something piquant, in a Spencer Tracy/Katherine Hepburn way, about a star and producer getting divorced and fighting a custody battle over a script. If you look at this story from a perspective wider than that of Hello! magazine, it dramatises a problem for the British film industry. This seems to be a boom era for British writers. Helen Fielding's Bridget Jones's Diary opens this week, Nick Hornby's High Fidelity made about $30m last year, JK Rowling's Harry Potter is taking over the world, nobody can resist Joanne Harris's Chocolat and we're eagerly awaiting Deborah Moggach's Tulip Fever, Hornby's About A Boy and Louis de Bernieres's Captain Corelli's Mandolin. In Hollywood these titles gained American gloss, lost European integrity and will now make money for their American backers, including Universal, which has invested in Working Title, the British company that produced Bridget Jones's Diary. Their profits will further enrich the American film industry. If it had been possible to keep these titles in the UK, and make them look something like movies, the British film industry would be ploughing back hundreds of millions of dollars. We may be brilliant at creating what Variety calls "first-rate source material" but we're crap at making it work for us. While our film industry, through the Film Council, is howling for good scripts, the most promising works by British writers are not even offered to British producers. The assumption is that British producers can't match the Americans' money. Film rights are bought in stages. The first level of investment by the producer is the option payment, which confers the right to develop the script and raise money on it. Option payments are small, but agents aim to get the maximum money up front as guarantee of the producer's intentions. Those intentions may not be honourable, as Jenny Colgan, now entertaining Guardian readers with her dispatches from LA, has learned. The British book that holds the record for its sojourn in Development Hell is Douglas Adams's Hitchiker's Guide to the Galaxy, eagerly awaited for 20 years. A producer may even buy an option to prevent a book being filmed, fearing it may damage the market for another of his or her projects. To help British producers compete, the Film Council has set up a Development Fund, making £5m a year available for three years. "We constantly lose out to the US because all the best-selling novels are optioned by them," their spokesman admits. "Development costs cripple British producers. Paying £10,000 for an option, then £5,000 to £8,000 for a first draft of a script, means that a producer can't afford to go any further to make the script really good." Taking an option is still a minute investment, even for a British producer; £10,000, or a Hollywood-sized £50,000, is nothing compared to the total cost of making a film - £12m to £18m in the UK, 10 times that in the US. For a writer, a story beginning with a smaller option from a sincere British producer could have a happier ending than one that began with big bucks bullshit from Hollywood. Film is too powerful a medium to be surrendered to market forces. Our cinema is the biggest and brightest mirror we can hold up to our nature and we need it to see who we are and what we believe. The French, whose domestic audience is the same size as ours, have never consented to see themselves through American eyes, but guarded their golden stories and pumped up commercial muscle. As a result, they can spend £40m on a film and their leading producers have offices in Hollywood. If we are ever to have a healthy film industry, our native producers must be allowed to bid for the best material. If we can regulate the export of everything from live pigs to Canova's Three Graces, we can surely find a way to give the British movie business a fair crack at our fiction bestsellers. And no, I don't know if Tom is having a thing with Penelope Cruz, or if Nicole is. Just don't ask.  Celia Brayfield's Heartswap is published by Warner Books, price £5.99.

fields.headline: Mandela's toughest challenge
fields.standfirst: The iconic former South African president is tackling a desperate situation in Burundi, says Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: The iconic former South African president is tackling a desperate situation in Burundi, says Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
As popular as he is, Nelson Mandela has rarely been afraid to defend the unpopular. Hence his willingness to put Colonel Muammar Gadafy's claim that the convicted Lockerbie bomber is innocent to Tony Blair.

And, while the Americans may hold Mr Mandela in even greater reverence than he is accorded in his homeland, which does not stop him defending Washington's arch foe - Fidel Castro.

But all of this is relatively straightforward compared to the most difficult task, and least noticed beyond Africa's borders, that Mr Mandela has taken on since he retired as president in 1999.

His iconic status, and reputation for forgiveness and reconciliation, led him into the snake pit of Burundi's civil war.

As in neighbouring Rwanda, a little more than one-tenth of Burundi's population is Tutsi. The vast majority is Hutu. But there the comparison ends.

The Tutsis have ruled Burundi with a heavy and often violent hand since independence four decades ago. Free elections were eventually held in 1993, and a moderate candidate with some of Mr Mandela's qualities was elected as Burundi's first Hutu president.

Within months, he was assassinated by Tutsi soldiers - almost certainly with the blessing of their superiors - and Burundi was kicked into a civil war that has cost hundreds of thousands of lives.

Some call it a slow genocide, compared to the massacres in Rwanda where close to one million people died in 10 weeks.

Mr Mandela was appointed mediator in 1999 after the death of the former negotiator, Tanzania's ex-president, Julius Nyerere. The South African statesman has made considerably more progress than his predecessor, who was viewed with great suspicion by the Tutsis, who he once openly likened to the 'boers'.

Mr Mandela played a crucial role in persuading the Burundian military government and 18 other players to sign a framework peace accord in August after months of negotiation.

But he has, so far, failed to get a key rebel group - the Forces for the Defence of Democracy (FDD) - to join the talks.

The war continues, with another rebel group occupying parts of the capital, Bujumbura, for a fortnight last month.

One reason for choosing Mr Mandela as mediator was the evident similarities between Burundi and the old South Africa. The tiny Central African nation is as ethnically divided as the apartheid state ever was, even if it does not have the same laws.

The army, civil service and government are dominated by Tutsis, who often hold the Hutu majority in contempt. It is a common refrain among Tutsis to say that Burundi is not ready for democracy because Hutus are too ignorant to vote.

But overcoming the fears and prejudices inherent in such attitudes is even more difficult than in South Africa.

In his homeland, Mr Mandela was able to persuade whites to put their trust in him, the law and a shared future with black people. Perhaps most importantly, while whites were surrendering political power, they still clung to the economic benefits they had built up over decades - centuries even - of discrimination and oppression.

Burundi is wholly different. Fear clouds every issue. The Tutsi minority is understandably loath to surrender control of the only source of protection - the army. Without domination of the military, Tutsis fear they will simply be massacred.

Yet Hutus view the army as an instrument of murder and repression, particularly given its role in murdering Burundi's only elected president and the massacres that followed.

Amnesty International has just released a report condemning the army and other security forces for widespread torture.

Political power also means jobs. Although Afrikaners in particular among South African whites relied heavily on the state to provide employment in the apartheid years, most were still well educated enough to find their way in the private sector when the government was no longer an automatic source of jobs.

In Burundi, the government is the source of almost all employment. The state provides around two-thirds of all steady work in the country, and whoever controls the government controls those jobs.

Tutsis say that, to surrender political power will cost them their livelihoods and maybe even their lives.

In South Africa, the majority of whites were persuaded they had more to lose than gain by clinging to an unworkable and unjust system.

In Burundi, Mr Mandela has only partially succeeded in persuading a suspicious Tutsi elite of the same.

webTitle: Council faces £260,000 loss over closure of poverty group

fields.headline: Council faces £260,000 loss over closure of poverty group
fields.trailText: Exclusive: A local authority that spent nearly £400,000 sponsoring a national lobby group set up by one of its own councillors could find itself more than £250,000 out of pocket after the pressure group closed down following allegations of a major financial scandal.Paul Humphries reports.
fields.body:
A local authority that spent nearly £400,000 sponsoring a national lobby group set up by one of its own councillors could find itself more than £250,000 out of pocket after the pressure group closed down following allegations of a major financial scandal.

Since the National Local Government Forum Against Poverty (NLGFAP) was voluntarily wound up last year, Rotherham council has been trying to recoup £260,000 it claims it is owed by the pressure group.

A new lobby group that took over from the anti-poverty forum - Local Government Against Poverty (LGAP) - claims it does not have a financial obligation to pay off the outstanding bill. The South Yorkshire authority is now seeking legal advice in pursuit of the money.

Rotherham had helped finance the cost of NLGFAP, which was set up in 1994 to help local authorities develop anti-poverty strategies. It was the lead authority on the forum, and was the brainchild of Rotherham councillor Garvin Reed.

The council ploughed more than £370,00 into NLGFAP, which had its headquarters in the South Yorkshire town. But in 1998, a police investigation began following allegations of a financial scandal within the forum.

At one point 150 councils from throughout England, Scotland and Wales were members of NLGFAP. But as the investigation progressed when concerns mounted, authorities began to drop out.

Last year, when it was decided to wind up the forum, membership had halved.

LGAP succeeded NLGFAP last year with the support of around 40 councils, and it is from the new organisation that Rotherham is attempting to recover its outstanding debt.

Bob Wilkinson, chairman of LGAP and a Vale of Glamorgan councillor who took over as national convenor of the old poverty forum when Mr Reed stood down, said LGAP has no financial responsibility to the council.

He said: "Who arranged for the underwriting of the forum? I didn't. That was negotiated by a small group of people and the majority didn't have any knowledge of it."

Tony Powell, a member of Cornwall county council and Caradon district council who is helping to administer the new poverty group in an individual capacity, said Rotherham's debt had been reduced by more than £100,000 in three years by payments from NLGFAP.

Both Vale of Glamorgan and Wakefield councils were still owed £16,000 each for the secondment of staff but, with the exception of the money owing Rotherham, all other external debts of NLGFAP had been paid.

Mr Powell said: "The outstanding debt to Rotherham is totally outside the remit of the new organisation. We have stated we have no liability to the debt."

He said he was not prepared to reveal if the new poverty group had funds transferred over from the now defunct forum.

A spokeswoman for Rotherham MBC said the council was seeking detailed legal advice on recovering money from the former NLGFAP.

She said: "The forum suspended debt repayments in May 2000 and we have discussed the issues in detail with the new body, which replaced the original forum, and we have also consulted with the council's district auditors. We are now putting together more information for counsel."

Mr Reed, the former national convenor and finance chair of the organisation, has been charged with conspiracy to defraud following a two-year investigation by fraud officers from South Yorkshire police, codenamed Operation Fear.

Two former Rotherham council officials, Bob Bone and John Cook, who were seconded to work for the forum, were also charged with conspiracy to defraud. All three will appear before Rotherham magistrates on April 12.

Labour councillor Reed became deputy leader of Rotherham council during his period as head of the NLGFAP. He stood down from that position when the investigation started but continues to sit as a councillor, although he is suspended by the Labour party pending the outcome of the investigations.

webTitle: Politics on the web - the story in links

fields.headline: Politics on the web - the story in links
fields.standfirst: The delay to the general election has left Westminster-watchers feeling all dressed up with nowhere to go. Here's our guide to how they can get their fix on the net
fields.trailText: The delay to the general election has left Westminster-watchers feeling all dressed up with nowhere to go. Here's our guide to how they can get their fix on the net.
fields.body:
1. Ann Widdecombe's political beliefs may be worrying - but not as frightening as her website. As usual Ann has ignored all the advice and published as many pictures of herself as possible, including a fetching one of her and a pot-bellied pig. Even weirder is williamhague.com.

2. Never shy of self-publicity, especially around election time, 231 MPs have documented what they have achieved in parliament since 1997. We can only assume the other 428 MPs have been snoozing on the backbenches.

3. One of the best things about politics and the net is that chat rooms allow political debate to crop up in the most unexpected of places. A Britney Spears fan site, for instance.

4. But some sites, such as faxyourmp.com do enable people to get the message across to their MPs.

5. People won't be able to vote online in the next election.

6. But you can register to vote online. Even if you don't plan to vote, it will improve your credit reference.

7. Trouble sleeeping? Why not log on to parliament and read verbatim the latest debates. That should soon sort it.

8. If you want information on how to get a passport but can't find Keith Vaz's phone number, go to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.

9. Treat the mother-in-law to a William Hague baseball cap at Politico's. Blair is also available in Labour red.

10. And if you've not had enough fun yet, why not play our quiz? It's the most fun the Whitehall mandarins ever have.

webTitle: Scotsman may recall man in Washington

fields.headline: Scotsman may recall man in Washington
fields.trailText: 11am: The Scotsman may recall its US correspondent amid speculation it is cutting costs, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Scotsman is considering recalling its Washington correspondent, Robert Tait, from the US amid speculation the paper is tightening its belt.

John McGurk, group editorial director of the Scotsman, confirmed the paper was "looking at the options" for keeping Mr Tait in Washington.

He said the move was consistent with an overall strategy of "allocating our resources more efficiently", rather than a sign that the paper was scaling back.

The possible relocation follows a whittling away of the paper's foreign coverage over the past year.

Mr Tait is the last remaining foreign correspondent working for the Scotsman, which has already got rid of its full-time correspondents at Brussels, Moscow and Middle East desks.

Its foreign coverage has traditionally been a mark of prestige for the paper and has been maintained in spite of growing demands on the paper's budget.

In particular, it has been regarded as a symbol of the Scotsman's role as Scotland's national, as opposed to regional, newspaper.

webTitle: In brief: Marlon Brando perfect match for Pope John XXIII

fields.headline: Marlon Brando perfect match for Pope John XXIII
fields.standfirst: Plus: Rachael Leigh Hunt baits serial killer; Schindler's List scribe endures Shackleton biopic; Rachel Weisz joins Hugh Grant in Nick Hornby's About a Boy
fields.trailText: Plus: Rachael Leigh Hunt baits serial killer; Schindler's List scribe endures Shackleton biopic; Rachel Weisz joins Hugh Grant in Nick Hornby's About a Boy
fields.body:
 The Italian state television network has asked Marlon Brando to portray Pope John XXIII in a TV film. "We approached Mr Brando because he was considered as the ideal candidate for the role. Facially, there are some resemblances between the two," a spokesperson for the channel is reported as saying. The Vatican, which beatified Pope John (1958-63) in September, is currently making preparations for his canonisation.

 Rachael Leigh Cook will star in and co-executive produce the indie comic romance Invisible Girl for first-time writer-director Max Hoffman. The film is about a young woman who no one notices until she uses herself as bait to capture a serial killer.

 Schindler's List scribe Steven Zaillian is to work on the screenplay for Endurance, a film about Ernest Shackleton's disastrous mission to the South Pole. Wolfgang Petersen (The Perfect Storm) will direct and produce the film which centres on Shackleton's 1915 expedition to Antarctica, which met with near-ruin when Shackleton's ship, the Endurance, was trapped in the ice in the Weddell Sea for 11 months.

 Rachel Weisz has been confirmed to star, with Toni Collette and Hugh Grant, in the Nick Hornby adaptation About a Boy. The movie is to be produced by Robert De Niro.

webTitle: Tim Burton's simian sex scene too hot for censors

fields.headline: Tim Burton's simian sex scene too hot for censors
fields.trailText: A passionate scene between an ape and a human in the remake of Planet of the Apes has been cut so that the film will not be given a certificate that will stop children from seeing it
fields.body:
Tim Burton's remake of Planet Of The Apes has been censored. According to reports, producers 20th Century Fox have quashed a scene involving a human Mark Wahlberg and an apeish Helena Bonham Carter consummating their love.

Special effects guru Rick Baker, a veteran of the Star Wars saga, told the US Daily News that Burton had: "Wanted to have sexual tension between [the two]. Tim wanted her to be sexually attractive to [human] men." But when the final cut is released in cinemas, viewers will see nothing more bestial than a chaste kiss.

A Fox insider told the newspaper: "Fox thought American audiences would recoil and that the movie would get an NC-17 rating. That would kill the movie for kids." The studio continues to deny that it has wielded the axe over Burton's simian-human sex sequences, but a "friend" of Bonham Carter confirms that: "The scene was in there originally, but the studio freaked out." The movie is scheduled for an August release in the UK.

The studio continues to deny that it has wielded the axe over Burton's simian-human sex sequences, but a "friend" of Bonham Carter confirms that: "The scene was in there originally, but the studio freaked out." The movie is scheduled for an August release in the UK.

webTitle: Burley and Houllier clash ahead of Champions League showdown

fields.headline: Burley and Houllier clash ahead of Champions League showdown
fields.trailText: When it comes to Ipswich Town, even the most broad-minded football supporter suffers from myopia. Nobody can really see the Tractor Boys qualifying for the Champions League, despite the fact the they lie fourth in the Premiership, just one point behind Leeds with a game in hand.
fields.body:
When it comes to Ipswich Town, even the most broad-minded football supporter suffers from myopia. Nobody can really see the Tractor Boys qualifying for the Champions League, despite the fact the they lie fourth in the Premiership, just one point behind Leeds with a game in hand.

A win against a weary Liverpool side tonight will set those doubters straight. It would put Ipswich six points clear of Gerard Houllier's men, with a relatively easy run-in against Newcastle, Middlesbrough, Coventry, Charlton, Manchester City and Derby to follow.

No wonder Ipswich manager George Burley is sounding so upbeat. "If we finish third it's because we deserve it," he said. "Of course we are good enough and then it's a case of 'can we compete in the Champions League?'"

Unlike Houllier, who has bemoaned his side's heavy schedule, Burley refuses to accept that players who are winning games get tired. Ipswich have three games in six days compared to Liverpool's four in eight, but Burley said: "It's one of those things, you have to get on with it.

"The boys have shown great consistency to be fourth in the league at the moment," he added. "We are looking lively, fresh and raring to go, really. The players are hungry to finish as high as possible."

Liverpool, who will fly from Speke airport to Stansted today to avoid a tiring coach journey, are still unhappy about having to play their third game in six days.

Houllier hardly disguised his attitude when he told reporters: "It's not the best date to play them, and they knew that, and that's probably why they put pressure on the Premier League to play the game on that day.

"But we will cope, I'm very much looking forward to the game. It's very important for our ambitions for a Champions League spot, and I can tell you we will be up for it."

They will have to be. Although Liverpool have games in hand on most of their rivals they face a tough fortnight - with matches against Leeds, Everton, Barcelona and Spurs coming and going within the space of twelve days. Houllier's side know that if they stumble now they might not to be able to catch up.

Liverpool are definitely without Vladimir Smicer and Nick Barmby, and could be without Steven Gerrard who, despite only coming on as a second-half substitute on Sunday, has reported some muscle stiffness. But Emile Heskey, who was rested for the first-half of Liverpool's game against Ipswich in December, will almost certainly start.

Ipswich won that game 1-0, and you sense that Houllier is keen to get his revenge.

"Ipswich were very lucky when they were at Anfield," he said. "We had about eight open chances and missed them all, it's not as if we hadn't created any chances. I think they were extremely lucky."

And Houllier's annoyance was further underlined when he was asked to comment on Ipswich's spectacular success this season.

He replied: "I'm very focused on my team, I don't like to speak about the opposition, particularly about that opposition."

fields.headline: Philips chief in insider-dealing probe
fields.trailText: 1.30am: The head of Philips Electronics is to be investigated after he bought shares in Endemol, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The chief executive of Philips Electronics is to face an insider-dealing probe after he bought shares in the company behind TV hit Big Brother.

Cor Boonstra bought shares in Dutch production house Endemol in March last year, just before Spanish telecoms giant Telefonica launched a successful bid for the company.

The executive today said he would co-operate with the investigation, which will be conducted by the STE financial watchdog and Dutch public prosecutors.

"Mr Boonstra has offered his full co-operation to the STE and to the public prosecutors and is confident about the proceedings," said a spokesperson.

Philips refused to comment on a "private transaction", while a Telefonica spokesman expressed surprise at news of the probe.

Mr Boonstra, who leaves Philips next month, has no direct links with Endemol, although his partner Silvia Toth was a member of the company's supervisory board.

Insider dealing investigations are common in the Dutch business world, where directors of one company often sit on the supervisory board of another.

In 1999, 13 cases were referred to prosecutors.

fields.headline: Tiger Woods on course to become sponsorship billionaire
fields.standfirst: Sports sponsorship: top five earners
fields.trailText:
1pm: Tiger Woods is on course to become the world's first sponsorship billionaire after his US Masters win, writes Claire Cozens.
Sports sponsorship: top five earners
fields.body:
Tiger Woods is on course to become the world's first sponsorship billionaire after yesterday's historic win at Augusta's National club.

The golfing star became the first person to have won four consecutive major championships when he took the US Masters yesterday.

Now media pundits are predicting he will be the first person to make $1bn (£650m) from advertising and sponsorship contracts.

Gene DeWitt of New York advertising agency Optimedia described Woods as "the next mega-property", adding: "He's got it all, he's an athlete and a charming man. People love him and that's the most important thing."

Woods already has a £65,000 contract with Nike, which signed him up back in 1996.

He also promotes Rolex watches, Titleist golf equipment and American Express and recently signed a £20m deal to appear in advertising for Buick cars in the US.

The golfer is even paid to talk about the company that did his corrective laser eye surgery.

Tiger Woods's youthful image and down-to-earth roots have helped transform the image of the sport, breaking down its crusty reputation and making it the sport of choice among trendy youngsters.

Woods's latest victory places him in the same class as all-time sporting greats Muhammed Ali and Michael Jordan.

Formula One racing drivers have traditionally been by far the highest-paid sports stars.

But the ever-increasing sums that even relatively unsuccessful stars such as tennis player Anna Kournikova can command through advertising and sponsorship make the amount of money earned through sport pale into insignificance.

American sports magazine ESPN recently estimated Woods would earn £4bn if he continued playing until the age of 65.

But the magazine said only £1bn of this would come from prize money, with the remaining £3bn earned through endorsements.

fields.headline: PR trade body closes in on Harkin
fields.trailText:
1pm:
The IPR is starting a formal complaints procedure against the co-founder of R-JH, reports Julia Day.
11.30am: PR firms move in on Sophie's clients
Apr 9: Sophie's partner fights for survival
fields.body:
The Institute of Public Relations is set to take the unprecedented step of launching a complaints procedure against Murray Harkin, co-founder of R-JH, without an official complaint being lodged against him.

The PR trade body, of which Mr Harkin and Sophie Wessex are members, has received a flood of calls and emails from members concerned that Mr Harkin's behaviour has brought the industry in to disrepute.

IPR members are worried Mr Harkin has breached the IPR's code of professional conduct and are demanding action is taken, although no formal complaint has yet been received.

But this will not stop the IPR starting an official complaints procedure against him, unless Mr Harkin can assure them the newspaper reports of his conduct are false.

The IPR has written to Mr Harkin demanding an explanation of his behaviour, which included offering to arrange gay sex parties for a client.

But Mr Harkin has fled the UK to take a holiday abroad.

"We want to hear Murray's side of the story before we decide whether to start more formal proceedings without someone having to issue a formal complaint," said an IPR spokeswoman.

"This is not the norm but this is not a normal situation, it is a very high-profile industry issue."

Another trade body, the Public Relations Consultants Association, has sent a statement to its members assuring them it is working to minimise damage caused to the PR industry's reputation.

webTitle: In brief: The Academy takes "Julia's" Oscar back

fields.headline: The Academy takes "Julia's" Oscar back
fields.standfirst: Plus: Strike puts Matrix sequels on hold; Paul Hogan demands credit from WGA; Putin privatises Mosfilm; Jack Nicholson plagued by doubts; Wicker Man on the way to the West End
fields.trailText: Plus: Strike puts Matrix sequels on hold; Paul Hogan demands credit from WGA; Putin privatises Mosfilm; Jack Nicholson plagued by doubts; Wicker Man on the way to the West End
fields.body:
 The ever-relaxed Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences has demanded that the Hollywood Wax Museum remove a fake Oscar statuette from the waxwork of last month's Academy Award-winner Julia Roberts. The museum had put a cheap Oscar imitation, purchased from a nearby souvenir shop, in the arms of a replica of the Erin Brockovich star two days before her success. The Academy, which vigorously protects appearances of the statuette and the term 'Oscar', immediately fired off a cease-and-desist letter. "The statuette is our copyrighted property, and it is not something available for use in any context that somebody else might think to use it in," says killjoy Academy rep Leslie Unger. "We have complied," sighs museum spokesman John Blanchette. "But we felt bullied... And the wax figure isn't happy either."

 Warner Bros is shelving its Australian production of The Matrix sequels until after the pending writers' and actors' strikes are resolved or averted. A small-scale Californian shoot should provide enough footage to keep the special-effects people busy in the meantime, according to reports. The big-budget thriller The Psychic, starring Cuba Gooding Jr and Gary Oldman, has also been indefinitely shelved. Previous cancelled projects include the Pierce Brosnan sci-fi flick A Sound of Thunder which faltered after the James Bond star asked for a rewrite and producers realised there wasn't sufficient time before the strike deadline. The Writers Guild of America has announced that it will resume contract negotiations with producers on April 17.

 Paul Hogan is threatening to sue the Writers Guild of America, after being stripped of a writing credit on his third Crocodile Dundee movie. Hogan says he wrote the original screenplay, created the characters and all the jokes for Crocodile Dundee in Los Angeles. The Aussie actor also stars in and produced the movie: "I have an ongoing problem with the Writers Guild because I am also the producer," he claims. "The producer is the natural enemy of the writer. Once I became a producer, they suddenly decided I wasn't the writer. I don't even get a credit on there. I think it has to do with the strike." Hogan plans to take his complaint to court.

 President Vladimir Putin has sparked a row among Russia's film-makers by privatising Mosfilm, the country's leading studio. Former Mosfilm deputy director Abdurakhman Mamilov denounced the action in an interview with the FT: "This decree means [Mosfilm] will lose its main source [of funds]. This is robbery. It is as if President Bush took away all the film rights from Universal."

 Surprise, surprise. Jack Nicholson used to be plagued with fears of sexual inadequacy and was confused about his sexual orientation, according to a new biographer. Author Patrick McGilligan, who interviewed countless friends and relatives of the star, says: "Jack saw himself as a loser where women were concerned." He also, says McGilligan, "used cocaine" to help him with sexual problems. "A number of his friends told me about it and Jack himself has talked about it on at least two occasions," writes the author.

 A stage version of the 1973 cult movie The Wicker Man may be on its way to the West End. Writer Anthony Shaffer has adapted his own screenplay about a remote Scottish island community consumed by paganism. The stage show will retain all the film's sacrificial ceremonies and naked rites, as well as the Scottish folk music used as accompaniment. The news comes after a recent rumour suggesting David Thewlis will star in a stage musical version of Tim Burton's 1990 classic Edward Scissorhands.

fields.headline: Rebel Code: Linus Torvalds, Open Source, and the War for the Soul of Software  by Glyn Moody (V)
fields.trailText: Once Stallman had decided on this new course of action - creating a free operating system - he soon made "the major design decision - that we would follow Unix," he says. In retrospect, it might have seemed the obvious choice, but at the time this was by' no means the case because Stallman knew little about the system. "I'd never used it," he says. "I'd only read a little about it, but it seemed like it was a good, clean design [that had some] nice clean and powerful ideas."
fields.body:
Once Stallman had decided on this new course of action - creating a free operating system - he soon made "the major design decision - that we would follow Unix," he says. In retrospect, it might have seemed the obvious choice, but at the time this was by' no means the case because Stallman knew little about the system. "I'd never used it," he says. "I'd only read a little about it, but it seemed like it was a good, clean design [that had some] nice clean and powerful ideas."

But the main impetus for his choice grew once again out of his experiences during the diaspora of the hacker community at the AI Lab. "Digital had discontinued the PDP - 1O" - the last machine on which ITS had run - "which meant that ITS was now completely unusable on any modern computer," Stallman says. "And I didn't want that kind of thing to happen again. The only way to prevent it from happening again was to write a portable system."

Stallman wanted an operating system that could be easily transferred from one type of hardware to another. Because most operating systems had been conceived as the housekeeping software for one type of computer, portability was the exception rather than the rule. "Unix was, at least as far as I knew, the only portable system that really had users on different kinds of computers. So it was portable not just in theory but in actual practice," Stallman says.

Another important reason why Stallman chose Unix as his model, he explains, was that he "decided to make the system compatible with Unix so people who had already written programs for Unix would be able to run them on this system. People who knew how to use Unix would know how to use this system without being required to learn something new." Once again, as he had with Emacs, he was building on something that already existed, but making it better - in this case, by creating a Unix - like system that could be shared freely

Although the project was born at this most unhappy time for Stallman, the name he chose for his new project showed a typical hacker humor. His Unix work-alike would be called GNU, an acronym that stood for "GNU'S Not Unix," and which thus explained itself self referentially. This kind of recursion is often used as a programming technique, and applying it to words is highly popular amongst hackers.

The name GNU also proved a fruitful source of inspiration for similarly self-referential names for many of the programs that went to make up the overall GNU project. Another important virtue of Unix was that its design "consists of a lot of small pieces, often fairly small pieces," Stallman explains; to create a Unix-like system, "what you do is you just have to write each piece. So I sat down and started writing small pieces."

Although this makes the entire process sound disarmingly simple, writing these "small pieces" involved reproducing work that had taken hundreds of people fifteen years - an even harder task than when Stallman matched the team of programmers at Symbolics. In his fight against that company, he was able to look at the source code - the underlying lines of programming - to help him write his own versions: hut with Unix this was not an option.

"I certainly never looked at the source code of Unix," Stallman says. "Never. I once accidentally saw a file, and when I realized it was part of Unix source code, I stopped looking at it." The reason was simple: The source code "was a trade secret, and I didn't want to be accused of stealing that trade secret," he says. "I condemn trade secrecy, I think it's an immoral practice, but for the project to succeed, I had to work within the immoral laws that existed."

Once again Stallman had set himself an almost impossible task that would require an exhaustive dedication and sacrifice - which was perhaps part of the attraction. "I wasn't certain I could finish the job," he recalls, "but it wasn't important for me to know whether I could finish the job; the point was I was going to start it."

The GNU project formally began, in January 1984, when Stallman started working on a replacement for an obscure programmer's tool called Yacc. One reason he chose this was "because there was a similar program available called Bison" - another typical hacker pun - but it wasn't compatible with Yacc; it was missing some features." Stallman obtained permission from the author to make Bison compatible with Yacc, and in doing so, he put in place the first small stone of the GNU edifice.

Having limbered up with this relatively minor task, Stallman moved on to one of the most important. One of the key elements of a Unix system is the C compiler. Programs written in C are text files whose contents are lines of instructions following the rules of the language. Before a computer can obey the instructions contained in the source code, they must be converted into binaries - the sequence of Os and 1s that the processor chip can understand.

This is the job of the C compiler - a kind of mediator between the source code and binaries, which is therefore an indispensable tool for every C programmer. As such, it held a particular importance for Stallman in his endeavor to create a new, freely available version of Unix. A poor C compiler might seriously damage the chances of GNU's being taken seriously; equally, a great C compiler that was free would immediately make people sit up and take notice of the project.

Once more, Stallman tried to build on an existing program to minimize the amount of work that needed doing, and something he had heard about seemed to be perfect for the job. The Amsterdam Compiler Kit was a powerful compiler that ran on Unix and could compile not just C but most of the languages then in use. It had been written by the U.S. academic Andrew Tanenbaum at the Free University of Amsterdam. Perhaps slightly misled by another name for the software - the Free University Compiler Kit - Stallman wrote to Tanenbaum to ask whether he could use it for his GNU project.

As Stallman recalls, [Tanenbaum] said, "The university is free; the compiler isn't. Why don't you give up that silly idea of a free system? I'd like to have some utilities to distribute with the compiler to boost sales. Contribute some utilities to me and I'll give you a share of the profits." What seemed eminently reasonable - generous even - to Tanenbaum, was an insult to Stallman, for whom proprietary software of the kind represented by the Amsterdam Compiler Kit was precisely what he was hoping to combat with his GNU project.

Tanenbaum doesn't recall what he said exactly, but he explains why he was unable to give permission for the Amsterdam Compiler Kit (ACK) to be used by Stallman as part of GNU: "I think we may have already signed a contract to sell ACK commercially via a company in the U.S. and one in Europe," he says. "Our research group needed that money to support graduate students, etc., and as I recall, we were already committed when he came around."

Despite these laudable aims, Stallman saw only Tanenbaum's refusal to aid him in his free software crusade. His response was identical to that he had made to Symbolics a few years earlier: He determined to write his own rival software that would match or beat the offending code.

In September 1984, after an unsuccessful attempt to adapt yet another compiler, Stallman returned to his most successful program so far, Emacs. The code for this new Emacs, which became known as GNU Emacs, had "nothing in common with the original Emacs, which was written in TECO," Stallman says. And in another symbolic act of return to his AI Lab roots, he decided to rewrite most of GNU Emacs in Lisp, that "powerful and elegant language" Stallman prized so highly.

By early 1985, GNU Emacs was able to edit files, and Stallman made it available publicly. This was an important step because it represented the first time people could use and judge GNU software. Even though the free GNU operating system was almost nonexistent, people could still use Emacs: The Unix compatibility that was Stallman's constant guide meant that GNU Emacs could run on any Unix and provide him with a huge potential constituency of users.

First, "people started asking for and writing improvements, and the result was I kept working on Emacs a lot, much longer that I'd expected to, and it ended up much better than I'd originally planned on its being," recalls Stallman. This approach of releasing code and encouraging feedback and modifications from users, although not new - it had formed an implicit part of the entire Unix culture for year - became central to the rapid improvement of free software over the next fifteen years. Its adoption in an extreme form for the development of Linux was one of the key factors in its rapid growth and robustness.

The second consequence of making Emacs available was that Stallman could sell it on tape, the standard distribution medium before floppies; this was alongside free distribution on the Internet because at that time few people had access to this fledgling medium. As well as serving users who might otherwise find it difficult to obtain copies, selling tapes bad the even more beneficial effect of giving Stallman an income. "See," he says, "I had quit my job at MIT to start the GNU project. It acts as housekeeper (handling tasks such as the screen and keyboard) and judge (ensuring that all the competing calls for attention from user programs are handled correctly). In addition, it made sense to develop all the programming tools first so that they could then be used in the creation of the kernel.

A microkernel is a kernel that takes the idea of a small, central adjudicating piece of software to its logical conclusion; it makes all the other housekeeping tasks normally found in a kernel into programs that are controlled just like end-user applications such as word processing and spreadsheets. He also thought the design provided some "nice features."

"In effect, the problem with this was it was a research project, and in general my policy was to avoid research projects [and] use tried-and-true designs, because a research project is risky. You may try out an idea and find that it doesn't work very well. Anyway, we tried out this design, and found out that it was hard to get it finished."

In fact, "in retrospect, it seems that developing a monolithic kernel would have been maybe faster and easier and might have been the right thing to do" - the first working version of the Hurd wasn't released until 1996. But Stallman is philosophical about the matter: "You see," he says, "any individual software project is just a piece of the GNU project; the GNU project isn't fundamentally about developing this piece of software or that piece of software. GNU, like any operating system, is a collection of many programs. We wrote some, and we obtained some from elsewhere; in the end, we achieved the overall goal of a complete free system."

As Stallman began writing the components of his GNU operating system and released them to the public, one of his primary concerns was to ensure that the programs he and his fellow coders were creating would remain free and open as they were passed on from user to user; simply putting them in the public domain would not achieve this because someone could easily come along and sell the GNU programs as proprietary products. Stallman needed to do something new and radical, namely, to draw up a software license that did not restrict the user's rights, as most did, but that protected them.

He did this first with the GNU Emacs General Public License, in 1985. "I worked with a lawyer to draw it up," he says; he had to make sure that the freedoms he was trying to perpetuate were watertight legally. Under this new "copyleft" - as opposed to copyright - users could copy the program, modify it, and sell the original or the modified versions. They could not modify the rights granted by the copyleft to any user, however; for example, software based on the program they sold had also to be freely available. Similarly, modifications they made to a copylefted program had to be copylefted - and so freely available. Furthermore, if software released under the GNU General Public License (GPL) were combined with proprietary (nonfree) code, the resultant combination had to be released under the GPL. In other words, the GNU GPL "converted" software it was used with to its own license, an extraordinarily clever approach to propagating freedom.

This first GNU Emacs General Public License (GPL) was followed later by a GCC GPL and a similar license for several other GNU programs. But Stallman realized that this piecemeal approach was not only inelegant (a cardinal sin among hackers) but also inconvenient because it blocked certain uses. For example. "you couldn't take code from one [program released under a GPL license] and put it in another." Stallman explains, "so I decided that we had better have a single license that could be used for all of them." This was the GNU General Public License - what Stallman calls "the subroutinised license" because "you could drop it verbatim into any program and it would apply," just as programming subroutines can be dropped into other code to save time - and boost their elegance.

Stallman's intent in crafting the GNU GPL was to protect the newly forged liberties that his GNU software embodied. But the GNU GPL had another consequence that would prove key to the success of later free software projects such as Linux.

The freedom to modify a GNU GPL program means that the source code for copylefted software must be available: If the binaries only - the sequence of 0s and 1s - are supplied, modifying the program is impractical and therefore breaches the license. Part of the GNU GPL's effect is therefore to ensure that the source is always available for a program; this is vital if others are to adapt and - especially - improve the program. More - over, the GNU GPL also ensures that such improvements must be freely available, along with their source code, to enable the community as a whole to benefit from the collective advances of all users.

It also minimizes duplication of effort. Once a program carrying out a function is released under copyleft, others can then take this work for granted when they write similar software. There is no need to reinvent the wheel every time a particular type of program is written as is the case with commercial software.

Stallman created in the GNU GPL a kind of written constitution for the hacker world that enshrined basic assumptions about how their community should function. In doing so, he enabled that world to progress far more efficiently than it had in the past when all these "laws" were unwritten. As the use of the GNU GPL became more common, so its power grew, because the more copylefted programs there are the greater the pool for future such programs to draw on; this eases their creation and the pool of GPL'd software grows yet further.

This enormous efficiency acted as one of the main engines in driving the free software projects on to their extraordinary successes during the 1990s. For this alone, and for his work in putting together the GNU system, the computer community's debt to Stallman is immense.

Yet for Stallman this emphasis on inherent efficiency misses the point about the GNU project and about the GNU GPL. His essential concern is freedom, and the GNU project a means to an end rather than an end in itself.

"The overall purpose." Stallman explains, "is to give the users freedom by giving them free software they can use and to extend the boundaries of what you can do with entirely free software as far as possible. Because the idea of GNU is to make it possible for people to do things with their computers without accepting [the] domination of somebody else. Without letting some owner of software say, 'I won't let you understand how this works; I'm going to keep you helplessly dependent on me and if you share with your friends. I'll call you a pirate and put you in jail)'."

"I consider that immoral." Stallman continues, "and I'm working to put an end to that way of life, because it's a way of life nobody should have to be part of, and the only way you can do that is by writing a lot of software and saying to people, 'Come, use it, share it with your friends, change it to do whatever you want it do. Join us, have fun.' And that's what GNU is for, it's to give people the alternative of living in freedom, and the individual software packages like GNU Emacs and GCC or the GNU Hurd, they're important because they're parts of getting that larger job done."

Stallman has not only devoted much of his time and energy to this cause, he has given his money, too. In 1990, he won a McArthur Foundation fellowship, worth somewhere in the neighborhood of $230,000, divided into quarterly installments over five years. "That was a lot more money than I need to live on, and more income than I had ever had before. Rather than spending it, I decided to invest most of it in mutual funds so that I can live on it for the rest of my life while working on free software or another worthy cause."

He has no car: "I live in a city where you don't need to have a car." He rents a room: "I don't want to own a house, I don't want to spend a lot of money. If you spend a lot of money then you're the slave of having to make money. The money then jerks you around, controls your life." Stallman has never married or had children. "That takes a lot of money. There's only one way I could have made that money, and that is by doing what I'd be ashamed of - writing nonfree software. "If I had been developing proprietary software, I would have been spending my life building walls to imprison people." he believes.

Deadly serious intensity aside, Stallman also has a lively sense of humor that manifests itself in a constant stream of ideas, puns, and hacker-type plays on words that courses through his conversations. His personal Web site carries a picture of him dressed as the outrageous be-toga'd Saint lGNUcius - a character he is happy to re-create in his travels around the world with his music CDs and a battered Toshiba portable as he gives talks whenever and wherever he can to spread his message.

And yet many have a different image of Stallman: It is not so much playful mock saint as implacable Old Testament prophet - a kind of geek Moses bearing the GNU GPL commandments and trying to drag his hacker tribe to the promised land of freedom whether they want to go or not. His long hair, which falls thickly to his shoulders, full beard, and intense gaze doubtless contribute to the effect.

This impression arises largely from Stallman's ability to offend even supporters through his constant refusal to compromise. "The only reason we have a wholly free operating system is because of the movement at said we want an operating system that's wholly free, not 90 percent free," he says. "If you don't have freedom as a principle, you can never see a reason not to make an exception. There are constantly going to be times when for one reason or another there's some practical convenience in making an exception."

He admits that sometimes he gets tired of hammering home this message over and over again, but believes he must keep on doing it, even beyond the tolerance of most of his audiences if need be. "I'm never sanguine. I've achieved a lot, but it's not whole job. The job is not finished."

When will it be finished? "Well, maybe never," he acknowledges. "In what sense is freedom ever assured for the future? People are always going to have to work to keep a free society."

This is the real point of the self-referential GNU's Not Unix, and of ideas like "copyleft." For Stallman, free software matters not because software is special and deserves a special freedom; indeed, he acknowledges that "there are more important issues of freedom - the issues of freedom that everybody's heard of are much more important than this: freedom of speech, freedom of the press, free assembly."

Free software matters because all freedoms matter, and software happens to be the domain in which Stallman can contribute most. "I don't see how I could do something more important in some other area," he says. Stallman's work is significant not only because it engendered many of the key elements and pioneered many of the processes that made the success of what came to be the combined GNU/Linux operating system possible but because it provides an ethical backdrop against which the entire free software and open source storey is unfolding.

Stallman, too, should be seen as more than just the greatest hacker who has ever lived - which he almost certainly is. His example of unswerving dedication to lofty ideals may be too idealistic and daunting for most to follow, but it provides a yardstick of integrity against which the actions of his fellow coders, both great and not-so-great, may be judged.

Another important reason why Stallman chose Unix as his model, he explains, was that he "decided to make the system compatible with Unix so people who had already written programs for Unix would be able to run them on this system. Once again, as he had with Emacs, he was building on something that already existed, but making it better - in this case, by creating a Unix - like system that could be shared freely Although the project was born at this most unhappy time for Stallman, the name he chose for his new project showed a typical hacker humor. This kind of recursion is often used as a programming technique, and applying it to words is highly popular amongst hackers. "I condemn trade secrecy, I think it's an immoral practice, but for the project to succeed, I had to work within the immoral laws that existed." As usual, he was sensibly trying to save time and effort by taking existing code that had tackled one of the harder parts and building on it. He also thought the design provided some "nice features." Stallman was lucky - or so he thought at the time. "Eventually we found a microkernel that at least was supposedly already developed and working," he says, "and we just had to write the user programs [that] do the jobs . . . normally done by parts of the kernel" to create that missing heart of the GNU operating system, which was dubbed the GNU Hurd. Unfortunately, the microkernel he found "wasn't already working totally reliably," as he had believed. Moreover, eliminating all the errors from this code proved much more difficult than expected. "It turns out that the debugging environment we had was hard." he explains. "In effect, the problem with this was it was a research project, and in general my policy was to avoid research projects [and] use tried-and-true designs, because a research project is risky. You may try out an idea and find that it doesn't work very well. Anyway, we tried out this design, and found out that it was hard to get it finished." In fact, "in retrospect, it seems that developing a monolithic kernel would have been maybe faster and easier and might have been the right thing to do" - the first working version of the Hurd wasn't released until 1996. But Stallman is philosophical about the matter: "You see," he says, "any individual software project is just a piece of the GNU project; the GNU project isn't fundamentally about developing this piece of software or that piece of software. GNU, like any operating system, is a collection of many programs. We wrote some, and we obtained some from elsewhere; in the end, we achieved the overall goal of a complete free system." As Stallman began writing the components of his GNU operating system and released them to the public, one of his primary concerns was to ensure that the programs he and his fellow coders were creating would remain free and open as they were passed on from user to user; simply putting them in the public domain would not achieve this because someone could easily come along and sell the GNU programs as proprietary products. Stallman needed to do something new and radical, namely, to draw up a software license that did not restrict the user's rights, as most did, but that protected them. He did this first with the GNU Emacs General Public License, in 1985. "I worked with a lawyer to draw it up," he says; he had to make sure that the freedoms he was trying to perpetuate were watertight legally. Under this new "copyleft" - as opposed to copyright - users could copy the program, modify it, and sell the original or the modified versions. They could not modify the rights granted by the copyleft to any user, however; for example, software based on the program they sold had also to be freely available. Similarly, modifications they made to a copylefted program had to be copylefted - and so freely available. Furthermore, if software released under the GNU General Public License (GPL) were combined with proprietary (nonfree) code, the resultant combination had to be released under the GPL. In other words, the GNU GPL "converted" software it was used with to its own license, an extraordinarily clever approach to propagating freedom. This first GNU Emacs General Public License (GPL) was followed later by a GCC GPL and a similar license for several other GNU programs. But Stallman realized that this piecemeal approach was not only inelegant (a cardinal sin among hackers) but also inconvenient because it blocked certain uses. For example. "you couldn't take code from one [program released under a GPL license] and put it in another." Stallman explains, "so I decided that we had better have a single license that could be used for all of them." This was the GNU General Public License - what Stallman calls "the subroutinised license" because "you could drop it verbatim into any program and it would apply," just as programming subroutines can be dropped into other code to save time - and boost their elegance. Stallman's intent in crafting the GNU GPL was to protect the newly forged liberties that his GNU software embodied. But the GNU GPL had another consequence that would prove key to the success of later free software projects such as Linux. The freedom to modify a GNU GPL program means that the source code for copylefted software must be available: If the binaries only - the sequence of 0s and 1s - are supplied, modifying the program is impractical and therefore breaches the license. Part of the GNU GPL's effect is therefore to ensure that the source is always available for a program; this is vital if others are to adapt and - especially - improve the program. More - over, the GNU GPL also ensures that such improvements must be freely available, along with their source code, to enable the community as a whole to benefit from the collective advances of all users. It also minimizes duplication of effort. Once a program carrying out a function is released under copyleft, others can then take this work for granted when they write similar software. There is no need to reinvent the wheel every time a particular type of program is written as is the case with commercial software. Stallman created in the GNU GPL a kind of written constitution for the hacker world that enshrined basic assumptions about how their community should function. In doing so, he enabled that world to progress far more efficiently than it had in the past when all these "laws" were unwritten. As the use of the GNU GPL became more common, so its power grew, because the more copylefted programs there are the greater the pool for future such programs to draw on; this eases their creation and the pool of GPL'd software grows yet further. This enormous efficiency acted as one of the main engines in driving the free software projects on to their extraordinary successes during the 1990s. For this alone, and for his work in putting together the GNU system, the computer community's debt to Stallman is immense. Yet for Stallman this emphasis on inherent efficiency misses the point about the GNU project and about the GNU GPL. His essential concern is freedom, and the GNU project a means to an end rather than an end in itself. "The overall purpose." Stallman explains, "is to give the users freedom by giving them free software they can use and to extend the boundaries of what you can do with entirely free software as far as possible. Because the idea of GNU is to make it possible for people to do things with their computers without accepting [the] domination of somebody else. Without letting some owner of software say, 'I won't let you understand how this works; I'm going to keep you helplessly dependent on me and if you share with your friends. I'll call you a pirate and put you in jail)'." "I consider that immoral." Stallman continues, "and I'm working to put an end to that way of life, because it's a way of life nobody should have to be part of, and the only way you can do that is by writing a lot of software and saying to people, 'Come, use it, share it with your friends, change it to do whatever you want it do. Join us, have fun.' And that's what GNU is for, it's to give people the alternative of living in freedom, and the individual software packages like GNU Emacs and GCC or the GNU Hurd, they're important because they're parts of getting that larger job done." Stallman has not only devoted much of his time and energy to this cause, he has given his money, too. In 1990, he won a McArthur Foundation fellowship, worth somewhere in the neighborhood of $230,000, divided into quarterly installments over five years. "That was a lot more money than I need to live on, and more income than I had ever had before. Rather than spending it, I decided to invest most of it in mutual funds so that I can live on it for the rest of my life while working on free software or another worthy cause." He has no car: "I live in a city where you don't need to have a car." He rents a room: "I don't want to own a house, I don't want to spend a lot of money. If you spend a lot of money then you're the slave of having to make money. The money then jerks you around, controls your life." Stallman has never married or had children. "That takes a lot of money. There's only one way I could have made that money, and that is by doing what I'd be ashamed of - writing nonfree software. "If I had been developing proprietary software, I would have been spending my life building walls to imprison people." he believes. Deadly serious intensity aside, Stallman also has a lively sense of humor that manifests itself in a constant stream of ideas, puns, and hacker-type plays on words that courses through his conversations. His personal Web site carries a picture of him dressed as the outrageous be-toga'd Saint lGNUcius - a character he is happy to re-create in his travels around the world with his music CDs and a battered Toshiba portable as he gives talks whenever and wherever he can to spread his message. And yet many have a different image of Stallman: It is not so much playful mock saint as implacable Old Testament prophet - a kind of geek Moses bearing the GNU GPL commandments and trying to drag his hacker tribe to the promised land of freedom whether they want to go or not. His long hair, which falls thickly to his shoulders, full beard, and intense gaze doubtless contribute to the effect. This impression arises largely from Stallman's ability to offend even supporters through his constant refusal to compromise. "The only reason we have a wholly free operating system is because of the movement at said we want an operating system that's wholly free, not 90 percent free," he says. "If you don't have freedom as a principle, you can never see a reason not to make an exception. There are constantly going to be times when for one reason or another there's some practical convenience in making an exception." He admits that sometimes he gets tired of hammering home this message over and over again, but believes he must keep on doing it, even beyond the tolerance of most of his audiences if need be. "I'm never sanguine. I've achieved a lot, but it's not whole job. The job is not finished." When will it be finished? "Well, maybe never," he acknowledges. "In what sense is freedom ever assured for the future? People are always going to have to work to keep a free society." This is the real point of the self-referential GNU's Not Unix, and of ideas like "copyleft." For Stallman, free software matters not because software is special and deserves a special freedom; indeed, he acknowledges that "there are more important issues of freedom - the issues of freedom that everybody's heard of are much more important than this: freedom of speech, freedom of the press, free assembly." Free software matters because all freedoms matter, and software happens to be the domain in which Stallman can contribute most. "I don't see how I could do something more important in some other area," he says. Stallman's work is significant not only because it engendered many of the key elements and pioneered many of the processes that made the success of what came to be the combined GNU/Linux operating system possible but because it provides an ethical backdrop against which the entire free software and open source storey is unfolding. Stallman, too, should be seen as more than just the greatest hacker who has ever lived - which he almost certainly is. His example of unswerving dedication to lofty ideals may be too idealistic and daunting for most to follow, but it provides a yardstick of integrity against which the actions of his fellow coders, both great and not-so-great, may be judged.

fields.headline: Factory workers lose out to Millionaire
fields.trailText: 12.30pm TV overnights: BBC1's Clocking Off made little headway against ITV's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? last night. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Much-lauded BBC1 drama Clocking Off made little headway on its second outing against ITV's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? last night, picking up only 100,000 viewers after its disappointing 5.8m opener a week ago.

The first series of Clocking Off went out early last year on Sunday night and averaged 8.2m over six weeks.

BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey shifted the second run to between 9pm and 10pm on Monday after a run of poor-performing Sunday evening dramas prompted a rethink.

But so far the gamble has not paid off. Last night Clocking Off managed just 5.9m and a 23% share, according to unofficial overnights.

Millionaire on ITV had a hefty 10.2m viewers and 41% audience share.

Elsewhere last night BBC2's rejigged Monday line-up of comedy and Jamie Oliver continued to lord it over Channel 4.

The Naked Chef repeat at 8.30pm and Paul Merton's encounter with Terry Venables in Room 101 from 10pm brought BBC2 its best post-7pm audience shares.

Both had 13% of the available audience at the time, with Naked Chef pulling in 3.2m viewers and Room 101 managing 2.7m.

The pukka young chef was up against repeated Channel 4 Equinox documentary the Box, which looked at airplane black box recorders between 8pm and 9pm.

But the Box brought in only 1m viewers and a 4% audience share.

Room 101 was against repeated Julia Roberts movie Steel Magnolias on Channel 4, which began at 10pm and ran until 12.10am, pulling in 2.1m and a 16% share.

Between 9pm and 10pm, BBC2's comedy duo of Never Mind the Buzzcocks and Harry Enfield's Television Programme repeat beat Channel 4's to the Ends of the Earth documentary on surfing.

Buzzcocks had 2.5m and Harry Enfield pulled in 2.1m; while Channel 4's Ride the Wild Surf had just 1.6m.

webTitle: MPs call for register of royals' interests

fields.headline: MPs call for register of royals' interests
fields.trailText: 12pm: The extent of concern in Westminster today over the Sophie Wessex fiasco was made clear as nearly 50 MPs backed a motion calling for the royal family to be forced to register their business interests.
fields.body:
The extent of concern in Westminster today over the Sophie Wessex fiasco was made clear as nearly 50 MPs backed a motion calling for the royal family to be forced to register their business interests.

The petition, tabled by the Labour backbencher Gordon Prentice, "applauds the decision of Buckingham Palace to consider issuing guidance on how the business affairs of working members might be conducted in future."

Although the early day motion stands no chance of being debated in the House of Commons - MPs break today for their fortnight's Easter recess - it is a good barometer of the strength of feeling among Labour members.

The motion called for the setting up a register of interests for the monarchy similar to the compulsory register of members' interests in which all MPs must declare outside earnings and interests. There is currently a voluntary register for peers in the House of Lords.

Mr Prentice, MP for Pendle, also demanded that the Commons select committee on public administration report back on the possible reform of current practices and urged Buckingham Palace to consult MPs for advice.

The chairman of the Commons public administration committee, Tony Wright MP, has already called for the modernisation of the monarchy, and veteran republican MP Tony Benn this week reiterated his call for an elected head of state.

fields.headline: Tesco stacks up online sales
fields.standfirst: Tesco was the first to enter the online grocery market and now, with over 1m users and weekly sales of £6m, it is reaping the rewards.
fields.trailText:
Tesco was the first to enter the online grocery market and now, with over 1m users and weekly sales of £6m, it is reaping the rewards. By Amy Vickers.

Apr 10: Tesco unveils £1bn profits
fields.body:
When Tesco boss Terry Leahy was first smitten by internet grocery shopping six years ago, he saw a future in which millions of customers shopped from their homes. He knew that if Tesco moved quickly enough it would gain a stranglehold over the fledgling market.

And that is effectively what happened. Mr Leahy mapped out the future of grocery retailing at a time when many of his competitors chose to ignore the internet. He recruited a couple of internet visionaries and set about developing an internet grocery operation.

Tesco first hit the web in 1997 as Tesco Direct, a slow paper-based system that allowed customers to order via the internet, telephone or fax.

It soon became clear that the way forward was to ditch everything except the internet operation, thus cutting costs, and run the service in conjunction with each individual store.

This happened at the beginning of 1999, but it wasn't until the end of that year that the overall strategy for Tesco.com, incorporating Tesco Direct and the ISP, really started to take shape.

Meanwhile, rival stores Sainsbury's and Asda concentrated on building vast warehouses to act as delivery hubs for online grocery shopping. Both have yet to make much headway in the online grocery market. In fact, Tesco.com claims its "world leading system is at least two years ahead of the competition".

By April 2000, Tesco had hived off Tesco.com as a separate business and started aggressively rolling out internet shopping to all its UK stores, amid rumours of a possible separate flotation.

The IPO didn't materialise, but given the ensuing success of Tesco.com, it may only be a matter of time. Tesco.com is arguably the leading UK online grocery retailer and boasts it can reach 90% of the UK population.

While Tesco.com is still posting losses, albeit just £9m for the full-year of expansion, its revenues of £237m are staggering, and should give some cheer to beleaguered e-commerce companies struggling to survive.

According to market research group Datamonitor, British grocery shoppers spent £395m online last year. Tesco.com's figures would suggest it has the lion's share of this market.

Tesco claims the division, on which it has so far spent around £60m, now has more than 1m registered users who generate weekly sales of £6m, through 70,000 orders a week. Not a bad little earner.

webTitle: MPs call for commission to speed Whitehall reform

fields.headline: MPs call for commission to speed Whitehall reform
fields.trailText: Tony Blair should attack the refusal of Whitehall to embrace fundamental reforms by establishing a royal commission on the future of the civil service, a Labour controlled select committee of MPs recommends today.
fields.body:
Tony Blair should attack the refusal of Whitehall to embrace fundamental reforms by establishing a royal commission on the future of the civil service, a Labour controlled select committee of MPs recommends today.

The proposal has support in parts of Downing Street where there is growing frustration at the slowness of change in Whitehall and civil servants disinterest in the outcome of Labour's many policy initiatives. Mr Blair and his senior advisers want civil servants to focus much more on results and spend less time fighting departmental turf wars.

The proposal for a royal commission comes from the Commons public administration committee which says there is a feeling "in some quarters that the civil service has once again absorbed attempts at reform. A possible conclusion may be that the service is incapable of effectively changing itself and that reform must be imposed from the outside".

The MPs also point out that the head of the civil service, Sir Richard Wilson, has admitted he will not meet his target of 35% women in the senior civil service by 2005. "If this one target cannot be met for reasons which could have been foreseen ... it raises questions about the basis for such target setting," the report says.

The MPs also call for the posts of permanent secretaries - the most senior departmental post - to be opened up to external open competition. In recent months, both the Home Office and the Education Department have filled such vacancies from within Whitehall.

The report says local councils and agencies have complained of the "constant need to bid and rebid for central funds and the requirement to comply with a plethora of inspection regimes and externally imposed targets".

The MPs say these targets imply a lack of trust and stem from an excessive centralism.

They suggest "the twin imperatives of performance and accountability seem to us point inexorably towards a system of elected regional government combined with unitary local authorities".

The report also calls for the government's much criticised annual report to be changed so that claims about the government's record are subject to independent verification and endorsement.

fields.headline: Murdoch may contest Turner for NTV
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: Rupert Murdoch has emerged as a rival to Ted Turner in the fight for control of Russia's NTV, reports Dan Milmo.
Apr 5: Russia's defiant TV crew becomes the news
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch has emerged as a surprise rival to media tycoon Ted Turner in the tussle for control of the NTV television station in Russia.

The owner of News Corp has been approached to back an alternative bid for the private broadcaster, which has been taken over by the state-controlled Gazprom gas group in a boardroom coup.

Mr Turner, founder of the CNN news channel and vice-president of AOL Time Warner, has joined a consortium that plans to buy most of the 47% stake in NTV owned by founder Vladimir Gusinsky.

However, Mr Turner will only go ahead with the deal if he receives assurances Gazprom will maintain the editorial independence of the station, which is Russia's only independent national network.

This pause has allowed commercial rivals of the cable mogul to approach Mr Murdoch, who is understood to have given the move short shrift despite his history of enmity with Mr Turner.

The shrewd billionaire is unlikely to be drawn into a situation that has become a major political embarrassment for president Vladimir Putin.

Mr Putin has been accused of hounding NTV for its criticism of the ongoing war in Chechnya and secretly backing the Gazprom takeover.

German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder was dragged into the affair today when he was interviewed by an NTV-owned radio station during a state visit to Russia.

Mr Schroeder had promised to discuss the importance of an independent media with Mr Putin but ducked the NTV issue during the phone-in.
