webTitle: Castro may see Costner's Cuban Missile Crisis movie

fields.headline: Castro may see Costner's Cuban Missile Crisis movie
fields.trailText: Thirteen Days is to be screened in Cuba and Russia before some of the key figures of the period
fields.body:
The political drama Thirteen Days will play next week in Cuba and Russia, the two countries with whom America experienced a three-way standoff in the nuclear crisis the movie depicts.

Next Monday night's screening in Havana will include a discussion with executive producers Kevin Costner, Peter Almond and Beacon Pictures chairman Armyan Bernstein.

Organized by the Cuban film society, Instituto Cubano del Arte e Industria Cinematograficos, the screening will certainly be attended by Cuban government officials who were involved in the Missile Crisis, known as the Crisis of October in Cuba, and Fidel Castro is rumoured to be considering paying a visit.

Moscow's audience will also include some of the key figures of the period: former US Secretary of Defense, Robert McNamara, Theodore Sorensen, the former special counsel to President Kennedy, and Anatoly Dobrynin, the former Soviet Ambassador to the United States.

The film has attracted worldwide political attention, claimed Gary Shapiro, Beacon Pictures' marketing head. In the first few days of the Bush administration, Dubya requested a screening of the film. "If the White House pays attention, then so does the rest of the world," says Shapiro.

Confirming that Castro personally requested the Cuba screening, Bernstein added: "We are proud to have made a film that has not only entertained audiences around the world but has also made people think and talk about the issues of power and leadership in the nuclear age."

fields.headline: Illegal sheep movements investigated
fields.standfirst:
 Illegal movements may have spread disease
 High street sales grow
 Pubs lose money

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 Illegal movements may have spread disease
 High street sales grow
 Pubs lose money
fields.body:
Trading standards officers have investigated 309 suspected cases of illegal sheep movements since the outbreak of the foot and mouth epidemic, it emerged last night.

A report drawn up last week for the prime minister, seen by BBC2's Newsnight, suggested that the scale of the illicit movements may have contributed to the spread of the disease.

Meanwhile, it was revealed today that the crisis has helped high street sales grow for the second consecutive month as consumers have stocked up on meat

It also emerged today that the disease is costing the beer and pubs industry £38m a month, with one in 10 pubs either closing or suffering a significant dip in profits, according to industry body the Brewers and Licensed Retailers Association.

The disease, which has also badly affected rural tourism, has caused the turnover in pubs to fall an average of 18%, although in some heavily-infected regions, such as Devon and Cumbria, losses are as high as 46%.

There was some good news today however, as Stonehenge re-opened to visitors after being closed for more than five weeks because of the crisis.

On illegal sheep movements, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, last night acknowledged that they could have led to foot and mouth being transmitted to areas that had previously been disease-free.

"It is highly unlikely to be windborne or to do with happenstance or anything other than the movements of vehicles, people or livestock," he said.

"If people have done something wrong - and that means moving livestock without licences - then they should be prosecuted."

The practice of "bed and breakfasting" sheep - lending them out to neighbouring farmers in order to fraudulently claim EU subsidies - is said to be widespread in some areas.

However, a few desperate farmers are even suspected of deliberately infecting their flocks with foot and mouth in order to claim compensation, according to Newsnight.

Graham Cull, a trading standards advisor who helped compile the report for Downing Street, said that he believed that more alleged cases of illegal movements would come to light.

Officials are were still trying to establish how cases had broken out over the weekend in three previously unaffected areas - Whitby in north Yorkshire, Jedburgh in the Scottish Borders and Caerphilly in south Wales.

Advice from the Ministry of Agriculture and the National Farmers' Union stresses the importance of using the most stringent disinfectant methods for individuals and vehicles entering and leaving farms.

According to Maff, there were 29 new cases yesterday taking the total for the UK to 1,164.

Professor Roy Anderson of Imperial College, London, who advises the government on animal health, said today: "We are at a critical phase of this particular epidemic.

"The case numbers, which were once above 60, in the last 10 days or so have fallen below 30 and have been hovering around 20 cases a day, so there is evidence that the current policy is beginning to have an effect."

webTitle: Hostel girl's father awaits DNA tests

fields.headline: Hostel girl's father awaits DNA tests
fields.trailText: The father of murdered schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson today said he had not raised his hopes of finding her killer after the arrest of a man wanted in connection with her death.
fields.body:
The father of murdered schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson today said he had not raised his hopes of finding her killer after the arrest of a man wanted in connection with her death.

John Dickinson said he would be adopting a "wait and see" attitude following the arrest of Spaniard Francisco Arce Montez in Florida last month.

Montez, 50, who is wanted for questioning over the rape and murder of his daughter, was picked up by police in Miami beach on suspicion of burglary, trespass, and of lewd and lascivious behaviour in an unconnected incident.

He was named in court last month by a French judge as a chief suspect in the Dickinson case who was "particularly" wanted by police from a list of around 50 people sought for questioning.

But Mr Dickinson, 43, from Bodmin, Cornwall, said he had known about the arrest for some time and was awaiting the results of DNA tests.

He asked: "Why build your hopes up to have them dashed? We just have to wait and see." He added: "I am aware of the situation and the family are aware of the situation. "We understand this man is one of 48 the police are looking for and we will be awaiting the results of DNA sampling."

The family had suffered many disappointments in the five years since Caroline's death, he said, adding: "The press occasionally hear of the odd one, but there have been very many.

"We have every confidence that we have very good DNA evidence as to who the perpetrator was, so why build your hopes up? It is simply a matter of waiting for confirmation or otherwise."

Caroline, from Bodmin, Cornwall, was 13 years old when she was raped and strangled while sharing a youth hostel dormitory with four classmates during a school trip to Pleine Fougeres, Brittany, in July 1996.

Last week an inquest, which ruled that her death was unlawful, heard that the killer's DNA was found on Caroline's clothes but tests on nearly 3,500 men have led to nothing.

fields.headline: Tuesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are already looking forward to Chris Evans' and Billie Piper's lovely £6m summer wedding
fields.trailText: No doubting the biggest rumour of the day. According to the Sun, AC Milan are planning a spectacular £70m double bid for David Beckham and Michael Owen - which breaks down as a world-record £40m for Beckham and £30m for Owen. The paper claims that Milan will offer Becks and Owen £31m over five years, which works out as £120,000 a week. Better still for Becks, the Sun also reports that Milan president Silvio Berlusconi is "rumoured to be ready to offer" his wife Posh Spice her own TV show on one of his many channels.
fields.body:
No doubting the biggest rumour of the day. According to the Sun, AC Milan are planning a spectacular £70m double bid for David Beckham and Michael Owen - which breaks down as a world-record £40m for Beckham and £30m for Owen. The paper claims that Milan will offer Becks and Owen £31m over five years, which works out as £120,000 a week. Better still for Becks, the Sun also reports that Milan president Silvio Berlusconi is "rumoured to be ready to offer" his wife Posh Spice her own TV show on one of his many channels.

Glenn Hoddle will make a £5m bid for Mustapha Hadji if Coventry are relegated, reports the Daily Express. The paper says that Hadji has a clause in his contract allowing him to talk to other clubs if Coventry go down. It's a busy day for Spurs transfer gossip, with the Mirror reporting that Fulham are lining up a £5m bid for Ian Walker, while Planet Football reckons that Barcelona are the latest club to put Sol Campbell on their summer shopping list.

PSV president Harry Van Raaij has warned Manchester United that he won't sell Ruud Van Nistelrooy for less than £18.5m. "We are still concentrating on winning the championship," he said. "After that it is possible we might sell, but only if United, or anyone else for that matter, are prepared to pay £18.5m. That is the price we want and we will not take a penny less."

Francis Jeffers could have played his last game for Everton, reports the Mirror. The paper says the England U-21 international could be ruled out for the rest of the season with a shoulder injury, and is "likely to leave for either Arsenal or Manchester United in the summer".

Ipswich manager George Burley has dismissed rumours linking Arsenal with a £10m move for Titus Bramble. "You're always going to get speculation, but we are looking to add to our squad, not sell any of our key players," he said.

fields.headline: PR firms move in on Sophie's clients
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The Thai hotel in the Sophie Wessex scandal has been inundated with calls from UK PR firms eyeing the account. By Julia Day.

Apr 9: News of the World cries foul
Apr 9: Bleak outlook for Sophie firm
fields.body:
The Thai hotel at the centre of the Sophie Wessex scandal has been inundated with calls from UK PR companies clamouring to pick up the account R-JH lost.

MediaGuardian.co.uk yesterday revealed that the Banyan Tree in Phuket had ditched the countess's PR firm after R-JH managing director Murray Harkin claimed he could arrange gay sex parties at the hotel.

The Banyan Tree has since received a flood of calls from UK firms wanting to promote the hotel chain in the UK.

But the R-JH saga has forced the luxury hotel chain to rethink its whole UK PR strategy.

"We are going to take a step back and re-evaluate the situation before jumping in to another decision, says Reene Ho-Phang, director of marketing communications at the Banyan Tree.

"But any PR company we do hire must have experience in handling hotels. We want to make sure the people we are working with are committed to the account," she said.

Ms Ho-Phang said the hotel was monitoring reaction to the R-JH story in Asia and the US, and has PR companies in those markets ready to counter any negative fall-out.

webTitle: Hoping that Easter can resurrect trade

fields.headline: Hoping that Easter can resurrect trade
fields.standfirst: Every few days, Guardian Unlimited is checking how foot and mouth is affecting the lives and livelihoods of a small panel of people directly affected by the outbreak. Here is the latest report by Derek Brown, on the front line in his home town of Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire
fields.trailText: Every few days, Guardian Unlimited is checking how foot and mouth is affecting the lives and livelihoods of a small panel of people directly affected by the outbreak. Here is the latest report by Derek Brown, on the front line in his home town of Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire.
fields.body:
Easter is looming. It's crunch time for anyone involved, even marginally, in the tourism and day-trip trade. For many businesses here on the edge of the Cotswolds, it's a vital source of extra revenue, especially after two months of depressed and depressing trading.

The portents are not good. In some prime destination areas, businesses like guest houses and restaurants are reporting an 80% drop in advance bookings.

The hope must be that, when the holidays come, the trippers and tourists will suddenly materialise. Much will depend on the weather, on the progress of the disease through the week, and on gut instinct. In other words, it's anyone's guess.

The supermarket manager

The local Co-op store takes most of its revenue from local people, but looks to the summer season for added sales to self-catering holidaymakers and passers-by.

"I am a little concerned by what I hear on the news about trips to the countryside," said manager Tony Hatch.

"Maybe we won't get any tourist business over the holidays, when we would expect things to pick up normally. In a way, we have a captive audience because we are here in the town, and we have good customer loyalty, but the tourist trade for us is the icing on the cake."

The butcher

John Kench, the high street family butcher, would not normally expect more than marginal extra sales to holidaymakers. But then he hardly needs extra, with his local trade going great guns on the basis of his fully certificated British supplies. "Before all this, I would expect 100 transactions on a Saturday, and be pleased with anything over that. This last weekend, I had around 140. It's the same thing with everyone: traceability. Prices are steady now too, which helps," he said.

The caterer

Over the road at Stones bar-restaurant, there are signals that things might be picking up after a long lean spell. The lunchtime trade includes a trickle of obvious trippers, and Sunday - a key day for the restaurant - was encouragingly busy.

For owner Brain Galbraith, the future, even looking ahead the few days until Easter, is filled with uncertainty. "You just don't know from one minute to the next who is going to come in," he said.

The farmer

Marilyn Ivings, of Mill Farm at Church Enstone, is a firm believer in compromise - but not on public access to land where there is livestock.

"I've just had another farmer over here showing me a letter from Oxfordshire county council, telling him to reopen his footpaths. He is prepared to put down a straw mat and supplies of disinfectant, but I told him he shouldn't open up the paths.

"The county can't tell him to. At least, I don't think they can, and, if I'm wrong, that's just too bad," she adds.

Marilyn is pleased that the nearby Cotswold Wildlife Park is reopening: "There has got to be compromise. It's no good shutting everything down, because lots of things will close for good. I've heard they've been losing £26,000 a week. Well, you can't go on like that for long, can you?"

On Mill Farm, Marilyn and husband Ted know a thing or two about the fragility of countryside incomes. Their 35 suckler cows have, so far, produced 21 calves, but only six are bulls that automatically attract subsidy, while the 15 heifers will simply cost money to rear.

Had the ratio been the other way round, Marilyn and Ted would be better off by £3,000 over two years. And it's not just the vagaries of nature that are against them these days: the tractor has broken down, and they have just learned that it will cost £900 to repair.

But, of even greater concern, Marilyn has just learned of a new confirmed case of foot and mouth in nearby Worcestershire.

"It's closing in," she said. "We're still hoping and praying... "

webTitle: Coen Brothers soundtrack launches Soggy Bottom Boys

fields.headline: Coen Brothers soundtrack launches Soggy Bottom Boys
fields.trailText: The soundtrack to O Brother, Where Art Thou? has become a surprise hit in the USA where it is now approaching platinum status
fields.body:
America has fallen for a new pop sensation - and, for once, it's neither a voluptuous teenage girl nor an emotionally disturbed male youth. Step forward, the Soggy Bottom Boys, George Clooney's singing jailbird trio from the Coen Brothers' O Brother, Where Art Thou?.

While the comic movie, loosely based on the Odyssey and set in Depression-era America, has been only a mild success by box-office standards, its soundtrack has become 2001's surprise hit, topping the US country charts and creeping its way to platinum status.

The eclectic collection of roots, bluegrass and country and western music, featuring the talents of Emmylou Harris, Alison Krauss and Dan Tyminski - who provided the singing voice for Clooney in the film - has sold 772,500 copies, while radio stations nationwide are furiously spinning its most memorable number, I Am a Man of Constant Sorrow (WindowsMedia). The album sits at number 14 on the Billboard chart - and all this without any marketing drive from the record label.

Its success has startled music industry insiders. "We like to call this a phenomaly - a phenomenon and an anomaly," says Michael Powers, promotions man for Mercury Nashville. "You look at a movie soundtrack that's about music, and it just sort of reacts with people."

Jim Rainwater, who runs a California record store, says that the soundtrack is selling way beyond country music fans. "What's funny is that we don't have country at all and we've sold a ton of 'em. It's definitely that intelligent, over-30 crowd, and those are the people that are looking for something new. The timing is just right and it's kind of a new, old thing."

And so the Soggy Bottom Boys are getting ready to capitalise by taking their sleeper hit on a concert tour, starting at New York's Carnegie Hall in June. Tour organizers say they hope the O Brother roadshow will help develop fans' newly discovered appetite for "real" music. "It really is about cultural zeitgeist, and tapping into a collective unconscious," says Janet Billig, who is producing the tour. "People are just reacting to something that's real."

fields.headline: Media Business
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 9
fields.trailText: April 9: News International and VNU have frozen staff recruitment.
fields.body:
News International and VNU have frozen staff recruitment.

Paul Clarke, managing director of Carat Business, has taken the industry by surprise with his sudden departure from the agency.

Columbia TriStar Films is to centralise its £17m media planning and buying account into Zenith Media.

MediaCom Scotland has won a raft of accounts, including the £1m brief for the Scottish Co-op retail chain Scotmid and its sister company Semi-Chem.

Time Europe has poached Carat International account director James Griffiths to be marketing director.

Sportal has poached Mary McGregor from the market analysis company Datamonitor to be its head of sales.

fields.headline: Thinking and driving
fields.standfirst: The Citroën C5 hasn't got the looks of its rivals - but it makes up for it with brains
fields.trailText: The Citroën C5 hasn't got the looks of its rivals - but it makes up for it with brains.
fields.body:
The label "C5" stands out very proudly on the boot of Citroën's new saloon. Of course, the last vehicle to be named a C5 was Sir Clive Sinclair's battery-driven bike and one may not thank Citroën for bringing back to mind images of almost prone motorists pottering haplessly into the middle of busy intersections with nothing more to protect them than an elongated perspex bucket.

I never went in one of Sir Clive's C5s, but I'm prepared to stick my neck out and maintain that the Citroën version is stronger, broader and faster. I also reckon it will sell more, but perhaps we should wait and see on that.

The car is certainly up against it in the battle for customers. The C5's rivals in what's known as the "upper-medium sector" (which is to say saloons for executives, but not for chairmen) are the Ford Mondeo, the VW Passat and the Renault Laguna. These are all, with good reason, award-winning cars. It's like being pitched in with Manchester United, Arsenal and Liverpool, week in week out. Is the best the C5 can hope for at this level a place in the UEFA Cup? Is this the Leicester City of saloon cars?

Citroën are clearly thinking more big league than that and, aware perhaps that the C5 is not the most beautiful object on the road (indeed, one has seen more beautiful road signs), they are investing their hopes in the car's unique futurism. We're meant, I think, to understand that, though the Mondeo and the Laguna have the edge when it comes to style and the Passat has the edge when it comes to looking like an Audi, all of them are, by comparison with the C5, products of the dim and distant 20th century.

Easier, perhaps, to sell a pretty car than a technological miracle, but Citroën are giving it a shot. The C5 is, for instance, one of the first cars to highlight its internal wiring system as a buying point: the "multiplex wiring" (nothing to do with cinemas), which enables the headlights and windscreen wipers to come on automatically and the windows to be operated by remote control, is the third thing Citroën mention about the car. The second thing they mention is the "advanced Direct Injection engines" and the first is the "Hydractive 3 suspension".

Even more than it was for Brunel, suspension has always been a Citroën fad. They are the great suspenders. You may recall the tremendous bateau-shaped Citroëns of old that would take a moment to rise up off the ground after their ignitions were switched on.

The 21st-century version of this is the Hydractive 3 system, which automatically lowers the car's height at motorway speeds and lifts it up high when the going gets bumpy - on farm tracks, for instance, or on most A-roads as they approach London. People with more sensitive backsides than mine may differ, but I cannot confidently say that the ride was gloriously more luxurious than in a Passat, Mondeo or Laguna, which don't go up and down.

I drove two versions of the C5 - firstly, the 2.2 HDi diesel, which comes with a new particulate filter that reduces particle emissions to a level "so low as to be almost unmeasurable". In addition, the engine is so frugal that a single tank of petrol could probably be made to last you a year and a half, as long as you never went above 35mph and accelerated very carefully. In as much as any four-door saloon car that does up to 126mph can be, the C5 with a 2.2 diesel engine is clearly a green choice. George Bush would hate it.

I then drove the V6 automatic, which needs refuelling every 10 minutes or so, doesn't filter its particles nearly as conscientiously and indeed guffs out almost a third as much again in terms of carbon dioxide. That said, it has the considerable advantage over the diesel model of not being a diesel model, and therefore not sounding like one.

I guess it will come down to the individual conscience in the end: how much can you make your fondness for the polar ice caps weigh against your desire to own a car that doesn't rattle like a lorry carrying a loose load of beer kegs? Tough call.

The interior, though unstartling, is generously decked with comforts. You can show films on the colour satellite navigation screen, though it is, of course, not recommended that you watch them while driving.

In a heroic resistance to trends elsewhere, there are no drinks holders, presumably because the car is French and French people are not so vulgar that they need to drink on the move. However, I did manage to wedge a chocolate milkshake into the ashtray, located, ostensibly for passengers in the rear, at the end of the central reservation containing the handbrake and gearstick.

And without any spillage, either, despite a journey which was at times winding and lumpy, as travel through south London increasingly is. Doubtless the Hydractive 3 system must take the credit for that smoothness, but I like to think the multiplex wiring played a part as well.

The lowdown

Citroën C5 2.2 HDi

Price: from £18,690

Top speed: 127mph

Acceleration: 0-62 in 10.2 seconds

Consumption: 44.1 mpg combined

At the wheel: Norma Waterson

On the stereo: Clannad

En route for: Cropreddy Festival

webTitle: Stella McCartney leaves Chloe to establish own fashion design label

fields.headline: Stella McCartney leaves Chloe to establish own fashion design label
fields.trailText: After months of speculation, Stella McCartney yesterday officially confirmed she was leaving Chloe to set up her own fashion house. Backed by the Gucci group, McCartney plans a rapid development for the label over the next couple of years, opening stores around the world to sell her own label designs.
fields.body:
After months of speculation, Stella McCartney yesterday officially confirmed she was leaving Chloe to set up her own fashion house. Backed by the Gucci group, McCartney plans a rapid development for the label over the next couple of years, opening stores around the world to sell her own label designs.

McCartney, who has designed for Chloe since 1997, will set up her label from scratch, in time for her to show as part of the spring/summer 2002 collections, which hit the catwalks in the autumn. "I am incredibly excited about the decision," said the 30-year old daughter of ex-Beatle Paul. "In Gucci group, I have found a partner with the skills necessary to make this business a success. I have always wanted to start my own label and I feel ready for the challenge."

Meanwhile, Chloe announced that McCartney's collaborator, 27-year-old Briton Phoebe Philo, will take over as creative director of the Paris based label. Philo was delighted at the promotion, her first position at the head of a label. "I am excited and thrilled and cannot wait to get going," said the designer, who graduated from Central St Martins in 1996 before working with McCartney. "Although we have accomplished so much in the last four years, I think there is a lot of space for Chloe to grow and I look forward to making that happen."

Under the terms of McCartney's new agreement, she will hold the title of creative director of the label Stella McCartney, which she will jointly own with the Gucci group.

It was stressed that McCartney will have full creative control of the brand, which will operate as a separate and independent company. "I have had the pleasure in knowing Stella for several years," said Tom Ford, creative director of Gucci group, as well as designer of the labels Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent. "Her clothes have enormous appeal for women all over the world. I am thrilled she has decided to build her label with us."

Although full financial details were not disclosed, it is thought to be similar in terms to the agreement that Gucci group signed last December with Alexander McQueen. In that instance, the Gucci group took control of 51% of the east Londoner's label, but McQueen only signed under the assurance that he remain autonomous from Ford.

At the time of his agreement with Gucci group, McQueen was already well established as a designer brand. However, McCartney is not in the same position. Following her graduation from Central St Martins in 1995, she designed a small range under her own name for two years. But when McCartney was given the task of resurrecting Chloe, which had slumped under the design direction of Karl Lagerfeld, her own line was closed. McCartney's designs at Chloe went on to quadruple sales during her four years at the house.

Gucci group have equally strong ambitions for McCartney's new label, which will be shown in London or Paris. As well as finding key sites for the McCartney stores, they plan to launch money spinning products like accessories and perfume. However, shoes will still be problematic, as McCartney, a supporter of animal rights, will refuse to work with leather.

The president of Chloe, Ralph Toledano, said Philo would have no problem working with animal skins. He added of her appointment. "Phoebe was definitely the only one, crystal clear."

Rock chic: Cutting edge style with vintage touches

 The VH1/Vogue Designer of the Year, McCartney is famous for her "rock chick" look

 Her trademark is a combination of contemporary styles with vintage touches - at her spring/summer 2001 show, skirt suits and pillbox hats were shown alongside tailored denim, deep-V swimsuits and T-shirts with cheeky slogans

 Celebrity commissions have included Madonna's wedding dress and the heavily beaded gown worn by Kate Hudson at this year's Oscars

 Although McCartney refuses to design accessories made from leather, she set trends at Chloe with her sell-out diamante studded heart sunglasses

 McCartney's last collection for Chloe, shown in Paris last month, revealed a mature edge that could point to the direction of her new label. Instead of her tongue-in-cheek standards came convincing fake fur coats, velvet hipsters and backless cashmere sweaters

"I have had the pleasure in knowing Stella for several years," said Tom Ford, creative director of Gucci group, as well as designer of the labels Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent. "Her clothes have enormous appeal for women all over the world. I am thrilled she has decided to build her label with us." Although full financial details were not disclosed, it is thought to be similar in terms to the agreement that Gucci group signed last December with Alexander McQueen. In that instance, the Gucci group took control of 51% of the east Londoner's label, but McQueen only signed under the assurance that he remain autonomous from Ford. At the time of his agreement with Gucci group, McQueen was already well established as a designer brand. However, McCartney is not in the same position. As well as finding key sites for the McCartney stores, they plan to launch money spinning products like accessories and perfume. The president of Chloe, Ralph Toledano, said Philo would have no problem working with animal skins. He added of her appointment. "Phoebe was definitely the only one, crystal clear." Rock chic: Cutting edge style with vintage touches  The VH1/Vogue Designer of the Year, McCartney is famous for her "rock chick" look  Her trademark is a combination of contemporary styles with vintage touches - at her spring/summer 2001 show, skirt suits and pillbox hats were shown alongside tailored denim, deep-V swimsuits and T-shirts with cheeky slogans  Celebrity commissions have included Madonna's wedding dress and the heavily beaded gown worn by Kate Hudson at this year's Oscars  Although McCartney refuses to design accessories made from leather, she set trends at Chloe with her sell-out diamante studded heart sunglasses  McCartney's last collection for Chloe, shown in Paris last month, revealed a mature edge that could point to the direction of her new label. Instead of her tongue-in-cheek standards came convincing fake fur coats, velvet hipsters and backless cashmere sweaters

fields.headline: Marconi axes 1,500 UK jobs
fields.standfirst: More business news
fields.trailText: Telecoms equipment group Marconi today announced it was axing 3,000 jobs over the next year - 1,500 of them in the UK.
fields.body:
Telecoms equipment group Marconi today announced it was axing 3,000 jobs over the next year - 1,500 of them in the UK.

The redundancies form part of Marconi's plans to reorganise its business and shake up its management.

The job losses represent around 6% of Marconi's total workforce of 55,000 - around 20,000 of which are employed in the UK, many at large sites in Coventry and Liverpool.

Marconi has not revealed details of the locations of where the job cuts would fall, as it wanted to tell staff first.

But the group did unveil some good news in addition to the job cuts, with plans to create 3,000 "highly skilled, high technology jobs" at sites in Nottingham, Northampton and Ansty, near Coventry.

"While today's announcement contains some regrettable news, Marconi plans to be a net creator of jobs in the UK over the next 24 months, " John Mayo, Marconi's deputy chief executive, said.

"Reshaping and modernisation leads us to recognise that our requirement for certain jobs has reduced. However we will also be recruiting, reflecting our changing skill requirements, and investing in new systems and state-of-the-art facilities.

"Where possible, we will retrain and invest in our current workforce. Where this is not possible, we will work with our employees to help them pursue other opportunities."

But the announcement - which had been widely anticipated - has angered unions, who are furious that the news was leaked and feared their members may be the victims of the company's tumbling share price.

A spokesman for the Manufacturing Science Finance union said: "We are shocked by the announcement and by the way it was handled. There was an appalling lack of consultation with us and our members.

"We will work to avoid compulsory redundancies. We don't see the rationale, and think these are short-term reasons to combat a drop in share price. We believe Marconi is still profitable.

"We are particularly annoyed that this is another high profile company that has ridden roughshod over its workforce by making an announcement of job losses in the press rather than with the workers.

He said the union would seek a meeting with the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, and press for legislation to prevent companies from repeating Marconi's action.

Danny Carrigan, national officer of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union and chairman of the Marconi trade unions, said: "We spoke to the company at length last night and the position is not as bleak as it looked this time yesterday. "

He added: "Over the next 18 months there could be a net gain of jobs, so what we're doing is saying to Marconi that they should support us as we will not accept any redundancies.

"We believe this has more to do with appeasing the anxiety of shareholders than it is dealing with problems in the company."

A shop stewards' meeting would take place in Birmingham tomorrow to discuss the situation and there would be further discussions with Marconi on Thursday, he added.

Marconi's announcement comes amid worries about the slowdown in the US, where its share price has come under pressure.

But today shares in the group surged ahead as Marconi said it expected full-year operating profits to be in line with expectations.

Marconi said it expected the shake-up to cost about £400m, but as a result of the change it expects to cut costs of more than £200m by the end of the year to March 2003.

Today's plans will also see a management shake up, with Mr Mayo becoming chief executive, replacing Lord Simpson who will become chairman, replacing Sir Roger Hurn who is to retire. Marconi said it was reorganising itself into three divisions: networks, enterprise and wireless.

Related articles

09.04.2001: Marconi unions braced for 1,300 layoffs

fields.headline: Wall Street Journal Europe names new director
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Rien Van Lent has been appointed managing director of the Wall Street Journal Europe, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Dow Jones has appointed Rien Van Lent as new managing director for the Wall Street Journal Europe as the incumbent returns to an executive position in the US.

Mr Van Lent joins the newspaper from the Dutch newspaper group Het Financiaale Dagblad, where he has been head of business development since 1996.

Ken Herts, who was brought over to launch the newspaper's European edition in 1998, was due to return to the US this summer, a spokeswoman said.

The Wall Street Journal Europe is boasting a circulation increase of 20% since last January.

fields.headline: 1963: The Profumo scandal
fields.standfirst: At the height of the cold war in the early 60s, as the established order was challenged as never before, Britons paid rapt attention to a sordid little affair which involved a cabinet minister, a showgirl and a Soviet naval attache. Derek Brown looks back on 1963
fields.trailText: At the height of the cold war in the early 60s, as the established order was challenged as never before, Britons paid rapt attention to a sordid little affair which involved a cabinet minister, a showgirl and a Soviet naval attache. Derek Brown looks back on 1963.
fields.body:
Introduction

Sexual intercourse began
In nineteen sixty-three
(Which was rather late for me)
Between the end of the Chatterley ban
And the Beatles' first LP.

- Philip Larkin, 'Annus Mirabilis'

That old rogue Larkin was out by a few years of course, but he captured perfectly the mood of the early 1960s. It was an era in which anything was possible and nothing was safe; a time when the established order was being challenged, subverted, and ultimately buried.

The Chatterley ban was indeed one of the first shibboleths to evaporate. In August 1960 Penguin was prosecuted for publishing one of DH Lawrence's lesser works, Lady Chatterley's Lover, notable only for its use of the f-word and some sublimely silly sex scenes. The trial was farcical - at one stage the jurors were invited to consider whether they would be happy for their wives and servants to read such a book - and the outcome rarely in doubt. When Penguin was given the go ahead to publish, there was minor pandemonium: the initial print run of 200,000 copies sold out on the day of issue, November 10, at the then rather stiff price of 3s 6d (17.5p).

Several more sensations were to unfold before - to follow Larkin's conceit - the Beatles' first LP. 1961 saw the first publication of a little magazine trying to revive an age old tradition of political and social satire. It was called Private Eye. In the same year, and the same spirit, a group of Cambridge graduates - Alan Bennett, Peter Cook, Dudley Moore and Jonathan Miller - brought their irreverent revue, Beyond the Fringe, to London's West End.

In 1962 satire burst out on television, with the late night show That Was The Week That Was, or TW3 to its aficionados. It thrived by debunking religion, politics, royalty and sex, attracting a colossal audience of some 12m viewers - almost as many as the other TV sensation of the age, Coronation Street - making presenter David Frost a national celebrity, and giving the BBC governors some sleepless nights.

The mood of iconoclasm spread even to the Palace of Westminster. In 1961 a young and ardent Labour MP, Anthony Wedgwood-Benn, was barred from the House of Commons after winning a byelection at Bristol South-east, on account of having inherited a viscountcy. Tony Benn, as we now know him, went on to campaign successfully for peers to be allowed to renounce the titles - and, in his case, to shear several syllables off their names as well.

The mood of the day was embodied in the explosion of pop culture. Towards the end of 1962 there was a surge of interest in a new group - they were not called bands then - from Liverpool. It wasn't so much the music at first which caught the public eye (their first single, Love Me Do, barely scraped into the Top 20), but rather their bizarrely long hair. The following year, curiosity became craze, and the Beatles were on their way to their first LP.

The political context

Some commentators have compared the convulsions of the early 1960s, leading up to the election of Harold Wilson's first Labour government in 1964, with the sweeping aside of the Thatcher-Major years and the accession of Tony Blair in 1997. The analogy is tempting: both events involved the ending of long periods of unbroken Conservative government, and the promise at least of a new era. But it is a false comparison none the less. What happened in 1997 was a change of management and style. In 1964, the upheaval was much more fundamental.

At the start of the decade, the prime minister, Harold Macmillan, was still basking in the glow of his 1959 near-landslide election victory, with a Commons majority of over 100. The cartoonists called him Supermac, and political writers were addicted to the adjective "unflappable". Urbane, patrician and when the occasion demanded utterly ruthless, he seemed scarcely threatened by a Labour party wracked by left-right dissent.

But Supermac was not invincible at all. There was rising discontent in the country and in the Tory party over Britain's lacklustre postwar economic performance. Japan and Germany were booming, while the UK's hidebound economy was bedevilled by inflation and dreadful labour relations. Belatedly, the government lumbered towards an application to join the European Economic Community, universally known as the Common Market, but the nation was less and less enamoured by ministers who seemed to represent a bygone age.

Rising discontent led to a series of resounding byelection defeats for the government, most sensationally at Orpington in Kent in March 1962, when a Tory majority of nearly 15,000 was turned into a majority of 7,800 for Jeremy Lubbock of the suddenly resurgent Liberal party. Macmillan, hitherto unflappable, began to flap like a wet hen. Four months after Orpington, in one of the most ruthless political bloodlettings of modern times, he abruptly sacked and replaced seven senior ministers - one-third of the entire cabinet. It was instantly dubbed 'the night of the long knives'. Supermac became Mac the Knife.

Conservative disarray, meanwhile, was being mirrored by Labour consolidation. For much of the 1950s, the party had been convulsed by ideological wrangling, most notably over the issue of nuclear disarmament. Hugh Gaitskell, who had taken over the leadership from the last Labour prime minister, Clement Attlee, was politically all but hamstrung by the internecine strife. But the new decade, with its intangible but unmistakable sense of change, brought a new sense of purpose - and opportunity - to the party. By the time Aneurin Bevan, the leading leftist scourge of the establishment, died in 1960, the party was reinventing itself as a movement for change.

Harold Wilson, seen as a pragmatic leftist, first challenged Gaitskell for the leadership, unsuccessfully, in November 1960. But he and his generation of Labour leaders - George Brown, Jim Callaghan, Denis Healey - were honing a new style of politics which looked to the challenges of the future, not the ideology of the past. That their time was coming, they had no doubt. But they could not have known that their ascent to power would be hastened by a scandal more sensational than any in modern British politics.

Tarts, toffs and traitors

Even today, in our peculiar society, we get excited when ministers and other public figures are caught with their pants down. In 1963, the very notion was deeply, deliciously shocking.

It was still mostly a pre-pill, pre-promiscuity age, when unmarried pregnancy was a matter of deep family shame, and backstreet abortionists thrived. The tabloid newspapers were already brash but not yet sex-crazed, and were by and large polite to politicians. But when the storm broke, it was not simply driven by sex; there was a deep, dark context of rank treachery.

Since the early 1950s, when diplomats Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean fled to their paymasters in Moscow, the chattering classes had speculated about the existence of a "third man". The brave new world of the 1960s did nothing to curb the tittle-tattle; indeed, as the cold war intensified, the issue assumed ever more menacing implications.

In 1961 George Blake, another ex-diplomat, was given a record 42-year prison sentence for spying for the Russians. Sensationally, he was said to have been brainwashed by communists while in captivity in Korea. Even more sensationally, he was to escape from jail after serving only five years.

The cold war was at its coldest, and the Soviet Union was at the zenith of its power, launching the first man into space, and defying the world by supervising the construction of the Berlin Wall. America's apparent impotence, meanwhile, was underlined by the fiasco of the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba.

In 1962, the Cuban missile crisis brought the world terrifyingly close to nuclear annihilation.

Close to the peak of the crisis, a 38-year-old Admiralty clerk and the son of a vicar, William Vassall, was jailed for 18 years for spying for the USSR. He had been recruited by the KGB in a homosexual "honey trap". In July 1963 the government named Kim Philby, former Foreign Office colleague of Burgess and Maclean, as the "third man". But even that huge revelation was subsumed in a greater sensation now gripping the nation.

For months, rumours had circulated about the private life of John Dennis Profumo, secretary of state for war. Educated at Harrow and Oxford, he was a quintessential high Tory who had achieved cabinet rank after serving in a number of junior posts. He was married to the film star Valerie Hobson, and moved effortlessly in the highest of society.

In the deferential spirit of the 1950s, the rumours may have been restricted to salon gossip. Now, in the new age of iconoclasm, the whispers were amplified in the media. That Was The Week That Was scored a telling blow with a splendid parody of the old music hall number, She was Poor but she was Honest. The words of the new version went: "See him in the House of Commons / Making laws to put the blame / While the object of his passion / Walks the streets to hide her shame."

The "object of his passion" was a young woman whose name is now embedded in British political folklore: Christine Keeler.

Keeler, unlike Profumo, had had an extremely undistinguished life. Born in 1942, she left home at 16 after an unhappy childhood in the Thames Valley, and gravitated to London where she found work of a sort at Murray's cabaret club. There she met and befriended another showgirl, Marilyn "Mandy" Rice-Davies. Soon, both young women had drifted into the racy circle around Stephen Ward, a fashionable West End osteopath and socialite.

Keeler's relationship with Ward was both torrid and rocky. They broke up several times, but he seemed to exercise an almost centripetal force on her, and always she drifted back. Soon both young women were celebrated players, albeit with bit parts, in Ward's sexual circus.

Not all the action was centred on Ward's Wimpole Mews flat, equipped with two-way mirrors and other aids to lubricity. Soon, Keeler and Rice-Davies were circulating in more exalted milieux, including Lord Astor's country mansion of Cliveden. It was there that John Profumo first laid eyes on her. A brief but passionate affair ensued, and tongues began to wag.

Even then, it might have been brushed under the carpet in the time honoured English way, but Profumo made a fundamental error: he lied to the House of Commons. In March 1963 he told the chamber that there was "no impropriety whatever" in his relationship with Keeler. Ten weeks later he appeared before MPs again to say "with deep remorse" that he had misled the House, and would resign.

What brought Profumo down even more than his deceit of the Commons, was the startling revelation that Keeler had also slept with Eugene Ivanov, the naval attache at the Soviet embassy. It was that detail which captured world attention, notably in the United States, where the FBI compiled a detailed report called Operation Bowtie.

In Britain, Profumo's downfall naturally caused a huge sensation, inflated by the establishment's crude and cruel attempts to find scapegoats for its own embarrassment. As usual, official wrath was turned on those least able to defend themselves. Stephen Ward was prosecuted for living on immoral earnings. On the last day of his trial, he killed himself with an overdose of sleeping tablets.

Keeler was also tried and imprisoned on related charges. Rice-Davies, who escaped prosecution, earned a dubious immortality when, during the Ward trial, she was told that Lord Astor disputed her version of events and replied: "He would, wouldn't he?"

Less than two months after Ward's tragic and mysterious death, an official report was produced by Lord Denning, master of the rolls. It was a hot number: hundreds queued to buy a copy when it was released at midnight. But there were few juicy bits in Denning's findings. He criticised the government for failing to deal with the affair more quickly, but concluded that national security had not been compromised. And, to the dismay of the reading public, he failed to identify the man who, naked except for a mask, had served at Ward's dinner parties. There had been rumours that the "man in a mask" was a cabinet minister but Denning, who interviewed him, denied it.

There it ended, though it never really went away. The 1989 movie, Scandal reignited some of the controversy, and Christine Keeler raked over the embers in her autobiography, The Truth At Last, published early in 2001. In it, she revived some of the more startling claims made at the time - though alas she was unable to offer convincing new evidence to back them up. She claims for example, that the then MI5 chief, Sir Roger Hollis, was a Soviet spy; and that Stephen Ward ran a spy ring which included Hollis and Sir Anthony Blunt, who was surveyor of the Queen's pictures. Blunt was indeed revealed as a long-time Soviet agent in the 1980s, around the same time that Hollis, the object of numerous rumours, was officially cleared.

Now 58, Keeler has consistently said that successive governments have hushed up the truth of the sordid, sensational Profumo affair. Her only new (and unverifiable) claim, is that the cabinet minister made her pregnant.

And Profumo himself? Remarkably, he is still with us at 86, though friends say he is very frail now. It's nearly four decades since his humiliating fall from grace; years which he has devoted largely to charity work in London's East End. He has also remained true to his tribal code of honour, having never uttered a public word on the events which shook the nation in 1963.

The aftermath

The Profumo affair was no passing sensation. It all but brought down the Macmillan government and it almost certainly finished Macmillan himself as prime minister. In October 1963, less than a month after publication of the Denning report, the prime minister resigned citing ill health. There were no party elections in those days, and the mantle passed to the most improbable of candidates, the 14th Earl of Home.

The Tory mandarins - known as "the magic circle" - were desperate to keep out the obvious successor, Rab Butler, who was on the liberal wing of the party. They preferred the Old Etonian, cricket-loving laird, who was only too happy to oblige, quickly using the recent legislation sparked by the Anthony Wedgwood-Benn affair to renounce his ancient title and transform into being plain Sir Alec Douglas-Home.

It very nearly worked. Weeks after the installation of the new prime minister, the upheaval was subsumed in the global shock of the assassination of John F Kennedy. A year later, in October 1964, Sir Alec called a general election. The polls were against him and so were the satirists, who simply could not take seriously the cadaverous-featured drawling aristocrat. But the country was not so sure: the economy was looking up, the hugely respected Hugh Gaitskell had died and been replaced by the wily Harold Wilson, and Labour had been out of office since 1951.

In the end, that last point almost certainly swung the election. The slogan "13 wasted years" was drummed home again and again, and found resonance with an electorate who knew they were living in a new age; one that was no longer represented by the Tory old guard who had propelled an earl into Downing Street.

The result was close, though. Labour won 317 seats, the Conservatives 303, and the Liberals nine. Taking the Speaker and deputies into account, Wilson had a Commons majority of just four, to support him in his promise to deliver Britain into a new age.

Tarts, toffs and traitors Even today, in our peculiar society, we get excited when ministers and other public figures are caught with their pants down. In 1963, the very notion was deeply, deliciously shocking. It was still mostly a pre-pill, pre-promiscuity age, when unmarried pregnancy was a matter of deep family shame, and backstreet abortionists thrived. The tabloid newspapers were already brash but not yet sex-crazed, and were by and large polite to politicians. But when the storm broke, it was not simply driven by sex; there was a deep, dark context of rank treachery. Since the early 1950s, when diplomats Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean fled to their paymasters in Moscow, the chattering classes had speculated about the existence of a "third man". The brave new world of the 1960s did nothing to curb the tittle-tattle; indeed, as the cold war intensified, the issue assumed ever more menacing implications. In 1961 George Blake, another ex-diplomat, was given a record 42-year prison sentence for spying for the Russians. Sensationally, he was said to have been brainwashed by communists while in captivity in Korea. Even more sensationally, he was to escape from jail after serving only five years. The cold war was at its coldest, and the Soviet Union was at the zenith of its power, launching the first man into space, and defying the world by supervising the construction of the Berlin Wall. America's apparent impotence, meanwhile, was underlined by the fiasco of the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba. In 1962, the Cuban missile crisis brought the world terrifyingly close to nuclear annihilation. Close to the peak of the crisis, a 38-year-old Admiralty clerk and the son of a vicar, William Vassall, was jailed for 18 years for spying for the USSR. He had been recruited by the KGB in a homosexual "honey trap". In July 1963 the government named Kim Philby, former Foreign Office colleague of Burgess and Maclean, as the "third man". But even that huge revelation was subsumed in a greater sensation now gripping the nation. For months, rumours had circulated about the private life of John Dennis Profumo, secretary of state for war. Educated at Harrow and Oxford, he was a quintessential high Tory who had achieved cabinet rank after serving in a number of junior posts. He was married to the film star Valerie Hobson, and moved effortlessly in the highest of society. In the deferential spirit of the 1950s, the rumours may have been restricted to salon gossip. Now, in the new age of iconoclasm, the whispers were amplified in the media. That Was The Week That Was scored a telling blow with a splendid parody of the old music hall number, She was Poor but she was Honest. The words of the new version went: "See him in the House of Commons / Making laws to put the blame / While the object of his passion / Walks the streets to hide her shame." The "object of his passion" was a young woman whose name is now embedded in British political folklore: Christine Keeler. Keeler, unlike Profumo, had had an extremely undistinguished life. Born in 1942, she left home at 16 after an unhappy childhood in the Thames Valley, and gravitated to London where she found work of a sort at Murray's cabaret club. There she met and befriended another showgirl, Marilyn "Mandy" Rice-Davies. Soon, both young women had drifted into the racy circle around Stephen Ward, a fashionable West End osteopath and socialite. Keeler's relationship with Ward was both torrid and rocky. They broke up several times, but he seemed to exercise an almost centripetal force on her, and always she drifted back. Soon both young women were celebrated players, albeit with bit parts, in Ward's sexual circus. Not all the action was centred on Ward's Wimpole Mews flat, equipped with two-way mirrors and other aids to lubricity. Soon, Keeler and Rice-Davies were circulating in more exalted milieux, including Lord Astor's country mansion of Cliveden. It was there that John Profumo first laid eyes on her. A brief but passionate affair ensued, and tongues began to wag. Even then, it might have been brushed under the carpet in the time honoured English way, but Profumo made a fundamental error: he lied to the House of Commons. In March 1963 he told the chamber that there was "no impropriety whatever" in his relationship with Keeler. Ten weeks later he appeared before MPs again to say "with deep remorse" that he had misled the House, and would resign. What brought Profumo down even more than his deceit of the Commons, was the startling revelation that Keeler had also slept with Eugene Ivanov, the naval attache at the Soviet embassy. It was that detail which captured world attention, notably in the United States, where the FBI compiled a detailed report called Operation Bowtie. In Britain, Profumo's downfall naturally caused a huge sensation, inflated by the establishment's crude and cruel attempts to find scapegoats for its own embarrassment. As usual, official wrath was turned on those least able to defend themselves. Stephen Ward was prosecuted for living on immoral earnings. On the last day of his trial, he killed himself with an overdose of sleeping tablets. Keeler was also tried and imprisoned on related charges. Rice-Davies, who escaped prosecution, earned a dubious immortality when, during the Ward trial, she was told that Lord Astor disputed her version of events and replied: "He would, wouldn't he?" Less than two months after Ward's tragic and mysterious death, an official report was produced by Lord Denning, master of the rolls. It was a hot number: hundreds queued to buy a copy when it was released at midnight. But there were few juicy bits in Denning's findings. He criticised the government for failing to deal with the affair more quickly, but concluded that national security had not been compromised. And, to the dismay of the reading public, he failed to identify the man who, naked except for a mask, had served at Ward's dinner parties. There had been rumours that the "man in a mask" was a cabinet minister but Denning, who interviewed him, denied it. There it ended, though it never really went away. The 1989 movie, Scandal reignited some of the controversy, and Christine Keeler raked over the embers in her autobiography, The Truth At Last, published early in 2001. In it, she revived some of the more startling claims made at the time - though alas she was unable to offer convincing new evidence to back them up. She claims for example, that the then MI5 chief, Sir Roger Hollis, was a Soviet spy; and that Stephen Ward ran a spy ring which included Hollis and Sir Anthony Blunt, who was surveyor of the Queen's pictures. Blunt was indeed revealed as a long-time Soviet agent in the 1980s, around the same time that Hollis, the object of numerous rumours, was officially cleared. Now 58, Keeler has consistently said that successive governments have hushed up the truth of the sordid, sensational Profumo affair. Her only new (and unverifiable) claim, is that the cabinet minister made her pregnant. And Profumo himself? Remarkably, he is still with us at 86, though friends say he is very frail now. It's nearly four decades since his humiliating fall from grace; years which he has devoted largely to charity work in London's East End. He has also remained true to his tribal code of honour, having never uttered a public word on the events which shook the nation in 1963. The aftermath The Profumo affair was no passing sensation. It all but brought down the Macmillan government and it almost certainly finished Macmillan himself as prime minister. In October 1963, less than a month after publication of the Denning report, the prime minister resigned citing ill health. There were no party elections in those days, and the mantle passed to the most improbable of candidates, the 14th Earl of Home. The Tory mandarins - known as "the magic circle" - were desperate to keep out the obvious successor, Rab Butler, who was on the liberal wing of the party. They preferred the Old Etonian, cricket-loving laird, who was only too happy to oblige, quickly using the recent legislation sparked by the Anthony Wedgwood-Benn affair to renounce his ancient title and transform into being plain Sir Alec Douglas-Home. It very nearly worked. Weeks after the installation of the new prime minister, the upheaval was subsumed in the global shock of the assassination of John F Kennedy. A year later, in October 1964, Sir Alec called a general election. The polls were against him and so were the satirists, who simply could not take seriously the cadaverous-featured drawling aristocrat. But the country was not so sure: the economy was looking up, the hugely respected Hugh Gaitskell had died and been replaced by the wily Harold Wilson, and Labour had been out of office since 1951. In the end, that last point almost certainly swung the election. The slogan "13 wasted years" was drummed home again and again, and found resonance with an electorate who knew they were living in a new age; one that was no longer represented by the Tory old guard who had propelled an earl into Downing Street. The result was close, though. Labour won 317 seats, the Conservatives 303, and the Liberals nine. Taking the Speaker and deputies into account, Wilson had a Commons majority of just four, to support him in his promise to deliver Britain into a new age.

fields.headline: Tesco unveils £1bn profits
fields.trailText: Britain's largest retailer has today unveiled profits of more than £1bn for the first time, with total sales standing at nearly £23bn.
fields.body:
Britain's largest retailer has today unveiled profits of more than £1bn for the first time, with total sales standing at nearly £23bn.

The food retailer benefited from fast growth overseas, where sales were up 43% to £2.9bn, and underlined its position as Europe's biggest Internet grocer. Tesco.com made a loss of £9m on sales of £237m.

Much of the group's growth has been due to increasing its supply of non-food products, with Tesco aiming for sales in the sector of £5bn by next year. It sold £45m worth of televisions and DVD players in the company's first year as a major electrical retailer.

Chief executive Terry Leahy said the group now has one of the fastest growth rates of any international retailer. "We made good progress on our long term transformation from a domestic to an international retailer, and we achieved sales growth that is gaining momentum," he said.

Today's figures keep Tesco well ahead in the race to remain the UK's leading supermarket group. Sainsbury's last pre-tax profit figure was £509m, while Safeway recorded a profit of £236m.

The company's deputy chairman, David Reid, said he did not believe the billion pound profits figure was excessive. "The reason we are successful is because we are cutting prices," he said. "The customer has got a wide choice and they have been voting for Tesco."

Mr Reid said that during the recent foot and mouth crisis, the company has been working closely with UK farmers "to ease their plight and maintain confidence in British agriculture". He said its suppliers were paying farmers more quickly for meat and also paying above the market price.

While the figures from Tesco cover a period prior to the outbreak of the foot and mouth disease, Mr Reid said: "We are a great backer of British farmers in terms of trying to help them through the current crisis. We are absorbing costs which are not being passed on to the public."

After the figures were released this morning, a spokeswoman for the National Consumer Protection Council said: "It's high time Tesco cut their prices more and gave the customers more benefits from their profits.

"People should look very carefully when they shop at Tesco and ask for prices to be knocked down. They should query why something is such and such a price and go somewhere else to see if it is cheaper."

webTitle: Why philosophy is proving a popular course with lifers in one jail

fields.headline: The philosophers
fields.standfirst: A spell in prison gives you a lot of time to think, which is perhaps why philosophy is proving a popular course with lifers in one jail. By  Alan Smith
fields.trailText: A spell in prison gives you a lot of time to think, which is perhaps why philosophy is proving a popular course with lifers in one jail. By Alan Smith
fields.body:
When I started teaching philosophy in the prison it was a bit of a leap in the dark.

"They'll love it," Gwen, a full-time tutor, kept on saying. Gwen, after donkey's years with these guys, really does believe in their goodness.

"He just wants his mum really," is a typical Gwenism when some shaven- headed 18-stoner has shuffled off, pouting after one of her bollockings. So I shuffled off, obedient myself, to get philosophy launched on the sea of scepticism that I was sure awaited me.

Most of the guys were as unsure as I was about what was going to happen, although, as I found out later one or two of them, who had Open University degrees on the walls of their cells, were being a bit disingenuous.

Philosophy: it does have a bit of a ring to it, especially doing it in prison; it sounds rather wise, stately, a little bit superior. It didn't take long for us to leave that kind of nonsense behind. Wayne, direct as ever, gets us started.

"Come on then, Al, what's it all about, philosophy? How would you define it?"

I'm tempted to ask him, "What do you mean, definition?" but some merciful instinct for self-preservation stops me. They don't want some clever undergraduate posturing, these guys want an answer they can get a grip on right here and now so I tell them a bit about Socratic method, the method of the idiot child.

"You know," I tell them, "when some daft kid keeps on asking, why? why?" Yes, they know about that. "Well that's all that philosophy is. Philosophers just ask why."

There is a certain amount of storm to weather here.

"Is that it then? Is that all there is to it?" "Well, yes," I say, suddenly fearful that they will walk out on me and leave me to face Gwen with the ruin that I have made of her bright idea.

All this was months ago now and I have settled down with a regular group of 12. People come and go as sentences end and new guys are shipped in and this means that there are quite regular crises as philosophy virgins are seduced into our strange ways. Philosophy has attracted men who have long sentences to serve and they bring into class the hard-faced generosity that gets them through the years. They say things that frighten me to death. Wayne on abortion: "If we could turn back the years, Mark, wouldn't it be better, knowing as we do now that you were going to turn out to be a murdering nut-case who's been nothing but a drain on society, wouldn't aborting you have been a good idea?"

Dear God, I think, head in hands, he's gone too far this time. I ought to have warned him about all the trouble that Socrates was landed in by philosophy. But these guys are neighbours on the wing. They smile at each other. Sometimes, less often now, I get a bad time for being a weakling.

"For God's sake Al will you use your authority and sort these bastards out." "I have no authority, I repudiate it, I spit on authority." "Don't start all that shit," Pete tells me, knowing my game. "Right," says Wayne, brusquely, "come on let's get on with this." "I'll read this next bit shall I," says Pete. I shrug and away we go.

Wayne is a real asset; he just keeps on asking the obvious questions that no one else will ask for fear of looking stupid. He knows nothing. Or does he? Are his questions just a bit too good naturedly naive? I promise myself to get someone to have a peek in his pad where I suspect there are walls full of philosophy books. "Hold on," he says, the devious Yorkshire simpleton, "what's metaphysics then?" Before I can tumble into his trap, Isaac turns to him and treats us all to a lucid, delightful explanation. Isaac is the youngest by far and can get terrible stick, but I suspect that he has just done himself a power of good. "Right, OK," Wayne says, nodding gently into Isaac's beaming face.

We have been talking about aesthetics for the past month or so. This has led us into censorship and this week we have been reading JM Coetzee on Taking Offence. Coetzee suggests that taking offence is a transaction where the powerful and the powerless exchange roles and potencies. Far too late it dawns on me that making this explicit could get one or two of the more idealistic guys into trouble back on the wings where shifts in power, suspected or real, can have swift and devastating consequences.

"Now don't try this at home," I keep on saying, panic mounting as I wish more and more that I had stuck to Epistemology or Philosophy of Mind. Fortunately I have Mo and Pete in the class. These are the steadiest men you could hope to meet, both well into their second decade of imprisonment. Men I admire. Both of them scholars who put me to shame. They try out the idea and try its fit into various contexts: apartheid South Africa, family, prison. Wayne, who has really taken a shine to my version of Socratic method harries them into explanations, forces the occasional pursed- lipped concession. Johnny and Steve are quiet, ironic observers, dropping in occasional gems or deflating absurdities.

They watch me struggle to get a word in and smile as they see my temper going and language deteriorating. I was so unpleasant last week that I brought in a bag of sweets by way of apology. They are not impressed. "He only bought these," Mo points out, "because he was such a right bastard last time."

After two hours of this I feel drained and buzzing all at once. I can't for the life of me see the point of locking up my philosophers. When I say this to my wife she gives me a very old-fashioned look indeed and warns me about going native. Too late.

 Alan Smith teaches philosophy and English literature part-time at Wellingborough Prison.

fields.headline: Dirty hospitals to be named
fields.trailText: Forty-two hospitals will today be named and shamed by the government for having poor standards of hygiene as part of its campaign to clean up the NHS.
fields.body:
Forty-two hospitals will today be named and shamed by the government for having poor standards of hygiene as part of its campaign to clean up the NHS.

The list of dirty institutions, compiled after inspections carried out in more than 600 English hospitals, includes a handful of persistently bad offenders which require special measures to be introduced.

Ten of the worst culprits have already been put on "special measures" and hit squads of experts from the best trusts are to be sent in to tackle the problem and raise standards of cleanliness before an autumn deadline. It is understood that each hospital is being given between £250,000 and £750,000 to clean up. New national hospital cleaning standards aimed at raising cleanliness levels were also being published today.

The inspections of 689 hospitals this year found 94% had cleanliness standards that were acceptable or higher, while 6% were deemed poor. Similar inspections last year found that a third of hospitals had unacceptable cleaning standards.

Findings published in the Health Service Journal revealed that of 700 hospital buildings checked in a snap survey, 250 were given the lowest grade for basic sanitation standards such as tidiness of wards and litter collection.

Hospitals have been rated using a red, amber or green system. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is today expected to visit the Royal Free hospital, north London, which is one of the most improved hospitals, moving from a red rating last year to green.

He said: "Despite this marked improvement, there is to be no let-up in our drive to raise standards of hospital cleanliness. The fundamentals of care are too important to be left to chance."

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 50: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 50: The disease returns to the front pages with the news the government is to step up the precautionary measures.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Times
The paper puts foot and mouth on the front page, reporting that the government and National Farmers' Union are warning precautions must be stepped up after the virus spread to previously unaffected areas.

The Mirror
A short story on page two reveals agriculture minister Nick Brown is now blaming careless farmers for the latest spread of the disease outside existing outbreak areas.

Daily Express
The paper reports on page four that Cumbrian sheep farmer Moira Lineker has chained her gates together to prevent slaughtermen getting in to cull her flock.

Daily Mail
A report by Goldman Sachs estimates, in a worst-case scenario, the foot and mouth epidemic could cost the British economy £8.7bn in lost tourist revenue, tax and payments to farmers.

The Independent
On page six, the paper reveals Bobby Waugh, the Northumberland farmer whose livestock is suspected of triggering the outbreak, has received about £50,000 in government compensation.

fields.standfirst: But only on the football pitch, of course. Sid Lowe on the European aftermath, and the mis-match of the day
fields.trailText: It was Clash of the Titans in Gran Canaria on Sunday - Macca versus Vinny. And the islanders flocked to witness the spectacle - the Estadio Insular was full for the first time this season, while hundreds more fans lined the hillside and balconies overlooking the ground. Outside, tickets changed hands for as much as 30,000 pesetas (£120). Nothing to do with Figo, of course. Or Roberto Carlos, or Raúl - he wasn't even playing.

It was Vinny who drew first blood, a muscular challenge on Luis Figo and a flying overhead clearance sending the grancanarios wild. In truth, though, Samways and McManaman rarely crossed swords. The Las Palmas man always suspected as much - earlier in the week he admitted that he probably wouldn't get near enough to Macca to kick him: "Steve's a bit too quick for me", he confided.

It wasn't about pace, though - playing on opposite sides, Macca and Samways hardly saw each other, although Vinny might be grateful to the scouser for imploring him to calm down, clam down just when he was getting dangerously close to the ref's top pocket for a second time.

Unfortunately for the 20,000 fans who decked the Insular in brilliant yellow, it wasn't just Macca and Vinny who barely clashed - Las Palmas and Real Madrid hardly did either. Iker Casillas - who revealed he'd like the porn star Rocco Sifredi to play him in a bio-pic - was hardly called upon to display his impressive ball-handling skills. Nor was his opposite number Nacho González.

The game's only goal came ten minutes into the second half. Macca's pass released Figo and Guti tamely headed his superb cross straight at the keeper - luckily for the striker, it came straight back and he put in the rebound easily.

Madrid didn't play well, but the Man in the Moustache will be delighted with the result after Deportivo's 2-1 defeat at Zaragoza saw their lead at the top increase to eight points.

It's been a pretty awful week for Depor boss Javier Irureta. Asked to comment on it afterwards, he suddenly turned all PE teacher - "It's got seven days like any other" he said, before forcing the fat kid (Donato, or perhaps Turu Flores) to go running in just his under-pants.

Barca take the brickbats

Predictably, Madrid's win went down badly in Barcelona, especially after yet another week of mutual stirring from the two cities' partisan football press. Sport and El Mundo Deportivo had a field day with Real Madrid's defeat in Istanbul (sensational first half, hideous second), and sought to crank up a supposed rift between Roberto Carlos and Luis Figo after they had, heaven forbid!, given different reasons for Madrid's defeat - conclusive proof that they hate each other's guts.

The Madrid dailies got their revenge with Barça's turgid 0-0 draw against Liverpool. But while Marca and AS derided Serra Ferrer's side as "incapable", "fearful" and plain "boring", the Catalans blamed Gerard Houllier. Such a defensive performance and a 0-0 draw apparently "doesn't befit the great Liverpool teams of the 70s and 80s", teams which the Catalan press obviously never saw play. Just when you thought El Mundo Deportivo didn't have a clue however, it proved you totally wrong, referring to Liverpool as the "Red Devils".

Barça were certainly better to watch than Real this weekend but, 3-0 down in just twenty minutes, they dropped another two points in a 4-4 draw with Villarreal. Again, Víctor was Barça's worst nightmare - he got two, including a stunning 30-yard lob. Actually, Víctor wasn't Barça's very worst nightmare - that was Guardiola: two uncharacteristically sloppy errors from the captain gifted Villarreal their second and fourth goals.

Patrik Kluivert started the Barça come-back with a goal before] half time and went absolutely mental, screaming at his team- mates: "¡Hijos de puta! ¡Venga! ¡Joder!" - roughly, "Fucking c'mon, you sons of bitches". Nice to see he's got a firm grasp of Spanish (but why not Catalan like Hristo Stoichkov, who always preferred "fills de put" to "hijos de puta"?). Anyway, Kluivert's outburst certainly worked - he got another, and a neat Rivaldo finish brought it back to 3-3. Jorge López put Villarreal ahead again but, in the last minute, Kluivert completed his hat-trick to level the score at 4-4.

Gotta keep that pressure on

With Barça and Depor both dropping points, Valencia and Mallorca kept up the pressure for Champions League places. Kily González provided a superb finish to Mendieta's excellent pass as Héctor Cúper's (current) side beat Rayo 4-1, while Luis Aragonés's men sent Numancia to the bottom with a 2-0 win.

No doubt about the side of the week, or even the decade since they were in the tercera división eleven years ago. Even without top scorer Javi Moreno, Alavés followed up their Pink-shirted, penalty-fest demolition of Kaiserslautern with a 4-2 win against another side with a hideous kit, Valladolid (purple and black stripes for them).

Valladolid continue to loiter dangerously close to the relegation zone, level with Real Oviedo who were beaten 3-0 by John Benjamin's Real Sociedad - la Real are now out of the bottom three for the first time in 23 weeks. Racing Santander and Osasuna, 2nd and 3rd bottom, drew 1-1.

Espanyol lost 2-1 at the hands of Málaga with old-boy Dario Silva inevitably on the score-sheet. Like Catanha last week, though, the Uruguayan didn't celebrate his strike.

Speaking of Catanha - he's flying and so is his side Celta de Vigo. Deep in trouble in January, Celta have climbed ten places, and on Sunday they clocked up their fifth win on the trot, 2-1 against Athletic Bilbao. Catanha was on target again, heading home Gustavo López's cross. "Me and Gustavo understand each other perfectly" cooed Catanha afterwards, "I'm going to ask him to marry me".

Sloppy seconds

Two more players obviously madly in love are Atlético Madrid's José Juan Luque and Oscar Mena. Atléti have been on fire since Christmas and promotion, getting closer by the week, looks an even stronger possibility now after their 2-1 win over second-placed Tenerife on Sunday. Luque and Mena were so delighted that a mere peck on the cheek really wouldn't do - Marca's front cover is (dis?)graced by a photo of the two indulging in what could mildly be described as a bit of a snog. Hollywood beckons - fancy playing Iker Casillas, boys?
