fields.headline: Discreet art of the buyback
fields.trailText: Trevor Hemmings has become Blackpool's most powerful businessman over the last three years but remains discreet to the point of near-invisibility.
fields.body:
Trevor Hemmings has become Blackpool's most powerful businessman over the last three years but remains discreet to the point of near-invisibility.

The 65-year-old multimillionaire's interests in the resort could hardly be more prominent, however - among them are the Tower, the piers, the Winter Gardens, the Opera House, Louis Tussauds and a 50% share of Sea World.

Mr Hemmings moved to Lancashire from London as a child, trained as a master builder and made his first fortune working for Pontins holiday camps. He eventually bought the camps from Mr Pontin after serving several years as a director, but subsequently sold them to Scottish & Newcastle for shares. The stock soared, netting him £135m, and last year he quietly bought Pontins back from S&N for a fraction of that.

Mr Hemmings' fortune is estimated at around £450m. He employs 7,000 people at his hotels, 3,500 at pubs, the Vymura wallpaper firm and in horseracing. His most important publicly listed interests are a 50% holding in racecourse group Arena Leisure, a 30% stake in Littlewoods Pools owner Sportech and stakes in TV firm Entertainment Rights and gaming group London Clubs International.

Friends say his dislike of publicity is not mysterious. "It's just his style," said one. "He's accessible to the people that matter to him, down to earth, not at all flashy and is very approachable." He is also incredibly driven. "He's a real 7am to 10pm man, and thinks nothing of working through the night on a deal," says the friend. His businesses are run from Lancashire, but he is a Channel Islands resident and spends much of his time at his racing stud, Mony-musk, in Kanturk, County Cork.

fields.headline: Blackpool's towering gamble
fields.standfirst: The tycoon planning a Las Vegas-style makeover to revitalise the Golden Mile is meeting opposition
fields.trailText: The tycoon planning a Las Vegas-style makeover to revitalise the Golden Mile is meeting opposition.
fields.body:
Monday morning in the off-season at Blackpool and the resort's famous Golden Mile is almost deserted. A gale is whipping in off the Irish Sea, battering billboards advertising forthcoming shows starring Alvin Stardust, the Grumbleweeds and Roy "Chubby" Brown.

There is not a donkey in sight. Guest houses to the north of the promenade are mostly shut, the bowling alley and nightclubs lifeless and several bars boarded up.

One of the few signs of activity is at Gifts Galore, a seafront store opposite the north pier where jesters' hats and beachballs hanging from an awning bob defiantly in the wind.

Huddled inside is a small group of pensioners, browsing through the sticks of rock, postcards and rows of Britney Spears mugs while they wait to get on the coach back home. Two old ladies have strayed into the 'adults only' section and are sniggering uncontrollably at a extensive display of phallic novelty gags.

Yet their laughter disguises a more serious reality.

After decades of decline Britain's most popular holiday resort, synonymous with kiss-me-quick hats and hen parties, is in urgent need of resuscitation.

Unique solution

Blackpool still attracts 12m people each year but visitor numbers are 30% down on six years ago and, for a local economy that derives 85% of its income from tourism, that is a serious issue.

It is a similar story at most other seaside towns, though some are attracting tourists who cannot visit the country during the foot and mouth crisis.

Holidaymakers are shunning British resorts to take advantage of cheap packages and budget flights to go abroad for the sun, according to a recent study by the English Tourist Council.

A unique solution has been proposed for Blackpool. A reclusive multimillionaire wants to turn the town into a Las Vegas for the north, making it a gambling mecca that would attract tourists from all over Europe and revitalise the local economy.

Trevor Hemmings, a former builder who made his first fortune from Pontins holiday camps and is so low profile that some locals liken him to the Wizard of Oz, wants to build a series of Vegas-style casino, hotel and retail complexes on the seafront.

He proposes to build the Pharaoh's Palace Resort, a £130m complex with an ancient Egyptian theme, 100,000 sq ft of gaming floors to be open 24 hours a day, 2,500 slot machines, 100,000 sq ft of conference and exhibition space, a 3,000 sq ft auditorium, a 500-bed hotel and extensive retail space.

To some it is so extravagant as to be unrealistic but minister for tourism Janet Anderson was in town yesterday to hear the results of a new poll that claims 71% of locals are behind the concept and to underline that the government is taking it seriously.

Locals say she has to. Allan Cavill, chief executive of the Blackpool Challenge Partnership, a forum representing local public and private sector interests, says GDP is the 12th lowest in the UK and the third lowest in the region.

Unemployment in the town's four most central wards is 10% to 12%, the area is the third most deprived in the country and 6,000 homes have more than one family living in them.

"There are some pretty frightening social problems right behind the promenade," Mr Cavill said.

"We lost visitors throughout the 1980s and 1990s and it was probably only the slap in the face the Labour party delivered in 1998 when it said that it wouldn't hold its party conference here again until things improved that made people realise it wasn't OK."

Leisure Parcs, the company that Mr Hemmings has formed in partnership with Bank of Scotland and venture capitalists Electra, believes resort casinos can be used as a tool of urban renewal in the same way as they have transformed Atlantic City and Biloxi in the US.

Over there tax from gaming is ploughed back into the local community and into regeneration projects.

Marc Etches, the managing director of Leisure Parcs, claims that the introduction of up to six resort casino hotels offering up to 6,000 rooms could potentially create 15,000 direct jobs, a further 10,000 ancillary jobs and gross revenues in excess of £500m.

Leisure industry watchers believe predictions of 30m annual visitors spending £2bn by 2020 are optimistic. Mr Etches disagrees.

"If we can get 10m visitors now when we have an off-season that runs from October to May then 30m has to be realistic if we have a year round resort," he said. "Without this plan, Blackpool may be supping at the last chance saloon."

Basil Newby, owner of gay nightclub chain In the Pink Leisure, warns the town's image will have to change. "We've got a long way to go," he said. "Las Vegas gets Shirley Bassey and Tom Jones. We get Cannon and Ball and Hale and Pace."

Gaming review

Leisure Parcs has already spent £85m over the past three years buying up local landmarks including the Blackpool Tower, the resort's three piers, the Opera House Theatre, the Winter Gardens entertainment centre, Louis Tussauds Waxworks and the Savoy and Clifton Hotels.

However, it still has some obstacles to overcome if its vision is to become a reality. The first requires a change to the 1968 Regulation of Gaming Act which was introduced to kick organised crime out of gambling. It restricts the way that casinos advertise, bans live entertainment, limits the number of jackpot slot machines and says casinos can only admit new members after a 24-hour "cooling-off" period.

Government sources suggest an ongoing review of gaming will recommend the rules be relaxed when it reports to home secretary Jack Straw in June.

Levying taxes locally may be more difficult, confirms a Treasury spokesman. Regional councils do not have the power to tax local businesses or ring fence where the proceeds are spent. Leisure Parcs will have to modify its proposals.

It will also need other financial partners. The BCP is ready to commit £20m of cash it won through a single regeneration budget bid, but London Clubs International, Mr Etches' commercial partner, has already had its fingers burnt by a casino venture in Las Vegas and its share price has collapsed.

Despite the overwhelming support shown by yesterday's survey there is a growing sense of unease among local small businesses.

Dennis Smith has been running the Abbey Hotel, a 10-bed hotel since moving from Featherstone in west Yorkshire 12 years ago.

He is broadly in favour of casinos but fears shiny new four-star hotels offering subsidised rooms at two-star rates to encourage more gamblers could be disastrous for him and the 2,500 other small hotels in town.

"My business is down 70% over the past five years, the place next door has gone bankrupt twice since I've been here and, despite spending £80,000 improving a property that I bought for £126,000, I've been told it is now only worth £115,000," Mr Smith said. "This could be the straw that breaks me."

His concerns are echoed by David Gee, the owner of Gifts Galore, who last year saw trade rise to record levels after he decided to target the stag and hen parties and stay open beyond midnight.

"Casinos could destroy this town and my business," said Mr Gee. "The seafront will be nothing but pawn brokers and strip joints."

Infrastructure will also need to be improved. Seven million people live within a one hour drive of Blackpool but car parking and rail links would not be able to cope with the volume of visitors. Even now it is often quicker and cheaper for Londoners to fly to southern France or Spain than brave the Virgin train service to Blackpool.

Yet what worries locals most is that there is no alternative on the table if the Leisure Parcs plan falls at the first hurdle.

"How can highly trained people only come up with one option?" Mr Smith said. "There's a set of farts in the town hall who've been presented with this plan and think its manna from the gods. They think the town will be quids in but I tell you, ten years from now, thousands of us will be out of business."

The bets have been placed and the stakes are high. Blackpool must wait until the gaming review body reports in June to find out if it has any chance of winning.

fields.headline: Carlton and Granada tighten ONdigital's purse-strings
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Carlton and Granada TV are poised to rein in spending on OnDigital, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Carlton and Granada TV are poised to curb spending on OnDigital after completion of its ongoing strategic review.

The announcement is expected to be made at ONdigital's quarterly subscription figures briefing in a fortnight's time.

The two companies that control ITV are said to be concerned at the high levels of spending at ONdigital.

At present, ONdigital is spending more than £300m a year on acquiring new customers, most of which is taken up by set-top box subsidies.

It is thought ONdigital may be forced to slash subsidies on free set-top boxes, a move that could either lock ONdigital out of the digital market or prompt BSkyB to follow suit.

Analysts, however, are not convinced BSkyB is likely to change its own set-top box subsidy strategy - at least not in this current box's lifetime.

Neither parties would comment on the latest speculation, first reported in today's Daily Telegraph.

webTitle: Teaching children to control their anger

fields.headline: Teaching children to control their anger
fields.standfirst: An egg-timer is just one tool in a campaign to teach children in schools to control their rage. By  David Ward
fields.trailText: An egg-timer is just one tool in a campaign to teach children in schools to control their rage. By David Ward.
fields.body:
Everyone knows what happens if you give a full bottle of Coke a vigorous shake and then unscrew the top. So the year 3 children at Benchill primary in south Manchester dived for cover when visitor Kim Wade flexed her muscles.

Wade, head of Manchester's behaviour and support service, resisted the temptation to open the bottle and let the fizz drench the pupils. She had made her point: the frothing of the drink was a metaphor for the build-up and explosion of temper.

Benchill's children were having a session on anger management. There is no suggestion that they are any more angry than children at other schools in the city and the lesson was intended to help identify and deal with the rages that life in the classroom and playground can provoke.

Wade and her team run courses for four- to 16-year-olds in both anger management and conflict resolution as a way of defusing situations that lead to exclusions. They have devised their own programmes and do not confine their activities to children.

"If parents or teachers are having problems managing a child, we work with them too," said Wade. "And if children see everyone coming from the same direction, they tend to toe the line more readily."

Her team grabbed the headlines when the story broke of how they used a one-to-one anger management course to return to the classroom an eight-year-old girl (not from Benchill) who had been excluded five times in three years.

The crisis came when the girl kicked and spat at a teacher whose colleagues then threatened to strike.

The girl returned to school with the help of an egg-timer: when her temper threatened to explode, her teacher turned the timer over and the rage evaporated as the sand flowed through the glass.

Wade did not pack an egg-timer into her briefcase when she went to Benchill, but she did include reels of stickers (rewards for good behaviour) and Angry Arthur, Hiawyn Oram's prize-winning story of a boy whose rages set off thunderstorms, earthquakes and cosmic meltdown.

What, she asked, could Arthur have done rather than lose his rag when his mum refused to let him watch a cowboy film on television?

"He could have gone to bed as he was asked," suggested one angelic child. "He could have calmed down a bit and asked his mum nicely," said another. A third pragmatically suggested that he could have asked his mother to video the film.

"There's nothing wrong with getting angry, but it's what we do when we are angry that can cause problems," added Wade. "Put your hand up if you get angry and do the wrong thing."

A forest of hands shot up: infants tend to be honest and uninhibited.

The children then broke into groups to write down what made them angry: "nicking money", "snatching things", "when our mum wakes us up for school", "when I can't watch Popstars", "when someone gets in the bathroom before you", "scrime" [ie screaming].

The children gathered back in a corner of the sun-filled room and the bottle of Coke made its appearance as they were asked to consider the physical signs of their anger. They decided that they ground their teeth, went red in the face, stamped their feet and made fists as their hearts beat faster and their veins stood out.

"My baby stops breathing when he cries 'cos he's angry," said a voice from the middle of the crowd.

Wade invited the group to show what they looked like when they were in a temper. Most pulled horrible faces but Shelley let out a bat-like squeak of fury.

It was time for suggested antidotes. "Close your eyes and breathe in very slowly for five, count five and then breathe out very slowly for five," suggested Wade. Some children breathed too fast for therapy but slowed down at the second attempt before returning to their tables to draw pictures of angry people: some of the resulting Lowry-like figures were horribly deformed with frenzy.

"We are hoping to spread this work across the city in a preventative way, not just when a problem strikes," confided Wade in a quiet moment. "We tend to find that our work brings an early improvement. If progress dips, we will come back."

Dave Smith, Benchill's new head, sees anger management and conflict resolution as strategies in creating an atmosphere of stability and trust in which learning can flourish. "I'm trying to teach children that you don't run away from a problem," he said. "You confront it and someone will be there to support you."

Back with the year 3s, Wade asked how they might pass on to others - including adults - what they have learned. They agreed that slow breathing was a useful way to knock the stuffing out of rage.

One small girl suggested another helpful technique. "Give your mum a vodka and Coke," she said, with an eye on the bottle which had not been opened.

webTitle: High rate of suicide among female doctors

fields.headline: High rate of suicide among female doctors
fields.trailText: Female doctors are twice as likely to commit suicide as other women, according to government-funded research published today.
fields.body:
Female doctors are twice as likely to commit suicide as other women, according to government-funded research published today.

They take their own lives more often than male colleagues, according to a study which will ring alarm bells in the NHS, which is employing more women in medical posts.

The authors, from Oxford University's department of psychiatry, say ways must be found to combat stress and mental health problems among doctors, of whom more than a third are women. More work is also needed to ascertain why doctors in some specialist areas of medicine, such as community health - which includes family planning clinics, immunisation centres and children's services, anaethestics, psychiatry and general practice - are far more likely to kill themselves than in others.

The findings, published in the Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, emerged from a study of 223 doctors in England and Wales who had committed suicide or whose death came from an undetermined cause between 1979 and 1995. Male doctors appeared only two-thirds as likely to kill themselves as members of the general population, although unusually, the suicide rate among male community health doctors was 12 times that of women specialists in this area.

Other research has already demonstrated that GPs are more prone than others to think "suicidal thoughts" and the latest research suggests they are 3.5 times more at risk of putting these into practice than colleagues in general hospital medicine. Seniority was not a factor.

The authors say the risk to women doctors "requires particular monitoring in the light of the very large increase in the numbers of women entering medicine." John Ashton, the journal's co-editor, said : "This is a descriptive study. It doesn't enable us to get into causational links. You would need to do more detailed work."

But he speculated that women doctors, who were often intelligent, high achievers and perfectionists, might have a personality profile that made them more vulnerable.

The British Medical Association said: "There is an urgent need for family-friendly specialities in every speciality. It is particularly important to discover what drives these women to suicide since more than half the current medical graduates are women."

The Department of Health said: "All the strands are coming together to improve doctors' working conditions so hopefully these rates will come down."

fields.headline: The biggest C
fields.standfirst: Why does breast cancer attract more column inches and cash than any other form of the disease?  Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.trailText: Why does breast cancer attract more column inches and cash than any other form of the disease? Anita Chaudhuri reports.
fields.body:
A report just released by Macmillan Cancer Relief tells us what most of us already know: breast cancer has become a cause celeb. Of all the media coverage of cancer assessed by the study, a quarter was devoted to breast cancer (lung cancer got less than half that amount) while the number of celebrities involved was far higher (277 mentions) for breast cancer than for the 200 other types of known varieties.

Much of this has come about through the vigorous campaigning of Breakthrough, the charity that launched its Fashion Targets Breast Cancer initiative with a posse of pert-breasted supermodels and celebrities. This, naturally enough, ensured a steady flow of high-profile media coverage. Whatever one thinks of the methodology, the results are impressive since the charity has already raised £15m to launch a breast cancer research centre.

Which brings us back to the Macmillan study. This reveals that there are more than 200 cancers, most of which are never debated in the media. Colorectal cancers, for example, got just 7% of the press coverage reviewed, yet bowel cancer is the third biggest killer. Could it be that breast cancer has become fashionable to the detriment of other types of cancer awareness?

Delyth Morgan, chief executive of Breakthrough, refutes this. "Seven years ago, when I started at Breakthrough, no one talked about cancer of any form, least of all breast cancer which was combining two taboos, sex and death. The Macmillan report reflects how successful we are. We learned the lessons of the Aids campaigners in the 80s and we have worked hard to present the issues creatively. For that reason, Breakthrough has become a trailblazer for all cancer charities and many have mimicked our style of campaigning."

That much is certainly true: the Cancer Research Campaign recently produced a series of sexy ads featuring perfect bottoms to boost awareness of bowel cancer - but as yet there have been precious few glossy magazines fighting to give away black ribbons commemorating lung cancer awareness month, fewer still supermodels willing to adopt the disease as their pet charity. Well, they wouldn't, would they? That would mean stubbing out those super-chic, appetite-suppressing Marlboro Lights.

Breast cancer kills more than 13,000 women every year in the UK and more than 30,000 are diagnosed as having it. However, the disease is most prevalent in women over 65, least common among those under 30. "Our report shows that breast cancer awareness among the young is very high, thanks to these celebrity campaigns, and there is a very high degree of public interest and sympathy," says Deborah Lincoln of Macmillan. "This is good because cancer is a long-term disease, so they will know what to look for when they're older. The problem is, even with breast cancer, no campaign or magazine is really reaching out to older women, the at-risk group."

Certainly it is ironic that breast cancer is marketed as a young woman's disease, which it patently is not, while lung cancer is associated with elderly men. In fact lung cancer is rising among women at the rate of 11% per year, a pattern set to worsen given the high number of teenage girls who smoke. A recent study indicated that 33% of 11-15-year-old girls are regular smokers (far more than boys), many drawn by the promise of losing weight. So why are there no campaigns with glamorous spokesmodels getting the message through to them?

Lincoln says wryly: "Well, when you're 15, you think you're immortal, don't you? Getting the message through is never going to be easy, but added to that, there isn't the same media interest in lung cancer. There is far less public sympathy because many people take the view that sufferers of the disease are themselves to blame through smoking."

It is worth noting, too, that most of the celebrities involved with cancer charities tend to be women. "Men don't like talking about illness," Lincoln says. "And a lot of men are embarrassed about talking about their nether regions. Even our prostate cancer helpline gets more calls from women than men, presumably wives phoning on behalf of their husbands. Robbie Williams has started campaigning for the Institute of Cancer Research and George Carman QC talked about his cancer before he died, so things are changing slowly."

Morgan agrees. "I don't know if I'd say cancer was a gender issue. There's a women's media that has given us opportunities to debate the disease. Now men's magazines are catching up and beginning to discuss health. Maybe we'll see more debate about other types of cancers among men."

webTitle: Students hit by privatisation of university residences

fields.headline: Student rents soaring
fields.standfirst: Student pockets are being hit the hardest by large-scale privatisation of university residences, according to research out today.  Donald MacLeod  on a worrying trend
fields.trailText: Student pockets are being hit the hardest by large-scale privatisation of university residences, according to research out today. Donald MacLeod on a worrying trend
fields.body:
Student rents are soaring at much more than the rate of inflation, according to a National Union of Students survey published today. Since the last academic year, rent rises for self-catering accommodation are particularly steep, up to 8% compared to a national inflation rate of 2.7%. Not surprisingly, London shows the highest rents in the current academic year - a probable factor in the fall in applications to several universities in the capital.

Preliminary results of the annual NUS survey showed the average weekly rent for students in university or university-linked accommodation has risen from £54.72 to £57.32, an increase of 4.75%. But for self-catering accommodation, rises ranged from 8.2% for single rooms (an average rent of £50.40), 7.6% (£41.82) for shared rooms and 6.5% (£62.84) for en suite provision.

This reflects the declining popularity of communal dining halls among students as well as young people's efforts to economise by doing their own cooking.

Students were being priced out of education, said Rachel Cashman, the union's vice-president for welfare. "Housing for students continues to take up a huge proportion of their income. Accommodation costs are rising in some areas at almost three times the rate of inflation."

The situation was set to get even worse as universities privatised their halls of residence to raise funding, she argued. "It's like top-up fees through the back door. Universities are trying to privatise large chunks of their student accommodation. The priority for a lot of these private companies is building accommodation for conferences in the vacations rather than building a home for students during term-time.

"We have got to stop the conference culture where it is OK to sell off student residences to make big bucks from conferences."

But companies involved in building or managing student residences for universities and colleges argue their investment releases funds that institutions can invest in libraries and laboratories.

Clive Crawford, managing director for Jarvis University Partnerships Programme, said its investment at Plymouth University where they run 645 rooms had helped the university mount its bid for a joint medical school with Exeter.

"We have so far invested £100m in the sector - money which universities would otherwise have had to provide for themselves."

Crawford denied that students would pay higher rents in private-run halls. Rents had to relate to what the universities themselves charged. "They create the benchmark for private providers. I don't think from the student point of view what we do has any impact."

Jarvis, which manages 3,600 student rooms and has a further 2,600 under development, is building a student village in Manchester with more than 1,000 rooms for the city's three universities and the Northern College of Music. The firm also has developments at Reading, Glasgow, Oxford Brookes, York and Ulster, as well as managing 1,600 rooms for Luton University.

Many universities are struggling to modernise their halls of residence on dwindling funds, believes Crawford. All face what he calls the "en suite bomb" in trying to let rooms and attract students. "There will come a time when students no longer accept non-en suite accommodation. This accommodation fills up first - students don't want to share facilities with strangers."

 A legal judgment last week will strengthen the trend towards universities using property companies to manage their student accommodation. Greenwich won a six-year case against Customs and Excise over whether its student village should be zero-rated for VAT. Customs claimed the concession applied only if the university itself dealt directly with vacation lettings. A judicial review ruled that Customs should have made this clear, opening the way to possible claims for substantial refunds by other universities.

2. SOAS £84.62

3. Queen Mary College *£70.00

4. St Mary's Col, Twick'h'm £70.00

5. Westminster *£69.86

6. North London £68.00

7. South Bank *£66.51

8. King's College London *£65.24

9. London Institute *£64.80

10. London Guildhall *£64.50

fields.headline: Blair and the Queen
fields.standfirst:
A premier remains silent as Britain's monarchy reveals its avarice and cynicism

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The prime myth about the British monarchy is that it is not political.
fields.body:
The prime myth about the British monarchy is that it is not political. It is intensely and variously political, a huge political fact, a vast edifice of history louring over public life, a definer of the national image, a load on the national psyche, the focus of feeling and opinion that is itself politically potent.

It is therefore a suitable subject for the usual processes of politics such as challenge, debate, change, perhaps radical reform. The most dispiriting aspect of the latest defilement of the royal system is the government's refusal to accept that important ministers have any role whatever to play in such discussion.

I don't believe the monarchy is threatened. It's apparent, in this nation of deference and amnesia, that the odds in favour of a republic being invented are barely worth reckoning. Whatever Sophie did, the monarch would survive. However Edward tried to capitalise on his only inherited asset, nothing more drastic than scandal would follow. The British people have a bottomless capacity to live with the cynicism and pretence, the avarice and the self- importance, that has come to envelop their monarchy. They love the voyeurism it satisfies. Most of them also doubt that any other constitutional system would be better.

But even short of ruin, the monarchy needs taking apart. It has lost its magic in the half-century since an opinion poll found that 35% of the people believed the Queen had been chosen by God. At the same time it has become a more contentious issue. More of a social and cultural problem. More capable of provocation. More political, especially now that politics touches everything.

It's all very well sonorously agreeing that the royal family must remain above party, but such a rule is no longer adequate to the case. Now that ideology is dead, party no longer determines what is political. Every time Prince Charles talks about GM food or organic farming or architecture or homeopathic medicine, he is intervening in questions which reverberate with the kind of controversy that can only be given that name, and he changes his status from neutered cipher to the holder of important opinions, some of them outrageous.

So this is a political phenomenon, not to be fire-walled against a normal political response. Nor is it just about the people in the so-called family. One reformist device is to say that there are too many of these people, and that slimming down, via the elimination of certain countesses and dukes, would invigorate public sympathy. Unfortunately, that turns out to be a red herring.

For natural wastage is already occurring. It's perhaps a little-noticed fact. When the Queen Mother dies, she will not be replaced. Her particular office comes to an end. When Princess Margaret dies, her role also will be eliminated. Her children, one a successful creative businessman, don't look like public royals of the future. What about new Kents and Gloucesters? Running as far from the public eye as possible. Apparently Princess Alexandra and the Princess Royal have not bred natural public servants either. Very soon the problem will not be how to keep so many royals from abusing their status, but how to get the decent side of the work done. Who will there be left to salute a hundred march-pasts, fill a thousand charity presidencies, visit 10,000 hospitals, or do Wimbledon?

The broader royal family, in other words, is already waning. Many of its members no doubt trade on their connections, but in smaller ways than an upwardly mobile countess in public relations was always certain to do. As far as individuals are concerned, the future is narrowed down to the offspring of the fertile princes.

Someone will need to decide what they can and cannot be allowed to do within the rules. But this is not the real issue. The real issue is how the monarchy as an institution fits into British life, and how its utilitarian functions can become the focus of its existence, now that the magic is mostly torn apart.

The answer is elusive. For there's a desire to pretend the magic still exists. The aura of royalty continues to entrance a certain kind of operator, especially if he or she is foreign. Sheikhs and presidents have often heard little about the royal family's follies, and don't object to the hauteur and self-importance that remain its inextinguishable traits.

Rather like Edward Heath and Margaret Thatcher, royals' shelf-life can extend abroad for some years after they've been abandoned by their domestic audience, though it's impossible to believe anyone would spend a dime on British goods just because Princess Michael recommended them.

The afterglow of the magic can still be traced at home as well. Snobbery keeps it going. The age-old duplicity survives, of an audience that puts royals on a remote pedestal while still sucking up every detail of their private lives and then knocking them righteously to earth. But the downside is getting heavier. The sheer unreconstructed pervasiveness of the royals' own snobbery, their untouchable privilege, the grandeur of lives they often cannot pay for, not to mention the rapacity of the bewildered people who marry into them, have become an awful blot on modern Britain.

The forces that dominate the argument about this are first the Queen, and secondly the media. We never hear directly from the Queen, but her proxies are invariably on hand in defensive mode, shoring up the status quo, insisting that change can come only at imperceptible speed. It's true that she did eventually agree to pay some income tax. But the notion of scaling down the outward signs of monarchism, cutting back the houses, or formally de-royalising the more marginal figures is ruled out.

And most newspapers, for their part, go along with this, living to the commercial limit the British hypocrisies that want to keep all the royals, if only for the purpose of flaying them alive.

What these two power centres have in common is that the government fears or excessively respects them. Mr Blair doesn't want to have any part in a discussion, and in the wake of the Wessex scandal lets it be known, incredibly, that he doesn't believe the modernisation of the monarchy is a valid item on the public agenda. Even with an election in the offing, this seems a pretty craven retreat into on-message discipline. We must hope that, when the election is over, we find he doesn't really mean it.

For, as a believer in the constitutional monarchy, he must surely see that its value is in jeopardy even if its existence isn't. We have to have it, but the Queen and court can't be the ones to decide what it is, what it does, what it should look like, how it divides dignity and efficiency, how much we must be in thrall to its historic pretensions not to mention its churchly claims.

These are public servants. They exist only at the pleasure of parliament and people. They are a political fact, about which only the government can lead a debate that might get somewhere.

hugoyoung@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Labour's oaths of loyalty
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: To scrap government ministers' oath of personal loyalty to the Queen has been among Tony Benn's dearest wishes, as these early political diaries show. But the former cabinet minister steps down soon after half a century as an MP, with the ancient relationship still unchanged.
fields.body:
To scrap government ministers' oath of personal loyalty to the Queen has been among Tony Benn's dearest wishes, as these early political diaries show. But the former cabinet minister steps down soon after half a century as an MP, with the ancient relationship still unchanged.

October 21 1964

I had to go to the privy council office for a rehearsal of the ceremony of admission into the privy council. We were greeted by the most awful stoogey-looking people. The rehearsal was terribly degrading as we were told that we had to kneel on a footstool before the Queen and assent to the privy council oath which had a real Mau-Mau quality. Charlie [Pannell] and I chattered during the rehearsal and tried to look as if we were not taking it too seriously. I'm afraid the officials were profoundly shocked. I made no attempt to conceal my feelings.

Then we were driven to Buckingham Palace. An officer in breeches, spurs, a sword and full court dress greeted us and we went into a drawing room. Herbert Bowden, the new lord president of the council, was there, and I asked him whether I had to go through with it, as I did find the terms of the oath so degrading and distasteful. He said that he knew I would but that I had to do it because if I didn't I couldn't get cabinet papers. Many of the others with me felt the same but I suppose it was particularly unpleasant for me. Charlie said I ought to do it for the sake of the party and it was really for that reason that I did. I have always wanted to be a privy councillor because it is the greatest honour in the parliamentary field but when it came to it, it was terrible.

We were summoned in one by one to the Queen's drawing room and she shook us by the hand. Then we stood in a row and the oath was administered to those who were swearing. I affirmed. I did it because I disapprove of a religious oath for any but religious purposes.

We then went up to the Queen one after another, kneeling and picking up her hand and kissing it, and then bowing. I did the most miniature bow ever seen and returned to my line. When it was over she made a couple of remarks and we all walked by and shook hands. After that I had the oath of the postmaster general administered to me. I left the palace boiling with indignation and feeling that this was an attempt to impose tribal magic and personal loyalty on people whose real duty was only to their electors.

February 23 1968

At lunch I found myself sitting next to the Duke of Edinburgh. He wanted to connect the monarchy more directly with ministers and said he thought that privy councils were an absolute waste of time; that the PM's audience with the Queen should be broadened out to include other ministers who could explain things to her. He thought the ombudsman should have been put into the royal household to make the monarchy seem closer to the people and to represent the nation. The duke said he acted as a sort of unofficial ombudsman and I think he does. I tried to point out that the monarchy was linked in many people's minds with a lot of reactionary forces.

July 11 1969

At lunch, the Queen was very pleasant. I asked her if royalty had to be so formal. The Queen said that it is just that you have to dress up and be told what to do for privy council. Obviously, she did not like the suggestion the thing was more formal than necessary

October 6 1969

Harold warned me on Saturday that I might have to go to Balmoral to kiss hands with the Queen on appointment, and I said, "How ridiculous. I can't anyway, I'm going to Telford." He said, "Well, the palace insist." In the end I got out of it, but not without a very sharp exchange with the privy council office. I was damned if I was going to waste a whole day.

October 22 1969

I went to Buckingham Palace to be sworn in. Godfrey Agnew, who was clerk of the privy council, said how very upset the Queen had been at the newspaper story that other ministers who had gone up [to Balmoral] had not enjoyed it and had thought it a waste of time. Here was a man trying to preserve the monarchy on the basis that you couldn't conceivably discuss it, because if you did, its authority might be undermined.

Extracted with permission from Diaries 1963-72 (Hutchinson)

fields.headline: Modernising monarchy
fields.standfirst:
The task can't be left to the royals alone
Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: In the wake of the Wessexgate affair we are promised a thorough review of roles and responsibilities of the minor royals.
fields.body:
In the wake of the Wessexgate affair we are promised a thorough review of roles and responsibilities of the minor royals. Welcome though this is, it would be wishful to hold out much hope of radical reform since the review is to be carried out by the royal family itself. There is further talk of modernisation. This is also welcome, though it is even more uncertain who would do the modernising.

The Labour party - new or old - has always had an ambivalent attitude towards the monarchy. The subject has not been discussed at a party conference since 1923. If, as is rumoured, there are several cabinet members with republican sympathies they tend to keep them out of sight. The prime minister is a blank sheet. The only insider to have been at all forthcoming on the monarchy is Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell. In assorted articles he has described Prince Philip as "insensitive and stupid", Charles as an "overprivileged twit" who went to a "spanking academy" and the royal family in general as "thick... they represent much that is wrong in this country, notably its class system, obsession with titles, dressing up and patronage and the arrogance of unelected power." But that was in the days when he had on-the-record views of his own.

Since parliament has an aversion - both instinctive and constitutional - to discussing the monarchy it may be a job best left to the committees. There is a strong case for the public accounts committee and the public administration committee to set up a joint inquiry. One could examine the costs of the monarchy, the other could delve into the constitutional issues. All committees have the powers "to send for persons, papers and records". This would be the ideal forum in which to examine such esoterica as the civil list, prerogative powers and the Act of Settlement, which even the attorney general would now like to see reformed.

Rightly or wrongly, few subjects arouse greater public passions than the future of the monarchy and the conduct of the royal family. By refusing to join in the debate politicians merely confirm the impression that Westminster is detached from the true concerns of the country and is failing in its duty to scrutinise and invigilate power. Faced by a choice between continuing trial by tabloids and a dignified select committee inquiry, the royal family itself would be well advised to welcome some outside help in its programme of reform.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: A Wessex Special begins with a clarification on behalf of Kim Howells, the DTI dishpot whose transition from NUM Scargill loyalist to Blairy lickspittle won him a Turncoat nomination.
fields.body:
 A Wessex Special begins with a clarification on behalf of Kim Howells, the DTI dishpot whose transition from NUM Scargill loyalist to Blairy lickspittle won him a Turncoat nomination. When Kim said the royal family were "a bit bonkers" all assumed he was raising the mental health question under orders from Alastair Campbell - an easy mistake given Ali's routine smearing of people as mad and Kim's nerviness about tying a shoelace without express permission from No 10.

However, readers who recall items here about Kim's adult movie career in seventies X-rated classic The Body will have guessed that he meant that "bonkers" differently. My colleague Marina Hyde calls his office to say how much we were tickled by this ribald comment. "I can give him a message," says assistant Chris Raybould, warily.

Very well. Our money men arrive today from Thailand and Indonesia, and are anxious to cast Kim as the male lead in our new project The Countess and The Turncoat (subtitled Oh Ma'am, We're All Bonkers Now!). We want a meet for Wednesday at the Dorchester, so could he call us urgently? "Errr ..." And will he retain his old stage name of Kimberlii Howells? "Erm ... right. I'll ask him," says Chris. Excellent.

 Good to hear Jonathan Aitken reviewing the papers on Radio 4's Broadcasting House on Sunday morning, and showing such "sympathy" to Sophie over this "new low in tabloid nastiness". (Try to forgive them, Jonathan, even as Jesus forgave his persecutors). It's natural and right that the BBC should want Jonathan to share his personal morality with listeners, but if he does become a regular could all fees be sent straight to the trustee in bankruptcy? Another 572 years of weekly pontificating and he could pay us back. Next week, Kevin Maxwell's top tips on stakeholder pensions on Money Box Live.

 Meanwhile, the position of line-dancing, tank-top-wearing Times managing editor George Brock looks ever more delicate. George recently moved into low-rent apartments in Kensington Palace, you will recall, his wife being an assistant private secretary to the Queen. This means that he is enjoying gracious accommodation care of the monarchy while drawing a salary from arch republican Rupert Murdoch. When he hears all the juicy royal gossip, is his first loyalty to missus or gaffer? Marina calls editor Peter Stothard's office to ask whether he'll be conducting a "a review of possible conflicts of interest" (to borrow from his own Sophie leader yesterday) but Peter isn't in.

 Concern also mounts for the Queen's spin doctor Simon Walker, the genius who placed Sophie's "my Eddie's no screamer" interview in the News of the World. We call the palace to offer Simon the Diary PR account. Quite undeservedly, this column seems to have picked up a reputation for inaccuracy which may damage my own chances of following the well-trodden career path from here to the editor's chair, and Simon could be the man to turn things round. But just like Stodgy, Kimberlii and everyone else, he isn't there. Last night, a colleague of his called Sue informs us, in what office politics experts might view as a magnificently brave move, he left "at last for his very belated holiday". Sue insists he will get our job offer message on his return. Sorry, his what? "His return." Would you spell that, please? Hello? Sue? Hello??

 If Simon does return, how will Sandy Henney, the press adviser sacked by Prince Charles for a trivial cockup over a Telegraph picture exclusive, feel about it? webTitle: New role for Andrew in doubt after royal fiasco

fields.headline: New role for Andrew in doubt after royal fiasco
fields.standfirst: Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Buckingham Palace review of the business interests of minor royals is to examine the Duke of York's proposed trade ambassador role amid high-level concerns that it could end in another public relations disaster.
fields.body:
The Buckingham Palace review of the business interests of minor royals is to examine the Duke of York's proposed trade ambassador role amid high-level concerns that it could end in another public relations disaster.

Some royal sources are worried that if the prince is seen to be mixing pleasure with obligations to promote British businesses abroad he could become engulfed in a mess similar to that of the Earl and Countess of Wessex.

Prince Andrew is due to leave the Royal Navy in July, and it has been decided that he should take up a position as a roving promoter of British trade. But he is known for his enjoyment of leisure pursuits, and officials believe there must be strict rules to limit his foreign trips to business interests. "It would be a disaster again if he combined business and pleasure," one royal source said.

The prince is known to enjoy the high life. He was photographed earlier this year with a number of topless models on holiday in Thailand, and toured the notorious red light district of Patpong.

His recent friendships have been called into question: the prince has partied with Nellee Hooper, a record producer known for wild behaviour, and the socialite Ghislaine Maxwell, daughter of the late disgraced tycoon Robert Maxwell, who escorted him to a "hookers and pimps" party in New York.

Officials said the review, ordered in the wake of the "Sophie tapes" controversy, needs to be completed before the prince takes up his new role.

Yesterday the Countess of Wessex returned to her office at RJH Public Relations, as the firm's future looked grim. MediaGuardian.co.uk revealed that the Banyan Tree luxury hotel in Phuket, Thailand, had cut its ties with RJH. The complex was furious that the countess's business partner, Murray Harkin, suggested it would have been able to organise a private villa for gay sex. It was also angry that RJH, on its website, described the resort as a client: a deal had not been signed.

Professional organisations criticised the firm. The Public Relations Standards Council chairman, Roger Haywood, said: "She shouldn't use her connections like this. It's not good for the clients or the business and is damaging to PR in general." The Institute of Public Relations is writing to Mr Harkin for an explanation of his behaviour.

At Buckingham Palace shell-shocked officials were conducting a post mortem. The Queen was said to be despondent that the affair had prompted a political debate about the future of the monarchy. The atmosphere at Windsor, where the Queen is staying, was said to be "gloomy".

The Prince of Wales, who is at Balmoral, and the Queen are aghast at the way the affair was handled. Simon Walker, the beleaguered communications director seconded from BA to modernise the family's image, was the focus for blame. He is now on holiday in China.

There is particular resentment about Mr Walker because of his salary: he is thought to earn about £250,000, while a source suggested that the Queen's private secretary, Sir Robin Janvrin, is on around £160,000. Sir Robin is now attempting to repair relations with the press complaints commission, after palace briefings had blamed the watchdog for suggesting the countess's disastrous interview with the News of the World. Instead of heading off publication of earlier comments, incorrect and highly damaging versions of her remarks appeared elsewhere. The NoW finally published its original material on Sunday.

webTitle: Virus spreads as calls for vaccination grow

fields.headline: Virus spreads as calls for vaccination grow
fields.standfirst:
Containment policy Recruits trained to inoculate animals

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth epidemic continued to spread into previously uninfected areas yesterday as it emerged that a private company has been asked by the Ministry of Agriculture to train hundreds of people in Scotland to vaccinate animals.
fields.byline: John Vidal, Gerard Seenan  and Michael White
fields.body:
The foot and mouth epidemic continued to spread into previously uninfected areas yesterday as it emerged that a private company has been asked by the Ministry of Agriculture to train hundreds of people in Scotland to vaccinate animals.

A team of people from the Scottish Agricultural College is recruiting up to 225 people and the first exercise has taken place in Dumfries and Galloway, where there have been more than 130 outbreaks so far.

The recruits are being divided into 75 teams and will coordinate and vaccinate in infected areas if the decision is made to take this route.

Yesterday the Scottish executive's rural affairs department said vaccination exercises were taking place and that Scotland could decide a different policy to England and Wales. But it said vaccination was still not on the cards: "These are contingency plans but there have been no field trials. We are not considering it at this stage."

Extra troops were drafted into Scotland yesterday as the disease was confirmed at farms many miles from previous outbreaks. Until the weekend, Scottish cases had been confined to a relatively small area of Dumfries and Galloway and there was a wide belief that the disease there was being contained.

But new cases in Jedburgh and Hownam, between 25 and 30 miles from previously confirmed cases, have provoked an immediate revision of the operation.

The Scottish rural affairs minister, Ross Finnie, travelled to the newly infected area to assess the "very worrying" development.

The distance between the new outbreak and the previously isolated infection area is thought to be too far for the disease to have been carried in the air. The National Farmers' Union in Scotland said it suspected the virus had been transferred by people or on farm vehicles.

Ten farms adjoining the infected ones will now have 12,000 sheep and 2,500 cattle slaughtered.

As farmers' unions in Wales warned that their members were losing confidence in the government's ability to eliminate foot and mouth, the number of animals authorised for slaughter reached 1,366,000 - of which 888,000 had been killed. The minister of agriculture, Nick Brown, told MPs that the number waiting to be culled had risen to a record 478,000. Maff admitted it might have to store dead animals in sealed skips to cope with the backlog of 329,000 animals awaiting disposal.

Yesterday there were 22 new cases by 8pm, mostly in Cumbria and southern Scotland, bringing the total number of outbreaks across the country to 1,157. It is widely feared that most of the unique hill sheep of the Lake District will not survive. There have been nine confirmed cases within the national park, including near Bassenthwaite, Keswick and on common land on the fells. Yesterday a case was confirmed under Skiddaw mountain.

The council for national parks said four parks were now infected with 17 separate outbreaks, including six in the Yorkshire Dales. The charity predicted the loss of traditional farming methods, threatening dramatic changes to Britain's upland landscape, a high failure rate among small businesses and the collapse of support services.

But organised opposition to the EU slaughter-only policy is mounting. In the Netherlands, where there have been 18 confirmed cases, riot police used water cannon to disperse 200 angry farmers calling for vaccination, and in Britain the government was accused of acting illegally by forcing farmers to hand over healthy animals to be culled.

One campaign group, Stop Animal Deaths, said "scores" of people were prepared to defy moves to kill uninfected livestock. And Britain's 3,000 organic farmers were urged by the Soil Association to make a stand against the slaughter policy. The association set up a group called Farmers for Voluntary Vaccination and accused NFU leaders of suppressing the case for vaccination and leaving members "fearful and misinformed".

"They have failed to explain to members the virtues of potential alternatives," said a spokesman, Patrick Holden. "We must never again be forced to witness this medieval slaughter".

Mr Brown told the House of Commons he hoped it would soon be possible to start lifting some of the restrictions on livestock movement and urged farmers to cooperate fully with the mass slaughter policy. Vaccination of livestock remained an option, he said. "But it would be a major step to take, with significant consequences."

webTitle: Nine months old and heading for fifth home

fields.headline: Nine months old and heading for fifth home
fields.trailText: The twin baby girls adopted by Judith and Alan Kilshaw last night faced the prospect of a fifth home in just nine months of life, following the high court ruling that they should be returned to America.
fields.body:
The twin baby girls adopted by Judith and Alan Kilshaw last night faced the prospect of a fifth home in just nine months of life, following the high court ruling that they should be returned to America.

Whether or not the Kilshaws appeal against the decision, the turmoil that Kimberley and Belinda have experienced throughout their brief lives is unlikely to end just yet.

They will be taken from their home with foster parents in north Wales and placed with carers in America while a court in Missouri makes a final decision on who should be granted custody.

Their estranged natural parents, Tranda and Aaron Wecker, are separately seeking residence rights.

It is the latest twist in a remarkable saga that only became public because the Kilshaws approached The Sun newspaper to describe the difficulties they had adopting the girls, who were born in St Louis in July last year.

The Weckers had just split up and their mother was eager to have the twins adopted. She approached internet baby broker Tina Johnson, who placed the girls with a Californian couple, Richard and Vickie Allen, for a fee.

But two months later the Kilshaws offered her £8,200 - double the original fee - and she arranged to give the babies to them instead.

With the help of Ms Wecker she took the girls from the unwitting Allens and handed them over to the Kilshaws, who drove across the US so that they could carry out a speedy adoption in Arkansas, which has laxer adoption laws. A court in Little Rock subsequently annulled the arrangement.

News of the deal caused outrage in Britain and two days after the story broke in the Sun, in January this year, Flintshire social services served an emergency protection order on the Kilshaws. The authority put the two girls into the care of foster parents and applied to the family division of the high court to make the twins wards of court.

It is not yet know when the sisters will return to the US, although it is likely to take weeks as carers attempt to minimise the further disruption to their lives. The legal wrangles there could last much longer.

The Allens have withdrawn from the custody battle following claims - denied by the couple - that Mr Allen had molested two teenage babysitters. But the twins' natural parents are still fighting each other for custody.

Mr Wecker's counsel, Jeremy Rosenblatt, said yesterday: "He is thrilled and delighted with the decision of the English court. He will fight for the residence of his girls."

In his statement yesterday, Mr Justice Kirkwood commented: "The arrangements for the move of the twins are, and will remain, confidential. They will be carefully planned so as to avoid, so far as possible, any further distress."

But attempts to calm the furore have not been entirely successful.

Despite promising that they would stop commenting on the case, the Kilshaws continued to talk to the media and protest that the children should never have been removed from them.

At one point, court security staff had to search all those at tending the private hearing for recording equipment.

Yesterday Mrs Kilshaw repeatedly stormed out of court to scream at waiting reporters. She was restrained by friends, court staff and her eldest daughter Kaley as she yelled: "There is no justice. They said I lied." She added: "You want everything don't you? My life and my kids."

The Kilshaws were silent when the hearing ended, refusing to comment as they left the court by a back door usually reserved for judges.

The public relations agent Max Clifford is acting as their unpaid media adviser.

fields.headline: Royals still court press associations
fields.standfirst:
Buckingham Palace may be royally displeased about the Sophie scandal, but it will continue to invite media attention, says Anjali Kwatra

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Buckingham Palace may be royally displeased about the Sophie scandal, but it will continue invite media attention, says Anjali Kwatra.
fields.body:
Relations between the royal family and the media may be at an all-time low following the row over the Sophie tapes.

But however much the royals despise certain sections of the press, they reluctantly admit they cannot do without them.

Each time the Queen, Charles, Andrew or any of the rest of the clan appears in public, reporters are invited along to publicise their good deeds.

At the heart of coverage of royal events is the so-called rota system - the way in which Buckingham Palace tries to keep reporters, photographers and television journalists under control.

Each time any royal appears at a public engagement a number of passes are given out to journalists. Every event - no matter how small or boring - is covered by a Press Association reporter, usually the court or deputy court correspondent, who files copy for the wire service available for other news organisations to use.

It is at the discretion of the palace to decide how many other reporters can cover the event. The Queen prefers to carry out her duties without too many members of Her Majesty's press hanging around, so often the PA reporter will be the only one at an event. On the other hand, Prince Charles' officials are usually happy to create good PR by allowing the tabloids, the broadsheets and television crews in to record his duties.

Passes for Princess Anne are given out only rarely, partly because her schedule is just too hectic, but mainly because there is little press interest in her engagements.

But even if a reporter manages to gets his or her grubby hands on a pass, access to the royals is still not guaranteed. A fixed point pass usually gives standing room on the pavement, caged in a press pen, as the royal cavalcade sweeps past.

Much more coveted is a rota pass, which enables the reporter to follow the royal as they tour an event and even listen in on their conversations.

But the unwritten rule still applies: no questions are to be put directly to a royal - except on occasion by an uncouth television reporter.

When Charles hosted a dinner last month at St James's Palace for Prince's Trust ambassadors, including Geri Halliwell and Elton John, around 50 journalists were there to record the event.

But only one - a Press Association news reporter - was allowed inside the actual party. Another PA reporter and six national newspaper reporters were given rota passes allowing them to stand inside the door and question the celebrities as they arrived.

Three television crews were allowed to stand just outside the doors to film the arrivals.

Photographers with rota passes stood behind barricades on either side of the door, while the snappers with fixed point passes stood even further back.

News organisations are also invited to cover royal tours abroad and journalists often travel with the royal party on their plane.

This can be one of the rare times that the press get to speak directly to a royal, if he or she comes to the back of the aircraft for an informal and off-the-record chat.

fields.headline: Conspiracy theory turns to moonshine
fields.standfirst: Fuelled by a willing media, America's thirst for paranoiac conjecture is reaching new heights of lunacy, according to Julian Borger
fields.trailText: Fuelled by a willing media, America's thirst for paranoiac conjecture is reaching new heights of lunacy, according to Julian Borger in Washington.
fields.body:
The United States was born out of a profound distrust of government. The founding fathers had had a belly full of monarchs and their self-proclaimed divine right to rule. That fundamental suspicion underlies the modern nation like a geological fault, which breaks to the surface intermittently and unpredictably as a reminder of the country's uneasy relationship with federal power.

The remnants of distrust are everywhere - the legislative gridlock that is all but assured by the checks and balances built into the political system; the jealousy with which many Americans hoard their weapons, lest they be intimidated by Washington's armed legions. Then there are the rural militias training in the hills for the day when they have to confront the United Nations and its supposed plot to establish a single world government.

The suspicion does not run wide - these fears are shared by a small if significant minority - but it does run deep. And nowhere is it more apparent than in the corrosive paranoia of conspiracy theories that spring up through every crack in normal life.

There are of course the persistent conspiracy theories surrounding the assassination of President Kennedy and the belief that the US government has been consorting with aliens, whose spacecraft are parked in the mysterious Area 51 near Roswell, Nevada.

The UFO conspiracy theory has been fed and watered by the X-Files series on television, in which two FBI agents struggle ceaselessly to unveil the Byzantine plot woven around them. Now the same channel on which the show appears, Rupert Murdoch's Fox network, has dusted off a paranoid fantasy which is even more bizarre. It has just aired a portentous, documentary-style programme with the chilling title: "Conspiracy theory: Did we land on the moon?"

Yes, many people in this country believe that Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and all the rest walked, not on the moon, but on a huge artificially-lit studio somewhere in Nevada. This suspicious minority amounts to 20% of the population, according to the programme, which gave the convoluted theory a full and reverent hearing.

Those watching at home with gaping mouths were told how the Nasa hoax could be unmasked with a simple magnifying glass. The pictures taken on the "moon" showed light coming from different angles. Some details, apparently in deep shadow, were mysteriously illuminated. Some of the crosshairs on the famous moon photograph seemed to be behind objects in the foreground. The American flag appeared to flutter, despite the absence of air.

The US, we were told, realised it could not keep up with the Soviets in the space race, so Nasa simply faked it. At best, the astronauts simply orbited the earth a few times and came back. At worst, they never left the earth and instead headed straight to the Nevada studio.

The embattled Nasa spokesman who was asked to rebut the claims on air was left groping for words. "Claptrap" was his final verdict. Subsequent demolitions of the Fox evidence appeared on Nasa's site and other serious astronomical websites.

To begin with, there is more than one light source on the moon. Light is reflected by the earth and from the moon's own pale surface. It can illuminate objects, even those apparently in deep shadow, from different directions.

Moreover, on rudimentary black and white film, the light from very bright objects can bleed over and erase fine lines in the foreground, like crosshairs. And flags can flutter in a vacuum, especially when the flagpole is being handled by an astronaut.

Such mundane explanations do not seem to have the same penetrating power as conspiracy theories. A cursory check of a popular internet chatroom, where television output is constantly discussed, suggested that paranoia was fast taking the upper hand.

One chatter calling himself "seeker" (presumably after truth) expressed a widely shared sentiment when he said: "I WANT TO BELIEVE that we've been to the moon and that Nasa has been completely up front with us on the subject. But if Nasa lied about something as big as the moon landings, who knows where the lies end and the truth begins."

That is precisely the question posed by Bill Kaysing, the "star" witness in the Fox exposé and author of the topic's definitive work, We Never Went to the Moon.

"This whole moon business goes much further than Nasa, he said. In fact: "Nasa and the CIA and the whole US government is a rotten and corrupt organisation, designed just to get all the tax money they can out of people, to manipulate their minds, to keep them amused with sporting events and silly TV sitcoms."

Not to mention quasi-documentaries broadcast by Rupert Murdoch, friend of governments around the world. The plot, as they say, thickens.

fields.headline: Hostel girl murder suspect held
fields.trailText: A Spanish restaurant worker named as the chief suspect in the murder of British schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson has been arrested by police in Florida, it was reported early today.
fields.body:
A Spanish restaurant worker named as the chief suspect in the murder of British schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson has been arrested by police in Florida, it was reported early today.

Francisco Arce Montez, 50, was arrested by Miami Beach police last month after allegedly breaking into a woman's apartment attempting to commit what is described as a lewd and lascivious act while she slept, according to a BBC report.

Caroline, 13, was raped and smothered to death in bed in the dormitory of a French youth hostel during a school trip in 1996.

She and 40 other children were in the middle of an activity week at Pleine Fougeres in Brittany when an intruder entered their unlocked hostel in the early hours of July 18 and murdered the teenager.

An inquest ruled last week that her death was the result of unlawful killing.

More than 3,500 DNA samples have been taken by French police involved in the investigation and 2,000 lines of enquiry have been followed up but the killer has never been caught.

Mr Montez was recently named as the chief suspect by Francis Debons, the French judge leading the investigation into Caroline's murder.

He has been kept in Miami Dade county jail since his arrest on March 11 after being refused bail because he was a flight risk.

French consular officials in Miami said tests were being carried out on a sample of his DNA to see if it matched evidence from the scene of Caroline's murder in France. It is hoped the DNA test will determine whether there is sufficient evidence to begin extradition proceedings, the BBC reported.

Mr Montez was reportedly being hunted by French police because they believe he had a history of sexual assaults, and described his method of operation as being similar to that of Caroline's killer.

At last week's inquest into Caroline's death her father, John Dickinson, made a renewed appeal for help in solving the case. Mr Dickinson, an environmental health officer from Bodmin, has been fiercely critical of mistakes in the first inquiry by French police.

fields.headline: PR firm defends massive payment for London traffic advice
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: A PR company is being paid £100,000 a month for advice on how to introduce Ken Livingstone's controversial congestion charge. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
Transport for London is paying PR company Fishburn Hedges a staggering £100,000 a month for advice on how to introduce London mayor Ken Livingstone's controversial congestion charge.

Fishburn Hedges stands to rake in more than £2.4m over two years from the account, but the agency says it is offering value for money.

The agency's work forms part of TfL's plan to spend £20m promoting the proposed charge over the next two years.

Fishburn Hedges was hired by TfL in December 2000 and expects to continue working on the account until the congestion charge's expected introduction at the beginning of 2003.

The agency is consulting London boroughs and interested parties, such as disabled people, about the charge.

Two Fishburn Hedges staff have been seconded to TfL to work full-time on the project while six other staff are dedicating most of their time to the account.

"We went through a through and lengthy competitive tender process for this account and TfL, and we, believe they are getting value for money for what we are doing," said Ron Finlay, director of the agency.

But he refused to either confirm or deny the £100,000 figure, saying the charge was commensurate with the scale of the project.

"We are consulting with stakeholders and the public, and if it goes ahead we will manage all communications thereafter, making the public aware of how the charge will work."

TfL is preparing to put out a tender for an advertising agency to create a £20m campaign to tell people how the charge works.

fields.headline: Major scorns 'actor' Blair
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: John Major yesterday accused Tony Blair of exploiting his "actor-manager's capacity to milk sentiment in public" by repeatedly indicating that he shares the pain felt by other people.
fields.body:
John Major yesterday accused Tony Blair of exploiting his "actor-manager's capacity to milk sentiment in public" by repeatedly indicating that he shares the pain felt by other people.

"I was never one who could put my hand on my heart with tears dripping out of either eye, feeling the pain of others. If I felt pain, I felt it privately," the former Conservative prime minister said in a glossy magazine interview.

In making what amounts to his second attack in a week on New Labour's in-house style, just weeks before he leaves the Commons without any immediate wish to go to the Lords, Mr Major did not directly name the man who thrashed him at the polls in 1997.

But, even without last week's attack on New Labour "lies", "deceipt" and "spin" in the Spectator, there was no doubt about his target when he spoke to Tatler of public grief. "It just meant I did not have the actor-manager capacity to milk sentiment in public. I did not think it was my job as prime minister and I could not have done it. I think it often looks false."

Mr Major's famous thin skin is still evident. To suggestions that he was not tough enough to impose discipline on his wayward ministers, he says: "Some people said I was too nice, others too weak because I didn't sack ministers speedily enough.

"Well, I think we've seen in the recent case of Mr Mandelson that sometimes it's a good idea to preserve a little delay until you find out whether someone is guilty or not before you wreck their career."

As for leadership, he may have become prime minister too soon, though Tony Blair is younger, William Hague and Charles Kennedy younger still. "At this rate the next leader of a major party may well be pre-pubescent."
