webTitle: Comment: Kennedy should be wary of getting too cosy with Labour

fields.headline: Kennedy should be wary of getting too cosy with Labour
fields.standfirst:
He probably hankers for red boxes, but they come at a high price

Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: With the government's lead in the opinion polls little affected by foot and mouth, stock-market slumps or even prime ministerial jitters, two imponderables stand in the way of another easy Labour victory at the forthcoming election, whenever it comes forth.
fields.body:
With the government's lead in the opinion polls little affected by foot and mouth, stock-market slumps or even prime ministerial jitters, two imponderables stand in the way of another easy Labour victory at the forthcoming election, whenever it comes forth.

One is turnout - how far will it fall, and how adversely will this affect Labour? The other is the impact of the third-party vote. All of Charles Kennedy's awkward recent negotiations with the government don't address the real questions: how many seats will the Liberal Democrats have in the next parliament, and what will they do with them?

Even now, the strangeness of the last election, or the reasons for the Labour landslide, haven't quite sunk in. According to Herbert Morrison, when the British electorate say something, they say it in italics, but he meant that the system italicises their verdict. It did so notably in 1997, thanks above all to the collapse of the Tory vote: remember that Tony Blair won substantially fewer votes than John Major had in 1992.

Even that wasn't as odd as the Lib Dems' experience. In 1992 they won almost 6m votes, or 17.8% of the total, but only 20 seats; in 1997 they won fewer votes (5.24m) and a smaller share (6.8%) but 46 seats, more than twice as many.

Here the voters did use italics. The electoral system was just the same, but the electorate had rediscovered the art of tactical voting, and moved towards three-party politics for the first time since the 1920s.

Our new prime minister was more pleased by the Lib Dem success than by his own majority. We know that in the early morning of May 2 1997 Blair was dismayed by the size of the landslide. He could not now take the next step in his "project", by bringing the Lib Dems into some sort of governmental role and giving Paddy Ashdown the cabinet seat which he had been well-nigh promised. Whether Ashdown should have accepted office, even if he had held the parliamentary balance, is another matter.

Third parties face contrasting dangers. One is, as it were, casual sex leading to prostitution; the other is a steady affair leading to wedlock, and invisibility. The former is exacerbated by proportional representation. So, in the Irish Republic, Labour will get into bed with Fianna Fail or Fine Gael according to whim; in Germany, the Free Democrats have spent decades in office as partners of either the Christian Democrats or Social Democrats; and in Israel, every government always includes the small religious parties (with results many Israelis deplore).

Here, the historical tendency has been toward decorous but anonymous marriage, rather as a woman called Susan Brown used to become Mrs John Smith. By the 1900s, the Tories had absorbed the Liberal Unionists, and by the 1940s they had absorbed the National Liberals. Labour has had its own cannibalistic tendencies. Where now is the ILP? And how many political pundits can name the 26 people on the Labour benches technically elected as Co-op MPs?

In that way, Blair's fundamental attitude is acquisitive - and quite unhistorical. He wanted a coalition with the Lib Dems not just for tactical reasons, or to dish the Labour left: he had propounded the larger notion that a tragic and unnecessary split on the progressive side had led to a Conservative-dominated 20th century. For all that it has been widely accepted, this idea is quite false.

For one thing, the Blairite version rewrites history. That split seemed neither needless nor regrettable at the time, especially to socialists. They saw the Liberals as their real enemy, whom it was their destiny to defeat and supplant. As Beatrice Webb said in 1923, "The real and significant issue before the country is Liberalism v Labour." And when that issue was apparently decided, there didn't seem anything to mourn, not in 1945 when Labour had 47.8% of the vote and the Liberals less than 10% (and 12 seats), or for that matter 1959, when the Tories had 49.4% and the Liberals 5.9% (and six MPs).

Then came the Liberal revival, although it began, as it remained, largely as a protest vote by disaffected Tories. Thus Labour were soundly beaten in 1959, but won a parliamentary majority in 1964 with fewer popular votes; the difference was the defection of nearly a million and a half votes from Tories to Liberals.

For years afterwards, the Liberals flattered to deceive. In the first 1974 election, it was believed, not least by bookmakers, that they would finally break through and win 30 or even 50 seats. As I happily remember, that February you could back them at 16-1 to win between 11 and 20 seats. In the event they won 14, despite their 19.3% of the vote. It took more than 20 years more for that lost art of tactical voting to be relearned.

In one other way the Blairite version is unhistorical. When Disraeli said that England did not love coalitions, he was being glib, but he had a point. Coalition governments have been rare since the mid 19th century (which is to say since the birth of organised mass parties), with the rule-proving exceptions of wartime coalitions of national unity.

What "is" in our tradition is minority government. In what has come quaintly to be called a hung parliament, a ministry would govern without a parliamentary majority but supported passively by another party, as the Liberals were by the Irish party after 1910.

In other words, if - as is at least possible at an election in the near future - Labour wins the largest number of seats but not an absolute majority, there is no reason why the Lib Dems should join a coalition of any kind. They might be better placed to make their demands outside government. And even before the election, that has important lessons for Charles Kennedy, who has lately gone beyond the call of duty in backing the government.

Obviously it would be absurd to pretend that his party is now equidistant from the larger two, and as likely to support Tories as Labour. But it's no less absurd for him to say in effect, "Vote for me so you can get a Labour government." Much his best bet is that the voters will not lose their taste for tactical voting.

Very likely he hankers for red boxes and black limos. But the example of the Irish demanding, and getting, a Home Rule bill from outside the Liberal government 90 years ago suggests that office itself isn't necessary for a determined third party, with a real following, and real principles.

fields.headline: Could do better
fields.standfirst:
A poll on Labour's performance shows the need for improvement on the NHS and crime, while the chancellor has come top of the class

Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: A poll on Labour's performance shows the need for improvement on the NHS and crime, while the chancellor has come top of the class.
fields.body:
Labour is keen on targets and indicators, particularly to judge progress in the public sector. But how should we assess the Blair government itself? Ask the public.

Thanks to the 2001 British election study, paid for by the Economic and Social Research Council and based at the University of Essex, we are beginning to get some idea of how the public is assessing the first term (if that is what it is). The first phase of the study consisted of a survey of more than 3,000 electors, a sample three times larger than the average opinion poll. It is now complete and offers a snapshot of the state of opinion just prior to what is assumed to be the start of the official campaign.

One question in the survey asks the public to identify the "single most important issue in the general election". This is meant to tap the concerns of the electorate without any prompting by us. The top six issues ordered in their importance by the number of mentions are the National Health Service, the economy, education, taxation, crime and the UK's relations with Europe.

It is interesting that neither foot and mouth nor public transport figure. Foot and mouth disease may dominate the newspapers and television reports but it simply does not affect the vast majority of the voters in what is after all a highly urban society. Transport, on the other hand, does affect large numbers of people. But the states of the railways and the roads have been problems for so long now that as an issue transport is beginning to recede from public consciousness.

We asked respondents if they thought the government had done a good or a bad job in handling the top issues and the chart shows the public's response. Clearly, the jewel in the crown of public performance evaluations is the economy. More than half the electorate (56%) say they think the government has handled the economy well and only 14% badly. So Chancellor Gordon Brown gets a gold star for his performance as far as the voters are concerned.

However the economy is only the second most important issue in the list. Performance on the most important issue, the NHS, gets a much less positive evaluation. Voters who think that the government has done badly in its stewardship of the NHS outnumber those who think it has performed well by some 15% - 31% compared with 46%. Thus the health secretary, Alan Milburn, merits only three out of 10 for the performance of his ministry.

The third most important issue is education and here the evaluation is quite positive with 44% thinking that the government has performed well on the schools and 27% thinking that it has performed badly. This may not be quite a gold-star performance but nonetheless David Blunkett probably deserves nine out of 10 for his management of the Department for Education and Employment.

The fourth most salient issue is taxation, which again is the direct responsibility of Chancellor Gordon Brown. Labour did rather badly on the issue when it was in opposition - arguably it was the failing issue for the party - and so it is interesting to note that it gets a modestly positive evaluation at the present time. Some 34% think the government has done a good job and 31% think the opposite, which effectively neutralises the issue during the forthcoming election campaign. William Hague and the Conservatives are going to have a hard time making progress with accusations of stealth taxes when attitudes to the government's performance are generally favourable.

On crime performance, Labour gets a poor rating. About 29% of electors think that the government has done a good job while 41% think the opposite. Some people have argued that although the home secretary, Jack Straw, is disliked for his illiberal policies by many middle-class Labour supporters, this does not count since he really goes down well among working-class voters who live at the sharp end of the battle against crime. Actually the evidence points to the opposite conclusion. Some 33% of middle-class professionals think that the government has done badly on crime compared with 48% of manual workers. One reason for this is that manual workers think the government should be even tougher on crime than do the middle-class professionals; Mr Straw turns out to have few friends down on the council estates.

Finally, there are relations between the UK and Europe. In terms of government handling of membership of the European Monetary Union 32% of voters are positive and 21% negative. This registers a significant success for the government on an issue which it has been trying to avoid for some time.

But the euro is not Labour's issue. We also asked electors to indicate which party they thought would be best at handling the one issue they considered the most important. Labour beats the Conservatives on this question for all issues except Europe. On the question of the UK's joining the single currency some 41% think that the Conservatives would be best at handling the subject compared with only 22% who answer Labour.

We have compiled an overall index - not a scientific exercise - which we call the government quality evaluation index. Taking the scores on individual issues together the Blair government registers 41 out of a possible 60, that is to say a rating of 68%. Clearly there is room for improvement. Like Ofsted, the quality evaluation inspectorate (aka the electorate) are going to be invited to revisit and give additional reports.

 Paul Whiteley and David Sanders are professors of government at Essex University.

webTitle: Boffins brought in to save Commons deadwood

fields.headline: Boffins brought in to save Commons deadwood
fields.trailText: That MPs never die within the precincts of the Palace of Westminster is one of the quirkier conventions, if less pernicious practices, of the mock gothic fun palace. If a malfunctioning New Labour clone was discovered tomorrow without a pulse after corrective surgery by a Millbank spin doctor, officially he or she would still be with us.
fields.body:
That MPs never die within the precincts of the Palace of Westminster is one of the quirkier conventions, if less pernicious practices, of the mock gothic fun palace. If a malfunctioning New Labour clone was discovered tomorrow without a pulse after corrective surgery by a Millbank spin doctor, officially he or she would still be with us.

The final escape from Millbank's clutches would not be certified until a trip over the Thames to St Thomas' hospital to avoid unnecessary disruption to the club's proceedings. Which perhaps makes even more commendable the lengths the Commons authorities are going to keep the deadbeat and deadwood on the backbenches alive until they face a cull on June 7.

Oh how the Countess of Wessex, the royal turkey who thought it was Christmas, must be relieved that being dumb and stupid is not a handicap in Britain's first family!

In Westminster scientists were busy yesterday slipping agar plates familiar to biology pupils throughout the ages into a yellow tube - or a microbial air sampler to those who passed the GCSE - to monitor bacteria levels in the chamber. Or perhaps the search for microscopic germs invisible to the naked eye was particularly pointless when lifesize variants were on display.

Nick Brown versus Tim Yeo in the foot and mouth title fight (round eight) is unlikely to be remembered as one of the great parliamentary bouts. If we get to round 12 without a knock-out, hopefully the speaker will decide the outcome on points to put them and us out of our misery.

"Newcastle" Brown is a carnivore behaving like a herbivore, the tough urban fixer required by Downing Street to ooze concern for the farmers. When Tony Blair talks of reopening the countryside, I bet Mr Brown's thoughts turn to the green grass of St James' Park and drinking dens of the Bigg Market rather than national parks and market towns.

A politician who likes his meat with two veg and a nice bottle of red, at one point he seemed to suggest B&B proprietors have found new bodies to fill the beds left empty by tourists speeding past in sealed cars. "Many farmers are currently keeping cattle indoors," he said approvingly. Officials later insisted the agriculture minister meant in barns and byres, not bed and breakfasts, which is a pitty really.

But facts and figures he trotted out did leave some MPs wondering whether foot and mouth might be the best thing ever to happen to cows, sheep and pigs. Over the eight-week crisis approaching 1.4m animals have been slaughtered, said Mr Brown, against an average 500,000 per week during normal times. That adds up to an awful lot of reprieved livestock.

And with more than £250m set aside for compensation, no wonder we no longer read Daily Mail and Telegraph tales of farmers left with cows worth less than a pint of milk.

Tim Yeo, in comparison, is a herbivore trying desperately hard to look and sound like a carnivore, a congenial chap who failed to land a punch on Mr Brown yesterday despite getting the better of their earlier rounds.

His heart went out to those bright-eyed lambs, calves and piglets deprived of a nice little trip away from their fields with friends and family. Some of them might even be enjoying a short cruise on a ferry followed by a road tour of the continent if it were not for the disease.

Farmers spent "nights and days bringing them into the world, nurturing and rearing them", he bleated, only to see them ending up in pits. Has he even been to an abattoir?

Perhaps militant protesters should be out tramping the footpaths of Britain, spreading the disease, if they want to save animals from the butcher's slab.

Mr Brown accused farmers of doing just that themselves, transporting infected animals to previously virus-free zones in breach of regulations.

At least the miners never set fire to their own pits.

fields.headline: Foreign fields
fields.standfirst:
Blair is very fond of the countryside - as long as it is in France or Italy

Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Blair is very fond of the countryside - as long as it is in France or Italy.
fields.body:
Sophie Wessex, like all those Tory tittle- tattlers, is wrong about Tony Blair not liking the countryside; he does. The question is whether it's the British countryside or somebody else's.

From the evidence of their holiday destinations, it is clear the Blairs prefer holidays in rural Tuscany or France. John Smith could think of nothing better than climbing Scottish mountains. Blair, pleading for the resumption of the cream-tea trade, looks even more out of place in the UK countryside than Nick Brown (and that's saying something).

There is nothing wrong with Tony Blair's affection for foreign fields if what lures him to these landscapes is not just good wine but the whole rural package of tranquillity, traditional farming, viable rural communities and unspoilt wildlife. No one would grudge this affection so long as, when it comes to tackling problems at home, he remembers what makes these places so appealing. Evidence that he does is, at best, ambiguous. Back in Downing Street, Blair fails to understand that our country needs what Tuscany or Gascony still have: good quality of life and rich environments.

Tony Blair is not alone in this failing. As electioneering begins, pollsters are busy questioning voters about their priorities with boringly predictable lists: the economy, health, education and crime. In response, politicians wheel out facts and figures to demonstrate how well they have performed, or would do, in these areas.

None seem to have understood the recent volatility of the political scene. Unexpected quality-of-life issues have suddenly destabilised support for an apparently popular government - GM foods, the railways, Ken Livingstone and public funding for the London tube, foot and mouth, fuel protests and the WI's concern about rural services.

Superficially these seem disconnected and doubtless traditional politicians and focus groups are puzzling over the underlying trends. But all are environmental in the broadest sense of the word.

Again, polls don't reflect this. In a recent voter priority survey, the "environment" scored only 18%, perhaps because the word suggests abstractions like climate change rather than the immediate quality-of-life issues which suddenly mobilise people. Nor do these polls link the environment to issues like farming, and food. In the same survey, transport was a separate category.

Yet they can - and should - be connected. GM crop protests relate to fears about adulteration of food at source. Fury about rail chaos reflects a desire for efficient public transport, as does Ken Livingstone's election as London's mayor. The farmers' dissatisfaction results from the supermarkets' stranglehold on prices. And public anger at the foot and mouth crisis reflects horror at dubious practices which have put the traditional countryside in jeopardy, like illegally imported meat, unhygienic conditions and nightmare journeys made by animals.

Even fuel protesters, at first sight anti-environmental, claimed they would support higher fuel taxes if the money was reinvested in good public transport. Time and again, the desire for enhanced quality of life is made clear. The vision of a more sustainable rural economy, producing locally sourced food, is central to that, even for townies.

To give them their due, this government makes big claims about the environment. In the past year, Blair has made two major environmental speeches and pledged to go to Johannesburg for Rio+10. The environment minister, Michael Meacher, has steered through the admirable countryside and rights of way legislation. And, whatever the Tories say, there's been genuine commitment to helping the rural economy.

But there have also been huge inconsistencies, blind spots and u-turns. The government accepted a virtual whitewash of the supermarkets' power over farmers. Now, suddenly, Blair talks about the supermarkets exerting an "arm lock".

Two years ago Nick Brown had the chance to reform CAP by diverting subsidies from environmentally damaging food subsidies to rural development for sustainable tourism and organic food. After foot and mouth, that missed opportunity has become even more urgent. They talk of protecting wildlife, yet revive road building in sensitive areas. This, along with World Trade Organisation protests, will guarantee a stormy future.

The government has seemed so shaky recently because it has failed to grasp that these issues are connected and people feel very deeply about them. They have been taken by surprise each time and acted defensively, like abolishing the fuel escalator tax and then for good measure appeasing "motorists" by freeing up millions for environmentally damaging road schemes.

They cannot go on missing the connections that are being made by ordinary electors looking for a better quality of life. Developing stronger environmental politics is the key. Foot and mouth has as made it clear we cannot treat the countryside as a food factory. It is a life resource, just as essential to the quality of life of townsfolk as to the biodiversity of the planet.

fields.headline: Community aid to fight drugs
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.body:
A £300m anti-drugs programme, with £220m to assist communities to fight drugs, was announced yesterday by ministers including Ian McCartney, whose son died of a heroin overdose.

The cash is part of additional funds released by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in the Budget.

Mr McCartney's son, Hugh, 23, died after a heroin overdose in September 1999. Mr McCartney, the Cabinet Office minister, said yesterday: "No longer can we simply leave it to the police. The police need the eyes and ears of the community. Drugs weaken and damage and even destroy communities. They certainly weaken and damage families who have lost children to drugs."

Admitting that announcing the measures was a "bittersweet" experience, he said: "For me, it's almost saying if only, if only."

Losing one's child through drugs was especially difficult to cope with. "It's not just the loss of their life but the loss of the life to come, the loss of a vibrant young person killed by a drug dealer."

The £220m aimed at the most drug crime-ridden areas will be funnelled through the existing 376 crime and disorder reduction partnerships.

The bulk of this money will cover high visibility policing of drug hotspots, an increase in neighbourhood wardens, support for parents and residents groups, improved security including CCTV and street lighting, and more school truancy sweeps.

Pilot schemes are to begin in Hackney in north-east London, Stafford and Nottingham. Apart from the £220m, an extra £15m over three years has been set aside to build drug action teams, and an extra £50m to accelerate drugs testing, including saliva tests in police stations for anyone arrested and suspected of crime linked to drugs.

Ministers also released an extra £5m over two years to use more sports stars as role models and develop positive futures. Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson and United striker Andy Cole backed the initiative.

fields.headline: Dirty hospitals to be named
fields.trailText: Forty-two hospitals will today be named and shamed by the government for having poor standards of hygiene as part of its campaign to clean up the NHS.
fields.body:
Forty-two hospitals will today be named and shamed by the government for having poor standards of hygiene as part of its campaign to clean up the NHS.

The list of dirty institutions, compiled after inspections carried out in more than 600 English hospitals, includes a handful of persistently bad offenders which require special measures to be introduced.

Ten of the worst culprits have already been put on "special measures" and hit squads of experts from the best trusts are to be sent in to tackle the problem and raise standards of cleanliness before an autumn deadline. It is understood that each hospital is being given between £250,000 and £750,000 to clean up. New national hospital cleaning standards aimed at raising cleanliness levels were also being published today.

The inspections of 689 hospitals this year found 94% had cleanliness standards that were acceptable or higher, while 6% were deemed poor. Similar inspections last year found that a third of hospitals had unacceptable cleaning standards.

Findings published in the Health Service Journal revealed that of 700 hospital buildings checked in a snap survey, 250 were given the lowest grade for basic sanitation standards such as tidiness of wards and litter collection.

Hospitals have been rated using a red, amber or green system. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is today expected to visit the Royal Free hospital, north London, which is one of the most improved hospitals, moving from a red rating last year to green.

He said: "Despite this marked improvement, there is to be no let-up in our drive to raise standards of hospital cleanliness. The fundamentals of care are too important to be left to chance."

webTitle: ONdigital blames government for slow switch from analogue

fields.headline: ONdigital blames government for slow switch from analogue
fields.trailText: ONdigital chief executive Stuart Prebble yesterday delivered an attack on the BBC, ITV and the government for not doing more to encourage the take up of digital television.
fields.body:
ONdigital chief executive Stuart Prebble yesterday delivered an attack on the BBC, ITV and the government for not doing more to encourage the take up of digital television.

Mr Prebble said it was "fairly remarkable" that Britain had managed to get to about 7m digital homes without better support. "Between us [ONdigital, BSkyB and the cable companies] we've done fairly well. But it hasn't been easy for any of us.

"After a difficult start, BBC News 24 is not a bad service. But we have to hazard a guess that not many people have gone digital in order to see it. BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge are more or less invisible, and no one believes they have attracted more than a handful of viewers to go digital," he told the audience at a digital broadcasting conference.

"ITV has launched ITV2. Once again, you'd have to guess that so far not many people have rushed out to buy a digital TV to see it."

But Mr Prebble was most sharply critical of the government's failure to help the public understand digital TV.

"Since [culture secretary] Chris Smith made his announcement about analogue switch-off, more than 6m TV sets have been sold in the UK. All but maybe 150,000 of them have been analogue. That means the mountain we have to climb in order to switch off the analogue signal is as many as 6m sets higher than it might have been."

At the beginning of the year Mr Prebble insisted ONdigital would reach the 2m customer mark by the end of 2002. Recent reports have been more vague, mentioning 2003-4 as the target date. Much of ONdigital's hope for growth rests on digital sets which allow viewers to simply slot a card into the back to receive the company's service via the aerial.

The government has said the analogue signal will be switched off between 2006 and 2010.

fields.headline: Dimbleby sells his newspapers
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: David Dimbleby, the veteran journalist and broadcaster, has sold his family business of regional newspapers to Newsquest.
fields.body:
David Dimbleby, the veteran journalist and broadcaster, has sold his family business of regional newspapers to Newsquest in a deal understood to be worth around £12m in cash.

The sale of the nine newspapers, all based in greater London, ends a 105-year family tradition. Mr Dimbleby was sole owner and chairman after buying out his family in 1983.

The titles include some of the oldest in Britain, such as the Richmond & Twickenham Times, which started in 1873. Others in the stable include the Putney & Wimbledon Times, Wandsworth Borough News and Battersea News.

Mr Dimbleby, 62, who presents the BBC's Question Time, said the sale had been prompted by increasingly competitive trading conditions. The titles, he added, would have a better future as part of a larger group. Staff at Dimbleby Newspapers are unlikely to be saddened at the development. Mr Dimbleby has had frequent disputes with the National Union of Journalists over conditions and pay at the company.

A decision to move printing to a non-union site resulted in a six-week strike and the company was forced to pay compensation to a woman sacked while on maternity leave three years ago.

Jim Brown, executive chairman of Newsquest, said: "These are long respected titles in areas in which they circulate and we feel privileged to be acquiring them."

The agreement is part of the continuing consolidation of the regional newspaper industry. Gannett, the US publisher of USA Today, which owns Newsquest, has been a chief protagonist. The deal is subject to approval by the Department of Trade & Industry.

webTitle: Sophie Wessex: Clients shy away from PR disaster

fields.headline: Clients shy away from PR disaster
fields.standfirst:
Image hurt: Firm tainted by 'unprofessional conduct'
Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: RJH Public Relations yesterday tried to shore up its client base after damaging revelations about the way the countess and her partner, Murray Harkin, conducted the business. By Paul Kelso.
fields.body:
RJH Public Relations, the company founded by the Countess of Wessex, yesterday tried to shore up its client base after damaging revelations about the way the countess and her partner, Murray Harkin, conducted the business.

As the countess returned to work at the firm's offices in Mayfair, RJH suffered its first commercial blow when the Banyan Tree luxury hotel in Phuket, Thailand, withdrew its contract with RJH after hearing of Mr Harkin's comments that he could use the hotel as a venue for sex between the "sheikh" and other men.

"We are disappointed by the unprofessional conduct of RJH," said Renee Ho-Phang, a spokesman for the company.

The company responded to the resignations of the countess and the co-founder Mr Harkin, the man at the centre of the tabloid allegations, by appointing Jack Cassidy, a non-executive director, to the post of acting managing director in Mr Harkin's stead.

It also emerged that the countess had posed for pictures in the magazine Hello! at the Sotogrande resort in Spain, one of RJH's clients, but had not declared her interest in the accompanying article.

A spokeswoman for RJH said it was public knowledge that the company represented Sotogrande. Despite the "business as usual" message the confidence of some clients appeared to have been shaken.

Several clients including Teletext and the Lanesborough Hotel, London, declined to comment on whether they would continue to use the firm.

Doubts remain within the industry about the prospects of the company if it no longer has the added value of its association with the royal household. RJH has specialised in project-specific work, with few of their clients entering into long term contracts leaving the business vulnerable in the event of a loss of confidence.

The company was described as "lightweight and superficial" by Roger Harwood, chairman of the Public Relations Standards Council, who said the company's work had caused concern to others within the industry.

As the countess returned to work at the firm's offices in Mayfair, RJH suffered its first commercial blow when the Banyan Tree luxury hotel in Phuket, Thailand, withdrew its contract with RJH after hearing of Mr Harkin's comments that he could use the hotel as a venue for sex between the "sheikh" and other men. "We are disappointed by the unprofessional conduct of RJH," said Renee Ho-Phang, a spokesman for the company. The company responded to the resignations of the countess and the co-founder Mr Harkin, the man at the centre of the tabloid allegations, by appointing Jack Cassidy, a non-executive director, to the post of acting managing director in Mr Harkin's stead. It also emerged that the countess had posed for pictures in the magazine Hello! at the Sotogrande resort in Spain, one of RJH's clients, but had not declared her interest in the accompanying article. A spokeswoman for RJH said it was public knowledge that the company represented Sotogrande. Despite the "business as usual" message the confidence of some clients appeared to have been shaken. Several clients including Teletext and the Lanesborough Hotel, London, declined to comment on whether they would continue to use the firm. Doubts remain within the industry about the prospects of the company if it no longer has the added value of its association with the royal household. RJH has specialised in project-specific work, with few of their clients entering into long term contracts leaving the business vulnerable in the event of a loss of confidence. The company was described as "lightweight and superficial" by Roger Harwood, chairman of the Public Relations Standards Council, who said the company's work had caused concern to others within the industry. fields.headline: BBC series examines impact of Victorians
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The BBC is working on an eight-part series called What the Victorians did for us, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
The BBC is planning a major series exploring the way the Victorians have shaped today's world.

What the Victorians did for us will follow the success of the recent What the Romans did for us.

The eight-part series will air in the autumn on BBC2.

Executive producer Caroline van den Brul said: "We won't just be looking at the big things and conceptual leaps but also fantastic little nuggets."

The show will reveal how the Victorians introduced the concept of holidays and weekends and why the invention of the lawnmower meant not just the rich could play sports.

The series will also feature a reconstruction of the Great Exhibition.

fields.headline: Kellogg's targets people on the go
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Kellogg's is launching five of its cereal brands in ready-to-eat portions, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Kellogg's is launching five of its cereal brands in ready-to-eat portions to try to claw back sales from the increasing number of people who don't eat breakfast at home.

The range, Kellogg's To Go Twinpots, will be available later this month in Corn Flakes, Crunchy Nut Corn Flakes, Bran Flakes, Special K and Frosties varieties.

Each Twinpot contains individual portions of the cereal, extended-life milk, sugar and a spoon.

Twinpots will cost between 79p and 99p and will be sold in supermarkets, convenience stores, petrol station forecourts, city centre metro stores, takeaway food counters and sandwich bars.

Chris Doyle, Kellogg's head of marketing for out-of-home consumption, commented: "While Kellogg's is still the most popular cereal brand in the UK, we have recognised our consumers' eating habits are changing - people have less time to eat in the home."

The company says US research shows consumers spend 17 minutes a day preparing food in the home, compared with an average three-and-a-half hours 20 years ago.

The five brands featured will benefit collectively from £15m worth of advertising support this year.

Kellogg's To Go Twinpots will receive point-of-sale and PR support.

fields.headline: Court lambasts 'racist' Land Rover advert
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: The car manufacturer's advert 'constituted racial stereotyping and violated human dignity', reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Land Rover has been forced into an humiliating climbdown after an advertising campaign it ran in South Africa was judged racist and "a mockery of African culture".

A South African court has ordered the company to withdraw the offending advert, which showed a semi-nude African woman whose elongated breasts are blown sideways in the tailwind of a Land Rover.

But in an unprecedented move against an advertiser, the court also ruled the company must publish a statement that amounts to a humiliating public apology in all the publications the three-page advert originally appeared in.

The replacement adverts will contain a ruling by the country's Advertising Standards Authority, which judged the advert "irresponsible, exploitative and constitutes racial stereotyping and violates human dignity".

It added: "The insensitive portrayal of the woman makes a mockery of African culture."

ASA executive director Deline Beukes said this was the first time such a move had been ordered and that the sanction reflected the severity of the case.

Ms Beukes said the new sanction was a reaction to accusations the ASA was a toothless organisation.

She said it would discourage so-called "hit and run" advertising, where the desired shock effect is achieved before the ASA has the time to ban an advertisement.

fields.headline: Four years in 40 words (continued)
fields.standfirst:
Full list of MPs
Four years in 40 words (or so)
Leader: Common causes
fields.trailText:
56 Tess Kingham MP
Labour, Gloucester
fields.body:
56 Tess Kingham MP
Labour, Gloucester

I led a campaign involving Gloucester people, local media and health workers to get a new hospital for the city. We will have a new A&E department, children's centre and maternity services - proving that if politicians and local people lobby together, you get results.

57 Andrew Lansley MP
Shadow cabinet office minister
Conservative, South Cambridgeshire

During debates on the protection of children bill, I pressed the government to exempt voluntary organisations from charges. I continued to argue with ministers, and persuaded my Conservative colleagues and William Hague to support this exemption. On the day William said we would exempt volunteers from charges, the government itself, contrary to its previous arguments, agreed to the exemption.

58 Edward Leigh MP
Conservative, Gainsborough

The defence of freedom has been my main goal. Freedom of religion for persecuted Christians across the world with three adjournment debates, freedom for religious institutions to employ believers, freedom for people to continue minority pursuits. The Guardian sketchwriter has acknowledged my continual questioning of ministers and I have worked for the protection of human life in opposing embryonic cloning.

59 William Hague MP
Leader of the Opposition
Conservative, Richmond

With the help of my parliamentary colleagues and many others, we have rebuilt the Conservative party, reformed its organisation, reconnected with the mainstream majority of the country and put ourselves in a position where we can definitely win the next election.

60 Peter Lilley MP
Conservative, Hitchin and Harpenden

Forcing the government to change its policy on building on green fields, which I hope will disrupt plans, previously steamrollered through by local Labour and Lib Dem councillors and endorsed by Prescott, to build 10,000 homes on the green belt in my constituency.

61 Martin Linton MP
Labour, Battersea

I've contributed to 15 reports of the home affairs committee, edited a book of ideas for a second term, won amendments to the Political Parties Act, helped secure the future of New Covent Garden Market, affordable housing in riverside developments, and progress towards a London Orbital railway. Not earth-shaking, but far more than I achieved as a Guardian reporter.

62 Fiona Mactaggart MP
Labour, Slough

I secured a clause in the Immigration and Asylum Act retaining the right of appeal against deportation for people who have lived here for more than seven years. I have persuaded Berkshire Health Authority to do more to tackle the poor health of Slough.

63 Ken Maginnis MP
Ulster Unionist, Fermanagh and South Tyrone

The 1998 Belfast Agreement, even with its inevitable flaws. No more articles 2 and 3; international recognition of our place in the UK; a devolved legislature; political murders dropping from a 26-yearly average of 110 to single figures. It's a start.

64 Humfrey Malins MP
Conservative, Woking

Battling for a civilian Gulf war veteran, terribly ill after exposure to depleted uranium shells and always positive in outlook. I persuaded the defence minister to take a personal interest and even raised the matter with the prime minister at Question Time and got a personal response from him about the case.

65 Christine McCafferty MP
Labour, Calder Valley

Successful campaigns to reduce VAT on sanitary products, which were previously tax-rated as luxury items; for an open public inquiry on Harold Shipman that would include my constituents in Todmorden; and for inclusion of bio-diversity action plans in the countryside and rights of way bill.

66 Siobhain McDonagh MP
Labour, Mitcham and Morden

London Electricity threatened a local charitable trust, which houses elderly people, with a bill for £60,000 for the installation of central heating. After I had managed to get an adjournment debate and the London Evening Standard had picked up the story, London Electricity backed down and installed the heating for free.

67 Kevin McNamara MP
Labour, Hull North

I put the final nail in the coffin of capital punishment by moving the amendment to include protocol 6 (which prohibits the death penalty) to the human rights bill. To reintroduce capital punishment Britain would have to resile from the whole Convention, as it gives no opportunity for a signatory state to derogate from protocol 6.

68 Michael Meacher MP
Environment minister
Labour, Oldham West and Royton

The Countryside Act 2000; raising the profile of the environment throughout the country; international campaigning for action to combat global warming; a commitment to abolish fuel poverty by 2010; and setting a statutory target to triple recycling nationwide within five years.

69 Andrew Miller MP Labour
Ellesmere Port and Neston

Winning a six-year battle to get a constituent's relative out of a UN refugee camp on the Thai/Burmese border. A drop in the ocean compared to the suffering in Burma, but I will never forget the family's tears of joy as she landed in the UK.

70 Ray Michie MP
Liberal Democrat, Argyll and Bute

I campaigned for many years, as my father, Lord Bannerman of Kildonan, did before me, for the re-establishment of the Scottish Parliament. My greatest moment of satisfaction was the passing of the Scotland Act 1998. Clause 1 says it all: "There shall be a Scottish Parliament."

71 Dan Norris MP
Labour, Wansdyke

My proudest achievement has been bringing national charities, the Home Office, local government and Wansdyke businesses together to protect children. Copies of Protecting Our Children - a booklet which advises parents on how they can effectively prevent their children being sexually abused - have been distributed to every family with children in Somerset and the former Avon. All free of charge.

72 Lembit Öpik MP
Liberal Democrat, Montgomeryshire

I know I do big campaigns like asteroid threats, fox hunting and all that. But really, it's about individuals: like hip operations, CSA issues, housing crises, farming problems. Not UK front-page news, or Newsnight stuff. But it touches real people. If folk feel I've made their life better in a way they can point to, I'd be very proud.

73 Diana Organ MP Labour
Forest of Dean

I have set up a hysterectomies group to empower women and bring the issue of unnecessary hysterectomies to public attention. Lobbied for the development of a landscape of national importance for the Forest of Dean. Gained a commitment from the prime minister to sort out the long campaign on Freeminers' rights.

74 Richard Ottaway MP
Conservative, Croydon South

I stopped the development of the Medium Secure Unit for the mentally impaired next to three primary schools in Coulsdon, to the relief of parents in Croydon. On behalf of pensioners nationwide I brought the government to account over its handling of Equitable Life. And I finally cracked Mrs Johnson's social security claim.

75 Gordon Prentice MP
Labour, Pendle

I put forward my right to roam bill in an effort to encourage the government to open up the countryside. I was happy to withdraw it when the government decided at long last to bring in its own bill.

76 John Redwood MP
Conservative, Wokingham

I am proud to have been part of the opposition getting people to understand that this government is all spin and no substance. I enjoyed leading a campaign to give the motorist a better deal in Parliament. My proudest moment was when I asked the chancellor what the price of petrol was and he was unable to answer.

77 David Rendel MP
Liberal Democrat, Newbury

My most significant action was to get the National Audit Office to investigate the Conservative government's failure to publicise the halving of widows' Serps entitlements. This prompted the Labour government to exempt all those reaching pension age by October 5 2002 and thereafter to phase the changes in gradually, at a cost of £12bn.

78 Marion Roe MP
Conservative, Broxbourne

Since 1997 I have raised the issues surrounding installation of telecommunications masts with ministers many times. Last year I sponsored the launch of Mast Action UK, a charity that promotes the sensible siting of masts. I have succeeded in persuading both the Labour government and the Conservative party to adopt policies that give greater consultation opportunity to the affected community.

79 Andrew Rowe MP
Conservative, Faversham and Mid Kent

JC2000, which I invented and chaired, introduced 6.5m children in 18,250 schools and their parents to the true meaning of the millennium. As co-chair of the UK Youth Parliament. I have also helped to establish the first national representative voice for people under 18.

80 Mohammed Sarwar MP
Labour, Glasgow Govan

The successful campaign I led with shop stewards to win orders for Govan shipyard. We lobbied cabinet ministers and campaigned across Scotland, gathering 80,000 signatures on a petition supporting the yard. The government listened and delivered vital work. We fought for Govan and won.

81 Alan Simpson MP
Labour, Nottingham South

All my best shots have been about sustainability. The Warm Homes Act was passed after years of campaigning; challenging GM crops (in the courts and in the country) has been exhilarating; and my private bill to eliminate food poverty in Britain gives a lot of work to look forward to.

82 Rev Martin Smyth MP
Ulster Unionist, Belfast South

My adjournment debate in Westminster Hall was the first in a political forum to highlight the representation of minorities in the Molucca islands by Islamic extremists. The Indonesian government is aware of world concerns and some succour and mediation has eased the situation.

83 Nicholas Soames MP
Conservative, Mid Sussex

I'm proud just to have been a member of parliament and looked after the interests of those who elected me.

84 Richard Spring MP
Conservative, West Suffolk When I was deputy shadow culture, media and sport minister I constantly badgered the BBC and ITV about the way they used to just trot out government statistics which were treble counted. In the end, Trevor MacDonald's Tonight programme ran a show on it, and I asked a question at PMQs that embarrassed Blair, and now they've stopped using the figures.

85 Dr Phyllis Starkey MP
Labour, Milton Keynes South West

Milton Keynes is a young city. I highlighted the risk to young people's safety from unregulated bouncers at pubs and clubs with my private member's bill calling for a national registration scheme for bouncers. This is now part of government legislation.

86 Ian Stewart MP
Labour, Eccles

I have campaigned with other MPs and families to secure a fair deal from government for victims of vaccine damage. Success was achieved when the government increased the payment to £100,000 equivalent for each damaged child, backdated for children already compensated at lower levels.

87 Gavin Strang MP
Labour Edinburgh East and Musselburgh

As transport minister I introduced the rural bus subsidy scheme, providing 1,800 new bus services and 16m passenger journeys last year. As chair of the Craigmillar social inclusion partnership board, I am involved in the regeneration of this deprived area in my constituency.

88 Gisela Stuart MP, junior health minister
Labour, Birmingham Edgbaston

The two things I am proudest of having achieved are serving on the social security select committee and helping to bring about legislation which allows for fairer divisions of pensions on divorce, and succeeding in getting legislation which makes kerbcrawling an arrestable offence.

89 John Swinney MP
Leader, SNP
Tayside North

Contributing to the establishment of the first Scottish Parliament for 300 years. But on a more human level, MPs can genuinely make a difference to the lives of constituents: I still remember helping to secure £18,000 compensation from the Child Support Agency for a mother who was desperately in need of the money.

90 Teddy Taylor MP
Conservative, Rochford and Southend East

As democracy has declined, the main achievements of MPs today are either as social workers or community interventionists. Among my achievements since 1997 is inviting a young man who was about to commit suicide to give me a week to solve his problems, and contacting him after six days to say those problems had been solved.

91 Peter Temple-Morris
MP Labour, Leominster

For me the 1997 Parliament has been essentially personal. After some trauma early on I crossed the floor and joined the Parliamentary Labour party. I have achieved political peace of mind, a marvellous thing for which I am deeply grateful to the PLP.

92 Paul Truswell MP
Labour, Pudsey

David's Law - my private member's bill - closed the loophole on selling alcohol to young people highlighted by the tragic death of 14-year-old David Knowles in my constituency. It also outlawed the practice of adults buying alcohol and handing it to youngsters outside.

93 Prof Steve Webb MP
Liberal Democrat, Northavon

My proudest moment was when Alistair Darling stood up before Christmas and said the government was not going to cut pensions for millions of widows at a cost of billions of pounds. That was the culmination of a campaign involving myself, colleagues and pensioner groups.

94 Sir Raymond Whitney MP
Conservative, Wycombe

I am proud of helping to keep alive a constructive policy towards the EU in the Conservative party; trying to make people think clearly about healthcare; and my file of thank-you letters from constituents.

95 Dafydd Wigley MP
Plaid Cymru, Caernarfon

The landmark event in this parliament was the establishment of the National Assembly for Wales. I hope that I played some part in helping to ensure that this happened. The second landmark for me was to lead Plaid Cymru into the assembly election and to score 30% of the vote and emerge as the main opposition party in the assembly.

96 Ann Winterton MP
Conservative, Congleton

In addition to doing my best to represent the interests of my constituents at Westminster, my most worthwhile achievement in this parliament was to introduce my private member's bill, the medical treatment (prevention of euthanasia) bill.

97 Ian Taylor MP
Conservative, Esher and Walton

Standing up in favour of GM organisms, of stem cell therapy and promoting the Beagle 2 Mars Lander vehicle. In the constituency, being involved in successful campaigns to prevent the closure of an 18-bed ward at Walton Hospital and the campaign to keep McDonald's out of Hinchley Wood.

98 Tony Worthington MP
Labour, Clydebank and Milngavie

My greatest achievement will be shortly when I (and others) win a fair deal for asbestos victims after they were betrayed by the Chester Street Insurance Company, leaving them without compensation in their hour of need.

99 Tim Yeo MP, shadow agriculture minister
Conservative, South Suffolk My proudest achievement in the current parliament is to have successfully highlighted the plight of agriculture and the countryside and raised the profile of rural issues in political terms. No industry has been treated as badly as agriculture by Labour, and no people have suffered such attacks on their traditions, resources and environment as those in rural communities.

100 Sir George Young MP
Conservative, North West Hampshire In 1998, my constituents in Newton Common got a letter, out of the blue, from a property company that had acquired the common and were using a loophole in the law to demand up to £20,000 from each householder. I amended the countryside bill as it went.

Number crunching

A total of 231 MPs responded:

Labour - 151

Conservative - 49

Liberal Democrat - 20

Plaid Cymru - 3

Scottish National Party - 2

Ulster Unionists - 2

Sinn Fein - 1

Independent - 2

43 MPs mention passing legislation - 18 of introducing their own legislation (private member's bills etc).

27 MPs mention securing a new hospital or health investment (or saving an old hospital from closure).

25 MPs are proud of having been a member of a select committee.

19 MPs mention helping to create or safeguard jobs.

18 MPs mention helping individual constituents.

13 MPs mention securing educational investment (school building, nursery places, etc) for their constituency.

9 MPs mention securing substantial money for regeneration in their constituency.

9 MPs mention securing a new road or road improvement for their constituency.

7 MPs mention helping to establish the Scottish Parliament or the Welsh Assembly.

6 Labour MPs mention supporting the creation of the minimum wage.

5 MPs mention securing peace for Northern Ireland.

4 MPs mention securing flood defences for their constituency.

4 MPs are proud that former Far East PoWs received compensation.

 Additional research by James Tapsfield. Tim Parks's fortnightly column will appear tomorrow.

All talk?

Does your MP appear in this list? Do you think they've done what they say they have? Send us your own assessment of what they've achieved at politics.feedback@guardianunlimited.co.uk. Your verdicts will be published on Guardian Unlimited Politics.

Can't find your MP?

Visit Guardian Unlimited Politics to find out of if he/she answered our survey. All 231 responses are published on the site. MPs Norman Baker and Peter Bottomley will also be discussing the role of MPs on the site today at 2.30pm.

The Warm Homes Act was passed after years of campaigning; challenging GM crops (in the courts and in the country) has been exhilarating; and my private bill to eliminate food poverty in Britain gives a lot of work to look forward to. 82 Rev Martin Smyth MP Ulster Unionist, Belfast South My adjournment debate in Westminster Hall was the first in a political forum to highlight the representation of minorities in the Molucca islands by Islamic extremists. The Indonesian government is aware of world concerns and some succour and mediation has eased the situation. 83 Nicholas Soames MP Conservative, Mid Sussex I'm proud just to have been a member of parliament and looked after the interests of those who elected me. 84 Richard Spring MP Conservative, West Suffolk When I was deputy shadow culture, media and sport minister I constantly badgered the BBC and ITV about the way they used to just trot out government statistics which were treble counted. In the end, Trevor MacDonald's Tonight programme ran a show on it, and I asked a question at PMQs that embarrassed Blair, and now they've stopped using the figures. 85 Dr Phyllis Starkey MP Labour, Milton Keynes South West Milton Keynes is a young city. I highlighted the risk to young people's safety from unregulated bouncers at pubs and clubs with my private member's bill calling for a national registration scheme for bouncers. This is now part of government legislation. 86 Ian Stewart MP Labour, Eccles I have campaigned with other MPs and families to secure a fair deal from government for victims of vaccine damage. Success was achieved when the government increased the payment to £100,000 equivalent for each damaged child, backdated for children already compensated at lower levels. 87 Gavin Strang MP Labour Edinburgh East and Musselburgh As transport minister I introduced the rural bus subsidy scheme, providing 1,800 new bus services and 16m passenger journeys last year. As chair of the Craigmillar social inclusion partnership board, I am involved in the regeneration of this deprived area in my constituency. 88 Gisela Stuart MP, junior health minister Labour, Birmingham Edgbaston The two things I am proudest of having achieved are serving on the social security select committee and helping to bring about legislation which allows for fairer divisions of pensions on divorce, and succeeding in getting legislation which makes kerbcrawling an arrestable offence. 89 John Swinney MP Leader, SNP Tayside North Contributing to the establishment of the first Scottish Parliament for 300 years. But on a more human level, MPs can genuinely make a difference to the lives of constituents: I still remember helping to secure £18,000 compensation from the Child Support Agency for a mother who was desperately in need of the money. 90 Teddy Taylor MP Conservative, Rochford and Southend East As democracy has declined, the main achievements of MPs today are either as social workers or community interventionists. Among my achievements since 1997 is inviting a young man who was about to commit suicide to give me a week to solve his problems, and contacting him after six days to say those problems had been solved. 91 Peter Temple-Morris MP Labour, Leominster For me the 1997 Parliament has been essentially personal. After some trauma early on I crossed the floor and joined the Parliamentary Labour party. I have achieved political peace of mind, a marvellous thing for which I am deeply grateful to the PLP. 92 Paul Truswell MP Labour, Pudsey David's Law - my private member's bill - closed the loophole on selling alcohol to young people highlighted by the tragic death of 14-year-old David Knowles in my constituency. It also outlawed the practice of adults buying alcohol and handing it to youngsters outside. 93 Prof Steve Webb MP Liberal Democrat, Northavon My proudest moment was when Alistair Darling stood up before Christmas and said the government was not going to cut pensions for millions of widows at a cost of billions of pounds. That was the culmination of a campaign involving myself, colleagues and pensioner groups. 94 Sir Raymond Whitney MP Conservative, Wycombe I am proud of helping to keep alive a constructive policy towards the EU in the Conservative party; trying to make people think clearly about healthcare; and my file of thank-you letters from constituents. 95 Dafydd Wigley MP Plaid Cymru, Caernarfon The landmark event in this parliament was the establishment of the National Assembly for Wales. I hope that I played some part in helping to ensure that this happened. The second landmark for me was to lead Plaid Cymru into the assembly election and to score 30% of the vote and emerge as the main opposition party in the assembly. 96 Ann Winterton MP Conservative, Congleton In addition to doing my best to represent the interests of my constituents at Westminster, my most worthwhile achievement in this parliament was to introduce my private member's bill, the medical treatment (prevention of euthanasia) bill. 97 Ian Taylor MP Conservative, Esher and Walton Standing up in favour of GM organisms, of stem cell therapy and promoting the Beagle 2 Mars Lander vehicle. In the constituency, being involved in successful campaigns to prevent the closure of an 18-bed ward at Walton Hospital and the campaign to keep McDonald's out of Hinchley Wood. 98 Tony Worthington MP Labour, Clydebank and Milngavie My greatest achievement will be shortly when I (and others) win a fair deal for asbestos victims after they were betrayed by the Chester Street Insurance Company, leaving them without compensation in their hour of need. 99 Tim Yeo MP, shadow agriculture minister Conservative, South Suffolk My proudest achievement in the current parliament is to have successfully highlighted the plight of agriculture and the countryside and raised the profile of rural issues in political terms. No industry has been treated as badly as agriculture by Labour, and no people have suffered such attacks on their traditions, resources and environment as those in rural communities. 100 Sir George Young MP Conservative, North West Hampshire In 1998, my constituents in Newton Common got a letter, out of the blue, from a property company that had acquired the common and were using a loophole in the law to demand up to £20,000 from each householder. I amended the countryside bill as it went. Number crunching A total of 231 MPs responded: Labour - 151 Conservative - 49 Liberal Democrat - 20 Plaid Cymru - 3 Scottish National Party - 2 Ulster Unionists - 2 Sinn Fein - 1 Independent - 2 43 MPs mention passing legislation - 18 of introducing their own legislation (private member's bills etc). 27 MPs mention securing a new hospital or health investment (or saving an old hospital from closure). 25 MPs are proud of having been a member of a select committee. 19 MPs mention helping to create or safeguard jobs. 18 MPs mention helping individual constituents. 13 MPs mention securing educational investment (school building, nursery places, etc) for their constituency. 9 MPs mention securing substantial money for regeneration in their constituency. 9 MPs mention securing a new road or road improvement for their constituency. 7 MPs mention helping to establish the Scottish Parliament or the Welsh Assembly. 6 Labour MPs mention supporting the creation of the minimum wage. 5 MPs mention securing peace for Northern Ireland. 4 MPs mention securing flood defences for their constituency. 4 MPs are proud that former Far East PoWs received compensation.  Additional research by James Tapsfield. Tim Parks's fortnightly column will appear tomorrow. All talk? Does your MP appear in this list? Do you think they've done what they say they have? Send us your own assessment of what they've achieved at politics.feedback@guardianunlimited.co.uk. Your verdicts will be published on Guardian Unlimited Politics. Can't find your MP? Visit Guardian Unlimited Politics to find out of if he/she answered our survey. All 231 responses are published on the site. MPs Norman Baker and Peter Bottomley will also be discussing the role of MPs on the site today at 2.30pm.

fields.headline: Commons causes
fields.standfirst:
Our MPs are proud but lack pride

Special report: House of Commons
Four years in 40 words (or so)
Four years in 40 words (continued)
fields.trailText: They are almost convincing. Our MPs describe their accomplishments and the list is many and varied.
fields.body:
They are almost convincing. Our MPs describe their accomplishments in G2 today and the list is many and varied. Some have had direct impact on the lives of individual constituents; others have had a hand in the passage of legislation that will make life better for us all, which is no mean feat. Several mention their role in facilitating stem cell research - a free vote - or the passage of the minimum wage, New Labour's homage to the party's founders. Scottish, Irish and Welsh MPs express pride in their role in the creation of devolved government - which is diminishing the scope of Westminster for the sake of greater self-government in the United Kingdom's nations (except England).

MPs are proud to have raised their voices to get their constituency a new clinic or investment or stop a factory closing. If the pork barrel contains a nursery or new road, should we begrudge an MP a sense of achievement - in all systems of representative politics, serving the home district entails winning goodies for it.

And yet there is something missing from these accounts. They have a defensive, reticent quality, which may have to do with Westminster's existential dilemma. In a system dominated by party loyalty and executive prerogative, what are MPs for beyond their nocturnal strolls through the lobbies? Helping a mother with the child support agency or winning pensions for neglected ex- prisoners of war are creditable. But MPs are not social workers.

Few MPs mention their sense of pride in belonging to a representative assembly, and that may be for the good reason there is not much pride about the Commons these days. The Keith Vaz affair has merely confirmed last year's lesson from the way the chairs of Commons' select committees were so easily fobbed off by the government. This, the legislative branch of the constitution, has fallen into decrepitude. It is not the only one.
