fields.headline: Four years in 40 words (or so)
fields.standfirst:
It's election time and already we are being bombarded with lists of the government's supposed achievements. But what do individual MPs have to show for the past four years? Can ordinary members still get anything done, or has parliament been reduced to an irrelevant talking shop? To find out, we asked every MP to tell us what they were proudest of achieving since the last election - in just 40 words. More than 200 rose to the challenge and here we publish 100 of their answers. They make, says Henry Porter, surprising reading. Project research by Tom Happold

Full list of MPs
Four years in 40 words (continued)
Leader: Common causes
fields.trailText: It's election time and already we are being bombarded with lists of the government's supposed achievements. But what do individual MPs have to show for the past four years? Can ordinary members still get anything done, or has parliament been reduced to an irrelevant talking shop? To find out, we asked every MP to tell us what they were proudest of achieving since the last election - in just 40 words. More than 200 rose to the challenge and here we publish 100 of their answers. They make, says Henry Porter, surprising reading. Project research by Tom Happold.
fields.body:
Our Members of Parliament are largely a mystery to us. We know the names of the cabinet and a handful of the opposition front bench, a few eccentrics perhaps, and some notable old timers, but a lot of us are pushed to name our own member. MPs appear before us in a fleeting parade on election night, standing beside the returning officers, flushed and exuberant, only to vanish as they are absorbed into the drama of the night.

Many of those people on election night are being elected for the first time and you notice the extraordinary pride and hope. Yet they probably don't appreciate the life of unsung drudgery which lies ahead, nor that the vast majority of the 659 members simply disappear while trying to wrestle with the system of government and democracy wired up around them. To come to grips with this machine, to bid for the attention of your constituents and to attract the eye of the party managers, at the same time as holding true to the beliefs that have propelled you, requires considerable gifts of management and tenacity.

The life of a legislator is increasingly lived in an odd obscurity. The opportunities for making your mark in the chamber are almost non-existent and the occasions which might prompt passionate oratory are few and ill-attended. Government has removed itself from the palace. Today, everything is focused on Tony Blair and Gordon Brown in Downing Street, together with the numerous unelected officials who have palpably more power than most of those who have stood for election.

Modern legislators have been bested by the requirements of slick management and centralised presentation. An ambition to rise to the top can only be pursued in a manner which suggests conformity and accommodation. Hopes are buried and egos trampled, while outside Westminster the public remains suspicious that the £48,371 paid to each MP, plus £64,000 in secretarial and living allowances, is a waste of money. It is further argued that with the Scottish and Welsh assemblies, the pre-eminence of Europe and the concentration of power in Downing Street, that at least 100 members are surplus to requirements.

What we forget in all this is the difference between the role of a legislator and that of a representative. We use the terms interchangeably because they refer to the same people but there is a subtle distinction which is brought out in the responses to our survey. Forty-one MPs quoted their role in the drafting and passing of legislation and some, like Robin Cook, surveyed a panorama of almost global personal success.

But the great majority cited small local victories, the resurfacing of roads, the gaining of a passport denied by the immigration authorities, the opening of a school library, the tour of a Down's syndrome theatre group (Gerry Adams) and the solving of a housing problems which had driven a young man to threaten suicide (Teddy Taylor). Twenty-two MPs claimed the achievement of saving a hospital, opening a new one or gaining some other health improvement, while 10 talked about educational investments.

We may be cynical about these responses, given that the election is only nine weeks away and MPs need to remind constituents of their usefulness. However, it is true to say that as representatives they mostly display a doggedness and care which goes largely unremarked. Reading the answers 232 of them provided, a lot of people may change their mind on two issues.

The first is the size of the House of Commons. The respected backbencher Teddy Taylor says, "As democracy has declined, the main achievements of MPs are either as social workers or as community interventionists". He may be depressingly right about democracy - many on the Labour benches agree with him - but it doesn't follow that we should reduce the number of people who have access to ministers and the motivation to work in the way that he describes.

The second is the question of proportional representation, which is claimed to be a fairer way of distilling the nation's political sentiments into parliament. The problem with PR is that a member's direct responsibility for his constituents is lost in the proportional cocktail. Instead of one person charged with acting as social worker, administrative detective, court of last resort and so forth, there can be two or three, and it becomes unclear who has this crucial responsibility. An MP's relationship with her or his constituents is an essential part of democracy and these responses show it.

There are certain universals in a MP's life which means it is often difficult to tell from their replies which party they represent. MPs spend a good deal of time representing their constituents against the insensitive, inefficient and unjust arms of government, so the victories they write about are often non-political. Oddly enough the same applies to their work in committees, a part of the MP's life which goes completely ignored because so little of it receives detailed coverage. It is difficult to read Gisella Stuart's affiliation when she writes, "The two things I am proudest about are serving on the social security select committee and helping to bring about legislation which allows for fairer divisions of pensions on divorce ... and succeeding in getting legislation which makes kerb crawling an offence." Stuart is a junior health minister, but the contributions that give her satisfaction are interestingly bipartisan.

The same is true of members who have campaigned against violent club bouncers (Dr Phyllis Starkey, Lab); for the opening of a second hand furniture store (Caroline Spelman, Con); against the opening of a McDonald's (Ian Taylor, Con) and against the loophole which allowed alcohol to be sold to 14-year-olds (Paul Truswell, Lab). They could swap issues without compromising their political persuasions.

The responses also provide a very clear cutaway of the mainstream of opinion and concerns in Britain in 2001. It is predictable that hospitals and schools and regeneration projects feature so prominently, though it is odd that no MP has much to say about law and order.

If a similar survey had been conducted among members of the German, French or Dutch legislatures we would see less focus on health and education because their systems are better, and more on the environment, which among voters on the continent of 35 and under is considered the most pressing issue of all. Here there are relatively few MPs who rate this worth a mention. Only Alan Whitehead (Lab) appears to have absorbed the message about renewable energy sources. He may be regarded as being in the vanguard of one of the 21st century's principle concerns.

One cannot help smile at some of the replies which have a distinctly Pooterish quality. In a few MPs the sense of self worth seems quite out of proportion. When David Atkinson (Con) claims responsibility for alerting the world to the threat of the millennium bug it's hard to take him seriously. George Galloway (Lab) remarks that he has stood firm against the new imperialism and Anglo-American aggression and that he has been "a voice for the voiceless in the canyons of deprivation in the world".

When we started this project, we suspected the results would underline a sceptical view of the work of MPs. In fact it has done the opposite. What emerges from this sample of a third of all MPs is that notions of public service are hearteningly alive in the House of Commons. It would appear that they do a great deal of good which goes unnoticed. Over the next few days we will try to find out if their constituents agree. This is, after all, only one side of the story.

1 Gerry Adams MP
Sinn Fein leader
Sinn Fein, Belfast West

Getting the peace process back on track and being part of achieving the Good Friday Agreement. Following some conversations I had in New York last year, this St Patrick's Day saw 14 Down's syndrome adults, who make up the Sky's the Limit theatre group, travelling there to perform for US audiences.

2 David Amess
MP Conservative, Southend West

My proudest achievement was to pilot successfully through parliament the Warm Homes and Energy Conservation Act. This should improve the lives of up to 5m people, taking them out of fuel poverty by ensuring their homes are properly insulated.

3 James Arbuthnot MP
Opposition chief whip
Conservative, North East Hampshire

My achievement was shared with others of the Mull of Kintyre group. When Lord Chalfont won a select committee to consider the 1994 Chinook crash, he set us all on the first step towards redressing a gross injustice to the dead pilots.

4 Joseph Ashton MP
Labour, Bassetlaw

The Utting report exposed a horrifying catalogue of sexual abuse to children in care. The Ashton amendment I introduced fixed the age of consent at 18, not 16, in any situation where an adult was in charge of them.

5 Harry Barnes MP
Labour, North East Derbyshire

Major aspects of my two private member's bills have been turned by Labour into improved rights for disabled people and a more modern system of electoral registration. I hope I succeed, with War on Want, in winning greater support for a "Tobin Tax" on international currency exchanges. This would deter quick-buck speculators and raise billions for third-world development.

6 Kevin Barron MP
Labour, Rother Valley

In 1993-4 I promoted a private member's bill to ban the advertising and promotion of tobacco products, which was "talked out" by the Tories. My proudest parliamentary moment for this session, therefore, was to be involved in the passage of a government bill to ban tobacco advertising and promotion.

7 Hugh Bayley MP
Junior social security minister
Labour, City of York

In November I cleared my London diary and joined York's flood defence team. When we ran out of sandbags I appealed for sack workers to sew more overnight. By dawn they had delivered four-and-a-half tons of bags to fill. Thousands of York homes and businesses were saved by the sandbag walls.

8 Martin Bell MP
Independent, Tatton

My proudest moment in this Parliament has had little to do with any of my own speeches. It came on November 8 2000, when the government announced compensation payments of £10,000 each for the surviving Far East prisoners of war and their widows in a long-overdue recognition of their service and sacrifice.

9 Clive Betts MP
Government whip
Labour, Sheffield Attercliffe

It would have to be whipping the bill that established the minimum wage and organising the 24-hour sitting that eventually broke the Tory filibustering and got the legislation through.

10 Richard Burden MP
Labour, Birmingham Northfield

As the local Labour MP, I am proud to have played a part in saving the Longbridge car plant from closure. More than 20,000 jobs were at stake. The experts said Rover could not be saved. The community came together and we proved them wrong. Under new ownership, MG Rover is now doing well.

11 Simon Burns MP
Conservative, Chelmsford West

Successfully piloting through Parliament my private member's bill - the Football (Offences and Disorder) Act 1999 to tighten up the law on football hooligans, and pressuring the government to strengthen legislation further in 2000 by giving the courts the power to withdraw hooligans' passports and prevent them from causing trouble abroad.

12 Dr Vincent Cable MP
Lib Dem, Twickenham

Two years ago, working with Age Concern, I introduced a bill to outlaw age discrimination in the NHS after some elderly constituents had suffered serious neglect in hospital. Last week the government introduced new standards which meet the aims of my bill.

13 Dale Campbell-Savours MP
Labour, Workington

I have long argued for a system for the tracking of animals modelled on that operating in Holland. Finally, in 1997, after I'd made representations to Jeff Rooker, the agriculture minister, a centre was built in Workington. Now 618 people work there and trace all animals in the UK. It is vital to the current foot and mouth battle.

14 William Cash MP
Conservative, Stone

Successfully maintaining pressure within the country and the Conservative party for a policy of renegotiation of the European treaties; persuading the party to demand a white paper on political union; and being elected as chairman of the 200-strong all-party committee on third-world debt.

15 Christopher Chope MP
Conservative, Christchurch

My most satisfying success was to force the government to give a British passport to Sujata Halder, a volunteer worker at the Christchurch Citizens Advice Bureau. The minister was adamant in his refusal until I secured an adjournment debate whereupon he changed his mind before the debate - doubtless to avoid ridicule.

16 Dr David Clark MP
Labour, South Shields

The achievement that gives me the greatest satisfaction was writing the freedom of information white paper, Your Right to Know. This provided the basis for legislation which over time will enhance the rights of individuals and change fundamentally the way governments relate to their citizens.

17 Ann Clwyd MP
Labour, Cynon Valley

Some of the campaigns I have been particularly active in pursuing: speeding up the miners' compensation scheme; regulating cosmetic surgery; opposing the Ilusu dam scheme in Turkey; bringing Iraqi war criminals to justice.

18 Tim Collins MP
Conservative, Westmorland and Lonsdale

The suffering of Gussie Spence of Kendal sparked my campaign on adhesive arachnoiditis - excruciating pain endured after injecting Myodil into the spine. A Commons debate, ministerial meetings and work on an all-party group are all bringing a public inquiry nearer.

19 Tony Colman MP
Labour, Putney

Too many people in south-west London suffer sleep deprivation as a result of aircraft noise at night. I am delighted that, in contrast to my predecessor, I have managed to do something about that: the number of night flights arriving at Heathrow over Putney has been halved.

20 Francis Cook MP
Labour, Stockton North

As vice-president of the Nato parliamentary assembly, I managed to re-establish an effective working relationship between the Russian Duma and Nato parliamentarians in the form of the joint monitoring group of the permanent joint council.

21 Jeremy Corbyn MP
Labour, Islington North

The detention of General Pinochet for 503 days in Britain helped to change the political climate in Chile, which means there is now a real prospect of him being put on trial. I am delighted that the government has put so much money into housing repairs, but in a second term it must put money into new council housing in London.

22 Ann Cryer MP
Labour, Keighley

I'm most proud of my adjournment debate on forced marriages of British-Asian women in 1999. Since then the government has acted, setting itself an action plan which offers help to women who were without it before.

23 John Cummings MP
Labour, Easington

I've been instrumental in the adoption of the new multiple index of deprivation, which looks at access to services and health as well as income. Easington's new classification under these criteria has led to greater funds being available for the borough. I've also lobbied the government to accept compensation claims from former miners who have developed bronchitis or emphysema.

24 Jack Cunningham MP
Labour, Copeland

Working for the complete restoration of the Georgian port of Whitehaven; winning the case for the A595 improvement; supporting policies to reduce unemployment dramatically in Copeland. Leading the campaign to safeguard the future of Sellafield and the 16,000 jobs it sustains. In government, the creation of the FSA and launching the "modern government" initiative.

25 James Cunningham MP
Labour, Coventry South

My area I'm proudest of in this parliament is raising an airport safety private member's bill. Coventry airport had a plane crash in 1995 and I was concerned about the welfare and safety of my constituents living so near to the airfield.

26 Tam Dalyell MP
Labour, Linlithgow

The fact that the Lockerbie trial took place at Zeist, in an independent country; visiting Iraq with the Taoiseach, Albert Reynolds, thus restraining a little the bombing of Baghdad; opposing Blair's Balkan war, going separately to Belgrade and Kosovo; opposing the privatisation of air traffic control.

27 Jim Dobbin MP
Labour, Heywood and Middleton

I was instrumental in forcing a firm of cowboy builders operating in the Greater Manchester area to go into liquidation. My recent question to the prime minister allowed him to announce the creation for the first time of a minister for ex-servicemen and women.

28 David Atkinson MP
Conservative, Bournemouth East

My greatest achievement has been my contribution to saving this country and the wider industrial world from the threat of the millennium bug, through my initiative in the House of Commons, where I was the first MP to raise the issue, the Council of Europe, Western European Union and my visits to the US and Japan.

29 Alan Duncan MP
Conservative, Rutland and Melton

I played a major part in securing William Hague's election as party leader. I helped shift the public debate on Britain's healthcare while a frontbench spokesman, and have been able to help desperate farmers wrestling with foot and mouth disease locally.

30 Margaret Ewing MP
SNP, Moray

I was proud to be involved in the campaign for a maternity unit for Moray. Not only did we get a maternity unit, we also succeeded in getting a new hospital in the shape of Dr Gray's in Elgin.

31 Howard Flight MP
Conservative, Arundel and South Downs

I did all the opposition donkey work for the financial services and markets bill, effecting major improvements to it, in particular the establishment of an independent complaints office. In my constituency the most rewarding individual case involved securing legal help for a man infected with hepatitis C by the surgeon who operated on him.

32 Paul Flynn MP
Labour, Newport West

Helping make endowment mortgages unsellable, drugs prohibition indefensible, bull-bars unfashionable and Newport's delights web-visible. Exposing Labour's suicidal "block vote" in Wales, letting pets travel, and amplifying the near-silent voices of those who are pensioners, low-waged, imprisoned or inartic ulate.

33 Don Foster MP
Principal spokesman for environment, Liberal Democrat, Bath

Other than assisting numerous constituents, I've also beefed up the government's weak plans for freedom of information in local government; ensured that all homes for sale will in future require a home-energy efficiency audit; allowed school crossing patrols to be covered for help given to non-pupils; and helped ensure legislation against the scourge of leylandii.

34 George Foulkes MP
Scottish Office minister
Labour, Carrick, Cumnock and Doon Valley

My proudest achievement is to have played a little part in the return of democracy to Chile; by monitoring the plebiscite, supporting the election of Patricio Aylwin and giving some help to the left, which saw the return of Ricardo Lagos as a socialist president to avenge the coup that ousted Salvador Allende.

35 Maria Fyfe MP
Labour, Glasgow Maryhill

I am proudest of having been involved in the 50-50 campaign to ensure that the Scottish parliament started life with an almost equal representation of women, up there with the Scandinavian countries.

36 Anne Begg MP
Labour, Aberdeen South

I am most proud of the role I played in persuading the House of Commons to support the changes to the regulations on the use of embryonic stem cells in medical research. I believe that this has the potential to lead to the discovery and development of treatments and cures for some of the most horrific degenerative diseases.

37 George Galloway MP
Labour, Glasgow Kelvin

I am proudest to have stood firmly against the new imperialism and Anglo-American aggression around the world. To have been a voice for the voiceless here in Britain, where so many have been marginalised in the fight for "middle England", and in the canyons of deprivation in the world.

38 Mike Gapes MP
Labour, Ilford South

My proudest achievement was to be part of the British government's team negotiating the Good Friday Agreement when I was parliamentary private secretary to Paul Murphy. The most moving achievement was shaking hands with people with no hands at the "amputee camp" in Sierra Leone in February this year, which I visited as a member of the defence select committee.

39 Neil Gerrard MP
Labour, Walthamstow

I was proud to be involved in persuading the government to produce the first national strategy for HIV; to stand up for rights of asylum seekers, particularly on the asylum and immigration bill; and to be a member of the commission of inquiry into the right of return of Palestinian refugees.

40 Christopher Gill MP
Conservative, Ludlow

My battle for the retention of smaller abattoirs has resulted in major changes, to be implemented in April, in the way that meat inspection charges are levied. My efforts to highlight the iniquities of the common fisheries policy have resulted in a change of Conservative party policy, which now says that we will take back control of our fishing waters.

41 Cheryl Gillan MP
Conservative, Chesham and Amersham

Being able to persuade social services that a care package could be worked out to enable an elderly constituent to stay at home and be nursed there, which was what the constituent wanted more than anything.

42 Linda Gilroy MP
Labour, Plymouth Sutton

One in four Plymouth people missed out on school and have low basic skills. My constituent Sue Torr learned to read at the age of 38. By backing her "Shout It Out" literacy project in Westminster I hope I have helped her help more people to do the same.

43 Tommy Graham MP
Independent, Renfrewshire West

The fight to retain jobs in the Royal Ordnance factory at Bishopstone is something I consider as a personal achievement. The need to secure an indigenous armaments industry is essential for the future of the national security of this country.

44 Jane Griffiths MP
Labour, Reading East

I'm most proud of having raised the issue of men's health, in particular testicular and prostate cancer. I persuaded male councillors and members of Reading FC to pose in the street wearing only underpants; established the all-party group on male cancers; and asked parliamentary questions resulting in the availability of testing for prostate cancer for every man who requests it.

45 Peter Hain MP
trade and industry minister, Labour, Neath

Playing a key campaigning role in winning the referendum for a Welsh Assembly and achieving a huge 30% swing from the crushing "no" vote in 1979.

46 Archibald Hamilton MP
Conservative, Epsom and Ewell

I would much prefer to comment on what I have failed to achieve as an MP since 1997, which is to make the press and media in this country any more responsible. They continue to be answerable to no one other than their proprietors and are increasingly courted by politicians. This leaves a serious democratic deficit.

47 Harriet Harman MP Labour
Camberwell and Peckham

Being part of the government that introduced the national childcare strategy and the new deal for lone parents. Then, as a backbencher, chairing Southwark's Childcare Partnership, which got 4,100 more after-school club places for local children; and supporting its new-deal personal advisers who helped make 28,000 children better off by helping their mothers move off benefits and into work.

48 Sir Alan Haselhurst MP
Conservative, Saffron Walden

I took particular pleasure in helping a constituent of Polish extraction who had served as a nurse in the allied war effort. Having survived the torpedoing of a ship, she was entitled to a pension, but was unable to prove that she had been aboard. I extracted from the MoD records proof of her service, which led to her receiving her pension.

49 Andrew Hunter MP
Conservative, Basingstoke

My private member's bill, which became the Road Traffic (Vehicle Testing) Act 1999; a government commitment to a quieter M3 surface through Basingstoke; to have been one of only a handful of mainland MPs who have consistently opposed the sell-out to terrorism in Northern Ireland.

50 Michael Jack MP
Conservative, Fylde

My worthwhile achievements include helping hundreds of constituents with problems; my work on the agriculture select committee; helping to win business for aerospace and nuclear workers; and masterminding an event to raise £3,000 for the local hospice.

51 Ieuan Wyn Jones MP
Leader, Plaid Cymru, Ynys Mn

Despite its weaknesses, the Government of Wales Act 1998 represents a small but significant step forward for Wales. I'm glad to have taken part in the debate, both in Parliament and in helping to deliver a "yes" vote in the referendum.

52 Dr Lynne Jones MP
Labour, Birmingham Selly Oak

Child benefit, disability benefits and the state pension are all better as a result of the backbench "rebellions" in which I played a leading role. Through the all-party mental health group, I have helped mental health organisations work more effectively together. My persistence on behalf of constituents has secured a more just outcome in a large number of individual cases.

53 Tessa Jowell MP, education and employment minister
Labour, Dulwich and West Norwood

Delivering SureStart, the early-nurture programme for disadvantaged mums and their babies, because equality is a birthright. In my constituency, a new secondary school, a new community hospital promised, a police station kept open; and helping people such as Dr M, reunited with his daughter after eight years.

54 Robin Cook MP Foreign secretary
Labour, Livingston

Breaking the deadlock in the Lockerbie case; defending Kosovo; saving lives and relieving suffering in Sierra Leone; contributing to the fall of Milosevic; transforming Britain's relations with Europe; rebuilding respect for Britain in the world.

Labour, Houghton and Washington East

fields.bodyText: Our Members of Parliament are largely a mystery to us. We know the names of the cabinet and a handful of the opposition front bench, a few eccentrics perhaps, and some notable old timers, but a lot of us are pushed to name our own member. MPs appear before us in a fleeting parade on election night, standing beside the returning officers, flushed and exuberant, only to vanish as they are absorbed into the drama of the night. Many of those people on election night are being elected for the first time and you notice the extraordinary pride and hope. Yet they probably don't appreciate the life of unsung drudgery which lies ahead, nor that the vast majority of the 659 members simply disappear while trying to wrestle with the system of government and democracy wired up around them. To come to grips with this machine, to bid for the attention of your constituents and to attract the eye of the party managers, at the same time as holding true to the beliefs that have propelled you, requires considerable gifts of management and tenacity. The life of a legislator is increasingly lived in an odd obscurity. The opportunities for making your mark in the chamber are almost non-existent and the occasions which might prompt passionate oratory are few and ill-attended. Government has removed itself from the palace. Today, everything is focused on Tony Blair and Gordon Brown in Downing Street, together with the numerous unelected officials who have palpably more power than most of those who have stood for election. Modern legislators have been bested by the requirements of slick management and centralised presentation. An ambition to rise to the top can only be pursued in a manner which suggests conformity and accommodation. Hopes are buried and egos trampled, while outside Westminster the public remains suspicious that the £48,371 paid to each MP, plus £64,000 in secretarial and living allowances, is a waste of money. It is further argued that with the Scottish and Welsh assemblies, the pre-eminence of Europe and the concentration of power in Downing Street, that at least 100 members are surplus to requirements. What we forget in all this is the difference between the role of a legislator and that of a representative. We use the terms interchangeably because they refer to the same people but there is a subtle distinction which is brought out in the responses to our survey. Forty-one MPs quoted their role in the drafting and passing of legislation and some, like Robin Cook, surveyed a panorama of almost global personal success. But the great majority cited small local victories, the resurfacing of roads, the gaining of a passport denied by the immigration authorities, the opening of a school library, the tour of a Down's syndrome theatre group (Gerry Adams) and the solving of a housing problems which had driven a young man to threaten suicide (Teddy Taylor). Twenty-two MPs claimed the achievement of saving a hospital, opening a new one or gaining some other health improvement, while 10 talked about educational investments. We may be cynical about these responses, given that the election is only nine weeks away and MPs need to remind constituents of their usefulness. However, it is true to say that as representatives they mostly display a doggedness and care which goes largely unremarked. Reading the answers 232 of them provided, a lot of people may change their mind on two issues. The first is the size of the House of Commons. The respected backbencher Teddy Taylor says, "As democracy has declined, the main achievements of MPs are either as social workers or as community interventionists". He may be depressingly right about democracy - many on the Labour benches agree with him - but it doesn't follow that we should reduce the number of people who have access to ministers and the motivation to work in the way that he describes. The second is the question of proportional representation, which is claimed to be a fairer way of distilling the nation's political sentiments into parliament. The problem with PR is that a member's direct responsibility for his constituents is lost in the proportional cocktail. Instead of one person charged with acting as social worker, administrative detective, court of last resort and so forth, there can be two or three, and it becomes unclear who has this crucial responsibility. An MP's relationship with her or his constituents is an essential part of democracy and these responses show it. There are certain universals in a MP's life which means it is often difficult to tell from their replies which party they represent. MPs spend a good deal of time representing their constituents against the insensitive, inefficient and unjust arms of government, so the victories they write about are often non-political. Oddly enough the same applies to their work in committees, a part of the MP's life which goes completely ignored because so little of it receives detailed coverage. It is difficult to read Gisella Stuart's affiliation when she writes, "The two things I am proudest about are serving on the social security select committee and helping to bring about legislation which allows for fairer divisions of pensions on divorce ... and succeeding in getting legislation which makes kerb crawling an offence." Stuart is a junior health minister, but the contributions that give her satisfaction are interestingly bipartisan. The same is true of members who have campaigned against violent club bouncers (Dr Phyllis Starkey, Lab); for the opening of a second hand furniture store (Caroline Spelman, Con); against the opening of a McDonald's (Ian Taylor, Con) and against the loophole which allowed alcohol to be sold to 14-year-olds (Paul Truswell, Lab). They could swap issues without compromising their political persuasions. The responses also provide a very clear cutaway of the mainstream of opinion and concerns in Britain in 2001. It is predictable that hospitals and schools and regeneration projects feature so prominently, though it is odd that no MP has much to say about law and order. If a similar survey had been conducted among members of the German, French or Dutch legislatures we would see less focus on health and education because their systems are better, and more on the environment, which among voters on the continent of 35 and under is considered the most pressing issue of all. Here there are relatively few MPs who rate this worth a mention. Only Alan Whitehead (Lab) appears to have absorbed the message about renewable energy sources. He may be regarded as being in the vanguard of one of the 21st century's principle concerns. One cannot help smile at some of the replies which have a distinctly Pooterish quality. In a few MPs the sense of self worth seems quite out of proportion. When David Atkinson (Con) claims responsibility for alerting the world to the threat of the millennium bug it's hard to take him seriously. George Galloway (Lab) remarks that he has stood firm against the new imperialism and Anglo-American aggression and that he has been "a voice for the voiceless in the canyons of deprivation in the world". When we started this project, we suspected the results would underline a sceptical view of the work of MPs. In fact it has done the opposite. What emerges from this sample of a third of all MPs is that notions of public service are hearteningly alive in the House of Commons. It would appear that they do a great deal of good which goes unnoticed. Over the next few days we will try to find out if their constituents agree. This is, after all, only one side of the story. 1 Gerry Adams MP Sinn Fein leader Sinn Fein, Belfast West Getting the peace process back on track and being part of achieving the Good Friday Agreement. Following some conversations I had in New York last year, this St Patrick's Day saw 14 Down's syndrome adults, who make up the Sky's the Limit theatre group, travelling there to perform for US audiences. 2 David Amess MP Conservative, Southend West My proudest achievement was to pilot successfully through parliament the Warm Homes and Energy Conservation Act. This should improve the lives of up to 5m people, taking them out of fuel poverty by ensuring their homes are properly insulated. 3 James Arbuthnot MP Opposition chief whip Conservative, North East Hampshire My achievement was shared with others of the Mull of Kintyre group. When Lord Chalfont won a select committee to consider the 1994 Chinook crash, he set us all on the first step towards redressing a gross injustice to the dead pilots. 4 Joseph Ashton MP Labour, Bassetlaw The Utting report exposed a horrifying catalogue of sexual abuse to children in care. The Ashton amendment I introduced fixed the age of consent at 18, not 16, in any situation where an adult was in charge of them. 5 Harry Barnes MP Labour, North East Derbyshire Major aspects of my two private member's bills have been turned by Labour into improved rights for disabled people and a more modern system of electoral registration. I hope I succeed, with War on Want, in winning greater support for a "Tobin Tax" on international currency exchanges. This would deter quick-buck speculators and raise billions for third-world development. 6 Kevin Barron MP Labour, Rother Valley In 1993-4 I promoted a private member's bill to ban the advertising and promotion of tobacco products, which was "talked out" by the Tories. My proudest parliamentary moment for this session, therefore, was to be involved in the passage of a government bill to ban tobacco advertising and promotion. 7 Hugh Bayley MP Junior social security minister Labour, City of York In November I cleared my London diary and joined York's flood defence team. When we ran out of sandbags I appealed for sack workers to sew more overnight. By dawn they had delivered four-and-a-half tons of bags to fill. Thousands of York homes and businesses were saved by the sandbag walls. 8 Martin Bell MP Independent, Tatton My proudest moment in this Parliament has had little to do with any of my own speeches. It came on November 8 2000, when the government announced compensation payments of £10,000 each for the surviving Far East prisoners of war and their widows in a long-overdue recognition of their service and sacrifice. 9 Clive Betts MP Government whip Labour, Sheffield Attercliffe It would have to be whipping the bill that established the minimum wage and organising the 24-hour sitting that eventually broke the Tory filibustering and got the legislation through. 10 Richard Burden MP Labour, Birmingham Northfield As the local Labour MP, I am proud to have played a part in saving the Longbridge car plant from closure. More than 20,000 jobs were at stake. The experts said Rover could not be saved. The community came together and we proved them wrong. Under new ownership, MG Rover is now doing well. 11 Simon Burns MP Conservative, Chelmsford West Successfully piloting through Parliament my private member's bill - the Football (Offences and Disorder) Act 1999 to tighten up the law on football hooligans, and pressuring the government to strengthen legislation further in 2000 by giving the courts the power to withdraw hooligans' passports and prevent them from causing trouble abroad. 12 Dr Vincent Cable MP Lib Dem, Twickenham Two years ago, working with Age Concern, I introduced a bill to outlaw age discrimination in the NHS after some elderly constituents had suffered serious neglect in hospital. Last week the government introduced new standards which meet the aims of my bill. 13 Dale Campbell-Savours MP Labour, Workington I have long argued for a system for the tracking of animals modelled on that operating in Holland. Finally, in 1997, after I'd made representations to Jeff Rooker, the agriculture minister, a centre was built in Workington. Now 618 people work there and trace all animals in the UK. It is vital to the current foot and mouth battle. 14 William Cash MP Conservative, Stone Successfully maintaining pressure within the country and the Conservative party for a policy of renegotiation of the European treaties; persuading the party to demand a white paper on political union; and being elected as chairman of the 200-strong all-party committee on third-world debt. 15 Christopher Chope MP Conservative, Christchurch My most satisfying success was to force the government to give a British passport to Sujata Halder, a volunteer worker at the Christchurch Citizens Advice Bureau. The minister was adamant in his refusal until I secured an adjournment debate whereupon he changed his mind before the debate - doubtless to avoid ridicule. 16 Dr David Clark MP Labour, South Shields The achievement that gives me the greatest satisfaction was writing the freedom of information white paper, Your Right to Know. This provided the basis for legislation which over time will enhance the rights of individuals and change fundamentally the way governments relate to their citizens. 17 Ann Clwyd MP Labour, Cynon Valley Some of the campaigns I have been particularly active in pursuing: speeding up the miners' compensation scheme; regulating cosmetic surgery; opposing the Ilusu dam scheme in Turkey; bringing Iraqi war criminals to justice. 18 Tim Collins MP Conservative, Westmorland and Lonsdale The suffering of Gussie Spence of Kendal sparked my campaign on adhesive arachnoiditis - excruciating pain endured after injecting Myodil into the spine. A Commons debate, ministerial meetings and work on an all-party group are all bringing a public inquiry nearer. 19 Tony Colman MP Labour, Putney Too many people in south-west London suffer sleep deprivation as a result of aircraft noise at night. I am delighted that, in contrast to my predecessor, I have managed to do something about that: the number of night flights arriving at Heathrow over Putney has been halved. 20 Francis Cook MP Labour, Stockton North As vice-president of the Nato parliamentary assembly, I managed to re-establish an effective working relationship between the Russian Duma and Nato parliamentarians in the form of the joint monitoring group of the permanent joint council. 21 Jeremy Corbyn MP Labour, Islington North The detention of General Pinochet for 503 days in Britain helped to change the political climate in Chile, which means there is now a real prospect of him being put on trial. I am delighted that the government has put so much money into housing repairs, but in a second term it must put money into new council housing in London. 22 Ann Cryer MP Labour, Keighley I'm most proud of my adjournment debate on forced marriages of British-Asian women in 1999. Since then the government has acted, setting itself an action plan which offers help to women who were without it before. 23 John Cummings MP Labour, Easington I've been instrumental in the adoption of the new multiple index of deprivation, which looks at access to services and health as well as income. Easington's new classification under these criteria has led to greater funds being available for the borough. I've also lobbied the government to accept compensation claims from former miners who have developed bronchitis or emphysema. 24 Jack Cunningham MP Labour, Copeland Working for the complete restoration of the Georgian port of Whitehaven; winning the case for the A595 improvement; supporting policies to reduce unemployment dramatically in Copeland. Leading the campaign to safeguard the future of Sellafield and the 16,000 jobs it sustains. In government, the creation of the FSA and launching the "modern government" initiative. 25 James Cunningham MP Labour, Coventry South My area I'm proudest of in this parliament is raising an airport safety private member's bill. Coventry airport had a plane crash in 1995 and I was concerned about the welfare and safety of my constituents living so near to the airfield. 26 Tam Dalyell MP Labour, Linlithgow The fact that the Lockerbie trial took place at Zeist, in an independent country; visiting Iraq with the Taoiseach, Albert Reynolds, thus restraining a little the bombing of Baghdad; opposing Blair's Balkan war, going separately to Belgrade and Kosovo; opposing the privatisation of air traffic control. 27 Jim Dobbin MP Labour, Heywood and Middleton I was instrumental in forcing a firm of cowboy builders operating in the Greater Manchester area to go into liquidation. My recent question to the prime minister allowed him to announce the creation for the first time of a minister for ex-servicemen and women. 28 David Atkinson MP Conservative, Bournemouth East My greatest achievement has been my contribution to saving this country and the wider industrial world from the threat of the millennium bug, through my initiative in the House of Commons, where I was the first MP to raise the issue, the Council of Europe, Western European Union and my visits to the US and Japan. 29 Alan Duncan MP Conservative, Rutland and Melton I played a major part in securing William Hague's election as party leader. I helped shift the public debate on Britain's healthcare while a frontbench spokesman, and have been able to help desperate farmers wrestling with foot and mouth disease locally. 30 Margaret Ewing MP SNP, Moray I was proud to be involved in the campaign for a maternity unit for Moray. Not only did we get a maternity unit, we also succeeded in getting a new hospital in the shape of Dr Gray's in Elgin. 31 Howard Flight MP Conservative, Arundel and South Downs I did all the opposition donkey work for the financial services and markets bill, effecting major improvements to it, in particular the establishment of an independent complaints office. In my constituency the most rewarding individual case involved securing legal help for a man infected with hepatitis C by the surgeon who operated on him. 32 Paul Flynn MP Labour, Newport West Helping make endowment mortgages unsellable, drugs prohibition indefensible, bull-bars unfashionable and Newport's delights web-visible. Exposing Labour's suicidal "block vote" in Wales, letting pets travel, and amplifying the near-silent voices of those who are pensioners, low-waged, imprisoned or inartic ulate. 33 Don Foster MP Principal spokesman for environment, Liberal Democrat, Bath Other than assisting numerous constituents, I've also beefed up the government's weak plans for freedom of information in local government; ensured that all homes for sale will in future require a home-energy efficiency audit; allowed school crossing patrols to be covered for help given to non-pupils; and helped ensure legislation against the scourge of leylandii. 34 George Foulkes MP Scottish Office minister Labour, Carrick, Cumnock and Doon Valley My proudest achievement is to have played a little part in the return of democracy to Chile; by monitoring the plebiscite, supporting the election of Patricio Aylwin and giving some help to the left, which saw the return of Ricardo Lagos as a socialist president to avenge the coup that ousted Salvador Allende. 35 Maria Fyfe MP Labour, Glasgow Maryhill I am proudest of having been involved in the 50-50 campaign to ensure that the Scottish parliament started life with an almost equal representation of women, up there with the Scandinavian countries. 36 Anne Begg MP Labour, Aberdeen South I am most proud of the role I played in persuading the House of Commons to support the changes to the regulations on the use of embryonic stem cells in medical research. I believe that this has the potential to lead to the discovery and development of treatments and cures for some of the most horrific degenerative diseases. 37 George Galloway MP Labour, Glasgow Kelvin I am proudest to have stood firmly against the new imperialism and Anglo-American aggression around the world. To have been a voice for the voiceless here in Britain, where so many have been marginalised in the fight for "middle England", and in the canyons of deprivation in the world. 38 Mike Gapes MP Labour, Ilford South My proudest achievement was to be part of the British government's team negotiating the Good Friday Agreement when I was parliamentary private secretary to Paul Murphy. The most moving achievement was shaking hands with people with no hands at the "amputee camp" in Sierra Leone in February this year, which I visited as a member of the defence select committee. 39 Neil Gerrard MP Labour, Walthamstow I was proud to be involved in persuading the government to produce the first national strategy for HIV; to stand up for rights of asylum seekers, particularly on the asylum and immigration bill; and to be a member of the commission of inquiry into the right of return of Palestinian refugees. 40 Christopher Gill MP Conservative, Ludlow My battle for the retention of smaller abattoirs has resulted in major changes, to be implemented in April, in the way that meat inspection charges are levied. My efforts to highlight the iniquities of the common fisheries policy have resulted in a change of Conservative party policy, which now says that we will take back control of our fishing waters. 41 Cheryl Gillan MP Conservative, Chesham and Amersham Being able to persuade social services that a care package could be worked out to enable an elderly constituent to stay at home and be nursed there, which was what the constituent wanted more than anything. 42 Linda Gilroy MP Labour, Plymouth Sutton One in four Plymouth people missed out on school and have low basic skills. My constituent Sue Torr learned to read at the age of 38. By backing her "Shout It Out" literacy project in Westminster I hope I have helped her help more people to do the same. 43 Tommy Graham MP Independent, Renfrewshire West The fight to retain jobs in the Royal Ordnance factory at Bishopstone is something I consider as a personal achievement. webTitle: Vaz critics search for candidate to fight MP

fields.headline: Vaz critics search for candidate to fight MP
fields.standfirst:
Minister with heart problem under new pressure

Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Opponents of Keith Vaz in his home city of Leicester are trying to attract an independent candidate to run against the minister for Europe in the coming election campaign - in the same way that the BBC's Martin Bell successfully did against Neil Hamilton in 1997.
fields.body:
Opponents of Keith Vaz in his home city of Leicester are trying to attract an independent candidate to run against the minister for Europe in the coming election campaign - in the same way that the BBC's Martin Bell successfully did against Neil Hamilton in 1997.

Mr Bell, who is fulfilling his pledge to stand down as independent MP for Tatton after one term, confirmed yesterday that he had been approached by "various people in Leicester East" asking if he would run in the seat held by Mr Vaz with a majority of 18,442.

Because he had already agreed to stand in Brentwood, Essex, in protest against the alleged infiltration of the local Conservative association by the religious right, Mr Bell refused. It would let down too many people, he said.

Mr Vaz was the object of a series of complex investigations about influence peddling by the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, some of which are still unresolved accused her of unfair tactics and delay, she accused him of obstructing her inquiries. Downing Street has supported the minister.

But Mr Bell, the former foreign correspondent who still wears his trademark white suit, showed sympathy and wrote to his old BBC colleague, world affairs editor, John Simpson, to suggest he stood instead. Mr Simpson rang to say he would not do so, though yesterday's Sun quoted him as saying he is "talking about it with friends".

In a BBC statement yesterday the Dublin-based Mr Simpson said he will not be leaving the corporation despite the suggestion from Mr Bell. "I have no intention of pursuing it." But other sources within the East Midlands city - currently coping with an outbreak of tuberculosis - confirm that an informal group opposed to their MP has been putting out feelers.

It consists of some local lawyers and other activists, both Asian and white, some with Labour connections. "They feel they want to put up a candidate against Keith Vaz because Keith is a person seen as bad news for the city and for Asians in politics," one well- placed source said. Others confirmed it last night, though Mr Vaz's supporters denied all such knowledge and predicted that their MP, currently recovering from heart problems, would be well enough to campaign gently and hold his seat in the expected June 7 poll.

One pro-Vaz source in Leicester said last night that the Sun's report should be discounted because the paper is "influenced by its own agenda on Keith's job ( Europe) and his race". Critics, Leicester Asians among them, say the Vaz family's style of politics has damaged the city.

 No decision has been reached by Labour's ruling NEC over protests launched by activists in the Birmingham Perry Barr constituency against the selection of Kashmiri Muslim community worker, Khalid Mahmood, as candidate to succeed Jeff Rooker, the veteran social security minister. Complaints of ballot fixing have been rejected, but doubts about Mr Mahmood's personal record in Birmingham politics are being examined.

Both he and his critics were interviewed by an NEC panel which supervised the candidate selection at neighbouring Erdington where locally-raised columnist, Sion Simon, won easily.
Special report: House of Commons

fields.headline: Brussels 'lax' on animal transport
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Animal rights campaigners criticised the European commission yesterday for doing far too little to end the practice of transporting live animals to the continent in cramped overheated lorries on journeys which can last up to 50 hours.
fields.body:
Animal rights campaigners criticised the European commission yesterday for doing far too little to end the practice of transporting live animals to the continent in cramped overheated lorries on journeys which can last up to 50 hours.

Compassion in World Farming said proposals from Brussels to force road hauliers to install sophisticated equipment to monitor ventilation, temperature and humidity levels during such trips fell well short of what was needed.

"We would rather the commission went back to the drawing board and started again," CIWF spokeswoman Julie Briggs said.

"We think it's simply not enough. We believe we shouldn't have long journeys at all regardless of the type of vehicle being used. Animals suffer stress, can be trampled to death and become dehydrated."

Britain exports around 1m sheep to mainland Europe every year.

The commission proposals, which must be approved by EU governments stipulate that all new trucks used for such journeys need to be specially modified by January 2002. Older trucks would have to meet the new standards by the end of 2003.

It is estimated up to 20,000 lorries across Europe would need to be refitted with improved temperature controls as well as a warning system to alert the driver to dangerous increases in temperature.

webTitle: US spy plane: Frustrated US eyes reprisals

fields.headline: Frustrated US eyes reprisals
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Bush administration gave the first hints yesterday that growing American impatience with the spy plane standoff in China could provoke a much wider diplomatic freeze between Washington and Beijing.
fields.body:
The Bush administration gave the first hints yesterday that growing American impatience with the spy plane standoff in China could provoke a much wider diplomatic freeze between Washington and Beijing.

White House officials made clear that a presidential visit to China later this year could be at risk, while speculation grew that trade, human rights and arms issues are likely to be affected, whatever the outcome of the dispute.

The frustration levels rose as the dispute entered its second week with no immediate sign that the two sides were any closer to reaching a face-saving agreement. American officials had hinted late last week that the affair would be solved at the weekend.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, offered yesterday to help resolve the standoff over the US spy plane and its crew, which China has been holding on Hainan island since April 1. "I hope the direct discussions will lead to results," Mr Annan said. "But if my good offices are needed, I'm always available."

The US president, George Bush, warned of letting the crisis go on too long.

"Every day that goes by increases the potential that our relations with China will be damaged," he told reporters at the White House. " Diplomacy takes time, but ... the longer this goes, there is a point at which our relations with China become damaged."

Mr Bush's comments came as several senior members of Congress began referring to the standoff as a "hostage" crisis.

"I hate to increase the tension by elevating the rhetoric, but if you look up the definition of hostage, I don't see what else you can describe our 24 crewmen as," Henry Hyde, the Republican chairman of the House of Representatives international affairs committee, said.

"You can play semantic games if you want, but I think they're hostages," he said.

The White House hinted for the first time yesterday that Mr Bush was considering scrapping an October visit to Beijing. The visit, in which the president is to attend the annual Asia-Pacific economic summit, was still on the agenda White House spokesman Ari Fleischer said.

"But many members of Congress were supposed to go to China this week, and they cancelled their trip," he said. "And that's further evidence that the longer this goes on, the more damage risks getting done to US-China relations."

American officials, led by Brigadier-General Neal Seaock, the US military attache in China, had another 40-minute meeting with the crew of the plane yesterday, as the crisis entered its ninth day.

Mr Bush, meanwhile, sent a letter expressing regret at the death of the Chinese pilot, Wang Wei, in the incident.

His letter to the pilot's wife, Ruan Guoqin, came after she had accused the US of being "too cowardly" to apologise for the loss of her husband.

webTitle: US spy plane: Accidental tourists give island a lift

fields.headline: Accidental tourists give island a lift
fields.standfirst:
War of words gathers pace as the 24 crew of the US spy plane brought down on Hainan island begin their second week in captivity

Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: War of words gathers pace as the 24 crew of the US spy plane brought down on Hainan island begin their second week in captivity
fields.body:
"The Americans are really too much, they're always causing trouble," sighed the owner of the photo studio, standing beneath pictures of Chairman Mao. "I really don't know what we can do about them."

"By the way, have you been down south to Sanya? The beaches are really nice down there."

Hainan is an unlikely place for an international crisis: a subtropical island of white sands and palm trees in the South China Sea between Hong Kong and Vietnam, which the government has tried for years to turn into an international tourist resort.

But it has not yet made it all the way on to the international tourist map. The dip in the Chinese economy in the mid-90s left the island littered with half-finished tower blocks and office buildings.

In one of these ragged parts of the capital, Haikou, lies the luxury hotel at the centre of the diplomatic drama.

Brigadier-General Neal Sealock and his team have been pacing its granite corridors, pursued by packs of Hong Kong journalists, waiting for phone calls from local Chinese officials telling them when they can next meet the crew of their downed spy plane.

It is a surreal sight. On Friday night, after the long-awaited second meeting, Brig Sealock marched off to call President George Bush and the journalists raced to file their stories.

The commotion attracted curious looks from the pouting young women in spangly dresses who parade through the lobby each evening, accompanied by middle-aged men, or in some cases trailing a discreet few paces behind them.

The world's oldest profession is another ever-present part of Hainan's economic boom.

One of the hotel's managers seems delighted by his unexpected American guests. "This could really raise the profile of Hainan as an international destination," he says, when asked whether the crisis could be bad for tourism.

The city is completely without hostility towards foreigners, despite the recent tension. But in the colonnaded streets of crumbling Portuguese-style merchant houses, common in southern China, there is bitterness towards the US.

The Chinese media have played a big part in creating the public mood, focusing on allegations that the US plane caused the collision,and infringed on Chinese airspace before landing. The way the stories are written has led many to believe that the collision was in Chinese airspace.

In a nearby television shop the evening news was reporting the latest on the search for the missing pilot, Wang Wei.

Like most people, the owner of the shop said the US expression of regret for the incident did not go far enough.

"That's just some kind of sympathy - it's not enough. They should apologise, and they should give us appropriate compensation, that's the absolute minimum."

fields.headline: Macedonian army brutality condemned
fields.standfirst:
Stabilisation wins Skopje EU family embrace
Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Stabilisation wins Skopje EU family embrace despite complaints of military brutality
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele  in Skopje and  Ian Black in Luxembourg
fields.body:
International monitors in Macedonia have complained to the government about the arrest and beating of scores of ethnic Albanian civilians, and the vandalising of dozens of houses, by security forces "cleaning up" after the offensive against Albanian guerrillas.

Evidence of the damage was presented by representatives of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe as Macedonia was formally welcomed into the "extended European family" in Luxembourg.

Flanked by EU foreign ministers, the Macedonian prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, promised to meet the June deadline for improved relations between the ethnically Slav majority and the restive Albanian minority.

Mr Georgievski spoke of his "joy and pride" at the signing of a "stabilisation and association agreement" with the EU which gives Macedonia generous trade terms and strong political support.

Macedonia, which a month ago seemed close to civil war, is the first former Yugoslav republic to benefit from such an agreement.

Croatia is next in line for a special relationship, while the wealthier and long-peaceful Slovenia is already negotiating full EU membership.

The OSCE representatives visited most of the mountain villages suspected of being Albanian guerrilla bases and returned with sheafs of photographs of homes ransacked and marked with crosses as a token of Macedonian triumph. The Slavic Macedonians are Orthodox Christian. Most Albanians are Muslim.

"We were pleasantly surprised by the army's success but we don't want silly faux pas caused by heavy-handedness and beatings," a western diplomat said yesterday.

In the worst incident reported by the monitors, the army killed a boy of 16 who had returned by taxi with two companions from the city of Tetovo to Selce, once the stronghold of the self-styled National Liberation Army, to look after their sheep. He was shot four times.

One of the other boys, a deaf-mute, is said to be seriously traumatised by the incident, which occurred on Friday.

The Macedonian army says three suspected NLA guerrillas approached troops, who fired in self-defence.

The observers found that every car in Selce had its windows smashed. Only a few people were left in the village, from which the entire civilian population fled during the intense artillery bombardment which preceded an assault by special forces and police officers.

Cupboard drawers and clothes were strewn over the floor, suggesting that there had been a search for jewellery and valuables.

But television sets, videos, and fridges were largely still in place, unlike in the Albanian homes looted by Serb forces in Kosovo two years ago.

In the nearby village of Sipkovica, which has more than 200 houses, only about 10 had been searched, and nothing was broken. No weapons were found there.

In other villages the police arrested 200 people in the first two days of their sweep. The monitors have photographs of dozens of severely bruised men. Many of them were treated in Tetovo hospital.

"Several had broken ribs and noses, and your kidneys don't function too well after you've been with the police," one of the monitors said yesterday.

"People were just rounded up on their way to work."

Nevertheless, the EU felt able to indulge in a little cautious self-congratulation in Luxembourg, where its security and foreign policy supremo Javier Solana, the architect of yesterday's agreement, said: "There is a greater sense of stability, and the security environment has also improved significantly. We must begin to see results soon."

Anna Lindh, the foreign minister of Sweden, which holds the rotating EU presidency, told Mr Georgievski: "You have an enormous responsibility in front of you ... and I'm sure you're going to succeed."

fields.headline: Villages fight for pastoral sympathy
fields.standfirst:
Cull: anger at choice of site to slaughter and bury livestock

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Rural guerrillas armed only with anger, daffodils and a detailed knowledge of the local terrain are determined to halt the burning and burying of cattle and sheep 1,000ft up a mountain in the upper Usk valley in mid-Wales.
fields.body:
Rural guerrillas armed only with anger, daffodils and a detailed knowledge of the local terrain are determined to halt the burning and burying of cattle and sheep 1,000ft up a mountain in the upper Usk valley in mid-Wales.

Farmers and residents of Trecastle and Sennybridge in Powys fought - and lost - a government decision to dispose of culled animals from all over Powys on army ranges on Myndd Eppynt, which faces the Brecon Beacons.

They say that they fear water courses running into the Usk and Towy (rivers designated as sites of special scientific interest) will be polluted. They add they cannot understand why animals killed on land close to infected farms are being driven 60 or more miles along a main tourist highway to what they claim is a clean area. Why not slaughter, burn and bury on the killing fields of Welshpool and beyond?

They are an organised lot, with a website, an office pumping out petition forms and a small army of sandwich makers.

A mile or so out of Brecon, you pick up their first sign warning that you are about to enter Death Valley. "May sheep safely graze," reads another further along the A40. A third pleads: "Pray for us".

There is nothing like this near the Great Orton burial site in Cumbria.

Outside the community centre in Trecastle protesters maintain a picket line and throw their daffodils under the trucks that have brought in the 849 cattle that have been burned and the 6147 sheep that have been buried so far.

"It can only be a matter of time before they bring foot and mouth to this area," said Katherine Jones from Sennybridge. "We are frightened and angry."

There were no deliveries of carcasses yesterday: there was local uproar at the weekend after two truck drivers became lost on their way out of the army range and when at least two trucks were spotted leaking fluid, some of it blood according to the protesters, on to roads. "The last two days have been a fiasco," said Kirsty Williams, the local Liberal Democrat member of the Welsh assembly. "What the government wanted was an easy site where no planning permission was required and they could do what they liked. I was pretty shocked to hear about it first on the radio."

Much of the protesters' anger is directed at Carwyn Jones, rural affairs minister in the Welsh assembly. "We have been let down," added Katherine Jones. "The national assembly is supposed to be working in the national interest of Wales. But Carwyn Jones has become a puppet of Blair's government.

"They are willing for this area to be sacrificed so that a round-the-clock cull can be maintained. We have been sold down the river because this a is a rural area with a sparse population."

The issue is complicated by history and memories of what is perceived as another piece of treachery by the English against the Welsh. In 1940, 50 farms were purchased and residents told to move at a moment's notice to create the 30,000 acre training range still used by artillery troops today.

"When we heard of the plan to use Eppynt people here felt that those who had taken the land from their ancestors were now taking the livelihoods away from the descendants of those ancestors," said Glyn Powell, deputy president of the Farmers' Union of Wales. "They saw that another, sadder chapter was being added to a sad story."

The graziers were told of the burn and bury plan on March 29. Early on there was some direct action, with women blocking the A40 at Sennybridge.

They held a procession and a mock funeral and some local lads managed to stall trucks bringing pyre materials as they ground up the hill past historic Llywell church to the chosen sites. That road is now barricaded by police who maintain a strong presence.

Just over a week ago, a man, who protesters insist was nothing to do with them, drove a digger down that hill and into a police van, trapping and injuring the officer inside. A man has since been arrested and charged. After that, Terrence Grange, chief constable of the Dyfed Powys force, called for reinforcements.

A spokeswoman for the Welsh assembly said the Eppynt site was the best available.

"We took the advice of the environment agency in Wales before the decision was taken," she said.

"Disposal of carcasses at farms is not viable. Pyres take time to build. It is quicker and more effective to take the carcasses to one site to bury or burn them."

The people of the Usk valley disagree. Another sign at Trecastle reads: "Welsh assembly: you are the weakest link. Goodbye."

They add they cannot understand why animals killed on land close to infected farms are being driven 60 or more miles along a main tourist highway to what they claim is a clean area. Why not slaughter, burn and bury on the killing fields of Welshpool and beyond? They are an organised lot, with a website, an office pumping out petition forms and a small army of sandwich makers. A mile or so out of Brecon, you pick up their first sign warning that you are about to enter Death Valley. "May sheep safely graze," reads another further along the A40. A third pleads: "Pray for us". There is nothing like this near the Great Orton burial site in Cumbria. Outside the community centre in Trecastle protesters maintain a picket line and throw their daffodils under the trucks that have brought in the 849 cattle that have been burned and the 6147 sheep that have been buried so far. "It can only be a matter of time before they bring foot and mouth to this area," said Katherine Jones from Sennybridge. "We are frightened and angry." There were no deliveries of carcasses yesterday: there was local uproar at the weekend after two truck drivers became lost on their way out of the army range and when at least two trucks were spotted leaking fluid, some of it blood according to the protesters, on to roads. "The last two days have been a fiasco," said Kirsty Williams, the local Liberal Democrat member of the Welsh assembly. "What the government wanted was an easy site where no planning permission was required and they could do what they liked. I was pretty shocked to hear about it first on the radio." Much of the protesters' anger is directed at Carwyn Jones, rural affairs minister in the Welsh assembly. "We have been let down," added Katherine Jones. "The national assembly is supposed to be working in the national interest of Wales. But Carwyn Jones has become a puppet of Blair's government. "They are willing for this area to be sacrificed so that a round-the-clock cull can be maintained. We have been sold down the river because this a is a rural area with a sparse population." The issue is complicated by history and memories of what is perceived as another piece of treachery by the English against the Welsh. In 1940, 50 farms were purchased and residents told to move at a moment's notice to create the 30,000 acre training range still used by artillery troops today. "When we heard of the plan to use Eppynt people here felt that those who had taken the land from their ancestors were now taking the livelihoods away from the descendants of those ancestors," said Glyn Powell, deputy president of the Farmers' Union of Wales. "They saw that another, sadder chapter was being added to a sad story." The graziers were told of the burn and bury plan on March 29. Early on there was some direct action, with women blocking the A40 at Sennybridge. They held a procession and a mock funeral and some local lads managed to stall trucks bringing pyre materials as they ground up the hill past historic Llywell church to the chosen sites. That road is now barricaded by police who maintain a strong presence. Just over a week ago, a man, who protesters insist was nothing to do with them, drove a digger down that hill and into a police van, trapping and injuring the officer inside. A man has since been arrested and charged. After that, Terrence Grange, chief constable of the Dyfed Powys force, called for reinforcements. A spokeswoman for the Welsh assembly said the Eppynt site was the best available. "We took the advice of the environment agency in Wales before the decision was taken," she said. "Disposal of carcasses at farms is not viable. Pyres take time to build. It is quicker and more effective to take the carcasses to one site to bury or burn them." The people of the Usk valley disagree. Another sign at Trecastle reads: "Welsh assembly: you are the weakest link. Goodbye." webTitle: Internet twins belong in US, judge rules

fields.headline: Internet twins belong in US, judge rules
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The American twin girls at the centre of an internet adoption row must be returned to their birthplace in St Louis, Missouri, a judge at the high court in London ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
The American twin girls at the centre of an internet adoption row must be returned to their birthplace in St Louis, Missouri, a judge at the high court in London ruled yesterday.

A baby broker was paid £8,200 by Judith and Alan Kil shaw to arrange the adoption. But the transaction was the subject of dispute and the children were removed in January by Flintshire social services.

In the high court case, the Kilshaws, from Buckley, north Wales, had hoped to regain custody of the nine-month-old sisters. They may appeal.

Mrs Kilshaw stormed repeatedly from the court where Mr Justice Kirkwood was giving his ruling in private. She had to be restrained by friends, court staff and her 18-year-old daughter Kaley as she screamed: "There is no justice. They said I lied." Wrestling with a court official she said, "You want everything, don't you, my life and my kids."

After more than five days of legal arguments and evidence from social workers, childcare experts, the babies' natural parents, and the Kilshaws, the judge had decided that the girls, known as Kimberley and Belinda, should be returned to the United States. They will be cared for by a foster family while a court in Missouri decides where they should make their permanent home. Their natural parents are estranged and are separately seeking custody of their children.

In a statement to the press, Mr Justice Kirkwood said: "The court held that it would not be in the welfare interests of the twins for them to be returned to Mr and Mrs Kilshaw. Mr and Mrs Kilshaw's application for a residence order was dismissed."

The court, he said, "rejected robustly an allegation by Mr and Mrs Kilshaw that the ac tions in the case of Flintshire county council were driven by a local or central government agenda. The county council has acted properly and in accordance with its statutory obligations throughout."

The Kilshaws refused to comment after the hearing and were driven away in a black cab waiting for them at the back of the court.

Michael Charles, their solicitor, said: "They are very disappointed with the decision. They are going to consider very carefully their legal position with regard to an appeal."

The proceedings had been "a great strain for Mr and Mrs Kilshaw who want only what is best for these children".

Karen Reilly, the head of children's services at Flintshire county council, clearly felt the ruling vindicated her department's actions: "[It] confirms our view that the intervention of the court was necessary to secure and promote the safety and welfare of these two children," she said.

"Their welfare has always been our highest priority and it will remain so whilst arrangements are made for their safe return to their native country."
