webTitle: Nine months old and heading for fifth home

fields.headline: Nine months old and heading for fifth home
fields.standfirst:
Adoption row Judge rules baby girls should return to their homeland where natural parents are battling for custody

Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The twin baby girls adopted by Judith and Alan Kilshaw last night faced the prospect of a fifth home in just nine months of life, following the high court ruling that they should be returned to America.
fields.body:
The twin baby girls adopted by Judith and Alan Kilshaw last night faced the prospect of a fifth home in just nine months of life, following the high court ruling that they should be returned to America.

Whether or not the Kilshaws appeal against the decision, the turmoil that Kimberley and Belinda have experienced throughout their brief lives is unlikely to end just yet.

They will be taken from their home with foster parents in north Wales and placed with carers in America while a court in Missouri makes a final decision on who should be granted custody.

Their estranged natural parents, Tranda and Aaron Wecker, are separately seeking residence rights.

It is the latest twist in a remarkable saga that only became public because the Kilshaws approached The Sun newspaper to describe the difficulties they had adopting the girls, who were born in St Louis in July last year.

The Weckers had just split up and their mother was eager to have the twins adopted. She approached internet baby broker Tina Johnson, who placed the girls with a Californian couple, Richard and Vickie Allen, for a fee.

But two months later the Kilshaws offered her £8,200 - double the original fee - and she arranged to give the babies to them instead.

With the help of Ms Wecker she took the girls from the unwitting Allens and handed them over to the Kilshaws, who drove across the US so that they could carry out a speedy adoption in Arkansas, which has laxer adoption laws. A court in Little Rock subsequently annulled the arrangement.

News of the deal caused outrage in Britain and two days after the story broke in the Sun, in January this year, Flintshire social services served an emergency protection order on the Kilshaws. The authority put the two girls into the care of foster parents and applied to the family division of the high court to make the twins wards of court.

It is not yet know when the sisters will return to the US, although it is likely to take weeks as carers attempt to minimise the further disruption to their lives. The legal wrangles there could last much longer.

The Allens have withdrawn from the custody battle following claims - denied by the couple - that Mr Allen had molested two teenage babysitters. But the twins' natural parents are still fighting each other for custody.

Mr Wecker's counsel, Jeremy Rosenblatt, said yesterday: "He is thrilled and delighted with the decision of the English court. He will fight for the residence of his girls."

In his statement yesterday, Mr Justice Kirkwood commented: "The arrangements for the move of the twins are, and will remain, confidential. They will be carefully planned so as to avoid, so far as possible, any further distress."

But attempts to calm the furore have not been entirely successful.

Despite promising that they would stop commenting on the case, the Kilshaws continued to talk to the media and protest that the children should never have been removed from them.

At one point, court security staff had to search all those at tending the private hearing for recording equipment.

Yesterday Mrs Kilshaw repeatedly stormed out of court to scream at waiting reporters. She was restrained by friends, court staff and her eldest daughter Kaley as she yelled: "There is no justice. They said I lied." She added: "You want everything don't you? My life and my kids."

The Kilshaws were silent when the hearing ended, refusing to comment as they left the court by a back door usually reserved for judges.

The public relations agent Max Clifford is acting as their unpaid media adviser.

fields.headline: Milosevic wife and daughter expelled
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The wife and daughter of the arrested former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic have been run out of the family's home town by opposition activists.
fields.body:
The wife and daughter of the arrested former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic have been run out of the family's home town by former opposition activists, one of them said yesterday.

"We have expelled Mirjana Markovic and her daughter Marija from Pozarevac because the entire family is unwelcome in our town," said Momcilo Veljkovic, a member of the student-based Otpor movement in the eastern Serbian community.

Ms Milosevic, under criminal investigation for firing shots with a pistol as her father was being driven away from his Belgrade villa to prison on April 1, arrived at the family's mansion in Pozarevac on Thursday in a black BMW escorted by other vehicles.

After Mrs Markovic's arrival on Friday, Mr Veljkovic told the mansion's security guards Otpor would hold protests there if she did not leave. The two women left the town half an hour later, witnesses said.

Their subsequent whereabouts were unclear but they were believed to be back in Belgrade where Mr Milosevic is in jail under investigation by Serbian justice authorities for alleged corruption and abuse of office.

Before the two women left Pozarevac on Friday, reporters saw plainclothes police guarding the mansion, while uniformed colleagues barred all approaches.

Belgrade's governing reform coalition, DOS, promised during negotiations over the surrender of the former president that it would guarantee the safety of his family and property.

fields.headline: Koreans angry at Japan's approval of book sanitising war atrocities
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: South Korea recalled its ambassador to Tokyo yesterday as a growing row over a Japanese history textbook threatened to undo three years of patient bridge-building by the two historic rivals.
fields.body:
South Korea recalled its ambassador to Tokyo yesterday as a growing row over a Japanese history textbook threatened to undo three years of patient bridge-building by the two historic rivals.

The protest followed the Japanese education ministry's approval of a new book criticised by China and both North and South Korea for its sanitisation of the imperial army's wartime atrocities.

Produced by rightwing scholars, the book omits any mention of "comfort women", the euphemism for the hundreds of thousands of Asians forced into sexual slavery in Japanese army brothels. It also casts doubts on the slaughter by Japanese troops of hundreds of thousands of Chinese civilians in the 1937 Nanking massacre.

Since Kim Dae-jung became South Korean president in 1998, Seoul has tried to move towards reconciliation with Tokyo despite public resentment towards Japan dating from its harsh colonial rule over the peninsula from 1910 to 1945.

Next year the two countries will jointly host the football World Cup finals. Yesterday, however, demonstrators in Seoul and Pusan burnt effigies of Japanese leaders and demanded South Korea pull out of hosting the competition.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Ministers opt to take breaks in the UK -  park authorities point out that there were 30 miles of trail open in the Peak Park, and 29 suggested walks.
fields.body:
In a piece headed Ministers opt to take breaks in the UK, page 9, April 7, we may have appeared to suggest that the whole Peak Park was closed when we said that David Blunkett would not be able to visit the area because it had had its first suspected case of foot and mouth disease. The park authorities point out that there were 30 miles of trail open in the Peak that day, and 29 suggested walks. See the Peak District National Park website.

A news report on the teachers' Easter conferences, page 6, yesterday, referred to a motion calling for industrial action which, it said, was expected to be endorsed by the Association of University Teachers. In fact, the motion was being considered by the Association of Teachers and Lecturers on the first day of their conference in Torquay, as mentioned earlier in the report.

In an article about Perry Wacker headed Search for new life ended in cauldron of death, page 4, April 6, we said in error that a solicitor, Chandika Wolpita, worked with a company Ratna & Co of Walworth Road, London. Mr Wolpita has never worked with Ratna & Co, whose premises are in East Ham, London. Apologies.

In our report of the Barcelona- Liverpool goalless draw, page 32, April 6, we recalled Liverpool's victory 25 years ago when, we said, they became "the only British side to plunder Barcelona". Perhaps we should have made it clear that they ceased to be that when Dundee United beat Barcelona 2-1 in their Uefa Cup quarter-final second leg at the Nou Camp in 1987, on their way to a place in that year's final.

In a report headed Hick facing the final curtain, page 30, March 28, we said that of the 130 players who had made more than 3,000 Test runs, Graeme Hick's average of 31.32 "betters" those of only two other front-line batsmen, Bec Congdon and Graeme Wood. We meant to say "is bettered by".

In an obituary of John Ardoin, the music critic, page 20, yesterday, we said the most important of his four books on Maria Callas, The Callas Legacy, "analysed all her recordings in scrumptious detail". We meant to say "scrupulous detail".

fields.body:
The government launched its latest anti-drug strategy at a rugby league ground in a rundown part of Manchester yesterday.

The £5m expansion of the Positive Futures initiative unveiled at the Salford Reds ground is aimed at steering vulnerable young people away from drugs and crime and into sports clubs. Sports stars will be involved in offering training, support and mentoring to the youngsters.

The scheme began 15 months ago in 24 areas including Manchester. The extra £5m will see it expand to another 80 areas.

Sir Alex Ferguson, manager of Manchester United, said it was important for whole communities to get involved in the fight against drugs. He was joined at the launch by sports stars including United player Andy Cole. An electronic billboard reinforced the message with: "Sport 1, Drugs 0."

Sir Alex said everyone was vulnerable to the temptations of drugs, including sports stars. "The only way around this is by raising awareness so that the temptations no longer exist."

Cole said he hoped that young people would look up to sports stars as role models. "Kids cannot get involved in sports unless they stay away from drugs.

"Anything to do with kids is close to my heart, because at the end of the day kids are our future. They need a lot of willpower to stay away from drugs."

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, said there was no big ger social problem than drugs, and it was important to mobilise the whole community against it. The scheme was not just fighting drugs but fighting the causes of drugs.

"It involves teachers, parents, schools and local authorities coming together to give the message to dealers that they are no longer welcome," he said.

Teenagers and younger children needed to see "people they look up to warning them off drugs".

Ian McCartney, the Cabinet Office minister whose son Hugh, 23, died from a heroin overdose, said young people were disengaging from normal school life with no self-esteem or self-respect and drifting into crime by hanging around the streets. Sport provided a way of getting them back.

The issue explained: drugs in sport

fields.headline: Orange tells of the 'lost' 750,000
fields.trailText: Orange, the mobile phone network, yesterday said 750,000 of its pre-pay customers had neither made or received a call in the past three months.
fields.body:
Orange, the mobile phone network, yesterday said 750,000 of its pre-pay customers had neither made or received a call in the past three months.

The figure, which represents some 6.4% of the Orange customer base, was the first time the company has publicly defined its "inactive" users.

The statement follows a similar announcement from Vodafone, which recently admitted that 9% of its customers should be classified as "inactive" and suggested that the industry has been overestimating the number of handsets actually in use.

The lower revenues from the pre-pay customer bases have been behind a shift in focus in all four networks from increasing market share to improving revenues per user.

In a trend begun by One2One, each of the companies has cut the handset subsidies paid to distributors, lifting the prices of their cheapest handsets and cutting the cost of acquiring customers.

Unlike Vodafone and One2One, Orange claimed never to have separately counted its inactive user base in its quarterly statement of customer numbers.

The company yesterday said it had added 1.2m net new customers in the first three months of the year, taking its total active base to 11m.

The figures from Orange again closed the gap between itself and the two largest British networks - Vodafone, which now has 12.3m customers in this country, and BT Cellnet, which has 11.2m.

One2One has just under 9m customers - which means that there are more than 44m handsets at present in circulation in Britain.

Orange also launched a low user tariff designed to encourage more customers on to monthly contracts which give the company a more predictable revenue stream.

Orange Everytime will cost £12.99 a month with 20 minutes of calls bundled in. Other calls, except for international, premium or other mobile networks, will be at a flat rate of 10p a minute.

"As markets develop we will be reinforcing our efforts to encourage loyalty and usage among customers," said Jean François Pontal, Orange chief executive.

The international Orange customer base reached 33.1m, up by around 50% over the same point last year.

The business, which is majority owned by France Télécom, also added 780,000 customers in France and another 660,000 users in its other markets during the quarter.

In France, where the chief brand is Itineris, the company now has 15.1m users and a market share of 48%.

Orange's shares climbed back above their float price last week and yesterday added another 9p to close at 661p.

fields.headline: EIB to finance 3G phone networks
fields.trailText: The European Investment Bank has confirmed that it is in talks with telecommunications companies over financing for third generation (3G) mobile phone networks.
fields.body:
The European Investment Bank has confirmed that it is in talks with telecommunications companies over financing for third generation (3G) mobile phone networks.

The bank is considering projects in Britain, Italy and Germany, said a spokesman.

"We are in contact with telecom operators. We have a list of projects that are in the pre-appraisal phase. It is likely that in the course of the year the EIB will be financing 3G projects," said the spokesman.

The EIB, the European Union's in-house bank, has already lent €11bn (£6.9m) to the telecoms industry, including €4.5bn to the mobile telephone sector, over the past five years. It is also understood that the Luxembourg-based bank has had talks with the European commission - which is keen to ensure 3G services are introduced as quickly as possible - about the provision of long-term loans to telecoms companies.

Loans to the telecoms sector would be in line with the EIB's mandate to help promote a knowledge-based economy in Europe. However, the bank would want to ensure that any lending went to financially viable projects. It is keen to avoid any suggestion of its resources being used to bail out a sector under heavy pressure from the cost of acquiring 3G mobile phone licences and building the networks. Roll-out costs in western Europe are estimated at €75bn.

Confirmation of the EIB's likely involvement in the introduction of 3G networks comes alongside news that France is pushing back the date for its second auction of 3G licences until after the presidential and parliamentary election in May next year.

France's initial auction saw only two bidders - France Télécom subsidiary Orange and SFR Cégétel - line up for the sale of four licences as a number of potential buyers declined to bid, with at least one complaining about the price the government was asking.

The second round was scheduled for the end of this year but appears to have been put back. "This is a sensitive issue in France and you could see that the presidential and general elections could contribute to the slowdown of certain decisions," said a government spokesman.

webTitle: Marlborough Stirling's decision to brave the market pays off

fields.headline: Marlborough Stirling's decision to brave the market pays off
fields.trailText: The fragile software and internet services sector yesterday saw its first flotation of the year when Marlborough Stirling braved the stock market.
fields.body:
The fragile software and internet services sector yesterday saw its first flotation of the year when Marlborough Stirling braved the stock market.

In the face of difficult market conditions, the Cheltenham-based software company listed on the London Stock Exchange at a discounted price of 140p per share, valuing it at just under £250m.

The initial public offering for Marlborough, which provides software and services to mortgage, life, pension and investment firms, was originally priced between 170p and 220p.

David Gales, the finance director, said Marlborough pressed ahead with the flotation because it was the "right time" for the company and it was not clear when market conditions would improve.

"We decided that being a listed company on the London main stock exchange would help our expansion into Europe," Mr Gales said.

Peter Whiting, a software analyst at house broker UBS Warburg, said: "There are reasons why companies float. They are not all driven by market conditions. Marlborough Stirling is growing quite rapidly and needs to be a quoted company to help it increase its business."

The group, which employs 860 people and whose customers include the Bank of Scotland and Prudential, will also use the £16m from its placing of 47m shares - about a quarter of the company - to develop products and for possible acquisitions.

Other investors made about £50m from selling their shares. Investment company 3i sold around 30% of its holding, leaving it with an 11% stake.

"The markets have been quite difficult but we are pleased with the IPO and the investors we have got, who are mainly London blue chips," Mr Gales said.

Marlborough's shares, which began trading at 144.5p, outperformed the technology sector, rising 12.5p from the placing price of 140p to close at 152.5p.

UBS Warburg is the sponsoring broker and adviser on the offering.

fields.headline: Britax may go for cash
fields.trailText: Is the wait over? According to the gossips, Britax, the engineering concern, is weeks away from accepting an offer that will value it at £420m, or 140p a share.
fields.body:
Is the wait over? According to the gossips, Britax, the engineering concern, is weeks away from accepting an offer that will value it at £420m, or 140p a share.

Britax, which makes children's car seats and aircraft interiors, revealed in January it had begun talks with potential buyers after a review by its chief executive, Bernard Brogan. But since then, nothing - prompting fears that the talks had hit the buffers because of Britax's exposure to the slowing American economy.

Sector watchers reckon the putative buyer is a venture capital firm attracted to Britax's strong cashflow - which could be used to support debt - and the possibility of a break-up. Any of Britax's three divisions could be sold to a trade buyer. US company GE Aerospace is likely to be interested in Britax's aerospace division should it come up for sale.

Britax shares ended 2p higher at 120.5p.

fields.headline: At this price?  Euro Sales
fields.trailText: The future is not looking particularly lucrative for Euro Sales Finance, the financial solutions company.
fields.body:
The future is not looking particularly lucrative for Euro Sales Finance, the financial solutions company.

The London-based group issued a profit warning yesterday which drove the shares down by 742.5p to close at 352.5p.

In the trading statement, Euro Sales said profits for the current financial year "would be materially below market expectations due to a lack of funding required to drive expected expansion".

Does this vague explanation tell investors why the company yesterday lost threequarters of its market value? Probably.

According to the statement the company had to restrict new client advances, which led to a delay in revenues.

"While ESF has the opportunity to expand its receivables book significantly, particularly in its growth markets in France and Germany, it has not been able to fund this expansion as expected," it said.

The lack of funding could be due to investor fears of a slowdown. But there are also rumours they are backing off because of the quality of Euro Sales' loan book.

Another possibility for withholding funding could be the concern surrounding the rapid rate of growth of the company and a need to focus on quality before expansion continues.

Whatever the reason, the company appears to be in real difficulty.

Euro Sales' core business is providing finance for small and medium-sized companies that do not have sufficient working capital, and a slight downturn could be beneficial.

But at the moment it cannot expand as fast as it would like and has had to admit profits are likely to suffer.

The company is in a volatile sector, and although a slight slowdown could boost its business, anything more severe might not be quite so advantageous.

Hold, therefore, until there is further clarification about why an investor has decided not to increase the amount it is prepared to lend to the company.

fields.headline: Marconi signals downturn
fields.standfirst: Unions fear large-scale redundancies
fields.trailText: Unions fear large-scale redundancies from Marconi
fields.body:
Marconi yesterday faced further pressure on its share price and anger from trade unions following speculation that it was poised to make large-scale redundancies in Britain and elsewhere.

The City has interpreted the leaks about possible job losses as a signal of a forthcoming profit warning - perhaps as early as this morning. The telecoms group is active in Europe but heavily exposed to a slowdown in the US economy.

The shares lost 9% of value in early trading but recovered to close at 310p, down 15p. Investors have repeatedly called on Marconi chief executive Lord Simpson to give a trading statement, having seen profit-warnings from US companies exposed to the telecoms sector such as Cisco and Lucent.

MSF, the lead union at Marconi, said it was appalled by leaks and rumours from the company before there had been any consultation.

Roger Lyons, MSF general secretary, said Marconi remained a profitable company with a highly skilled workforce. "They should not be sacrificing their skill base for short-term share price gain," he said.

A union source said members working at Marconi were likely to consider industrial action if there were substantial cutbacks. He said feelings were already running high because Marconi had outsourced many of its functions to increase earnings. The white collar MSF fears further cutbacks in Marconi's research and development arm.

The union was scheduled to meet Marconi last night and was steeled for the worst, with 1,300 redundancies from its 20,000 workforce anticipated at its main Coventry and Liverpool plants. Worldwide the company is expected to axe 3,000 jobs.

Marconi remained silent ahead of the discussions.

webTitle: Market forces: WPP caught in ads squeeze

fields.headline: WPP caught in ads squeeze
fields.trailText: The first thing to be cut from company budgets in a downturn is marketing spend, it is often said. On this consideration, short sellers yesterday attacked blue chip advertising group WPP .
fields.body:
The first thing to be cut from company budgets in a downturn is marketing spend, it is often said. On this consideration, short sellers yesterday attacked blue chip advertising group WPP .

Up 13p at best, WPP shares came off the boil in the last hour of trading to close 4.5p lower at 689.5p, as rumours of poor first quarter trading spread through City dealing rooms.

According to the gossip, a number of WPP's big American clients have pulled the plug on expensive advertising campaigns in the last four weeks as evidence of a US recession has mounted.

Traders pointed out that WPP, which makes half of its profits in the US, is already budgeting for zero growth in global advertising revenue this year and will not publish first quarter figures until mid-May.

Nevertheless, the fact the market has got a bee in its bonnet about WPP's exposure to the slowing US economy is ominous news.

If WPP does not move to reassure investors about current trading soon, say traders, it could find itself in the same pickle as Marconi , off 15p to 310p yesterday. In recent weeks, the City has pulverised the company's shares for its failure to disclose the impact of the US slowdown on its business.

In the meantime, leading shares drifted higher in thin volume, finding support from a strong performance on Wall Street after online book seller Amazon said its first quarter figures would beat expectations.

With Shell , up 19.5p to 561.5p, and BP , 18.5p higher at 598.5p, leading the way, the FTSE 100 came to rest 61.8 points higher at 5,663.3.

No one was prepared to read much into the gains, with most of the London brokerages operating at half strength in the run-up to Easter and with a number of tricky hurdles to be negotiated this week. Dealers are wary of today's figures from Motorola and Thursday's US retail sales data.

The tech sector remained under pressure from Friday's profits warning from Autonomy , down a further 25p to 300p. The FTSE Techmark 100 dropped 31.03 points to 1,749.08 with Anglo-Dutch software group CMG marked down 30.5p at 400p after a strange research note from Merrill Lynch.

Though Merrill did not change its profits forecasts, the note outlined potential "worst case" scenarios for the company, apparently to give its clients an idea of just how bad things could be.

Elsewhere, fears that the slowdown in IT spending has reached Europe continued to dog Logica , down 32p to 770p, and Misys , off 15p to 400p.

Telecoms testing firm Spirent , 30p lower at 305p, was still suffering from last week's profits warning from rival Agilent.

A strong performance from media display group Photobition , up 2.25p to 37.75p on the back of wild talk of a management buyout, was not enough to stop the FTSE mid 250 from closing lower. Dragged down by a poor showing by tech stocks it closed off 8.3 points at 6,043.3.

But sugar producer Tate & Lyle , which has warned on profits four times in the past year, was on the way up following a recommendation from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

In a note to clients, Schroder said a meeting with Tate had provided further indications of a strong recovery in the year ahead.

Apparently, Tate has been able to extract double-digit price increases for its products from soft drinks makers and Schroder is predicting a 39% uplift in earnings this year. Tate shares closed 3.75p higher at 222.75p.

Lower down the market, Nord Anglia Education , which provides back office administration for schools, rose 6.5p to 196.5p on talk of a big contract award from a London borough.

The cosmetics-with-a-conscience chain, Body Shop, advanced 2p to 80p as rumours of a bid from rival Lush were dusted down and given a fresh airing.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Huntingdon bank besieged
fields.body:
Huntingdon bank besieged

Animal rights activists yesterday occupied the London branch of Bank of New York for the second time in two weeks, in protest at its involvement with drug testing firm Huntingdon Life Sciences.

A group of about 10 protesters barricaded themselves inside the bank's offices on the 49th floor of Canary Wharf. Bank of New York administers American depository receipts, allowing US investors to buy shares in Huntingdon. Two other US banks, Citibank and Chase Manhattan, have withdrawn support from Huntingdon investors.

Police described the incident as a "peaceful, if abusive protest". Bank of New York refused to comment.

webTitle: Protests force Sainsbury out of Egypt with £125m loss

fields.headline: Protests force Sainsbury out of Egypt with £125m loss
fields.trailText: Sainsbury is to abandon its loss-making Egyptian interests at a cost of up to £125m after an organised boycott of its stores by Arab and Muslim groups who claimed the firm had ties with Israel.
fields.body:
Sainsbury is to abandon its loss-making Egyptian interests at a cost of up to £125m after an organised boycott of its stores by Arab and Muslim groups who claimed the firm had ties with Israel.

Chief executive Peter Davis said yesterday several Edge stores - in which Sainsbury holds a 80.1% stake - had been subject to violent attacks over the last three months. As a result, sales were "significantly down", a number of stores had been forced to close and the UK-based supermarket chain had been under mounting pressure to withdraw from the region.

"I would not have described us as having Israeli connections," Mr Davis said. "But a few trouble-makers in the region said all the profits from our stores were going straight to Israel - despite the fact the stores were not even profitable." The Sainsbury family's links with Israel are still hotly disputed and some local traders have reportedly played on the alleged ties to force the low-price Edge chain out of business.

Over the weekend, Sainsbury agreed the sale of its stake in Edge - acquired for £50m in 1999 - to minority stakeholder, El Hasharty Group, for an undisclosed sum. Yesterday, the retailer said it would take a one-off hit of between £100m and £125m. Sainsbury's Egyptian operations had generated £40.5m in sales over the 28 weeks to October, and operating losses of £10.2m.

Mr Davis would not be drawn on the question of job losses at Edge, but Egyptian businessmen have reportedly said thousands of redundancies would be inevitable were Sainsbury to pull out. There are about 100 Edge stores in Egypt, employing about 4,000 workers.

Sainsbury has been one of several multinational companies appearing on a list of businesses to be boycotted across the Middle East. Other firms to have had their sales hit by claims of having Israeli links include Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble.

"There are lessons to be learned from our experiences in Egypt," Mr Davis said. "We tried to do too much, too soon."

Sainsbury yesterday said its overall like-for-like sales - excluding revenue from petrol - had risen by 4.8%, slightly exceeding analysts' expectations.

Shares were up 9.75p, closing at £4.

webTitle: Schroders found guilty of sexual discrimination

fields.headline: Schroders found guilty of sexual discrimination
fields.trailText: Schroders, the investment bank now part of Citigroup of the US, has been found guilty at an employment tribunal of sexual discrimination against a female equities analyst.
fields.body:
Schroders, the investment bank now part of Citigroup of the US, has been found guilty at an employment tribunal of sexual discrimination against a female equities analyst.

The £120,000-a-year analyst, Julie Bower, was paid less than her male colleagues and received a lower bonus - that was "picked from the air" - than the men she worked with, the tribunal found.

Ms Bower won her claim of unfair dismissal and two claims of sexual discrimination in relation to both her dismissal and a £25,000 bonus, but the tribunal failed to back her equal pay claim for a £1.5m bonus, as well as two further claims of sexual discrimination.

The equal opportunities commission said the tribunal had agreed with Ms Bower that her bonus for 1998 - originally £25,000 and later increased to £50,000 - was not the going rate for an analyst and did not reflect a genuine evaluation of her performance. This would not have happened if she had not been a woman, the tribunal found.

In a case that lifted the lid on the secrecy surrounding levels of pay in the City, the awards given to some of her colleagues were revealed to the tribunal. According to the Press Association, Kieran Mahon was given £650,000 the same year - 26 times as much as Ms Bower - while Andy Smith was given £440,000.

The level of compensation to be paid to Ms Bower is yet to be set, and it is understood that Citigroup, which now owns Schroders, is deciding whether to appeal.

A spokesman for the bank which now owns the operation in which Ms Bowers worked said: "The judgement is about Schroder Securities in 1999. We've moved on since then. Schroder is now part of Salomon Smith Barney, which is owned by Citigroup, which has developed a robust set of human relations policies over many years".

The equal opportunities commission said: "The tribunal found that Schroders had no transparency in their pay system and that employees were forbidden to discuss pay and bonuses. Such a culture makes it all too easy for discrimination to occur."

Ms Bower, who is understood to have been fighting ovarian cancer at the time, said: "The way in which Schroders dealt with my complaints about the way I was being treated was completely unacceptable, and I hope that nobody ever has to go through the same sort of thing again."

fields.headline: Skills famine boosts Bupa
fields.trailText: A culture of increasingly generous private healthcare packages for staff at banks and hi-tech companies helped Bupa achieve a 40% jump in annual profits to £65.4m.
fields.body:
A culture of increasingly generous private healthcare packages for staff at banks and hi-tech companies helped Bupa achieve a 40% jump in annual profits to £65.4m.

The private healthcare mutual's earnings surged despite an £11m hit on its aborted purchase of Community Hospitals Group, which was blocked by competition regulators.

Chief executive Val Gooding said: "In certain sectors of the corporate market there is a lot of competition for employees. Having really good healthcare packages is an important part of attracting the best people."

Bupa's UK insurance operations moved from a loss of £39.6m to a surplus of £14.6m. The group said it had seen a particularly large boost in demand for corporate policies from telecoms, financial services and hi-tech companies.

Some firms have shed the "excess" employees are expected to pay on small claims. Others have widened employees' insurance to cover areas such as dentistry and eyecare.

Bupa's £230m bid for the 21-strong Community Hospitals chain was thwarted by trade secretary Stephen Byers in December, on the grounds that it would give the organisation a 40% share of the private hospitals market.

The decision eroded Community Hospitals' share price, causing a slump in the value of Bupa's 27% stake. Bupa has made an £11m provision on the loss of value, although the shares have since recovered, narrowing the potential loss to around £5m.

Ms Gooding said Bupa still wanted to expand its network of 36 hospitals: "We can't buy another large group in the UK but . . . we can expand our existing facilities or look overseas."

Bupa's ownership of hospitals and insurance has caused controversy. Critics claim the organisation could channel patients to its own facilities at the expense of independent hospital operators. Bupa insists the two sides of its business are run separately.

Bupa's profits from hospitals and care homes fell slightly to £61.1m, depressed by the cost of the minimum wage and the working time directive.

fields.headline: Discreet art of the buyback
fields.trailText: Trevor Hemmings has become Blackpool's most powerful businessman over the last three years but remains discreet to the point of near-invisibility.
fields.body:
Trevor Hemmings has become Blackpool's most powerful businessman over the last three years but remains discreet to the point of near-invisibility.

The 65-year-old multimillionaire's interests in the resort could hardly be more prominent, however - among them are the Tower, the piers, the Winter Gardens, the Opera House, Louis Tussauds and a 50% share of Sea World.

Mr Hemmings moved to Lancashire from London as a child, trained as a master builder and made his first fortune working for Pontins holiday camps. He eventually bought the camps from Mr Pontin after serving several years as a director, but subsequently sold them to Scottish & Newcastle for shares. The stock soared, netting him £135m, and last year he quietly bought Pontins back from S&N for a fraction of that.

Mr Hemmings' fortune is estimated at around £450m. He employs 7,000 people at his hotels, 3,500 at pubs, the Vymura wallpaper firm and in horseracing. His most important publicly listed interests are a 50% holding in racecourse group Arena Leisure, a 30% stake in Littlewoods Pools owner Sportech and stakes in TV firm Entertainment Rights and gaming group London Clubs International.

Friends say his dislike of publicity is not mysterious. "It's just his style," said one. "He's accessible to the people that matter to him, down to earth, not at all flashy and is very approachable." He is also incredibly driven. "He's a real 7am to 10pm man, and thinks nothing of working through the night on a deal," says the friend. His businesses are run from Lancashire, but he is a Channel Islands resident and spends much of his time at his racing stud, Mony-musk, in Kanturk, County Cork.

Related article
Blackpool's towering gamble

webTitle: Business: Easy to get lost in the Amazon jungle

fields.headline: Easy to get lost in the Amazon jungle
fields.standfirst: Notebook E-tail books need close scrutiny
fields.trailText: New-economy wonder stock Amazon.com yesterday turned in its best ever one-day performance, up almost 40% after Jeff Bezos, chief executive of the company that "offers Earth's Biggest Selection", reported sales up a fifth over the past year and first-quarter losses of just $50m.
fields.body:
New-economy wonder stock Amazon.com yesterday turned in its best ever one-day performance, up almost 40% after Jeff Bezos, chief executive of the company that "offers Earth's Biggest Selection", reported sales up a fifth over the past year and first-quarter losses of just $50m.

Well that is how yesterday's statement from the debt-laden online bookstore, which has canned its expansion plans and is now struggling to reach profitability before its cash pile runs out, might have been reported a year ago.

The shares did jump, from $8.37 to almost $12 at one stage, against an all-time high of $106. Sales in the first quarter were $695m, against $574m a year earlier, but back then analysts were forecasting a surge towards $2bn by now. Quarterly losses have shrunk from $99m to $50m, but only on a "pro forma operational basis" which handily ignores everything from interest payments on accumulated debts of $2.3bn to restructuring charges associated with firing 15% of the workforce.

Once incidentals, such as the cost of paying staff in stock options, are taken into account, annualised losses are running at close to $4 a share. If the share price does go up, there are holders of 70m options at an average exercise price of $32 waiting to take advantage.

In truth, the market is as unsure now about valuing a company like Amazon as it ever was during the dot.com bubble. Exuberant or otherwise, the daily response to news is irrational. Investors should avoid being sucked into such a volatile environment.

Powerless locals

British consumers pay among the lowest charges for gas and electricity in Europe - up to 90% less for gas than in Italy. But the downside of market liberalisation and tough regulation can be seen in yesterday's takeover of Powergen, a well managed, customer-friendly company, by Germany's E.ON. Ed Wallis, Powergen's boss since denationalisation, may have had global ambitions via Kentucky, but he simply lacked the financial firepower of the Düsseldorfers.

E.ON is one of five super-utility groups identified by PricewaterhouseCoopers as current European market leaders. With the exception of Sweden's Vattenfall, which operates in a relatively open market, they all enjoy a highly protective, illiberal regime, one that was meant to be forced open by the recent EU summit in Stockholm but retained thanks to a last-minute horse trade between France and Germany.

If E.ON and RWE, owner of Thames Water, can use their fortified home base and muscle to capture British utilities and customers, that is even more true of EdF, the state-owned French group that already owns London Electricity and Sweb and is poised to get Seeboard. It has lost perhaps 10% of its generating market in France but none of its domestic supply base because Paris refuses to implement EU directives. For another four years at least.

Italy and Spain are gradually opening their markets but France and Germany, free to buy their way in here, are not. British regulation means there are no national champions to take on E.ON and EdF. Time for a rethink, Mr Byers.

Panther escape

The pressure is clearly showing on Andrew Perloff, the formerly robust boss of a little property company called Panther Securities.

He should have been relaxed yesterday, reporting another steady increase in profitabilityfrom £2m to £2.4m at the pre-tax level on turnover of £6.5m. Plans are afoot to redevelop a Gray's Inn Road site in London as a business centre, while in Bristol hopes are high that a food superstore will get the green light from a planning inquiry. Recently, Panther picked up a freehold shop in Stockport, for £475,000, producing rental income of £65,000. All, straightforward property stuff of the sort that Mr Perloff has been doing for 36 years.

Yet about a third of Panther's year-end trading statement amounts to a rant against the stupidity of having to pay taxes, followed by an explosion about red tape strangling his business.

Mr Perloff's main gripe seems to be that because he owns 24% of the equity he misses out on the new 10% long-term capital gains tax rate, which has an equity ceiling of 10%, while the inland revenue also treats Panther as an investment company for tax purposes, even though Mr Perloff has to rush around between 60 blocks of property, dealing with 450 tenants and all sorts of builders and architects.

He makes many points, and some of them may be fair. But the overall impression is that Mr Perloff wants to retire, senses the downturn has arrived and wants to take as much money out as he can.

So what are we bid for Panther Securities?

webTitle: Big bonus on way for Billiton directors

fields.headline: Big bonus on way for Billiton directors
fields.standfirst: Mining group faces shareholder anger over plan to reward boardroom after £20bn merger
fields.trailText: Mining group faces shareholder anger over plan to reward boardroom after £20bn merger
fields.body:
The mining group Billiton will reveal plans next week to pay its top directors hefty bonuses following its merger with BHP of Australia.

The bonuses will be paid through a controversial plan which may prove unpopular with shareholders.

According to significant investors who have received visits from Billiton's senior management to discuss the terms of the £20bn merger with BHP, the company is in the throes of devising a way to allow the outstanding incentive plans to be paid out, regardless of ongoing performance, once the deal is completed.

Among those to receive the potential payouts, the precise terms of which will be revealed to shareholders next week, is Brian Gilbertson, who has already caused controversy among shareholders by holding the positions of chairman and chief executive.

The attempt to give executives the opportunity to cash in their performance plans early was described by one shareholder as " another example of getting a 'bonus' for doing a deal".

It follows the controversy surrounding £2.5m for executives at Royal Bank of Scotland following the takeover of NatWest last year and the row over £10m bonus paid to Chris Gent, Vodafone chief executive, for taking over Germany's Mannesmann.

The National Association of Pension Funds is recommending that investors vote against two members of the Royal Bank's remuneration committee at its annual meeting tomorrow.

Shareholders said yesterday that Billiton, which announced its merger with BHP last month, had put a number of suggestion before them concerning Mr Gilbertson, who has rights over almost 1m shares awarded in September 1999. The company's shares were trading at 265p when the option was awarded and ended yesterday at 318p.

Under the current terms of the options award, Mr Gilbertson and his fellow executive directors will be able to claim the shares subject to a number of performance criteria over three years.

Another shareholder said: "The company appears to want the discretion to effectively allow them to get the shares even when there is just a change of control [ownership]."

The discussions, which are thought to have resulted in Billiton making some concessions over its original plan, are understood to have been led by John Jackson, the senior non-executive director of Billiton and chairman of the remuneration committee.

The merger to form BHP Billiton has been structured in such a way that primary stock market listings can be maintained in London and Sydney. This allows BHP Billiton to remain quoted on the FTSE 100. Both companies have said there will no change of ownership once the deal is completed.

Billiton refused to comment on the remuneration plans yesterday.

The attempt to give executives the opportunity to cash in their performance plans early was described by one shareholder as " another example of getting a 'bonus' for doing a deal". It follows the controversy surrounding £2.5m for executives at Royal Bank of Scotland following the takeover of NatWest last year and the row over £10m bonus paid to Chris Gent, Vodafone chief executive, for taking over Germany's Mannesmann. The National Association of Pension Funds is recommending that investors vote against two members of the Royal Bank's remuneration committee at its annual meeting tomorrow. Shareholders said yesterday that Billiton, which announced its merger with BHP last month, had put a number of suggestion before them concerning Mr Gilbertson, who has rights over almost 1m shares awarded in September 1999. The company's shares were trading at 265p when the option was awarded and ended yesterday at 318p. Under the current terms of the options award, Mr Gilbertson and his fellow executive directors will be able to claim the shares subject to a number of performance criteria over three years. Another shareholder said: "The company appears to want the discretion to effectively allow them to get the shares even when there is just a change of control [ownership]." The discussions, which are thought to have resulted in Billiton making some concessions over its original plan, are understood to have been led by John Jackson, the senior non-executive director of Billiton and chairman of the remuneration committee. The merger to form BHP Billiton has been structured in such a way that primary stock market listings can be maintained in London and Sydney. This allows BHP Billiton to remain quoted on the FTSE 100. Both companies have said there will no change of ownership once the deal is completed. Billiton refused to comment on the remuneration plans yesterday.

webTitle: Powergen chairman stands to make £3m from E.ON takeover

fields.headline: Powergen chairman stands to make £3m from E.ON takeover
fields.trailText: Ed Wallis, chairman of Powergen, yesterday put himself in line for a £3m windfall after agreeing to sell his company to the Germans for what he admitted was a "disappointing" £9.6bn.
fields.body:
Ed Wallis, chairman of Powergen, yesterday put himself in line for a £3m windfall after agreeing to sell his company to the Germans for what he admitted was a "disappointing" £9.6bn.

He effectively blamed the end of independence on Britain's regulators and politicians who had left Powergen struggling for the critical mass it needed to become a global player.

Mr Wallis hoped the partnership with E.ON, the Dusseldorf-based power and water utility, would create an "Exxon of the electricity and gas sector".

The combine will be the second-largest energy service provider in the world and has ambitions to expand through acquisition in Britain and the US, according to E.ON chairman Ulrich Hartmann.

E.ON, itself a merger between Veba and Viag, has offered 765p per share, valuing Powergen shares at £5.1bn. The Germans will also take on the British company's £4.5bn of debt.

The deal will be heavily scrutinised by regulators in Europe and the US because Powergen last year bought LG&E in Kentucky. It might take a year for all hurdles to be cleared.

If it does go through, the cash deal will trigger several share options for Mr Wallis which together with his existing personal share holding would give the former power station manager more than £3m. Last year he was paid £800,000.

His finance director, Peter Dickson, will receive £1.6m and chief executive Nick Baldmore than £1m through share options.

Mr Wallis insisted the E.ON offer was good for shareholders, customers and employees alike. He had "no regrets at all" about building up the company and then selling it.

He complained that Powergen had been through 10 "pretty bloody" years as a relatively small utility surrounded by larger ones.

It had been easier for other privatised utilities such as Scottish Power and Centrica, which had a telecom arm or permission to accumulate a wider range of assets, he argued.

The 765p-a-share offer represents a 26% premium to the price in January when the group admitted it was in talks. It is 59p better than Friday's closing price.

Powergen last night closed up 13.5p at 719.5p with investors arguing that was a fair price given a formal deal was at least 12 months away.

If either side walks away from the deal there is a £50m "break" price. But few expect a rival bidder to come forward.

E.ON's move into Britain follows Electricité de France snapping up London Electricity and Sweb, and E.ON's German rival, RWE, buying Thames Water last year.

webTitle: Rival entrepreneurs join bidding for Eircom

fields.headline: Rival entrepreneurs join bidding for Eircom
fields.trailText: A bidding contest looks ready to break out for Eircom, the former state-run Irish telecoms business .
fields.body:
A bidding contest looks ready to break out for Eircom, the former state-run Irish telecoms business .

The company yesterday said it had received a second approach for its fixed line operation from a consortium including Irish entrepreneur Dermot Desmond. He lines up against Denis O'Brien, who sold the Irish telecoms business Esat to British Telecom last year for £1.9bn.

Mr O'Brien's consortium e-Island has lodged an indicative bid of €2.4bn (£1.5bn).

Mr Desmond, whose consortium is called International Investment & Underwriting, is one of Ireland's best known businessmen. He owns London City airport and Sandy Lane Hotel in Barbados.

"It is a fact of life that we have had some indicative offers, and the progress of those are being managed in a professional way," said Eircom chief executive Alfie Kane. "However, it does not follow that either will lead to a formal offer."

If Eircom falls to one of its predators it could result in a windfall for the large number of Irish people who queued up for shares when it was privatised just two years ago. They account for 20% of shareholders.

The offers have been made in the wake of Eircom's disposal of its mobile phone division, Eircell, to Vodafone for €3.5bn. After the sale, the company will be virtually debt-free.

The company will also be looking to shed the "cash hungry" internet software and content development operations but will keep hold of its profitable internet service providers. The two brands eircomNet and Indigo would be merged under eircomNet, with the loss of around 200 jobs.

Eircom expects to reduce its 11,000-strong workforce by 3,500 people by the end of 2003. Around 80 of 100 jobs in Britain are among those which will be lost.

webTitle: Way cleared for Galen to market hormone ring

fields.headline: Way cleared for Galen to market hormone ring
fields.trailText: Women's healthcare specialist Galen Holdings has gained approval from the Department of Health to begin selling radical hormone replacement rings.
fields.body:
Women's healthcare specialist Galen Holdings has gained approval from the Department of Health to begin selling its intra-vaginal rings, which could radically change the way hormone replacement therapy is administered.

The news sent the firm's shares up 12.5p to 780p, after a month-long slump due to fears that Galen had botched its recent £190m purchase of US firm Warner Chilcott.

Galen's intra-vaginal rings stay in the body for up to three months, gradually releasing hormones. They are intended to be more convenient than taking daily pills or having surgical implants, and could command annual sales of $150m (£100m).

Chairman John King said he was delighted with approval of the rings, which will be available on prescription within the next two months. "It's no longer a case of whether this technology will be approved internationally, but when."

Mr King, who owns a 12% stake in Galen, attacked recent rumours surrounding the purchase of Warner Chilcott, which makes contraceptive pills. He said: "It's beyond my comprehension why people should say some of these things. The performance of Warner Chilcott since acquisition has been excellent and continues to be excellent."

Among the sceptics has been the stock market bear raider Simon Cawkwell, known as Evil Knievil, who recently closed his "short" position in Galen shares, making a five-figure profit. Mr Cawkwell said: "Even if things are straight in the US, it's a very highly valued company."

Some investors on internet bulletin boards have questioned Galen's reluctance to issue a stock market statement dismissing the negative rumours about Warner Chilcott.

Mr King said: "We're not prepared to get into a discourse with these people. The best way to demonstrate that things are going well is to get our heads down and get on with things."

Galen has been a stock market phenomenon since its £180m flotation in 1997. The firm last year became Northern Ireland's first £1bn public company. Its capitalisation his now £1.24bn.

Its growth has turned Mr King and founder Allen McClay into Ulster's wealthiest business duo, with a combined stake of 25% worth £310m.

webTitle: Porfile of world music producer Nick Gold

fields.headline: Our man in Havana
fields.standfirst: The man who brought us the Buena Vista Social Club is taking the Cuban phenomenon a step further.  John Fordham  meets Nick Gold
fields.trailText: The man who brought us the Buena Vista Social Clu b is taking the Cuban phenomenon a step further. John Fordham meets Nick Gold.
fields.body:
Nick Gold is fond of the Cuban question "Como no?", which means "Why not?" It would be the perfect soundbite, if such a glib and tacky notion were not anathema to this offbeat music-lover, the seat-of-the-pants architect of the Buena Vista Social Club phenomenon. Gold and his small company, World Circuit Records, have been operating a non-strategy based on the philosophy of "Como no?" for much of the past decade. Yards of newsprint and weeks of domination of album charts suggest they've been on the right track.

Gold isn't self-important, but in his shrugging, phlegmatic manner he's proud of himself at present. From early in World Circuit's history and his first recordings with the Malian singer-guitarist Ali Farka Toure, Gold has always suggested experimental variations on traditional idioms if the artist is up for it. Jazz saxophonist Steve Williamson and Irish folksters The Chieftains were on Toure's second World Circuit album. This time, Gold has gone further.

As producer of a new session for the powerhouse Buena Vista bassist Orlando "Cachaito" Lopez, Gold has pulled dub reggae, jazz, a Jamaican Hammond organist, a 1960s Cuban doo-wop guitarist, and even a turntable DJ into the elegant sway of classic Cuban dance music. In the best traditions of his label, it's a risky world-music experiment. But much of this complex and subtly vivacious album grew organically - fragments of tunes, chance meetings and spontaneously forged relationships turning into a tapestry of glowing colours swirling over one of the most infectious groove-making rhythm sections in world-music.

Nick Gold gives the impression of blinking in the glare of publicity. He never intended to run a record label, though he was a fanatical record collector from his teens. But after university in 1986, when he was waiting to go to teacher training college, Gold found himself holding down three jobs - two temporary and one voluntary - as assistant in the Kings Cross record shop Mole Jazz, working at an after-school play centre, and stuffing envelopes for the charity Community Music. The latter fixed work-experience placements for its helpers, and Gold wound up at Arts Worldwide, a promotional organisation touring non-mainstream international artists, mostly from Africa.

The company had decided to record its charges, and Gold got the job of overseeing things because he was the only member of staff with the word "record" in his CV. A little later, a label called World Circuit Limited was born. A little later still, Gold was running the show on his own.

A fast-moving, fast-talking man in his 30s with an arresting clatter of a voice somewhere between an auctioneer's and a sports broadcaster's, Gold exudes irrepressible enthusiasm for his work, and shuttles back and forth from Cuba as if commuting to a day-job. He recalls he knew next to nothing about recording technology at the start. The jazz records that inspired him involved nothing more technical than a few microphones, and the right musicians in the right room. But Gold had a sharp instinct for good material, and began working closely with the former Arts Worldwide performers to produce repertoires that would balance authenticity with accessibility.

One of his most fruitful relationships was with Ali Farka Toure from the early 1990s, and American guitarist Ry Cooder's out-of-the-blue call to the World Circuit office while searching for Toure in London led them to get together to share ideas. Gold was also listening to vintage Cuban dance music from the pre-revolutionary years and the interest sparked a relationship with the Cuban bandleader Juan de Marcos Gonzalez. Gold was astonished to find that many of the Cuban stars of the 1940s were still alive and playing.

Gold planned a joint Malian-Cuban recording for the second of two sessions on a trip to Havana in 1996. But the Africans' passport applications were lost and they never made it. The producer found himself searching for something to do with a variety of veteran dance-band musicians in Havana's Egrem Studio, some of whom knew each other by reputation, all of whom were intrigued by the occasion.

"You'd wander around and there'd be pockets of them in corners, some around the piano, some around a guitar," says Gold. "You'd hear bits that sounded good and record them. As it went on, it was obvious we were getting something wonderful on tape, and the Buena Vista thing just went from there.

"They were very word-of-mouth successful, right off the bat. The record started to sell very well, and it kept churning on, and then when the Wenders movie came out it became a phenomenon. But the way we made that record is no different from the way we've always worked, and the way we've done it all the way up to this new CD of Cachaito's. I started with that beautiful groove, just the rhythm section and we built it up from there.

"I love things that come together like that. What comes out of it is always different from the way you imagined. That's why we shouldn't fear homogenised corporate-culture so much. This kind of music-making is too strong to be destroyed."

 Cachaito Lopez performs with special guests Ibrahim Ferrer, Pee Wee Ellis, plus Kinky and Anga Diaz at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), on Saturday.

fields.headline: Mandela questions Lockerbie verdict
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela has said he will present Tony Blair with fresh evidence supposedly clearing the Libyan intelligence officer jailed for the Lockerbie bombing.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela has said he will present Tony Blair with fresh evidence supposedly clearing the Libyan intelligence officer jailed for the Lockerbie bombing.

The move follows a meeting with the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, and with the family of the imprisoned terrorist, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi,, in Tripoli on Sunday.

The former South African president is also expected to press Mr Blair to lift the remaining sanctions against Libya.

"I don't promise anything, but the leader [Colonel Gadafy] informed me of facts which I did not know and I will visit Britain soon to discuss this case with its prime minister. But I promise that I will spare no effort to achieve positive results," Mr Mandela said yesterday at the end of his one-day visit to the Libyan capital.

Mr Mandela, who has previously said he trusted Col Gadafy "without reservation", did not reveal the new evidence or specifically say he was convinced by it. The former South African president is already scheduled to meet Mr Blair in London on April 28.

Megrahi was jailed for life in January by a Scottish court sitting in the Netherlands for planting the bomb on the PanAm flight that killed 270 people in 1988.

Two years ago as South Africa's president, Mr Mandela played a crucial role along with Saudi Arabia in breaking the international deadlock over the Lockerbie bombing when he helped persuade Col Gadafy to surrender Megrahi and his co-accused, Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah, for trial on neutral ground. Mr Fhimah was acquitted by the court.

In February, Mr Mandela accused London and Washington of reneging on the agreement by imposing fresh conditions for the complete lifting of United Nations sanctions against Libya which have so far only been suspended.

Britain and the US say sanctions should only be scrapped when Tripoli admits official responsibility for the destruction of PanAm 103 and pays compensation to the families of the victims.

"We had got certain guarantees, one of the most important [being] that if Libya delivered the suspects, the sanctions would be lifted. Not suspended, lifted," Mr Mandela said at the time.

"We expected that the west would honour its undertaking. Unfortunately, that was not done."

Mr Mandela also said he expected Britain to abide by an agreement to allow the UN a role in overseeing Megrahi's imprisonment.

Libya has repeatedly denied responsibility for the bombing and claims that the court that jailed Megrahi was acting under political pressure from Washington and London.

After the verdict, Col Gadafy promised to reveal evidence that would prove Megrahi's innocence and leave the Scottish judges with three choices - suicide, resignation or exposing "the truth". But the Libyan leader has yet to provide the promised proof.

Mr Mandela has not been afraid to side with Col Gadafy before on numerous occasions despite criticism from western governments which regard the Libyan government as a terrorist regime.

Col Gadafy was a consistent supporter of the African National Congress when it was banned in South Africa and most western governments were soft on the apartheid regime.

Mr Mandela has accused the Libyan leader's critics of hypocrisy and said he would not abandon Col Gadafy or other controversial friends such as Fidel Castro.

webTitle: Israel's reservists 'refusing to serve in West Bank'

fields.headline: Israel's reservists 'refusing to serve in West Bank'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli army is facing a crisis because many reservists are refusing to serve in the West Back for moral reasons.
fields.body:
The Israeli army is facing a crisis because many reservists are refusing to serve in the West Bank and Gaza for moral reasons, according to Israeli campaigners.

Ishai Menuchim, a spokesman for Yesh Gvuel (There's a Limit), who described himself as a major in the Israeli army reserve, said yesterday: "It is immoral to be there. The occupation is not democratic. It is evil to take part in an occupation."

As the conflict claimed the life of another Palestinian, Tayseer al-Omolee, 45, at Ramallah, in the West Bank, and Israeli forces fired rockets at the village of Beit Lahiya in Gaza, Mr Menuchim claimed the number refusing to serve was already much higher than during the previous Palestinian uprising. He also predicted that the number of refuseniks would swell.

One recent estimate is that 2,500 soldiers had refused to serve since the Palestinian uprising began in September.

He said that, of the refuseniks he had spoken with, many said they did not want to risk their lives on behalf of Jewish settlers.

Dodging military service is a divisive issue in Israel. One soldier released after serving a jail sentence said that his refusal had been on moral grounds. Contacted by phone during a long bus journey, however, he whispered that he did not want to talk about it at length, fearing the consequences if his opinions were overheard by other passengers.

There is resentment among some reservists, and among their parents, about being sent to the frontline, while ultra-Orthodox Jews are exempt on religious grounds.

Of the 31 Israeli soldiers killed since September, five have been reservists.

Among the grievances is the lack of compensation for disruptions caused by absences from work.

The liberal Israeli daily, Ha'aretz, in an editorial yesterday warned that ignoring the reservists while giving favoured treatment to ultra-Orthodox Jews was causing serious harm. "If this is not fixed soon, the damage may turn out to be irreversible," it said.

The Israeli army is heavily dependent on reservists. Almost every male has to do three years in the army when they become 18; women serve two years.

They are then called up for about 30 days a year, an obligation that men can be under well into their 40s.

The army disputes that there is a serious refusenik problem and claimed that motivation among the soldiers, both full-time and reservists, was high.

Captain Sharon Feingold, an army spokeswoman, said that 95%-97% of reservists were reporting for duty, compared with 85% in the years leading up to the Palestinian uprising.

Officially, 837 people failed to report for duty in the period October to April. This compared, she said, with 1,059 during the same period the previous year. Those who refused to serve had received jail sentences, normally about two weeks to a month.

She claimed that statistics that had appeared in the Israeli press suggesting a drop in motivation had been misleading. They were based on questionnaires asking young people where they wanted to serve, and had been filled in while the peace talks werestill going on.

Mr Menuchim, still a reservist despite being jailed for refusing to serve in Lebanon, disputes the army claims.

He said the number of people in jail did not reflect the scale of the problem. He said that of 100 reservists who had contacted his organisation since the Palestinian uprising saying they would not serve in the West Bank or Gaza, only five had been sent to military court: one had been released and four had been jailed.

Of the remaining 95, their refusals had either been quietly brushed under the carpet or they had been posted within Israel.

He maintained that the situation will get worse.

 The spiritual leader of Israel's Shas party provoked a row yesterday after the publication of a sermon in which he called on God to annihilate Arabs and rain missiles down upon them.

Israeli politicians from the left and right condemned the remarks. A Shas spokesman said he had been referring to Arab terrorists not all Arabs.

fields.headline: Italians bust suspected sex ring
fields.trailText: Italian police yesterday began arresting more than 100 alleged members of an international organisation of sex racketeers and people traffickers.
fields.body:
Italian police yesterday began arresting more than 100 alleged members of an international organisation of sex racketeers and people traffickers in what is believed to be the largest operation of its kind mounted in Italy.

Among the first people to be arrested in "Operation Sunflower" was the reigning Universal Boxing Federation's world welterweight champion, Marco Prescutti.

The 29-year-old from Perugia is accused of inducing foreign women to work as prostitutes for the sex organisation.

Lured from eastern Europe and Latin America with the promises of jobs in show business, the victims were allegedly raped and beaten, and killed if they refused to work as prostitutes.

"It was a slave trade. The women were raped, kept locked up in apartments and sent out to work on the streets," Antonella Duchini, the Perugia public prosecutor who coordinated the investigation, told state television.

The suspects, mostly Italian and Albanian, have been charged with mafia conspiracy, enslavement, kidnap and international drug trafficking.

The organisation was based in the Umbrian town of Perugia but carried on its business in Lazio, Lombardy and the Campania region around Naples. It owned night clubs, apartments and a hotel, and generated a revenue of more than 2bn lire (£650,000) a month, investigators said.

The organisers allegedly provided the women with passports, tickets and tourist visas. But instead of being given legitimate jobs, they were put to work as prostitutes in night clubs and sold on to Albanian crime gangs who put them on the streets.

The pimps allegedly bought control over the women for a little over £3,000 each. Those who refused to be controlled by the Albanians were beaten and forcibly drugged.

The investigation, conducted by the Carabinieri paramilitary police, began last year following the murder of a young Russian woman and the disappearance of a Polish prostitute, who, police believe, died from an overdose after being force-fed drugs.

Investigators said the sex merchants had strong links to Italian organised crime groups, particularly the Naples area Camorra and the Calabrian 'Ndrangheta.

Italian crime groups have allowed Albanian and Nigerian pimps to run the sex trade in large areas of Italy in return for favours such as assistance in arms and drugs trafficking, a police source said. They get an indirect financial benefit by operating extortion rackets against property owners connected with the business.

"The mafia doesn't feel under threat from these foreign crime groups, at least not in southern Italy where it has a strong territorial presence," the source said. "In central and northern Italy there is more room for the Albanian gangs to expand."

webTitle: Late surge puts left into second round of Peru's presidential election

fields.headline: Late surge puts left into second round of Peru's presidential election
fields.trailText: Alejandro Toledo led the first round of the Peruvian elections on Sunday and will probably face a controversial former president, Alan Garcia, in a run-off vote.
fields.body:
Alejandro Toledo led the first round of the Peruvian elections on Sunday and will probably face a controversial former president, Alan Garcia, in a run-off vote.

Mr Garcia appears to have made a stunning comeback to Peruvian politics only three months after returning to the country following nine years in exile. With half the votes counted, he had 26.2% - 2.5 percentage points ahead of the third-placed candidate, Lourdes Flores. Mr Toledo was in the lead with 36.3%.

Mr Garcia's vastly superior skills as an orator worked in his favour against the politically inexperienced Mr Toledo, the former shoe-shine boy and US-educated economist who was a symbol of resistance against the authoritarian regime of President Alberto Fujimori.

Mr Garcia was president between 1985 and 1990. His youth and charisma meant that he was originally hailed as "Latin America's JF Kennedy" but his term ended with annual inflation topping 7,600%, surging guerrilla violence and rampant corruption.

Painting himself as the elder statesman who has matured and put behind his youthful leftwing ideas, Mr Garcia has enchanted many Peruvians who appear willing to forgive his first-term performance. "I voted for Alan because I don't believe he is going to go in and make the same mistakes," said Carlos Alvarez, a 49-year-old tailor in Lima.

Sunday's election was the first since Mr Fujimori fled to Japan last year after a bribery scandal. It is almost exactly a year since Mr Fujimori won a third term, beating Mr Toledo in a contest that was heavily rigged.

Mr Toledo, who has a doctorate from Stanford University and has been a visiting scholar at Harvard, capitalised during his campaign on his humble beginnings and ethnic background. He is a cholo , the Peruvian term for a person of mixed Indian and white blood. No Indian or cholo has been freely elected president in Peru's history, even though 45% of the country's 26m inhabitants are Indian.

But Mr Toledo's vote was far below that predicted by himself and recent polls, suggesting that voters were beginning to show more interest in a series of allegations that the 55-year-old had used drugs in the past and had abandoned an illegitimate daughter.

Ms Flores, 41, is a member of Lima's white elite with a reputation for honesty. A former congresswoman and outspoken opponent of Mr Fujimori, she had been in second place in opinion polls but her campaign began to fade after her father made a racial slur against Mr Toledo.

Mr Toledo, who is the centrist candidate, stands to pick up most votes from Ms Flores, who has the most rightwing policies. Mr Garcia, even though he has mellowed, is still the candidate furthest to the left.

Independent voting watchdogs reported no serious irregularities.

webTitle: Telephone dirty tricks muddy LA mayoral election

fields.headline: Telephone dirty tricks muddy LA mayoral election
fields.trailText: The people of Los Angeles vote for a new mayor today after a race tarnished in the last few days by dirty tricks campaigns seeking to exploit anti-semitism and fear of crime.
fields.body:
The people of Los Angeles vote for a new mayor today after a race tarnished in the last few days by dirty tricks campaigns seeking to exploit anti-semitism and fear of crime.

The race has been close and will almost certainly go to a runoff in June between the top two. The latest polls show the city attorney James Hahn, the former state assembly speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, and the Republican businessman Steve Soboroff leading the field of more than 20 candidates.

After a quiet start, the campaign grew increasingly bitter, the candidates slinging mud and engaging in angry exchanges at public meetings.

But a new tone was struck by a series of automated telephone calls purporting to be campaign messages.

In one a voice asked for contributions for Steve Soboroff and his "conservative coalition". It ended: "Soboroff's polling numbers have been falling and we have become entirely dependent upon Jewish money.

"Thank you and thank you from Steve Soboroff."

Another, purporting to come from the influential LA county supervisor Gloria Molina, warned voters that Mr Villaraigosa was sympathetic to criminals and soft on crime.

Fear of crime and the role of the police are key issues in the campaign.

In fact, Ms Molina is backing Mr Villaraigosa, and she has now sent a genuine message out on his behalf with her endorsement.

The tactics were condemned yesterday by politicians and religious leaders in the city, which has the second largest Jewish population, after New York.

"Clearly someone or some campaign has injected religion into the mayoral campaign to seek partisan advantage," said David Lehrer of the Anti-Defamation League.

The current Republican mayor, Richard Riordan, who is not seeking re-election, also condemned the messages.

"Los Angeles is the most diverse city in the United States," he said. "Angelenos have come a long, long way toward getting along with each other. We cannot tolerate vicious cowards who want to spread religious and racial prejudice in our city."

The source of the recordings remains unknown and could now become the subject of a police investigation. Automated telephone messages, which can be delivered simultaneously to thousands of homes for three cents each, are fast being taken up as a way of reaching voters.

The election could make Mr Villaraigosa the first Latino mayor of Los Angeles since 1872. He is backed by the unions and liberals and the majority of the large Latino community, but a rival Latino candidate, Xavier Becerra, could rob him of victory.
