webTitle: Effort to separate twins enters fourth day

fields.headline: Effort to separate twins enters fourth day
fields.trailText: A pair of conjoined twin sisters who share a brain cavity yesterday entered an epic fourth night on an operating table in Singapore as surgeons worked round the clock to separate them.
fields.byline: John Aglionby,  south-east Asia correspondent, and  Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
A pair of conjoined twin sisters who share a brain cavity yesterday entered an epic fourth night on an operating table in Singapore as surgeons worked round the clock to separate them.

Ganga and Jamuna Shrestha, from Nepal, who turned 11 months old under general anaesthetic yesterday, are "doing fine" after more than 75 hours of surgery, according to Ho Lai Fung, the communications manager at Singapore General Hospital.

But in spite of optimistic messages from the hospital, experts elsewhere voiced concern at the length of time the operation was taking.

"If they have been operating continuously for four days I think it is some sort of record," said Leo Strunin, president of the Association of Anaesthetists in London. "Keeping two very small children anaesthetised for a very long time needs a lot of skill."

The risks of infection increase as time goes on.

Ms Fung said the operation could well continue into today because "the separation is proving to be much more complex than was originally envisaged". The original estimate was 24 to 36 hours.

"The doctors are working as fast as they can but there are so many blood vessels that need to be separated and rejoined it is a painstaking procedure," Ms Fung said.

But she stressed nothing was going wrong. "The girls' vital signs have remained stable and both the surgical and anaesthetic teams are happy with the progress," she said.

Ganga and Jamuna have craniopagus, a rare condition in which they are joined at the back of the head. American doctors have found records of only 79 similar cases between 1487 and 1987. Only 2% of conjoined twins are attached at the head.

The operation to separate them is difficult. Ben Carson, a neurosurgeon at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore in the US, has become something of a celebrity after two successes - one in the US and the second in South Africa - both of which took less than 30 hours.

In South Africa two years ago, he successfully separated Luka and Joseph Banda after rehearsals with a virtual reality simulator which turned merged scans into a three-dimensional image of the twins' brains. More than 100 blood vessels had to be tracked and then cut.

Mr Carson is an adviser to the team operating in Singapore, whose members have also been practising with simulators. They declined to comment yesterday.

More than a dozen anaesthetists, plastic surgeons and neurosurgeons have been working constantly on the Nepali twins in two teams since 4pm on Friday.

The plastic surgeons opened the skulls and are in charge of reconstructing the bones and skin. The neurosurgeons have been dividing the brains and blood vessels while neurologists have used electrodes attached to the brain to determine which part belongs to which girl.

The girls' mother, Sandhya Shrestha, father, KC Bushan, and grandfather, Arjun Dev Shrestha, with an army of well-wishers, have been keeping a vigil at the hospital since the operation began. They have left the site only to pray at a local Hindu temple and to take an occasional shower.

Mr Shrestha told local media on Sunday: "When we see the doctors are happy, we are happy too."

The fight to save the lives of the girls - named after sacred rivers in India - began almost immediately after they were born on May 9. Doctors near their mountain home, a 24-hour drive from the Nepali capital, Kathmandu, said they had to be operated on quickly because they risked serious illness or death as their growing brains pressed into each other in the skull cavity they share.

Singapore Airlines flew the family to the island republic six weeks after the girls were born and doctors offered their services free.

Singaporeans meanwhile practically adopted the family; they sent hundreds of letters and raised £250,000 to cover medical costs and other expenses.

webTitle: RAF crew die in Kosovo crash

fields.headline: RAF crew die in Kosovo crash
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Kosovo
Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText:
Two pilots were killed when an RAF Puma helicopter carrying three crew members and four British soldiers crashed
   near the border of Kosovo and Macedonia yesterday.
fields.body:
Two pilots were killed when an RAF Puma helicopter carrying three crew members and four British soldiers crashed near the border of Kosovo and Macedonia yesterday.

The dead men were named as Captain Andrew Crous, 28, of the Army Air Corps, and RAF Flight Lieutenant James Maguire, 31, both based at RAF Benson in Oxfordshire.

The five survivors - four soldiers from the 2nd Royal Tank Regiment and an RAF loadmaster - were described as walking wounded, and were being treated at Camp Bondsteel, the main US army base in south-eastern Kosovo.

A spokesman for the Ministry of Defence said: "It appears that the aircraft had to execute an emergency landing in heavy rain, low cloud and mountainous terrain. There is absolutely no evidence of any hostile action."

The helicopter came down near Kacanik, south-west of Pristina, Kosovo's main city. Major Fergus Smith, speaking for British peacekeeping forces in Kosovo, said: "The circumstances surrounding the incident are unclear and will be subject to an inquiry."

British troops recently reinforced K-For soldiers along Kosovo's border where ethnic Albanian extremists have been infiltrating Macedonia.

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

B1 Tiger Woods is the first golfer to:

(a) Hold 4 major titles at once

(b) Grow claws

(c) Eat Kitekat

(d) Be neutered

B2 Tyger Tyger

(a) He can bite

(b) Jedi knight

(c) Turning right

(d) Burning bright

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: La Dolce Vita | Analyze This | Human Traffic
fields.body:
Films

The Madness Of King George
(Nicholas Hytner, 1994)
6pm, FilmFour

George III, of course, the king who lost the American colonies and whose bouts of madness may have been caused by the pain of porphyria. Alan Bennett's accomplished reworking of his stage play is both a handsome historical drama about skulduggery at court - epitomised by Rupert Everett's foppish, scheming Prince of Wales - and a moving study of the man inside the ermine. Nigel Hawthorne's George is magnificent, lurching from nobility to wild-eyed tantrums to, under the regime of progressive doctor Ian Holm, utter wretchedness in a soiled nappy.

Excalibur
(John Boorman, 1981)
8pm, Sky Cinema

Boorman seems to have got lost in the mists of time with this confusing version of the Arthurian legend: the narrative is all but engulfed by whizz-bang visuals. However, the images are often brilliant, there are savage battles, curious sex (armour-clad Nigel Terry roasting by the fire with Helen Mirren), and Nicol Williams's Merlin is just dotty.

La Dolce Vita
(Federico Fellini, 1960)
8pm, FilmFour

One of Fellini's brilliant, semi-autobiographical extravaganzas, which has Marcello Mastroianni as a provincial hack seduced by the more-sour-than-sweet life of Rome's finest. He is fascinated by a film star (Anita Ekberg) and a rich nymphomaniac (Anouk Aimee); he ignores the love of Yvonne Furneaux. The city is evoked throughout by Fellini's flamboyant imagery.

Analyze This
(Harold Ramis, 1999)
10pm, Sky Premier

The central (some say only) joke in this mafia comedy - a sort of Feel-Goodfellas - has a mobster on the psychiatrist's couch, trying to make sense of his violent impulses and other anti-social behaviour. It may seem overly familiar to viewers of TV's The Sopranos, but in Ramis's well-handled, cleverly scripted story it's a very good joke. And the two leads are terrific: Robert De Niro, revisiting his Scorsese mobsters down the years, as deadly Paul Viti; wisecracking Billy Crystal as the doc, Ben Sobol: "What is my goal here? To make you a happy, well adjusted gangster?".

Human Traffic
(Justin Kerrigan, 1999)
1.15am, FilmFour

In Cardiff, five friends forget about their dead-end jobs for a weekend of clubs, drugs, drink and parties. The performances - by John Simm, Lorraine Pilkington, Shaun Parkes, Nicola Reynolds and Danny Dyer - are vibrant, Dave Bennett's camerawork has mindbending energy, and Kerrigan, in his directorial debut, captures both the agony and the Ecstasy of "48 hours off from the world, man".

Sports

Live Snooker
2pm, Sky Sports 2

With the countdown to this year's World Championships now very much on - it starts in Sheffield in less than two weeks - now is the time for players to finely hone their form or, for those who failed to make the cut for the Crucible, to prove their quality in what will be their last tournament of the season. Snooker, often rather dull to be frank, is starting to hot up.

fields.headline: In the bird house
fields.standfirst: Achvaneran
fields.trailText: Achvaneran.
fields.body:
The original idea, several years ago, of a dooket in the garden was to keep some doves in there, but in their flights around the strath they were picked off one by one either by the local peregrine or the goshawk, so in the end we reluctantly gave them away to someone with a very large aviary.

This year painting the wooden dooket was long overdue, but the exact timing was difficult as during the winter the seven starlings roosting there rarely seemed to be away from it very long, and the paint would have to dry. At the beginning of April the decision was made that on the first dry day we would get underway, as the starlings had been looking for nest material.

A close inspection indicated there was more bare wood than old white paint, and the first job was the unpleasant task of scraping off all the lichens and mosses. The starlings had gone off early in the morning and were probably down by the river probing in cow pats for food, but as soon as I started scraping, one flew into the huge sycamore overlooking the garden and sat there watching me the whole time. Just occasionally it called like a curlew, as if to tell me it was there, and sometimes the calls were echoed by a real curlew down by the river.

The starling imitation is so good it can be taken for the real thing, even throughout the winter when the curlews have all gone to the coast. During the winter large numbers of starlings gather in this part of the strath before they fly off to Inverness where they roost in their thousands.

But despite the gathering, sometimes swirling only a field away, "our" seven will have none of it, and by the time the crowd head for the city, the seven are already in bed for the night.

fields.headline: It's gym life, but not as we know it
fields.trailText: All Sorts | Crossroads
fields.body:
The truth, it is oft said, is stranger than fiction. From the outset, daytime television seems to support this thesis. Consider All Sorts (Channel 4) for example.

Presented by a young woman rowing a boat (I'm not sure if this is a regular set-up or not), it profiles ordinary but out-of-the-ordinary people. There's Stephanie who got so bored with the gym, she took to exercising at home using her cat instead of dumbells. Thus, Stephanie explained, she combines keeping fit with paying attention to her pet. She has even produced a book and a video about the joys of "catflexing". (We can only hope she hasn't adapted her microwave to create a sauna in the kitchen.)

Then there's Londoner Victor Feinstein, a championship body-builder who keeps to a strict diet and exercise regime. So far, so mildly strange, you might think. The coup de grce , however, is that Victor is eight years old. In a pair of skimpy trunks, he pouts and poses like any muscle mary, but whereas older bodybuilders look like constipated minotaurs, Victor looks like an emaciated chicken. More worrying than Victor's award-winning ways is the fact that there are actually awards - the English Under-10 Body Building Championships, to be precise - for him to win.

Gary Tiplady, meanwhile, got so depressed about being teased for looking like Jaws from the James Bond films (poor Gary has a thyroid disorder), he went out and got himself some metal teeth in a bid to jump-start a career in the movies. I don't want to be cruel about Gary - he could give you a nasty bite - but given that Jaws last appeared in a Bond film in Moonraker in 1979, he has perhaps missed the boat on that one.

It is these people who are the stars of All Sorts. They are the kind of people who, if you chatted to them at a party, you would say, "Well, the world don't move to the beat of just one drum. What might be right for you may not be right some." Then, you'd excuse yourself to go to the bathroom and climb out of the window, knocking your host's potpourri down the toilet as you escape. Sad but true, you couldn't make it up.

They have tried making it up in Crossroads (ITV) and, given the number of weird folks who now populate the four-star hotel, they are doing rather well. Indeed, the shenanigans in Kings Oak (not a pub, more a state of affairs) actually go some way to disprove the notion that fiction is truth's dowdy sister.

A hostelry that has a handyman who bears an uncanny resemblance to a camel is, you will agree, no ordinary hotel. That Bradley the handyman is also gay, has a boyfriend and can play football stretches one's imagination to an extent shied away from even by Twin Peaks. Likewise, letting Jill Harvey sit on reception in the beauty salon - albeit on a temporary basis - isn't something that passes for normal, at least not in this reality. Looking as she does like a potato with lipstick on, her presence is as incongruous as Phil Mitchell manning the phone for The Samaritans.

Meanwhile down on the hotel's reception proper, her daughter Sarah Jane looks and acts like someone who auditioned to be Dr Who's assistant but was overlooked in favour of someone more expressive - K-9 maybe - and Minty is someone you'd never want to suck on, even if the alternative was permanent onion breath. Indeed, so bizarre is it, the Addams Family wouldn't want to stay at Crossroads.

Yet as weird as the characters are, the storylines are mundane, monotonous and inconsequential. In yesterday's action-packed episode, the storylines included: a lost earring; a hangover; a powercut caused by dodgy record decks (a nod to the younger audience); a couple of illicit snogs; some frying potatoes; a bit of toast being buttered; and the world's shortest football match, about which everyone remained strangely silent afterwards. With the ad break containing more engaging narratives than Crossroads, it makes Neighbours look like Clocking Off. Well, not quite, but you get the picture.

Not that excitement wasn't promised. "My head's going to explode any minute", sighed Mandy, the chambermaid. Alas, it didn't, though we live in hope that a David Cronenberg homage episode is in the works. If it does, however, Doris will not be pleased. Brain is such a persistent stain, and the Crossroads towels will never be the same.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Black Market Britain | My Life - The Story And Music Of Billy Joel | Night Waves
fields.body:
Dodgy entrepreneurs involved in Black Market Britain (8.0pm, Radio 4) may be among the hidden casualties of the foot-and-mouth crisis. The widespread suspension of car boot sales has robbed them of lucrative outlets. In the first of two programmes, Allan Urry investigates a trade unofficially estimated to skim £8,000m a year off legitimate businesses. The wide boys at the back of the lorries offer anything from fake designer clothes to pirated software and seem well ahead of their pursuers at the moment.

Billy Joel is, as he acknowledges in My Life - The Story And Music Of Billy Joel (9.0pm, Radio 2), wholly competent at everything he does, but he still regards himself as just "a product". He trained as a classical pianist and says that he is now giving up popular music for ever. If he means it, he can look back on a remarkable career in which he has sold more than 100m records, some still in demand after 25 years.

With a forthcoming British Museum exhibition focusing on Egypt's last pharaoh, Paul Allen and his guests on Night Waves (9.45pm, Radio 4) contemplate our endless fascination with Cleopatra. She was certainly extraordinary, fluent in nine languages, skilled in mathematics, and gifted with wit and charm (so long as you weren't her brother).

fields.headline: George Bull
fields.standfirst: Journalist and polymath drawn to Italy and Japan
fields.trailText: Journalist and polymath drawn to Italy and Japan.
fields.body:
A combination of expertise on Machiavelli, Michelangelo, the Renaissance, Rome, Japanese history and contemporary political life, is not common among journalists, even of the old school of scholarly craftsmen: but George Bull, who has died aged 71, was an exceptional journalist -constantly reaching out for fields unconquered by his restless, inquiring mind.

No doubt because of his Catholic upbringing he was attracted early on to Italian culture and art and developed a love of Renaissance Italy. He translated Vasari, Cellini, Castiglione, Aretino and Machiavelli for Penguin books. His book on The Prince is a classic of its kind and remains in print after 40 years, having sold more than a million copies. His 1995 biography of Michelangelo is a notable contribution to the volumes written on that genius. Yet throughout, he remained the working journalist, brilliant interviewer, excellent reporter and distinctive editor.

Bull was born to working- class parents in the east end of London and was very young when his father died. His mother, Bridget, came from an Irish immigrant family and was the family's principal support. George was educated by the Society of Jesus, an institution for which he retained a lifelong regard; it was the society that took him to Wimbledon College and from there to Brasenose College, Oxford. At Wimbledon he started and edited a school magazine, the Distributist, inspired by George's devotion to GK Chesterton's ideas and writings.After Oxford, he was recruited to the Financial Times by its great talent-spotting editor Sir Gordon Newton. Bull was first a reporter and then foreign news editor (1956-59). He then spent a year with the London bureau of McGraw-Hill World News as news editor before joining the Director, the Institute of Directors' monthly magazine. Under his and Eric Foster's control it effectively became the British equivalent of Fortune magazine.

Bull was successively the Director's editor and editor-in-chief from 1960 till 1984. Two years after leaving it he became director of the Anglo-Japanese Economic Institute, a body which links Tokyo with the widest range of British political, industrial and cultural activities. And as the organiser-in-chief of this rather special, if largely unpublicised institution, Bull became a de facto Anglo-Japanese ambassador at large in London.

For this, in 1999, he was awarded by the emperor of Japan the prestigious Order of the Sacred Treasure (Gold Rays with Neck Ribbon).

There were no boundaries to Bull's activities: he launched and ran a series of monthly and quarterly journals dealing with Japanese affairs: an independent journal on banking and another journal to analyse the pyschological aspects of international conflict, International Minds.

He was a director and trustee of the Tablet and the Universe; governor of Westminster Choir School and St Thomas More School and of St Mary's College, Strawberry Hill 1976-87; a member of the United Kingdom committee of the European Cultural Foundation since 1987 and co-founder in 1996 - and director - of the Institute of Public Enterprise Studies. He was appointed OBE in 1990.

He is survived by his widow and four children.

George Bull, journalist, writer, translator, consultant; born August 23 1929; died April 6 2001

fields.headline: Douglas Wain-Hobson
fields.standfirst: He survived sculptural controversy in Balham to embellish many public spaces
fields.trailText: He survived sculptural controversy in Balham to embellish many public spaces.
fields.body:
Following his success as a prizewinner in the Institute of Contemporary Arts' Unknown Political Prisoner sculpture competition in 1953, Douglas "Dougie" Wain-Hobson, who has died aged 82, was commissioned to produce a sculpture for the lawn outside the new wing of St James Hospital in Balham, London.

When unveiled, the life-size male nude, sans fig-leaf, so shocked people living nearby, that petitions were signed, and the locals attempted to raise £500 (Dougie's fee) to buy the statue from the hospital, and return it to the sculptor. Overnight, someone thoughtfully provided the statue, titled Recovery but soon better known as the "Leafless Man of Balham", with a green hospital gown and a white apron loincloth. Weeks later, police were called in, following a student dance at the hospital, when the statue was discovered to be partially covered with surgical plaster and bandages.

In the 1950s, Dougie was one of the country's leading young sculptors - in the ICA competition he had been one of seven prizewinners from 3,500 entries. Other finalists included Eduardo Paolozzi, Barbara Hepworth, Elizabeth Frink, FE McWilliam and the winner, Reg Butler.

The Balham episode certainly appeared to do him little harm, as Dougie was quickly commissioned to do several portrait heads, and architects continued to use his sculpture to embellish buildings. In 1964, he produced a 9ft-high bronze figure of Shakespeare for the Shakespeare Centre at Stratford-on-Avon, to celebrate the 400th anniversary of the writer's birth.

Dougie was born at Norton, Derbyshire, the only son of a builder. His mother encouraged her son's early interest in drawing and constantly sent in his work for competitions. The family moved to Sheffield where Dougie contracted tuberculosis. To aid recovery he was sent by his mother to her family home in Lincolnshire, where he lived with his grandparents for two years.

He left school at 11, with little formal education, but his talent for drawing led, at 14, to a scholarship at Sheffield art school. Starting as a painter, his innate practical skills - he was never happier than when working with his hands - inspired a move to sculpture. In 1938, he entered the Royal College of Art. It was here that Dougie met his wife, Joan Drummond, an engraver and illustrator, before their studies were interrupted by the second world war.

Dougie served in the army between 1940-45. He and Joan married in 1944 and resumed their studies after the war. In 1946, he won the RCA silver medal for sculpture and, in 1947, the Rome scholarship in sculpture. He and Joan spent three years in Italy - which Dougie saw as the most formative part of his education. He loved Italy.

After his return to London in 1950, he began teaching, part-time, at the RCA and at Kingston School of Art. He exhibited his sculpture at the 1951 Festival of Britain shows, and at the Battersea Park Open Air exhibition; he also designed medals and coins for the Royal Mint and was commissioned to produce sculpture, for the Barbican, Norwich Union and Hoares bank on Fleet Street. Then came the ICA competition - and Balham.

Alongside his sculpture there were increasing teaching commitments, and he became senior tutor in sculpture at the RCA. He was a popular figure in the department. In the life-room, he once dismissed the model, left the room himself, to return with a skeleton and a very large polythene bag filled with water. "That's what we would look like without the skeleton underneath," said Dougie. In 1968, he left the RCA to become head of fine art at Manchester Polytechnic. From 1978 to 1983 he was dean of the faculty of art and design there.

When unveiled, the life-size male nude, sans fig-leaf, so shocked people living nearby, that petitions were signed, and the locals attempted to raise £500 (Dougie's fee) to buy the statue from the hospital, and return it to the sculptor. Overnight, someone thoughtfully provided the statue, titled Recovery but soon better known as the "Leafless Man of Balham", with a green hospital gown and a white apron loincloth. Weeks later, police were called in, following a student dance at the hospital, when the statue was discovered to be partially covered with surgical plaster and bandages. Other finalists included Eduardo Paolozzi, Barbara Hepworth, Elizabeth Frink, FE McWilliam and the winner, Reg Butler. The Balham episode certainly appeared to do him little harm, as Dougie was quickly commissioned to do several portrait heads, and architects continued to use his sculpture to embellish buildings. In 1964, he produced a 9ft-high bronze figure of Shakespeare for the Shakespeare Centre at Stratford-on-Avon, to celebrate the 400th anniversary of the writer's birth. fields.headline: Lonnie Glosson
fields.standfirst: Virtuoso player of country-style harmonica
fields.trailText: Virtuoso player of country-style harmonica.
fields.body:
The popularity of the harmonica among American folk, blues and country musicians owes much to pioneers like Lonnie Glosson, who has died aged 93. There were recordings and broadcasts spread across seven decades; and Glosson sold harmonicas and instruction books to hundreds of thousands of mail-order customers, through radio shows with his fellow harmonica-player Wayne Raney, syndicated all over North America.

Many years later, in the BBC television documentary series the Friendly Invasion, the two men re-enacted the show, though with a slight adjustment of pitch. "Neighbours, we're going to be demonstrating the talking harmonica and telling you how you too can have one just exactly like the ones your old friends Lonnie Glosson and Wayne Raney plays. For this entire deal, the talking harmonica and the play-by-ear instructions, just send your name and address and $3.98 to BBC Television network, London, England."

Born in Judsonia, Arkansas, Glosson learned to play the harmonica, or "French harp" as it was then called, from his mother Cora. Moving to St Louis in 1925, he interspersed bricklaying with appearances on station KMOX, graduating in 1930 to the midwest's most popular country music showcase, the National Barn Dance on WLS, Chicago. In 1932 he made his first record, coupling the two impressionist performances that are fundamental to rural harmonica-playing, a mock foxhunt and a train imitation. He would recreate the sounds of hounds, horns, train-whistles and airbrakes over the next 50 years, adding what became his best-known piece, I Want My Mama, an impression of a plaintive child.

In the 1940s Glosson worked on Kentucky's Renfro Valley Barn Dance and Nashville's Grand Ole Opry before teaming up with Raney, a fellow Arkansawyer 13 years his junior: their joint composition Why Don't You Haul Off And Love Me, inspired by a remark made by Glosson's infant daughter Mary, was a hit for Raney in 1949, vying for top place in the country charts with Hank Williams's Lovesick Blues.

The duet split up about 1956, and Glosson went back on the road, mostly playing in schools, where he would give a programme of country and gospel songs.

He is survived by his companion, Marcella Pry, six children and many grandchildren.

 Lonnie Glosson, country musician, born February 14 1908; died March 2 2001

webTitle: Why is breast cancer media friendly?

fields.headline: The biggest C
fields.standfirst: Why does breast cancer attract more column inches and cash than any other form of the disease?  Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.trailText: Why does breast cancer attract more column inches and cash than any other form of the disease? Anita Chaudhuri reports.
fields.body:
A report just released by Macmillan Cancer Relief tells us what most of us already know: breast cancer has become a cause celeb. Of all the media coverage of cancer assessed by the study, a quarter was devoted to breast cancer (lung cancer got less than half that amount) while the number of celebrities involved was far higher (277 mentions) for breast cancer than for the 200 other types of known varieties.

Much of this has come about through the vigorous campaigning of Breakthrough, the charity that launched its Fashion Targets Breast Cancer initiative with a posse of pert-breasted supermodels and celebrities. This, naturally enough, ensured a steady flow of high-profile media coverage. Whatever one thinks of the methodology, the results are impressive since the charity has already raised £15m to launch a breast cancer research centre.

Which brings us back to the Macmillan study. This reveals that there are more than 200 cancers, most of which are never debated in the media. Colorectal cancers, for example, got just 7% of the press coverage reviewed, yet bowel cancer is the third biggest killer. Could it be that breast cancer has become fashionable to the detriment of other types of cancer awareness?

Delyth Morgan, chief executive of Breakthrough, refutes this. "Seven years ago, when I started at Breakthrough, no one talked about cancer of any form, least of all breast cancer which was combining two taboos, sex and death. The Macmillan report reflects how successful we are. We learned the lessons of the Aids campaigners in the 80s and we have worked hard to present the issues creatively. For that reason, Breakthrough has become a trailblazer for all cancer charities and many have mimicked our style of campaigning."

That much is certainly true: the Cancer Research Campaign recently produced a series of sexy ads featuring perfect bottoms to boost awareness of bowel cancer - but as yet there have been precious few glossy magazines fighting to give away black ribbons commemorating lung cancer awareness month, fewer still supermodels willing to adopt the disease as their pet charity. Well, they wouldn't, would they? That would mean stubbing out those super-chic, appetite-suppressing Marlboro Lights.

Breast cancer kills more than 13,000 women every year in the UK and more than 30,000 are diagnosed as having it. However, the disease is most prevalent in women over 65, least common among those under 30. "Our report shows that breast cancer awareness among the young is very high, thanks to these celebrity campaigns, and there is a very high degree of public interest and sympathy," says Deborah Lincoln of Macmillan. "This is good because cancer is a long-term disease, so they will know what to look for when they're older. The problem is, even with breast cancer, no campaign or magazine is really reaching out to older women, the at-risk group."

Certainly it is ironic that breast cancer is marketed as a young woman's disease, which it patently is not, while lung cancer is associated with elderly men. In fact lung cancer is rising among women at the rate of 11% per year, a pattern set to worsen given the high number of teenage girls who smoke. A recent study indicated that 33% of 11-15-year-old girls are regular smokers (far more than boys), many drawn by the promise of losing weight. So why are there no campaigns with glamorous spokesmodels getting the message through to them?

Lincoln says wryly: "Well, when you're 15, you think you're immortal, don't you? Getting the message through is never going to be easy, but added to that, there isn't the same media interest in lung cancer. There is far less public sympathy because many people take the view that sufferers of the disease are themselves to blame through smoking."

It is worth noting, too, that most of the celebrities involved with cancer charities tend to be women. "Men don't like talking about illness," Lincoln says. "And a lot of men are embarrassed about talking about their nether regions. Even our prostate cancer helpline gets more calls from women than men, presumably wives phoning on behalf of their husbands. Robbie Williams has started campaigning for the Institute of Cancer Research and George Carman QC talked about his cancer before he died, so things are changing slowly."

Morgan agrees. "I don't know if I'd say cancer was a gender issue. There's a women's media that has given us opportunities to debate the disease. Now men's magazines are catching up and beginning to discuss health. Maybe we'll see more debate about other types of cancers among men."

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: (Sigh.) It's springtime. The blossom is budding on the bough and the cat's on heat. She yowls from room to room, beside herself, frotting against the furniture and male guests' trainers.
fields.body:
(Sigh.) It's springtime. The blossom is budding on the bough and the cat's on heat. She yowls from room to room, beside herself, frotting against the furniture and male guests' trainers. After dark, she belts up and down the stairs late into the night, as though she's in training for something sporting and potentially charitable. I expect she will ask me to sponsor her if she is.

Is over-infantilisation of the cat a sign of a perverse psyche? No more so than the global aberration that is the Weakest Link franchise, as the BBC signs deals with over 20 countries to produce their own versions of the gameshow. Like a virulent outbreak of something contagious, Anne Robinson imitators are cropping up around the world, all russet locks, wry winks and black frock coats.

Australia's version has already received more than one hundred complaints about the way she treats contestants, while Belgian TV has selected a well-known sex therapist and former Miss Belgium for the role. But contrast the posters of the original 56-year-old presenter now advertising the imminent airing of the programme in the US. The photographs have been retouched so that Anne now enjoys a silky smooth complexion, bright blue eyes, instead of hazel, and an all-new, slender body.

How are we to interpret this cloning frenzy? Perhaps we are witnessing a global redefinition of what it is to be ginger. Or a continuation of the trend to define ladies by their hair colour alone. And what's the psychosexual origin of our obsession with this sharp but seductive authoritarian? Oh nanny, be cruel, but wrinkle-free while you're at it.

Meanwhile, is your juicer getting the best coverage it deserves? Think carefully. Perhaps it needs its own ambassador. Sidelines is delighted to discover that the delicious Cindy Crawford is devoting her energies to the promotion of food mixing. Crawford, the new ambassador for Moulinex, assures us that the latest innovations from the company "offer care, comfort and always even greater pleasure". Even the mincer, Cindy? I must admit, the two-tier steamer had me pretty excited as well. Perhaps it's just what the cat needs by way of distraction. A slow spin in a liquidiser would surely encourage her to reassess her current lascivious state.

webTitle: India Knight on being a single mother

fields.headline: Sick (piles of it) and tired (very)
fields.standfirst: To prepare for her role as a single parent in the film About A Boy, Rachel Weisz will, she says, be doing lots and lots of research. Well, here are a few tips for starters
fields.trailText: To prepare for her role as a single parent in the film About A Boy, Rachel Weisz will, she says, be doing lots and lots of research. Well, here are a few tips for starters.
fields.body:
Some of us have single motherhood thrust upon us, but I have a theory that everyone is a single mother anyway, unless they have the good fortune to be married to one of those exemplars - bearded, usually, and I won't make jokes about which daily newspaper they favour - who get sympathy menstrual cramp, pee sitting down as a mark of "respect" and are always willing to whip you up a nourishing bean casserole when it all gets, like, too much. Yes, they do still exist, although actually, "be married" is wrong - the bearded wonder would, of course, be a "partner". Howdy!

Partner by name, but not necessarily by nature: there's only so much the poor man can achieve in the first place. Proper, partnerless single mothers may have a hard time, but they never have to put up with the uniquely self-satisfied look of a father who nobly takes the children swimming one Saturday afternoon in four and who can thus relax, safe in the knowledge that he pulls his weight, gives a hand and is generally Incredibly Useful and Supportive.

Such women won't know the infinite joys of having a spouse come home from a busy day at the office and wonder what she's been doing all day - two children under five: how hard can it be? - before asking why she is still in her pyjamas at 7pm and muttering darkly about how it's not very sexy, you know, to sit there with banana Cow & Gate all down your front.

Which is my first bit of advice for the ridiculously pulchritudinous and unmumsy Rachel Weisz, who has stated her intention to carry out a great deal of research as preparation for her forthcoming role as a single parent in the film adaptation of Nick Hornby's novel About A Boy. She needs to get grubbier and much, much plainer. Walking about not knowing there is baby sick (or "posset" as it is winsomely called in baby manuals) on either shoulder would be a good place to start. Partnered mothers get told to change their tops; their single equivalents wander about all day looking revolting.

It's not just baby sick, or indeed curiously liquid baby poo; later, there's also poster paint, crumbs of Play-Doh (in the hair, usually), small stickers of dinosaurs which it amuses your children to attach to your backside, secretly, just as you're about to go out somewhere where backsides matter. My eldest son once drew a Pokemon called Wigglytuff on my forehead while I was dozing on the sofa; helpfully, he'd used an indelible laundry marker pen.

As for plainer: you quickly learn to dump the Luella Bartley when there's a shelled mutant drawn on your head and jam on your fishnets (besides, single mother = no time to shave your legs, so fishnets are a bad look anyhow). Also, you'll be quite fat, despite running around like a blue-arsed fly. There's no one to get thin for and besides, you'll feel compelled to wolf down the comforting remains of your children's meals. Sooner or later, you'll start examining those ads for elasticated slacks in Sunday supplements and wondering if they aren't really quite unexpectedly stylish.

Tip two is: set the alarm at hourly intervals throughout the night and get out of bed - you're single, so no one else is going to. Your child may be wailing because he's had a bad dream (bless), or simply because he quite fancies a Bob the Builder video at 4am (less bless). Or, sometimes, just because he's bored and wants to play trains (chugga-chugga, Mummy's a locomotive, all the way round the sitting room. Look! Her face is red and she is puffing, just like a real engine!).

Alternatively, spend a couple of hours on the sofa, pausing only to wonder whether it is actually possible to die of migraine, before answering the door to an irate neighbour complaining that she can hear the TV/galumphing engine action through the walls, and that her children always slept through until at least, oh, noon (dark look: you are an unfit mother).

After a couple of months, or even years of this, by 7am - lo! a new day has begun - you'll be able to start making extravagant comparisons between your life and those of people in prisoner of war camps. These comparisons will offend pretty much anyone with whom you share them, so soon you'll have no friends.

Thus tip three: cultivate loneliness. You have no pals, either because they don't like your flippant remarks about PoWs or because they're at work interacting - sigh - with fellow adult humans. Sometimes, usually mid-morning, you feel that you are in fact going mad. Your vocabulary may become affected; your greatest expression of dismay will become "Oh, poopoos"; envy will be expressed as a variant of "Lucky beggar".

When lonely, go to the park and wheel buggy pointlessly round and round. Sit on bench and notice that there are other people in the world. Wish they were your friends. Come home; tell yourself you are feeling "a little bit sad."

So there you are: overweight, dirty around the edges, hairy-legged, sleep deprived, friendless, or paranoid enough to believe that you are. You can't string a sentence together any more. Richard and Judy have become your best pretend friends. In extreme circumstances, you may find yourself purchasing items from satellite shopping channels (No-Wet Wonderfoam used to get me every time). Going to Sainsbury's is your very own Calvary: there is nothing more hideous than shopping with small children.

Example: "Why why why can't I have Batman spaghetti shapes?"

"Because."

"Why why why?"

"Because they're disgusting."

"Jamie has them at his house."

"Well, we don't."

"But why?"

"Just leave it."

"But Jamie has them."

"Yes, and that's why he's fat and pasty and common-looking." Oh-myGod, did I say that? Yes, you did. If you can't die of migraine, you can surely die of shame.

Lying in bed at night, ponder these questions (but be quick about it, because you'll be up in the next hour or so): what happened to my social life? What happened to my waistline? What is happening in the world, and why haven't I read a newspaper for six months? Are those women in Mother & Baby magazine, photogenically playing bricks on polished parquet floors, for real and, if so, where's the sick? Where are the Playmobil men with no arms? Where are the stains? Tell yourself off for getting so hysterical and count your blessings: despite everything, you love your children passionately, you're not 14 and you don't live on the 17th floor. Try to think of some other cheery thoughts, and fail.

And this, dear reader, is where my own experience ends. It is when you get an au pair, thank the baby Jesus that you can afford one, and start your own campaign to accord all single mothers sainthood status. The story perks up massively from that point on, but I can't write any more of it, since one of my children has climbed on to my lap, offering nostrils for inspection and asking if he has "nosestuff" for the fourth time in 10 minutes. Good luck to Rachel Weisz: she'll need it.

Sooner or later, you'll start examining those ads for elasticated slacks in Sunday supplements and wondering if they aren't really quite unexpectedly stylish. Tip two is: set the alarm at hourly intervals throughout the night and get out of bed - you're single, so no one else is going to. Your child may be wailing because he's had a bad dream (bless), or simply because he quite fancies a Bob the Builder video at 4am (less bless). Or, sometimes, just because he's bored and wants to play trains (chugga-chugga, Mummy's a locomotive, all the way round the sitting room. Look! Her face is red and she is puffing, just like a real engine!). Alternatively, spend a couple of hours on the sofa, pausing only to wonder whether it is actually possible to die of migraine, before answering the door to an irate neighbour complaining that she can hear the TV/galumphing engine action through the walls, and that her children always slept through until at least, oh, noon (dark look: you are an unfit mother). After a couple of months, or even years of this, by 7am - lo! a new day has begun - you'll be able to start making extravagant comparisons between your life and those of people in prisoner of war camps. These comparisons will offend pretty much anyone with whom you share them, so soon you'll have no friends. Thus tip three: cultivate loneliness. You have no pals, either because they don't like your flippant remarks about PoWs or because they're at work interacting - sigh - with fellow adult humans. Sometimes, usually mid-morning, you feel that you are in fact going mad. Your vocabulary may become affected; your greatest expression of dismay will become "Oh, poopoos"; envy will be expressed as a variant of "Lucky beggar". When lonely, go to the park and wheel buggy pointlessly round and round. Sit on bench and notice that there are other people in the world. Wish they were your friends. Come home; tell yourself you are feeling "a little bit sad." So there you are: overweight, dirty around the edges, hairy-legged, sleep deprived, friendless, or paranoid enough to believe that you are. You can't string a sentence together any more. Richard and Judy have become your best pretend friends. In extreme circumstances, you may find yourself purchasing items from satellite shopping channels (No-Wet Wonderfoam used to get me every time). Going to Sainsbury's is your very own Calvary: there is nothing more hideous than shopping with small children. Example: "Why why why can't I have Batman spaghetti shapes?" "Because." "Why why why?" "Because they're disgusting." "Jamie has them at his house." "Well, we don't." "But why?" "Just leave it." "But Jamie has them." "Yes, and that's why he's fat and pasty and common-looking." Oh-myGod, did I say that? Yes, you did. If you can't die of migraine, you can surely die of shame. Lying in bed at night, ponder these questions (but be quick about it, because you'll be up in the next hour or so): what happened to my social life? What happened to my waistline? What is happening in the world, and why haven't I read a newspaper for six months? Are those women in Mother & Baby magazine, photogenically playing bricks on polished parquet floors, for real and, if so, where's the sick? Where are the Playmobil men with no arms? Where are the stains? Tell yourself off for getting so hysterical and count your blessings: despite everything, you love your children passionately, you're not 14 and you don't live on the 17th floor. Try to think of some other cheery thoughts, and fail. And this, dear reader, is where my own experience ends. It is when you get an au pair, thank the baby Jesus that you can afford one, and start your own campaign to accord all single mothers sainthood status. The story perks up massively from that point on, but I can't write any more of it, since one of my children has climbed on to my lap, offering nostrils for inspection and asking if he has "nosestuff" for the fourth time in 10 minutes. Good luck to Rachel Weisz: she'll need it.

fields.headline: Scottish masterpiece vandalised in US
fields.trailText: A £750,000 landscape by the artist Thomas Gainsborough has been vandalised while on loan to an American museum.
fields.body:
A £750,000 landscape by the artist Thomas Gainsborough has been vandalised while on loan to an American museum.

The National Gallery of Scotland said the painting, entitled Rocky Landscape, was damaged while hanging in the Memphis Brooks Museum of Art, where it has been on loan from Scotland's national collection in Edinburgh.

A three centimetre gouge was found in the left hand corner of the canvas, but has since been repaired.

A painting owned by the American museum was also damaged, indicating that the Gainsborough piece was vandalised while on display and not while being transported.

The work is one of 50 masterpieces on loan to three American galleries in an exhibition entitled Scottish Treasures: Masterpieces from the National Gallery of Scotland.

A gallery spokesman said: "It is an unfortunate incident, but we are grateful the damage was not more serious.

"However, we have impressed upon the Memphis Brooks Museum the need for them to step up security to avoid this happening again.

"It is necessary for us to be involved in the active loaning to other institutions in order that we can borrow from those institutions.

"We exercise extremely stringent conservation and security standards to facilitate this kind of loaning for works coming in as well as those going out."

The painting was first exhibited in 1783 and became part of the Scottish collection in 1962.

webTitle: High rate of suicide among female doctors

fields.headline: High rate of suicide among female doctors
fields.trailText: Female doctors are twice as likely to commit suicide as other women, according to government-funded research published today.
fields.body:
Female doctors are twice as likely to commit suicide as other women, according to government-funded research published today.

They take their own lives more often than male colleagues, according to a study which will ring alarm bells in the NHS, which is employing more women in medical posts.

The authors, from Oxford University's department of psychiatry, say ways must be found to combat stress and mental health problems among doctors, of whom more than a third are women. More work is also needed to ascertain why doctors in some specialist areas of medicine, such as community health - which includes family planning clinics, immunisation centres and children's services, anaethestics, psychiatry and general practice - are far more likely to kill themselves than in others.

The findings, published in the Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, emerged from a study of 223 doctors in England and Wales who had committed suicide or whose death came from an undetermined cause between 1979 and 1995. Male doctors appeared only two-thirds as likely to kill themselves as members of the general population, although unusually, the suicide rate among male community health doctors was 12 times that of women specialists in this area.

Other research has already demonstrated that GPs are more prone than others to think "suicidal thoughts" and the latest research suggests they are 3.5 times more at risk of putting these into practice than colleagues in general hospital medicine. Seniority was not a factor.

The authors say the risk to women doctors "requires particular monitoring in the light of the very large increase in the numbers of women entering medicine." John Ashton, the journal's co-editor, said : "This is a descriptive study. It doesn't enable us to get into causational links. You would need to do more detailed work."

But he speculated that women doctors, who were often intelligent, high achievers and perfectionists, might have a personality profile that made them more vulnerable.

The British Medical Association said: "There is an urgent need for family-friendly specialities in every speciality. It is particularly important to discover what drives these women to suicide since more than half the current medical graduates are women."

The Department of Health said: "All the strands are coming together to improve doctors' working conditions so hopefully these rates will come down."

webTitle: Queen may decide to keep business guidelines private

fields.headline: Queen may decide to keep business guidelines private
fields.standfirst:
Family affair: Review to focus on conflicts of interest
Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Family affair: Review to focus on conflicts of interest
fields.body:
The royal family tried to raise the drawbridge on further scrutiny of its outside activities yesterday as officials at Buckingham Palace claimed that the Queen may decide not to publish any guidelines drawn up to regulate the business activities of family members, after the internal review of the Sophie Wessex affair.

Officials said the review would be conducted by the lord chamberlain of the household, Lord Luce, and completed within weeks.

He can consult family members and outside advisers, including judges and civil servants, but the guidelines will devised internally.

One official said: "There are a number of facets to be considered, and one person from the outside will not necessarily have the expertise for them all. Whether the guidelines are eventually published will depend on the outcome."

Lord Luce's inquiry will concentrate on how to avoid potential conflicts of interest, while maintaining the right of family members, such as Sophie, Countess of Wessex, to continue working. She may find her public relations skills restricted to charity work.

There is likely to be renewed emphasis on making no con tentious or partisan remarks, even in private.

Constitutional specialists said other members of the extended royal family seemed able to earn their living without controversy, including the Duke of Gloucester, who is an architect, and Viscount Linley, Princess Margaret's son, who runs a furniture business.

Vernon Bogdanor, professor of government at Oxford University, said: "It is coming to be expected that most members of the royal family will be involved in outside activities, and just like everyone else they have to avoid a conflict of interest."

Monarchs abroad, while usually subject to written constitutions, do not appear to have guidelines for their business activities. Most princes are expected to work.

The Dutch royal family's website shows that Queen Beatrix's husband, Claus, served on several boards of directors until he retired.

Willem-Alexander, heir to the throne as Prince of Orange, served in the navy and now interests himself in water management. His brother, Johan Friso, is a mechanical engineer and former management consultant with McKinsey, now employed by the investment bank Goldman Sachs in London. Constantijn, the youngest son, has worked at the European commission in Brussels. All are state school educated.

Crown Prince Haakon of Norway recently announced plans to live with his waitress girlfriend, and her son aged three by a previous relationship, in a flat in Oslo, while King Harald and his wife, Sonja, daughter of a shopkeeper, can be seen queuing for the cinema and dining in city restaurants.

The Norwegian media are fiercely protective of their royal family, however much they enjoy reporting the trials of the House of Windsor.

In Copenhagen, Queen Margrethe can be seen slipping into the palace carrying shopping bags, and her husband, Hendrik, once refused to attend royal events until he was paid for it. Any Dane can ask for an audience with a member of the royal family.
Where the Cabinet Stands: Tony Blair, PM Monarchist. His spokesman yesterday confirmed that prime minister did not believe monarchy's structure needed improving.

John Prescott, deputy PM In 1997 was not a monarchist.

Gordon Brown, chancellor Likely republican, but keeps views private. Yesterday noted Palace was debating size of Civil List.

Robin Cook, foreign secretary Shares an interest in horses but little else.

Jack Straw, home secretary In opposition proposed that royal family model itself on bicycling Scandinavians.

Stephen Byers, trade Was first in Cabinet to comment on affair - he would 'make his excuses and leave if offered gifts by unknown sheikh'.

David Blunkett, education Attended Queen Mother's 100th birthday celebrations at St Paul's.

Mo Mowlam, Cabinet Office Suggested Queen should move out of Palace, but likes Charles's eccentricities.

Margaret Beckett, leader of House 'Much more important things to worry about', but is 'perfectly content' with Queen.

Alan Milburn, health Former bookshop radical, now arch moderniser, is likely to oppose monarchy, but not make it a public issue.

Geoff Hoon, defence MoD paid £1.8m of £2.4m to refurbish Bagshot Park, 57-room home of Prince Edward.

Nick Brown, agriculture Otherwise preoccupied, but rumoured not to be keen to take calls from Charles, even pretending to be absent

John Reid, Scottish secretary Ex-communist and a Roman Catholic.

Lord Irvine, lord chancellor Self styled Cardinal Wolsey is one of few monarchists in the Cabinet.

webTitle: Prince Andrew: another royal accident waiting to happen?

fields.headline: Prince Andrew: another royal accident waiting to happen?
fields.standfirst:
Career move International role and playboy lifestyle together spell trouble
Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Prince Andrew's career move - International role and playboy lifestyle together spell trouble
fields.body:
The Duke of York has a problem with his public image- even though he is the Queen's favourite son, he has served his country with honour for more than 20 years as a Royal Navy helicopter pilot, and he has even come through a failed marriage without bringing too much disgrace on the royal family.

But last November, when news came of Prince Andrew's career change when he leaves the navy this summer, the reaction to his choice among Buckingham Palace aides and politicians was, at best, amusement, at worst, astonishment.

Most had assumed he would be on the golf course, battling to reduce his seven handicap.

Instead, the prince told the palace's twice-yearly Way Ahead Group, he would become an international figurehead for British industry.

As a roving ambassador for British Trade International, the government body for promoting exports and inward investment, he will replace his cousin, the Duke of Kent, and accompany trade missions and lead promotional visits overseas.

The post, which he takes up in July, is unpaid but covers all travel expenses. The prince has a £249,000-a-year allowance from the Queen.

"I am thoroughly looking forward to [the new job]," he said recently, "because it will be a complete contrast to my role in the navy, where I am necessarily working behind closed doors.

"Now I will have to deal with the press."

The appointment had the backing of the Queen, but stunned palace aides and politicians; they believe Prince Andrew's personality and lifestyle make him a disastrous choice.

That fear, of the prince "dealing with the press", will be reinforced by what has happened to the Countess of Wessex. Even Prince Charles is understood to have voiced reservations about his brother's suitability.

One Labour MP said last night: "When I heard about this I couldn't believe it.

"It shows an appalling lack of judgment. I suppose there are some countries where his presence might impress, but he is a liability."

However the prince is convinced he can help restore the royal family's battered reputation. Peter Mandelson is understood to have given behind-the scenes backing for Prince Andrew's cause. The former Northern Ireland secretary met him while working on the NSPCC's Full Stop campaign against child abuse, which Prince Andrew chaired.

Within weeks of the ambassador announcement, however, Prince Andrew was making what seemed a midlife bid to reclaim his reputation for high living after almost 10 years in the sidelines.

In January, to his mother's great annoyance, he was photographed sunbathing on a luxury catamarin off Thailand, surrounded by topless women.

He was staying at the exclusive Amanpuri resort on Phuket as a guest of another contact made through the NSPCC campaign: Johan Eliasch, millionaire owner of Head, the tennis equipment company.

That episode was followed by sightings apparently showing Prince Andrew's return to playboy habits: outside Soho clubs like China White, at glitterati bashes in Los Angeles, or turning up at a hookers and pimps halloween party in New York.

Central to the reinvention has been the prince's partner at the New York party, Ghislaine Maxwell, daughter of the late disgraced media mogul - an association that caused concern among palace aides.

In recent months, the pair have spent a lot of time together in a lifestyle that has revived doubts about the prince's suitability to be the international representative of British industry.

"My fear is that he thinks this job will be some kind of sinecure," said one MP.

The response of Martin O'Neill, chairman of the Commons trade and industry select committee, was marginally more diplomatic.

"Provided he has no vested or conflicting interests, then one can imagine that his appointment would not be to the detriment of our interests," said Mr O'Neill.

There is also the fear that Prince Andrew has inherited an unenviable knack for offensive gaffes from his father, Prince Philip. Though his navy duties have kept him out of the limelight, on a visit to Malta in 1999, for example, he embarrassed the royal family when he suggested that royal staff had routinely lied about events, likening the palace machine to the old Soviet regime

A British Trade International spokesman said last night that it had received no complaints about the duke's appointment, quite the contrary: "The response we have had has been positive."

webTitle: Banana trader slips up in metric battle as court rules for Europe

fields.headline: Banana trader slips up in metric battle as court rules for Europe
fields.trailText: Market trader convicted of falling foul of European directives on metrication by weighing and selling a bunch of bananas by the pound at his market stall in Southwick
fields.body:
There is an air of defiance in the display of bananas piled in the front of Steve Thoburn's Sunderland fruit shop; a broad-fingered, curving gesture of contempt for British and European bureaucracy.

Yesterday, Thoburn became the first person to be convicted of falling foul of European directives on metrication by weighing and selling a bunch of bananas by the pound at his market stall in Southwick.

At Sunderland magistrates court, the market trader turned reluctant metric martyr was given a conditional six-month discharge for two counts of breaching the 1985 Weights and Measures Act in a case that has roused the country.

This is not just about fruit and veg, according to Thoburn's legion of supporters. It is David and Goliath; the man in overalls against the suits of Brussels; UK sovereignty versus burgeoning European power.

And they have vowed to carry on the fight, despite yesterday's defeat and Thoburn's growing weariness with his campaigning role. A fresh appeal for fighting funds will be launched today in sections of the national press and Thoburn's lawyers will consider whether to appeal to the Divisional Court in London.

"I'm just gutted," said Thoburn after the verdict. "I need some time to think, to be with my family. I've had tremendous support from all over the country and especially my customers. But I just want to be left alone to get on with my life and sell my fruit. I never set out to be a figurehead. It's a very lonely place to be."

After five days of legal argument, District Judge Bruce Morgan pronounced that European law was supreme and that in signing up to the EEC, as it was then known, Britain had agreed to abide by its rules and regulations and had agreed to the eventual demise of the imperial measuring system.

"This country has decided that its political future lies with Europe. As such it has joined this European club and by doing so has agreed to be bound by the rules and regulations," said Mr Morgan.

He criticised the byzantine complexities of the legislation in the case of what he called "the most famous bunch of bananas in British legal history" and told Mr Thoburn he recognised that he was a decent, hardworking man simply trying to do right by his customers. "I accept that what he did he did because he believed he was right. He is a second generation greengrocer carrying on from his father and he wished to retain what he regarded as part of his cultural heritage, the imperial scale." He said Sunderland council, however, had acted properly in enforcing the law.

Thoburn, 36, was thrust into the spotlight after an undercover trading standards officer with Sunderland council bought a pound of bananas for 34p from Thoburn's market stall last summer. The prosecution stemmed from a 1994 EU directive that was signed into British law and took effect last year, making it an offence to sell loose goods in pounds and ounces. Customers can ask for a pound of bananas but traders are obliged to weigh them in metric units. Thoburn had used imperial scales.

Thoburn's counsel, Michael Shrimpton, had argued that the 1985 Weights and Measures Act specifically allowed dual trading and superseded the EU directive.

Yesterday, Mr Shrimpton said they could only afford to appeal if the public helped with Thoburn's expenses. "This is an ordinary market trader in Sunderland but he has had to bear the burden of defending the British constitution," he said.

"For the first time in an English court a judge has said that when we went into the EU in 1972 there was a revolution, or a huge change in our constitutional arrangement. I'm confident that the British public will be alarmed at the terms of the judgment and the way in which the sovereignty of the British parliament can be undermined by European directives."

Sunderland council, which has been vilified for its prosecution of Mr Thoburn, said it did not believe the public fully understood the details of the case or their intent in pursuing it.

"It was not the council's purpose to seek to bankrupt this person in what is clearly a test case and the council has endeavoured to act magnanimously by not seeking an order for costs at this stage."

They will seek costs, however, if the case goes to appeal. It has been estimated that the council has spent £75,000 on the case. The defence costs have been put at £35,000.

Neil Herron, a fishmonger who was also threatened with prosecution for using imperial weights and is now Thoburn's campaign manager said the public should put their money where their convictions were.

Back in Southwick, news of the verdict had filtered through the streets and market stalls.

"It is an absolute waste of money and it should never have been brought in the first place," said Maureen Duncan, 66, who has lived in the area for 20 years. "I go into Steve's and the other shops and say I want a pound of this or a quarter of that and I say, you are going to have to work it out because I just want it in pounds. It's what we understand. When I think of the money the council have spent on this. That's a lot of bananas, whichever way you measure it."

fields.headline: Forward the republic
fields.trailText: It is clear that recent events will further stimulate the debate about the monarchy that the Guardian initiated a few months ago (Palace launches shake-up, April 9).
fields.body:
It is clear that recent events will further stimulate the debate about the monarchy that the Guardian initiated a few months ago (Palace launches shake-up, April 9). The danger is that this will focus exclusively on whether the Windsors should be replaced by some sort of republican system. There is another option. Constitutional monarchies appear to work elsewhere in Europe. Could it be that at the moment we simply have the wrong family in the job? Certainly our predecessors in 1689 reached a similar conclusion and had little compunction in acting upon it.

May I propose that, when the present queen is no longer with us, the monarchy be offered one week as the National Lottery prize? The process complete, there would need to be a clear written contract between the new royals and the country, providing us with the opportunity to have a written constitution at last.
Chris Curson
Brighton

 Sadly, the public mood is probably to keep the monarchy, at least until the Queen Mother dies. Meanwhile it is clear that we need a trimmed down, more cost-effective monarchy. The public deserves value for money.

Here are some suggestions for how to achieve this: there should be a televised Big Brother-type format for all those currently enjoying the privileges of royal titles. Those refusing to take part could be automatically excluded. To help them learn to identify with ordinary people, daily tasks could include managing on a budget; looking after small children while trying to cook a meal and cleaning toilets. Also, having a conversation with an ordinary person, with marks deducted for being patronising, racist or tedious.

Every few days the nation could vote to evict another member, until they are down to a manageable and cost-effective size of two to four.
Mary M Scott
Aberdeen mscottenergy@lineone.net

 Your leader (April 9) shows a remarkable lack of understanding of the nature of contemporary monarchies, and the changing role of younger royals. Princess Stephanie of Monaco has managed to combine a number of careers (including a couple of records) and a number of gentlemen (I believe she's happily settled with a circus ringmaster at the moment), without losing any of her privileges.
T Millbank
London tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk

 I work in a shop and am therefore not in the same orbit as pop stars and politicians. However, I do read newspapers and, as a result, I have been aware for some time that the News of the World employs a journalist who creates his stories by purporting to be a wealthy sheikh and coaxing public figures into indiscretions, most usually about drugs and hookers.

If I knew this, how had it escaped the notice of the senior partners of a public relations firm? I'm not shocked by the revelations but the incompetence is alarming!
Jon Harrison
London jon.harrison@ forbiddenplanet.com

 Question: what is the difference between Sophie Wessex running a PR company and MPs sitting as company directors? Answer: both are employed for their supposed contacts and influence, but only MPs have another full-time job paid for out of the public purse.
Prue Bray
Winnersh, Berks prue@bray.telinco.co.uk

 Stop the press! Top PR person takes cocaine! I await eagerly tomorrow's headlines: "Man in pub drinks alcohol" or perhaps "shock horror - hippies smoke pot".
Neil Knowles
London
neil@elektralighting.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Signing up for Maxwell
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley is a little forgetful in his account of Robert Maxwell offering him a column (I too was Maxwell's plaything, April 9).
fields.body:
Roy Hattersley is a little forgetful in his account of Robert Maxwell offering him a column (I too was Maxwell's plaything, April 9). Soon after I started editing the Sunday Mirror in January 1985 I was called up to Maxwell's office, where he was enjoying a few drinks with Hattersley and Hattersley's friend, Lord Williams of Elvel.

Maxwell boomed that he wanted me to hire Hattersley as a columnist on the Sunday Mirror. I demurred. I had just hired another columnist and couldn't afford two on the budget that Maxwell had given me. I told Maxwell this after Williams and Hattersley had departed but agreed to talk to Hattersley anyway. We had lunch at the Savoy with another Sunday Mirror executive, Joyce Hopkirk.

Hattersley explained to us that he was fighting an expensive libel case and needed some money. Instead of a regular column I offered to publish some of his features and suggested he keep in touch with Joyce Hopkirk. It was left at that.

At the time I had no doubt that it wasn't Maxwell's idea at all but that the initiative had come from Lord Williams on Hattersley's behalf. Otherwise, of course, Maxwell would have insisted in his inimitable way.
Peter Thompson
London mayfair.news@virgin.net

fields.headline: Covering the tracks on manslaughter
fields.trailText: I note that British Transport Police are assisting the CPS in considering whether or not to bring charges against Railtrack and Thames Trains for corporate manslaughter (Paddington rail crash charges considered, April 9).
fields.body:
I note that British Transport Police are assisting the CPS in considering whether or not to bring charges against Railtrack and Thames Trains for corporate manslaughter (Paddington rail crash charges considered, April 9). These charges might concern Simon Osborne, the secretary and solicitor for Railtrack and a member of the board of the British Transport Police Committee, where he sits alongside the managing directors of First Group and Chiltern Railways.

Last August, Osborne wrote to the Home Office protesting that the newer tighter laws proposed for corporate manslaughter were too tough. Ian Johnston, who takes over as chief constable of the BTP next month, was appointed by the committee on which Osborne sits. The resulting tangle of responsibility needs sorting out sooner rather than later. The government's intention to wait for "a suitable legislative opportunity" to set up a replacement independent police authority looks complacent. And as of any "independent" authority, we must ask the question, independent of whom? The government, the rail industry, or the rail users?
Dr Chris Williams
European Centre for the Study of Policing, Open University Chris.Williams@open.ac.uk

It is frustrating to hear government ministers wringing their hands over fare rises (Go by air or road, says transport minister, April 9) when the solution is sitting in their in-tray.

The government is currently re-privatising the railway by offering companies longer franchises of up to 20 years. In drawing up new contracts the government is free to rewrite the rules on fares regulation. Yet it is quietly allowing the existing, inadequate system of fare regulation to roll forward into new franchise contracts with no consultation, no debate, and no parliamentary approval.
Jonathan Bray
Transport 2000

Does Lord Macdonald realise that not everybody owns a car and there are limited destinations for air travellers? Why not re-nationalise our rail system, which is much more efficient and environmentally sustainable form of transport compared to road or air travel?
Martin Arundell
Glasgow m.arundell@freeuk.com

fields.headline: Cash, please
fields.trailText: The agriculture minister has asked farmers, like me, not to appeal against the cull of their healthy livestock (Hopes raised as figures for new cases stay stable, April 9).
fields.body:
The agriculture minister has asked farmers, like me, not to appeal against the cull of their healthy livestock (Hopes raised as figures for new cases stay stable, April 9). I wonder if the ministry really appreciates what a sacrifice they are asking from us?

The minister himself has said the crisis will go on for a long time. That means farmers cannot restock, so are being asked to give up both their livestock and their livelihoods. The ministry buys the livestock via compulsory purchase, but has not yet offered to pay consequential compensation for the loss of livelihoods.

But it is thousands of local rural businesses that are really suffering. The government should set up consequential compensation to all affected: to the tourism businesses, agricultural suppliers, hauliers - even florists and hairdressers are reputed to be suffering in my town.

It's all very well having politicians (from any party) promising to help afterwards. Who can trust the promises of politicians? A distinct fund should be established now. Anthony Steel
Lockerbie, Dumfriesshire

webTitle: Letters: Your call is in a queue

fields.headline: Your call is in a queue
fields.trailText: I identify wholeheartedly with your frustration (Leader, April 7). I frequently waste time waiting for repair/delivery men whose concern seems to be their convenience, not mine.
fields.body:
I identify wholeheartedly with your frustration (Leader, April 7). I frequently waste time waiting for repair/delivery men whose concern seems to be their convenience, not mine. Our small company is often pestered by cold callers to buy goods. Yet whenever I phone any organisation to report a fault my call is always "in a queue because all operators are busy". It would greatly improve customer care if we had fewer people making cold calls and more available to receive calls from existing customers.
Angela Embleton
Darlington

 The increase in technologies now available to us 24 hours a day means that a demand for 24 hour a day servicing is a reality. Whatever "work related stress disorders" (Letters, April 9) these services may cause for the providers would be more than made up for by the financial return 24 hour service providers might expect.
Julian Hodge
London

 Surely when Robert Worcester (Letters, April 9) spoke to a "girl" at NTL, he should have been told that a "repairboy" would be calling round?
Jessica Gedge
London
jgedge@talk21.com

 Long before the foot and mouth outbreak, most of the footpaths and bridleways in this part of the world were knee-deep in mud. With an average of over an inch of rain every week for the past year, we shall need several weeks of dry weather before the countryside becomes an attractive propositon for visitors. Perhaps Mr Hague could include an increase of sunshine in his manifesto?
Rev David Moseley
Colyton, Devon
davidmoseley@tinyworld. co.uk

 So, in the early 1990s, brewers introduced "methanol-soaked alcopops" (Keep taking the pils, Media Guardian, April 9)? Could this revelation point to a possible explanation for the supposed "dumbing down" of Britain? Or perhaps it's merely an example of the phenomenon in action?
Nicholas Pound
Liverpool

 Tim Parks has missed out what must rank as a near perfect insult here in Naples (What can we sing that will make them really mad? March 27). A Neapolitan fan intent on hitting the Veronese where it hurts unfurled a banner at a Napoli-Verona match reading: "Giulietta è una zoccola" ("Juliet's a slag").
Chris Rose
Naples, Italy

fields.headline: Cook's less ethical side
fields.trailText: Robin Cook has played a key role in maintaining economic sanctions on Iraq, thus helping to perpetuate a humanitarian crisis which, according to Unicef, has claimed the lives of some 500,000 children since 1990 (Leader, April 9).
fields.body:
Robin Cook has played a key role in maintaining economic sanctions on Iraq, thus helping to perpetuate a humanitarian crisis which, according to Unicef, has claimed the lives of some 500,000 children since 1990. Your leader (April 9) intimates that this may be a "blindspot", where "for many people, Mr Cook's words have not been reflected in policy".

Others see the sanctions in starker terms: as "humanly catastrophic [and] morally indefensible" (Catholic aid agency Cafod); as "illegal and immoral" (former UN humanitarian coordinator for Iraq, Denis Halliday); and as "a silent war against Iraq's children" (Save the Children Fund UK).
Milan Rai
voices in the wilderness uk voices@viwuk.freeserve. co.uk

 Doubtless it was the business, rather than the ethical dimension of foreign policy that justified Cook in meeting Suharto of Indonesia in 1998, and the ethical dimension that allowed the Foreign Office to call Suharto a dictator only after he had fallen.
Adrian Kozlowski
Birmingham
