webTitle: Murdered victim's family sues police for negligence

fields.headline: 'I'm going. I've got no blood left in me'
fields.standfirst: Loraine Whiting was killed by her violent husband, but her life might have been saved if police had let medics into the house where she lay shot. Now her family are suing the force involved.  Fiona Bawdon  reports
fields.trailText: Loraine Whiting was killed by her violent husband, but her life might have been saved if police had let medics into the house where she lay shot. Now her family are suing the force involved. Fiona Bawdon reports.
fields.body:
At around 9pm on March 10 1995, Loraine Whiting's estranged and violent husband, Len Carter, turned up on the doorstep of her home in Sittingbourne, Kent. He was dressed up as a policeman, and carrying a shotgun. For three hours, he tried to persuade her to come back to him. When she refused, he shot her in the thigh.

Bleeding, 49-year-old Whiting dialled 999. As she spoke to the emergency services, Carter, 48, shot her twice more in the legs before killing himself with a shot to the head. An ambulance arrived about nine minutes after Whiting made the call. The crew, however, were prevented by police from entering the house for an hour, during which time she pleaded for help down the phone, repeating again and again that the gunman was dead.

By the time police and medics finally entered the house, she had bled to death. A Home Office pathologist told the subsequent inquest that had she been treated when the ambulance first got there, she would have had a 98% chance of survival.

Since her death, her family - she has three children from a previous marriage - has been fighting to find out why police inaction allowed her to die. Now, with the help of Imran Khan and Michael Mansfield QC - the solicitor and barrister who represented the family of the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence - they have launched a groundbreaking legal action against Kent police.

Whiting's brother, Paul Jarrett, says: "The police should have allowed the medics to enter the house when they were first told Carter was dead, which was a few minutes after the ambulance arrived."

The family heard about Whiting's emergency call for the first time at the inquest. Her daughter, Catherine Elvin, explains: "No one had told us she'd been on the phone. I didn't have a clue. As far as I was concerned, mum died when she got to hospital. That was all I knew."

At the inquest, the family was given a transcript of Whiting's 61-minute phone conversation with the emergency services. This, together with the evidence given by the officers, left them appalled and convinced she could have survived.

Jarrett says the police operation was full of muddle and contradiction. There was confusion over who was in charge - two officers apparently claimed to have been in command on the night. Crucially, no officers in command listened to Whiting's phone conversation or spoke to her. The constable who did speak to her some 20 minutes after she first made the emergency call responded by calling for his colleagues to go in straight away. He was overruled by more senior officers.

The police insist that they were right to delay entry to the house because they had no way of confirming whether the gunman really was dead. They said: "There was no way of determining if the situation Loraine Whiting described was accurate or someone had put a gun to her head."

But the family dispute this. They say if the police were not aware Carter was dead, they should have been. Why did no officer senior enough to order entry to the house speak to Whiting?

The police complaints authority investigated the incident and exonerated all of the officers involved. Of one of the officers whose behaviour the family criticise, it says that he "denied that he failed ... to exercise effective leadership or action in respect of police response ... He said that he made the decision not to listen in to the call himself, so as to retain the freedom to respond effectively to other events as they arose."

Jarrett says that rather than listening to Whiting, the officer was relying on incomplete information he was reading off a computer screen. Whiting was speaking to an operator at Kent ambulance headquarters; the operator relayed the information to the ambulance at the scene; the ambulance crew relayed it to the scene-of-crime officer; the scene-of-crime officer relayed it to the control centre at Swale; and Swale relayed it to police headquarters. Where it was put on to the computer system.

Elvin is equally unimpressed. "If mum had been a celebrity, they would have gone in there and come out heroes," she says.

The transcript of the phone conversation makes harrowing reading. Whiting insists a total of 30 times that Carter is dead. She tells both the ambulance operator and the constable she spoke to how urgently she needs help: "I've lost so much blood ... I'm just bleeding." And: "I'm going. I've got no blood left in me."

When asked where Carter shot himself, she replies: "In the head."

"He's shot himself in the head?"

"Yeah."

Later the operator says: "He is definitely dead?"

"Yes - he's dead." Later: "Just someone come in - he's dead. He put the gun in his mouth."

So far, the family have had only the written transcript they obtained at the inquest to go on. The police originally refused to hand over the 999 tape, explaining that it was "an extremely traumatic item to listen to". They have now agreed to release it.

According to the transcript, Whiting's screams as she is shot again are audible, as is Carter telling her: "Kid, I'm going to kill myself." A series of bangs is then heard, followed by a silence of a few minutes. Whiting comes back on the line saying: "I've been shot. He's shot himself. He's still in here. He's dead. He's shot himself." The family say this exchange makes a nonsense of police claims that they could not enter the house because they feared Whiting was speaking under duress and they were being lured into a trap.

After hitting brick walls everywhere else, the family finally ended up at Khan's door. What first sparked his interest in the case, he says, was a piece of uncanny symmetry: while police officers from the Met were investigating the family's complaint about Kent police, the Met was, in turn, being investigated by Kent over another of Khan's cases: the Stephen Lawrence murder. Elvin recalls: "Talking to Imran was like a breath of fresh air. It was like, hallelujah!"

The force is trying to get the case thrown out as an "abuse of process". It also argues that the case should not go ahead because it was launched outside the usual time limit for death and injury claims. In its defence, it says the police had to delay entry to the house until the arrival of a third armed response vehicle, with a crew experienced in firearms incidents.

The police have also obtained a second Home Office pathologist's report which says that even if they had entered the house when the first ARV arrived, Whiting's injuries were such she would still have died. Jarrett dismisses this report as "too convenient".

If it is allowed to go ahead, the case will break new legal ground. The police's long-standing blanket protection from being sued for negligence was recently overturned by the European court of human rights. In Osman v the United Kingdom, the court ruled that total immunity was a breach of human rights and that each negligence case should be decided on its merits. "It must be established ... that the [police] knew or ought to have known at the time of the existence of a real and immediate risk to the life of an identified individual ... from the criminal acts of a third party and that they failed to take measures which were in the scope of their powers which, judged reasonably, might have been expected to avoid that risk," it said.

Traditionally, actions to hold police accountable in this way were thrown out by judges. In 1989, the House of Lords rejected a claim by the mother of the Yorkshire ripper's last victim, Jacqueline Hill, who had tried to sue for negligence arguing that it was police incompetence in not catching the killer earlier which had led to her daughter's death.

Whiting's family stress that going to court is very much a last resort. They feel they have no alternative but to fund an expensive and highly risky case in an untested area of law.

Elvin says: "All we ever wanted was an apology and an explanation. Nobody's perfect. Everyone makes mistakes. We accept that. We have been reduced to having to do this. We have been forced into this to find out the answers as to why mum died and why people couldn't make decisions and act quickly enough."

fields.headline: Marcel Berlins
fields.standfirst: The richest case in British legal history collapses, and the end of love letters to barristers
fields.trailText: The richest case in British legal history collapses, and the end of love letters to barristers.
fields.body:
 When the very rich go to court to sue the very rich, making all the lawyers in the case very rich as well, lesser beings may be forgiven a smirk, a chortle, or even a broad smile when the trial turns out to be a fiasco. This has happened in what was billed as the most monied case in British legal history.

At stake is the fortune of the Thyssen family, estimated at well over a billion pounds and still counting. I won't try to explain the legal issues, but you won't be surprised to know that lots of people want a slice of the dosh. A very long trial in Bermuda, using 32 highly paid English and Bermudan barristers, was to have decided who gets what. Unfortunately (tee-hee-hee) the case has collapsed after 15 months, not even half-way through.

And the reason for its sudden crash (I think a guffaw is now permissible) is that the judge got into a dispute about his own remuneration - he claimed he'd been misled about his original contract - and voluntarily withdrew from the case when his new financial requests weren't agreed. So now the whole thing, which has already cost over £70m in legal fees, has to start all over again, with a new judge. Oh dear, how sorry I feel for everyone involved.

 It has long been the custom for a juror who wishes to send a note to a barrister in the case to ask a court official, or sometimes one of the other lawyers, to carry the missive physically to the recipient. Such a note, I hardly need to add, contains an expression of love and/or lust, since according to another ancient tradition, dating back to the Magna Carta, any juror is entitled to fancy any barrister in the trial. Whether nookie does or doesn't follow is, of course, up to the lawyer.

But I'm delighted to see that new technology has finally done away with the inefficient "personal carriage of billets doux" system. In a case which finished yesterday in the high court, five police officers challenged an inquest jury's verdict of "unlawful killing" (of a man in police custody) on the ground that a woman member of the jury had become infatuated with Leslie Thomas, the handsome barrister acting for the deceased's family.

It wasn't alleged that anything had happened bodily between the two during the course of the inquest - or, indeed, after - but the stricken woman, the police claimed, had influenced other jurors in their verdict. They lost the case.

Here is the pleasing and important part. The woman had submitted her feelings for Thomas not on paper, but by way of mobile phone text messages, thus saving various court intermediaries the trouble of transporting notes, thereby freeing them for other duties and saving the taxpayer significant sums. I understand the Lord Chancellor is thinking of making it a law that, in future, all manifestations of juror lust and infatuation towards barristers shall be conducted electronically.

 Sassy is not a word in widespread use for describing female members of our judiciary. Nor youthful, sexy, glamorous or rambunctious. These are just a few of the adjectives used by the press on Marilyn Milian, America's newest television judge. She's a real judge or, rather, was one, but when the call came from the People's Court to dispense justice in front of millions rather than in a Miami courtroom, it was no contest.

I seem to remember that a British TV company once tried the "people's court" format (the dispute is real, and the parties agree to be bound by the judge's decision) but they used an elderly male, which didn't do wonders for ratings. I certainly don't remember writing anything like the New York Times's coverage of Judge Marilyn: "She flashes a winning smile at the waiter, ordering a glass of merlot, the hearty, zesty kind. 'Like my men,' she says with a deep, throaty laugh."

 I did a disservice to Rabinder Singh last week. In making the point that members of Matrix chambers weren't always on the side of the weak and oppressed claiming infringement of their human rights, I wrote that "Rabinder Singh defends the Home Office in cases brought by immigrants or asylum seekers".

It's true that he occasionally used to. But a few months ago he was appointed independent monitor of the entry clearance system, which requires him to be, as its name suggests, wholly independent of government. It would obviously be contrary to that role if he were to act for the Home Office in immigration or asylum cases, and he doesn't do so.

fields.headline: Karembeu adds to Boro blues
fields.trailText: Three points would have gone a long way but neither team took their chances as Christian Karembeu saw red in a tempestuous Tees-Wear derby last night.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
The futures of Sunderland and Middlesbrough may lie alongside either the cream of the continent or the whey of the Nationwide but the 118th Tees-Wear league derby ended in rip-roaring if predictable stalemate last night.

As the repercussions of this breathless draw shiver through the respective camps, the likelihood remains that neither scenario will come to pass. Sunderland's European challenge continues to stutter; Boror, a point better off in the cramped scrap for survival, live in hope.

The blistering frenzy of this match was epitomised by a second mindless booking for Christian Karembeu after a spat with Darren Williams in the dying stages. The Frenchman, cautioned earlier for kicking the ball away, was dismissed with Terry Venables protesting on the pitch.

At least Venables had won the day's first skirmish with the Wearsiders by agreeing to pay Inter Bratislava £3m for the Slovakian international striker Szilard Nemeth. The 22-year-old had been courted by Internazionale and had trained recently with Sunderland; instead the lure of a five-year deal, a strike partnership with Alen Boksic and the possibility of First Division football next season clearly proved more tempting.

With the suspended centre-half Ugo Ehiogu Boro's second leading league goalscorer with three, they began with Dean Windass alongside the Croatian. The former Bradford forward made an immediate impact, colliding with Thomas Sorensen after four minutes and earning a yellow card.

That challenge was the first of a tempestuous game which prompted seven yellow cards and Karembeu's red. Amid the fire and brimstone Don Hutchison's cheeky lob and quickly taken free-kick, both of which had Mark Schwarzer scurrying in the home goal, briefly broke up the first-half niggling.

The visitors' slick breaks were unsettling Boro's nervous rearguard. Kevin Kilbane flicked on for Michael Gray to chase and the full-back's cross forced a desperate block from Steve Vickers. The centre-half then survived a penalty appeal as Julio Arca stumbled before Phillips, played onside by Curtis Fleming, burst through, rounded Schwarzer and struck the outside of the post.

The England hopeful, with one goal in nine games, is yet to score in front of the watching Sven-Goran Eriksson. "Give him a shout and tell him not to come to our last six," said Peter Reid, who watched in disbelief as Kilbane, standing on the goal-line, failed to make contact with Phillips' nod back.

In response to the onslaught, Venables dropped Paul Okon into a more withdrawn role and Boro rode the storm. They might even have led before the interval. First Noel Whelan's inswinging corner was flicked on by Windass and the substitute Dean Gordon, sliding in at the far post, scuffed a shot wide. Then Windass trundled through a sleepy back-line and Sorensen did well to block with his legs.

Although Emerson Thome, at the foot of a mass scrum on the goal-line, should have eased the Mackems ahead, Boro's improvement continued into the second half despite the loss of the hamstrung Fleming and Gianluca Festa with a groin injury. Robbie Mustoe threw off his defensive shackles to emerge from a cluttered midfield and rip a shot at Sorensen. The Dane could only parry but Boksic slammed the rebound wastefully into the side-netting. The home side could hardly afford such profligacy but within minutes had repeated the trick. Karembeu lobbed into the area and Hamilton Ricard, a half-time replacement for Whelan, hammered the ball the wrong side of the post.

"I was disappointed not to win it," added Venables. "I suppose, looking back, it was a good point. But having got through the first 20 minutes we expected to get so much more."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: How to win the public relations battle against elected mayors

fields.headline: How to win the public relations battle against elected mayors
fields.standfirst: If local politicians improved their relationship with voters, interest in directly elected mayors would wane, says public relations guru Mark Fletcher-Brown
fields.trailText: If local politicians improved their relationship with voters, interest in directly elected mayors would wane, says public relations guru Mark Fletcher-Brown.
fields.body:
Directly elected mayors could be about to sweep the country. Birmingham, Lewisham and Watford are poised for referendums on the idea, and campaigns are starting up in a number of other towns and cities.

Many councillors, however, are set dead against the idea. They argue that the mayoral model concentrates too much power in one person's hands and that changes in political structures will not offer a magic solution to local problems, no matter what the government says.

Some councillors are choosing to keep their heads down and not talk about mayors, but voters can circumvent their local authority and force a referendum if they collect just 5% of the local electorate's signatures.

Instead, local politicians have to win the public relations battle against the new model. Here are ten ways to make sure the mayoral issue isn't an issue for your council:

One: we're delivering anyway

Forget the big strategic agenda here. If you want to sell the benefits of the services you deliver you've got to find the bits that are most noticed by your audience and highlight those. Bins may not seem sexy, but if you are able to ensure that you pick up rubbish bags and litter then you'll get more accolades than by opening yet another Mandela Centre in your town. Think about education, too. Many councils spend above the government's recommended amount for schools.

Two: we're listening

Councils are listening. Consultation is spreading across local government like a rash. But listening only looks like listening when you signal that you've heard. Feedback to your local residents. Let them know that you've heard them. Tell them the difference that their contribution has made. Or tell them it hasn't.

Three: remember the little things

We're all acutely aware of the microscopic details of day to day life. It's often these that tell us whether we're being treated well, or getting good value for money. For example, you may go out for dinner, spending a small fortune, and be served cheap coffee at the end of the meal. That one detail could well put you off the whole thing. It's a detail but it matters. Look at your council from a detailed point of view. What are the things that people worry about? Do you keep people hanging on the phone? Do you treat people well at receptions? Do you make an extra effort to be friendly?

Four: be accountable

The mayor is attractive because there will be a name - someone you can look to; someone you can blame. It's shorthand for personal responsibility. There's nothing more annoying than having to deal with some town hall jobsworth who won't even wear a name badge. Ensure that all of your staff, particularly front line staff, are named and willing to be accountable for their actions.

Five: be consistent

Another thing that drives people up the wall, and makes good copy for the local rag, is appearing inconsistent. Councillors could be simultaneously upping their allowances and cutting the funding to a community group. Now the fact is that they're dealt with in different parts of the building - and it was probably an external body that said councillors should be paid more anyway - but it quickly looks like inconsistency. It's a source of grief and resentment and likely to precipitate a demand for someone to go in and sort it out. Enter the mayor.

Six: be human

Look to Chinese/American relationships at the moment. The pressure's on for someone to say "sorry". For some reason, probably insurance staff and lawyers, public bodies struggle to mouth the word. And so they will either say nothing or something that sounds like a cop out. It makes the organisation seem impersonal. And again, the mayor could be the very person to go in and make them behave like human beings.

Seven: admit mistakes

Common sense tells us that we cannot be right all of the time. So naturally, when people in any organisation fail to admit to errors we either believe that they are lying or that they are simply hiding the truth. Either way it's not healthy. Of course, you can admit you are wrong in a way that enhances your credibility. It's another part of being a personal, people-driven bureaucracy.

Eight: pass on the credit

We have a culture that abhors the me-first, self-driven approach. And when councils push out endless pictures of members and officers smiling and taking the credit for something they've done it can simply reinforce the perception that they think they are more important than the community. Push your customers first. Bask only in reflected glory. Appear demure and self-effacing. It's what makes Britain Britain.

Nine: share the problem

Don't allow others to believe that you have all of the answers. You don't. Nobody does. But if you work with local people and admit that you will help them to feel that they are creating the solution. You get lots of ideas. They get what they want. And they appreciate subliminally that life is a lot more complex than the debate on elected mayors would have them believe.

Ten: keep it on the ground

Don't spend your public life talking about strategies, especially strategies that sprawl over a 20-year period. It's too big a picture. Stick to the real things that make immediate, tangible differences to the daily lives of the people who pick up the bill.

 Mark Fletcher-Brown works for the communications consultancy Reputation
fields.bodyText: Directly elected mayors could be about to sweep the country. Birmingham, Lewisham and Watford are poised for referendums on the idea, and campaigns are starting up in a number of other towns and cities. Many councillors, however, are set dead against the idea. They argue that the mayoral model concentrates too much power in one person's hands and that changes in political structures will not offer a magic solution to local problems, no matter what the government says. Some councillors are choosing to keep their heads down and not talk about mayors, but voters can circumvent their local authority and force a referendum if they collect just 5% of the local electorate's signatures. Instead, local politicians have to win the public relations battle against the new model.
